HEADLINE: Because It's There

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly, is the author of the forthcoming book "The Coming Anarchy: Shattering the Dreams of the Post-Cold War."

 BODY:

A GREAT WALL
 Six Presidents and China:
 An Investigative History.
 By Patrick Tyler.
 Illustrated. 476 pp. New York:
 A Century Foundation Book/
 Public Affairs. $27.50. 
 China constitutes the ultimate reality check on any administration's foreign policy. For other parts of the world, whose strategic and economic importance is either arguable or negligible, Presidents may get by with posturing. But China -- with its billion-plus population, its economy, soon to become the world's largest, and its belligerent rulers, with their ability to manufacture 1,000 ballistic and cruise missiles if they choose to capture Taiwan -- can exact the most disastrous consequences for sloppy thinking. In 1979, China suffered tens of thousands of casualties in a brief border war with Vietnam, just so Beijing's leaders could teach Hanoi a lesson for invading Cambodia. Nobody should doubt China's willingness to go to war in defense of its interests.
America's relations with this volatile and gargantuan power are the subject of "A Great Wall," by Patrick Tyler. Tyler, a former Beijing bureau chief of The New York Times, is by training an investigative reporter, and this book is primarily the reconstructed inside story, obtained through interviews and newly declassified documents, of how every President from Richard Nixon to Bill Clinton has dealt with China. Tyler's ability to weave a narrative, his intimacy with China itself and his overall fairness toward both Republican and Democratic administrations make this book a powerful statement in defense of pragmatism. Its overarching theme is that with China the stakes are so high that every President -- including Ronald Reagan, with his deep commitment to Taiwan, and Clinton, with his emphasis on human rights -- bowed eventually to Nixon's outline for engagement simply because there was no other choice.
Nixon's accomplishment, Tyler makes clear, was more operational than conceptual, since the idea of using China as a lever against the Soviet Union was not new (it was one that had tantalized Lyndon Johnson). This is no airbrushed account of how Nixon and his national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, in Tyler's words, "pulled off the opening." Nixon is shown as obsessively partisan, terrified that a Democrat like Senator Mike Mansfield might be photographed with Mao Zedong before he was. Tyler also notes Kissinger's every unpleasantness -- his nail-biting, his deceitfulness, his use of China policy to subvert the State Department, run by William Rogers before Kissinger himself became Secretary of State.
Yet the completeness of Tyler's account works to give Nixon and Kissinger their due. During his historic visit to China in February 1972, Nixon set the standard for toughness and clarity when he looked across the table at Prime Minister Zhou Enlai and defended America's military presence in the Pacific, admonishing Zhou that if America withdrew, the Soviets would move in. "Nixon said that he realized he sounded like an old cold warrior, 'But it is the world as I see it, and when I analyze it, it is what brings us, China and America, together.' "
Kissinger is shown fawning before the Chinese. But Tyler lets James Lilley, a China-born career officer with the Central Intelligence Agency, explain Kissinger's approach: "You embrace them, you make all the right statements about building strong and genuine relations, and all the while you run espionage operations." After a review of Kissinger's secret understandings with the Chinese during the Presidencies of Nixon and Gerald Ford, President Jimmy Carter's national security aide for China, Michel Oksenberg, concluded that they were "perfectly defensible," and recommended Carter reaffirm them. He did.
Tyler's book is an absorbing account of how ambitious men in every administration battled and undermined each other over China, with policy determined not so much by openness as by secrecy and mutual deception and by the luck of events. Ford and Kissinger failed to establish diplomatic relations with China, while Carter and his national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, succeeded -- not because they were smarter, but because the Carter Administration's efforts coincided with the rise to power in China of the liberalizing and fiercely anti-Soviet Deng Xiaoping. After providing a highly critical commentary on Brzezinski's machinations, Tyler writes, "Given the irreconcilable positions over arms sales to Taiwan, it is, perhaps, hard to imagine that normalization could have proceeded in any more orderly a fashion." Had Carter's Secretary of State, Cyrus Vance, directed the talks, "insisting with lawyerly precision on America's right to sell arms to Taiwan, normalization might never have occurred." The virtue of deception and ambiguity was that they allowed the two sides to disagree while insisting that they didn't.
Indeed, to turn up one's nose at the unbridled ambition and bureaucratic subterfuge on display in these pages would be a sterile reaction. The Washington infighting, Tyler explains, does not begin to compare with that going on in Beijing. And if one could not win bureaucratic battles in Washington, how could one expect to be a match for the Chinese?
In statecraft, success goes to those with aggressive self-interest. Reagan, with all his anti-Communism, did not succeed in selling advanced FX fighter jets to Taiwan. But his pragmatic successor, George Bush, sold the Taiwanese F-16's because the production line was in Texas, Bush's home state and crucial to his bid for re-election.
By the end of this book, though, the distinctions are less between this administration and that one, between liberal and conservative, between Democrat and Republican, than between a hardheaded cold war dynasty of Presidents and their advisers -- all of whom evinced focus and discipline regarding China -- and the unfocused, undisciplined Clinton Administration. Here Tyler is unsparing. He describes a first-term President who refused to meet with his top foreign policy and intelligence advisers, and eventually adopted a policy, dominated by human rights concerns, that was fashionable without being sensible -- and would later have to be abandoned. In a devastating rebuttal from within the Administration at the end of 1993, J. Stapleton Roy, the United States Ambassador to China, said, "If you look at the 150 years since the Opium Wars, then you can't avoid the conclusion that the last 15 years are the best 15 years in China's modern history and of those 15 years, the last 2 years are the best in terms of prosperity, individual choice, access to outside sources of information, freedom of movement within the country and stable domestic conditions." When asked if China would satisfy Clinton's demands for improved human rights, the Ambassador said he didn't know, because the Administration never defined what it meant by significant progress.
In Clinton's defense, it must be said that he has moved toward the realistic center on China policy, to the chagrin of preachy pundits. But how focused is he? Zhu Rongji, the Chinese Prime Minister, stuck his neck out to visit the United States last April, ready for compromise. Yet, Tyler says, "the President took no time to develop a relationship with Premier Zhu and was inattentive to the opportunities that developed in early 1999 to break down the final barriers holding back China's entry to the World Trade Organization."
Such inattention adds up and, combined with cultural misunderstanding, could lead ultimately to one of those conflagrations born out of miscalculation, like World War I. One hopes that Clinton, in what is left of his term in office, and our future leaders will show the same seriousness of purpose toward China that, as Tyler so ably demonstrates, defined our Presidents during the cold war.

HEADLINE: Pleasantville

BYLINE: By David L. Kirp; David L. Kirp, professor at the Goldman School of Public Policy at the University of California, Berkeley, is the author of "Our Town: Race, Class, and the Soul of Suburbia" and the forthcoming "Almost Home: America's Love-Hate Relationship With Its Communities."

 BODY:

CELEBRATION, U.S.A.
 Living in Disney's Brave New Town.
 By Douglas Frantz and Catherine Collins.
 Illustrated. 342 pp. New York:
 A Marian Wood Book/Henry Holt & Company. $25.
 
 THE CELEBRATION
 CHRONICLES
 Life, Liberty, and the Pursuit
 of Property Value in Disney's New Town.
By Andrew Ross.
 Illustrated. 340 pp. New York:
 Ballantine Books. $25.95. 
 ON Nov. 18, 1995, nearly 5,000 people showed up at the soon-to-be town of Celebration, Fla. They were as impatient and obsessed as the teen-agers who camped out last spring in hopes of securing seats for the midnight opening of "Star Wars: The Phantom Menace." But these were grown-ups, and the stakes they were playing for were far higher than being first on the block to see the young Darth Vader. They had put in play every aspect of their lives -- leaving their hometowns, putting their houses on the market, changing jobs, plunking down their earnest money -- for a 1-in-10 chance of moving into a mosquito-infested bit of central Florida flood plain.
These would-be residents were ready to pay more than a third above market price for the privilege of living in houses so shoddily constructed that they might not be standing in 20 years. They were volunteering to move to a minutely planned town where the artifices of design were intended to evoke neighborly sentiment. Their lives would be regulated in intimate detail, down to the ratio of grass, trees and shrubs on their property and the color of the curtains (white) they could hang in their windows. They would be surveyed as regularly as the Nielsen families; those who accepted the lure of a free computer and cell phone would live with a "Zeus Box" that monitored every telephone call they made and every Web site they visited.
Americans are forever pulling up stakes and starting over, heading out for some new promised land. In this sense, Celebration fever is nothing extraordinary. But the impetus behind this particular migration is very different: an extraordinary faith in the Walt Disney Company, parent of the Celebration Company, whose success depends on creating and marketing fantasy. Year after year, many of the would-be residents had spent their vacations in one of Disney's worlds, in the company of a smiling rodent and a raspy-voiced duck. Now they were betting that, with wallboard and concrete, this company could transform them into characters living in their own Magic Kingdom. They were also wagering that Disney's market magic would translate into big profits when they were ready to move on.
Among these newcomers were Andrew Ross, an American studies professor at New York University, the author of "The Celebration Chronicles," and the authors of "Celebration, U.S.A.," Douglas Frantz, a national correspondent for The New York Times, and his wife, Catherine Collins, also a journalist, who came with their two youngest children. Many anecdotes show up in both books -- no surprise, since there is only so much worth recounting in the life of a very small town. A steady stream of sightseers, under the pardonable misapprehension that Celebration is an annex of Disney World or "The Truman Show" come to life, marvel at how closely the inhabitants resemble actual people. A resident called the Lemon Lady upsets decorum -- and threatens property values -- when she plasters her car with images of lemons to dramatize her rage at her falling-down home.
The centerpiece of both books is the protracted war over the soul of the new public school. In wooing prospective residents, the excellence of Celebration School was one of Disney's biggest selling points. Even as the company brought in world-famous architects, among them Philip Johnson, Michael Graves and Robert Venturi, to design the town's public buildings, it recruited pedagogues of similar stature to design the school's curriculum. When it opened, Celebration School combined just about every progressive innovation of the past generation -- it was as if Johnson, Graves and Venturi had collaborated on a single building. But many parents, who perceived chaos rather than learning taking place, soon grew disenchanted with the experiment. In the most overtly political gesture the residents of Celebration would make, they organized to pressure Disney into abandoning much of its distinctive approach to education, reshaping the school into a conventional grade factory.
The workmanlike prose in "Celebration U.S.A." reflects a scrupulously maintained reportorial balance. Its tales of family life ring true because they are drawn directly from the authors' own experiences. On balance, though, "The Celebration Chronicles" is more entertaining and more insightful. Ross is a raconteur with delicious -- and telling -- anecdotes: Disney's nightly vacuuming of the town's main street; the snow blowers that turn the Christmas party into a sea of soapy flakes; the Hell's Angels who gather at Sweet's ice cream bar; the encephalitis-bearing mosquitoes that keep people off their front porches; Nala, the clawless 400-pound lion who stirs panic when she escapes from nearby Jungle Land. Ross also gives the tale of this new town some context, tracing its lineage to the environmental movement of the 1960's, the postwar Levittowns and much farther back in time to experiments like Brook Farm and the Oneida Community, which embodied Americans' persisting desire to create a utopia.
Both books have the same underlying story line. The parents of Celebration's baby boomer residents had fled the cities for the allure of suburban life, but to the residents of Celebration, suburbia meant only a bumper-to-bumper commute to sterility. The Disney Company promised the revival of Norman Rockwell's America. "There once was a place where neighbors greeted neighbors in the quiet of summer twilight," the Disney pitch ran. "Where children chased fireflies. . . . The movie house showed cartoons on Saturday. The grocery store delivered. . . . Remember that place? . . . It held a magic all its own. The special magic of an American hometown."
With the firm hand of Disney to smooth things over, these recruits to Celebration believed they could journey back to this storybook era. Yet that is an impossible dream, because there is no way to keep the miseries of our times at bay. Crime, abused wives and neglected children are all part of the Celebration story, even if the residents and the Disney Company hush them up.
The notion that a real working community can be invented from scratch is at best implausible. If the master builder is a company as money-driven and image-conscious as Disney, the rhetoric of community becomes merely a way to generate good corporate public relations -- and a vanity play. "I hope in 50 years they say, 'Thank God for Celebration,' "Michael Eisner, Disney's chief executive officer, said. The good vibes generated by Celebration have effectively given Disney a license to remake the surrounding landscape. A little wetlands preservation in Celebration has gone a long way, as the company has used its good-citizen image to obtain environmental permits for much-expanded theme parks and to secure three new Interstate interchanges.
What is to be made of the experiment itself? From the first, Disney insisted that it would not build yet another gated community, a hideaway from the world. The premise of that determination, advanced in the name of idealism, was mainly economics: the downtown merchants relied on the business that tourist traffic would bring. But in its deliberate insularity, Celebration is really a gated community without the gates.
Poor people have a place in working communities, yet Disney's prices insure that Celebration's residents have incomes ranging upward from the solidly middle class. The poor "are not going to have the same commitment to the town," Brent Herrington, Disney's on-the-scene manager, insists. And aside from the Mexican migrants who did much of the actual construction, Celebration is overwhelmingly white. What matters to Disney -- and, sad to say, to many of its residents as well -- is consumer satisfaction, not civitas. Consequently, what Ross calls a "hunger for small-town civility" is transmuted into "a hunger for civic order at all costs."
While the developers of planned communities typically set the initial ground rules, they are quick to hand over authority to a homeowners' association and disappear from the scene. Disney, however, has written the rules to make certain that the company, not the residents, will run the show for decades to come. (It even had the chutzpah to request a say in picking the minister for the first church to open in the town.)
More than a century ago, the railroad magnate George Pullman built a model community whose houses were designed, and whose residents' appearance and behavior regulated, by Pullman's inspectors. As in the town of Pullman, Ill., government in Celebration is treated as a property right that belongs to the founder. Consequently, in Celebration as in Pullman, residents are something less than citizens. The verdict of a Harper's Monthly writer who visited Pullman in 1885 fits Celebration equally well. For all the founder's invocation of American homilies, "the town is un-American . . . benevolent, well-wishing feudalism."

HEADLINE: Same Old Ball Game

BYLINE: By Burt Solomon; Burt Solomon, a staff correspondent at National Journal in Washington, is the author of "Where They Ain't: The Fabled Life and Untimely Death of the Original Baltimore Orioles, the Team That Gave Birth to Modern Baseball."

 BODY:

A CLEVER BASE-BALLIST
 The Life and Times
 of John Montgomery Ward.
 By Bryan Di Salvatore.
 Illustrated. 477 pp. New York:
 Pantheon Books. $27.50. 
 John Montgomery Ward, a distant cousin of the department store founder, was a vain Pennsylvanian who molded the early history of baseball - both on and off the field. In 1880, he pitched the second perfect game in the sport, five days after the first one. Ten years later he was the leader in baseball's only true revolution, as the organizer and ideologist of the Players' League, which lasted only a season. Then he became a discreet owner's man, as a manager and as a lawyer, trying to claim an august place in baseball's establishment but never quite succeeding.
Ward (1860-1925) was a complicated, self-contained and fascinating man. He was a man of many parts (besides everything else, married for a turbulent spell to a prominent actress), prone to deception and probably self-deception - a hard man to get a feel for. After reading Bryan Di Salvatore's biography, "A Clever Base-Ballist," we find he still is.
This is an annoying book (starting with its dedication in French and its pretentious epigraphs, mercifully translated, from Athenaeus, Herodotus and Dizzy Dean). It seems both padded and thin, as if Di Salvatore, in his first book, needed to pile on words to mask a shortage of well-digested knowledge. He writes four tedious pages on The New York Clipper, an influential sporting and theater weekly that ran an admiring profile of Ward, then just a few brief paragraphs on the 1879 season, Ward's second in the majors, in which he won an astonishing 47 games, and barely a page on his perfect game. Rarely does the book evoke any feeling of being there.
Mainly it plods along with little real sense of tension, which is quite remarkable given the times it portrays. The earth was shifting under Americans' feet. A pastoral society was becoming urban and industrial, and the economy was organizing itself into impersonal trusts.
Ward was a modern sort of fellow. He was - unusual for a ballplayer then - a college man (though he was booted out of Penn State for stealing chickens, before enrolling at Columbia's law school). As a curveball pitcher, Di Salvatore writes, "he was crafty, a thinker, a brain man, the professor. He noted strengths, weaknesses and tendencies. He didn't (or couldn't) overpower batters, pitchers; he outwitted them." He was a scientific ballplayer, as the breed was becoming known, sufficiently cerebral (and articulate) to become the author, in 1888, of a how-to book on playing baseball that Di Salvatore describes as "on the whole, an erudite and gracefully written document."
Ward seems modern in another way: he was at home in a celebrity culture. With his waxed mustache and mannered style he was a natural for New York, where he spent most of his career (mainly with the Giants). His first wife, Helen Dauvray, was a tiny, buxom, hard-eyed, self-dramatizing actress. Ward made her quit the stage, until his repeated philandering drove their childless marriage to a painfully public divorce, worthy of the cover of People were they living now.
There was something else about Ward that makes him seem oh-so-familiar: he was labor's leader in its eternal war against capital. Baseball as a business needed fewer decimal places than it does now, but the dynamics are recognizable. Ward, writing in a national magazine as early as 1886, accused the owners of buying and selling the ballplayers as if they were "live-stock" and likened the reserve rule, which bound a player to a ball club for as long as the club wished, to the fresh memory of slavery. "There was a time when the League stood for integrity and fair dealing; to-day it stands for dollars and cents" - or so the players proclaimed (in a manifesto "almost certainly written by Ward," Di Salvatore reports) in 1890. It was a sentiment that might have been uttered anytime since.
But soon he was a manager and twice, briefly, a team owner and later almost the president of the National League. He could be whatever he needed to be, a man ahead of his times. Yet a reader of "A Clever Base-Ballist" never really understands him from the inside. Why was this son of a "less-than-illustrious" businessman and a schoolteacher - a scion of the middle class, and a lawyer to boot - so passionate about workingmen's rights? Why, as the Players' League collapsed, did he back off from trying to quash the reserve rule after the courts had invited the players to do so? And why did he back away from baseball politics forever after?
Di Salvatore can only guess, and not very persuasively. Nor, he admits, was he able to learn much of anything about Ward's boyhood and adolescence, his homelife, his hobbies, his sandlot teammates, even his style of pitching. (It is sad how much information about all but the most prominent individuals gets lost, and so quickly.) He calls Ward "arrogant" and "fastidious" and "shrewd," but we never see what made him tick.
This is a pity. Di Salvatore is interesting on college life of Ward's time and on the origins and early days of baseball. The book includes some strong passages, like his lovely description of Ward's Pennsylvania hometown ("Bellefonte is peaceful as a napping dog. It also has a high opinion of itself") and his description of Ward's prose style as "concise, forceful and slyly self-effacing." But he also is prone to fits of purple prose, abrupt shifts in tone and metaphors that get out of hand (nearly as many pitchers claim to being the first to throw a curveball "as there are convenience stores in South Carolina"). He tries too hard to be clever - much like Ward.
Ward was standoffish - "there exists no known likeness of him smiling." His teammates disliked him, especially when he was in charge. He was smarter than they were and made sure they knew it. Ward is to be admired from afar, but he isn't someone you would want to spend too much time with, either in a dressing room or in a book in your lap.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By RAY CORMIER

 BODY:

Late-Season Northwest Trip
Q. My husband and I would like to stretch a November trip to the Napa Valley for a wedding with a cruise or train trip in the Northwest, or perhaps across Canada. What is available then? -- Sylvia K. Marzolf, Savannah, Ga.
A. Cruises up the Pacific Coast are hard to find by the end of October, but cruises on some of the major rivers of the Northwest continue. And scenic train rides are always available. You could easily travel both on water and by rail. 
 Among the cruises is a seven-day sailing out of Portland along the Willamette, Columbia and Snake Rivers on the Queen of the West. This 163-passenger stern-wheeler has outside cabins only. The cruise includes entertainment and excursions on the Mount Hood Scenic Railway, to Mount St. Helens and to Nez Perce Historical Park. Rates are $1,489 to $4,065 a person, double occupancy.
Farther north, the Victoria Clipper, a high-speed catamaran, offers shorter cruise-and-tour packages to Seattle, Vancouver and Victoria, British Columbia, with nights spent on shore in a choice of hotels. A two-night Seattle-Victoria package, for example, including a cruise, a champagne breakfast, accommodations and a tour in Victoria, costs $212 to $294 a person.
An agency that can give you more information on these trips and book them is Sunshine Travel and Cruise, Post Office Box 970, 100 West Second Street, The Dalles, Ore. 97058; (800) 578-1479, fax (541) 296-5561.
To see the Northwest by rail, contact Amtrak, (800) 872-7245, www.amtrak.com, which has a tour division. The railroad's Coast Starlight runs between Los Angeles and Seattle; you could pick it up in Martinez, near Oakland, for an overnight trip and wake up in Oregon. From Seattle, the Cascades route can take you to Vancouver.
In Canada, Via Rail operates trains throughout the Canadian West and across the country. Two routes are the 725-mile Skeena, between Jasper, Alberta, and Prince George, British Columbia, and the Malahat, which traverses Vancouver Island, south and north. And to really see Canada -- or at least a good chunk of it -- there is the Canadian, which runs between Vancouver and Toronto, through Kamloops, Jasper, Edmonton, Saskatoon and Winnipeg.
Via Rail, unlike Amtrak, does not arrange tours. Brewster Tours of Calgary, (800) 661-1152, fax (403) 260-4636, www.brewster.ca, is an agency that works with Via Rail. Shannon Birnie of Brewster said that customized tours can be arranged, but that among the package tours you might consider is the Winter Wonderland, offered from October to April. This seven-night rail-and-bus tour begins in Vancouver and includes two nights each in Jasper and Banff, and single nights on the train and in Lake Louise and Calgary. Rates are $735 to $891 a person, double occupancy.
You might want to look into a joint promotion of Amtrak and Via Rail, the North America Rail Pass. In fall and winter, the pass costs $450 and provides 30 days of economy-class travel (upgrades are possible) on both railroads. Contact Amtrak or the Via Rail Web site, www .viarail.ca, for more information.
 
Dublin Pub Tours
Q. How can I find out about literary pub tours in the fall in Dublin? -- Selma Kleinman, Rockaway Park, Queens
A. To raise a toast or two to Dublin's literary heritage, you should contact Colm Quilligan, the founder of Dublin Literary Pub Crawl Ltd., at (353-1) 670-5602 or (353-87) 263-0270, or by fax at (353-1) 670-5603. There is also www.dublinpubcrawl.com, but at last check, it had information only on the company's Paris Literary Promenade.
Mr. Quilligan said the Dublin tours are offered nightly at 7:30 and at noon on Sunday from Easter to the end of October, and on Thursday to Sunday at 7:30 P.M. and Sunday at noon the rest of the year. For two and a half hours, two actors lead the walkers to four pubs and other sites in Dublin to perform scenes by famous playwrights and novelists and have fun with a literary quiz (there are prizes).
A typical tour, Mr. Quilligan said, starts at the Duke on Duke Street, with extracts from "Waiting for Godot" and "Ulysses." Oscar Wilde is the main subject at Trinity College and a stop at O'Neill's pub nearby, then it's off to the Bank of Ireland (the Old Parliament House) and the next pub, the Old Stand, a haunt of Brendan Behan. Finally, the tour heads for Neary's and Davy Byrne's and the finale: a full-length performance of Beckett's 30-second play, "Breath."
At the rate of $1.33 to the punt, the evening costs $8.65, $7.30 for students, not including drinks. And you might want to bring your autograph book. Mr. Quilligan says the crawls have been joined on occasion by such actors as Kathy Bates, Brian Dennehy and Ian McKellen.
 
Paris Wine Show
Q. I want to plan a trip to Paris around the Salon National des Vins. When will it be held next? -- Allan R. Freelon, Durham, N.C.
A. The Salon des Caves Particulieres (the Independent Wine Growers Show) is held twice a year in Paris by the Confederation of Independent Wine Growers, or C.N.P.C., a union representing about 10,000 growers from all regions of France. While its primary function is to protect and promote the quality of wines made by independent growers, the union also organizes a series of shows throughout the year, in Paris and other cities.
Unlike many others, this salon is geared toward consumers, though professionals -- dealers, sommeliers, restaurateurs -- often attend, too. Each grower sets up a stand and is available to answer questions and give tastings. You can place large orders or buy a few bottles on the spot.
The largest show takes place at the Porte de Versailles in Paris in late autumn, and draws an average of 125,000 visitors. This year, it will be held Dec. 3 to 8. The next Paris show, at the Espace Champerret in the 17th arrondissement, will be April 14 to 17.
Admission to the show is about $6.50 and includes a souvenir engraved glass to use for unlimited free tastings. A catalogue listing all the participating growers costs about $3.25.
Other major cities where the shows are to be held are Lyons, Oct. 28 to Nov. 1; Reims, Nov. 12 to 15; Lille, Nov. 26 to 29, and Strasbourg, Feb. 25 to 28. For more information, go to the C.N.P.C.'s Web site, www.caves-particulieres.com, or call the union at (33-1) 44.74.51.24.
 RAY CORMIER

HEADLINE: L.A. Hotels With Attitude

BYLINE: By HILARY de VRIES; HILARY de VRIES reports on entertainment in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
THE hotel scene in Los Angeles is red hot. As part of the city's ongoing revival fueled by a booming local economy, several stylish new upstarts have taken their place alongside such dowagers as the Beverly Hills Hotel, the Regent Beverly Wilshire and the Hotel Bel-Air. This is good news for both travelers and residents who frequent hip hotel restaurants and bars, such as the Mondrian's Sky Bar, ground zero for the cognoscenti when it opened nearly three years ago.
What began with Ian Schrager's renovation of the Mondrian on the Sunset Strip in 1996 and the opening of Shutters on the Beach in Santa Monica in 1993 has gathered momentum in the past 12 months as several new or newly renovated hotels have opened -- with more to come this fall, including Casa Del Mar in Santa Monica and the W Los Angeles in Westwood. I recently stayed in three of them with my boyfriend, Michael. Two have been refurbished and are in Beverly Hills -- the Avalon, the former Beverly Carlton, and L'Ermitage, which has had a $65 million makeover. The Standard on Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood is new, renovated from a former retirement home. 

The Standard
The first time I called the Standard to book a room three weeks ahead, the reservations desk was so busy I was told to call back. Open since March, the 142-room Standard has been a hit with those looking for budget-priced, high-style accommodations on the Sunset Strip.
Owned by Andre Balazs, who bought and renovated the Chateau Marmont down the street, the Standard aims at a younger, less affluent -- and yes, harder partying -- crowd than either the Chateau or the Mondrian. When I reached a reservations agent some hours later, I was told the hotel's $95 rooms, among the cheapest in L.A., were long gone. "Those go really fast," the agent told me, adding with remarkable candor, "but they're right on the street and really noisy." That was all I needed to request a more expensive ($165) room on the hotel's quieter south side.
Even before you cross the threshold, the Standard lets you know who's boss. The motel-like 1960's three-story structure with its undulating facade is painted bright white and illuminated by glowing blue lights reminiscent of those bug zappers used at roadside "tourist courts." Under the carport, guests are greeted by valets dressed as gas station attendants circa 1950. The hotel's sign, a white vinyl banner roped to the carport, hangs upside down. No icy Armani-clad chic here. This is a rock-n-roll haven dolled up for 90's ironists. There aren't many places, even in L.A., where you'll find Arco lamps and Ligne Roset sofas in the lobby, a performance art aquarium behind the check-in desk, a resident tattoo artist in the barber shop and condoms in the minibar.
I was braced for similar attitude from the hotel staff, but check-in was smoothly professional, even friendly. And while I was easily the only guest pulling out a pair of reading glasses to sign the registration, the desk clerk assured me I was in for a "great party weekend" with as much enthusiasm as he greeted the group of tattooed 20-something males wearing cargo pants that was checking in next to me.
My room, 326, on the hotel's top floor overlooking the pool deck, was surprisingly large and filled with more stylishly ironic details, like the Andy Warhol flower-print drapes and the matchbook from Hollywood Bail Bonds wedged in the tail-fin ashtray. Decorated in vivid primary colors -- blue, black and white for the bedroom, Day-Glo orange and white for the bathroom -- the room suggested anything but repose. It had a king-size platform bed (with cotton sheets and a single wool blanket) and two nightstands with lamps on dimmers (one of which worked) directly across from a wall-sized mirror hanging over the built-in desk. There was one white plastic desk chair as well as a beanbag chair covered in silver vinyl. The small balcony overlooking the pool was unfurnished. The bathroom was even more spare, with a commercial toilet (no lid) next to a small tub with a shower head and two sets of white towels, Neutrogena soap and shampoo. Six plastic hangers and a laundry bag hung behind a white canvas curtain that served as the only closet.
The room was outfitted, however, with a wealth of electronic gadgets -- large-screen TV with a VCR and premium cable, a stereo with CD player, a cordless two-line phone -- and the minibar, crammed with a full split of vodka, Vaseline and an aromatherapy candle in a pill canister, was a party in itself. If I had just gotten out of college, the room would have qualified as nirvana. Pawing through the minibar (Veuve Clicquot and Gummi Bears!) I felt like Margaret Mead doing field research on Generation Next.
Downstairs in the hotel bar, which was decorated with a rec-room style desertscape mural and surprisingly comfortable wicker tub chairs, I joined Michael for a predinner drink. A breeze from the pool deck fluttered the gauzy drapes and votive candles flickering on the tables. Not that anyone seemed to notice, as the party was already raging with the raucous beer-and-martini crowd.
Dinner in the hotel restaurant -- a 24-hour-coffee shop tricked out in chic brown naugahyde booths -- was more successful. Thomas Rivera, who cooked at Odeon in New York, is the executive chef, and the menu is eclectic and very of-the-minute: miso soup, caesar salad and tuna wasabi pizza. We had a nicely grilled steak frites, chopped vegetable salad and a bottle of Cotes du Rhone from a wine list with unexpected depth. Only the noise from our uproarious fellow diners diminished the experience.
And then the evening really began. One does not -- or should not -- check into the Standard to get away from it all. Back in our room, we spent several minutes on our balcony surveying the bar crowd that had spilled onto the pool deck. Covered in electric blue Astroturf, white lounge chairs and two rectangles of actual grass, the pool area -- standard-sized pool, big deck -- resembles a David Hockney painting during the day. At night, however, it serves as a natural amphitheater. Even with our room's sliding glass doors shut, we could hear enough crowd noise to make sleep only a remote possibility.
Finally, after cranking the room's ventilation system -- there was no thermostat, only a fan with the settings "Blow, Hard, Harder, Stop" -- we created sufficient white noise to fall fitfully asleep. At 4 A.M., we were awakened by the sound of our neighbor's television. By 6:30, we were fully awake from doors slamming and vacuuming in the hall.
We needed sleep. Bolstered by a latte and an egg-white omelet from the restaurant that was now cheerily sun-splashed, we staggered out of the Standard, collected the car from the valets and drove home to take a nap.
The Standard, 8300 Sunset Boulevard, West Hollywood, Calif. 90069; (323) 650-9090, fax (323) 650-2820. Rooms from $95 to $200; suites, $550.
 
Avalon Hotel
The Avalon, in the southern reaches of Beverly Hills, is a world away from the Sunset Strip. The hotel is so low-profile we almost drove past its Lilliputian circular driveway before spotting the small, seafoam green sign among the palms. The former Beverly Carlton, where Marilyn Monroe once lived, it opened in May after a $6 million renovation. It has quickly become a favorite with clothing designers and other fashion people. Now a hideaway of retro chic -- the vintage kidney-shaped pool visible through the lobby's glass walls remains the hotel's focal point -- the Avalon is more evocative of sleepy 1950's-era Palm Springs than modern-day Los Angeles.
As we glided across the cool rosewood and aqua lobby where a thicket of bamboo trunks guards the copper-topped registration desk, the hotel felt more like a chic urban spa. Although it was still working out the opening night kinks -- tape on the glossy black lobby floor indicated where an office wall was yet to be installed -- the conscientious staff more than made up for it.
When we pulled up and the bellman thought he detected a burning smell, he personally checked to make sure the car was not overheating. And at check-in, when despite being the only guests in sight we did not get the room I'd requested -- a $165 terraced room in one of the hotel's two neighboring guesthouses -- we were swiftly given a large room on the top floor of the main "landmark" building with a balcony that overlooked the pool. (Some of the hotel's 88 rooms overlook busy Olympic Avenue.)
Riding the copper-sheathed elevator to the open-air corridors leading to our room, I anticipated plenty of trendy minimalism in Room 324. The lobby alone had convinced me the Avalon was a hotel for those who knew their Eames from their Noguchi. I don't, and it was with some relief that I found our room an oasis of zenlike comfort ballasted with a clear knowledge of a working professional's needs.
Many will appreciate the George Nelson bubble lamps and the Heywood-Wakefield table and moderne-style upholstered furniture done in shades of azure, green and periwinkle. I liked the oversized built-in desk and the Krups coffeemaker as well as the fax machine with a dedicated line in the spacious (Eames-style) double closet. I also loved the snowy cotton sheets, the charcoal chenille throw, the puffy down comforter in a linen duvet cover and the pile of feather pillows on the platform bed. Even the three jazz CD's provided with the stereo were to my taste.
The minibar, too, was L.A. perfect, with its Evian water, protein bars and canned fruit smoothies. Other thoughtful details included an iron and ironing board, stacks of hangers (padded and wooden), a full-length mirror, a 27-inch TV with VCR, and an individual air-conditioning unit with remote.
The bathroom, although not large, was its own sybaritic experience with white tile wainscoting, a sink fashioned from a porcelain bowl, piles of white towels and trendy Philosophy products in a shower dispenser. There was also a magnifying mirror, a hair dryer, a terrycloth robe and, thoughtfully, a chrome wheeled cart for holding towels or toiletries.
The room was such a plush cocoon that we had hoped to simply order a room service dinner. However, the dining room was available only for breakfast and lunch -- it has subsequently opened for dinner and offers 24-hour room service -- so we settled for a drink in the bar, which also doubles as the hotel's diminutive restaurant. With Muddy Waters on the soundtrack, a breeze rattling the palms surrounding the pool and the votive candles glinting off the vintage chrome chairs, it was easy to forget the big city was just outside.
After a quick dinner in Beverly Hills, we beetled back to the Avalon to crank the air-conditioning and watch an old movie from that comfy bed. When the noise from a private party on the pool deck again threatened sleep around 1 A.M., a call to the desk elicted a courteous and immediate response. Within minutes the revelers had been herded into the bar behind closed doors.
Awakened the next day at 8:30 by housekeeping -- we had looked in vain for a Do Not Disturb sign the night before -- we decided to greet the morning early. Michael took a turn in the very compact gym -- a bike, two treadmills, a Stairmaster and some free weights share the glass-walled space with an air-conditioning duct -- while I lolled on one of the black wood lounges by the pool.
At breakfast, despite being tempted by the protein shake with dates, we yielded to buttermilk pancakes and smoked salmon and bagels. With only two other guests sharing the dining room, we asked for, and received, a delayed checkout, in order to spend another solitary hour by the pool. When we slipped down the Avalon's circular drive later that afternoon, I felt as though we were stumbling out of Hollywood's Brigadoon.
Avalon Hotel, 9400 Olympic Boulevard, Beverly Hills, Calif. 90212; (800) 535-4715 or (310) 277-5221, fax (310) 277-4928. Rooms, $185 to $235; one-bedroom suites, $250.
 
L'Ermitage
"And here is your personalized stationery," the bellman said, flipping open the folder on the desk that held two sheets of paper and three business cards printed with my name (albeit misspelled) and the words "in residence." Now, that's service. But I discovered during our 24-hour stay (more about that in a minute) that service is what L'Ermitage is about. Maybe some A-list star or captain of industry can put L'Ermitage through its paces and find the flaws, but I couldn't.
Which isn't to say the hotel's recent $65 million renovation doesn't impress. It does, especially the 124 spacious minimalist rooms decorated in tea-colored silk and English sycamore (and updated with motion detectors, 40-inch TV with combination DVD and CD players as well as cell phones) that seem as conducive to a romantic weekend as a working stay. Once the kind of luxurious but off-the-beaten-path hotel where stars like Elizabeth Taylor repaired after surgery, L'Ermitage, which emerged from its own facelift a year ago, now offers intimate, boutique-style lodgings on Beverly Hill's busy Burton Way. The hushed elegance begins in the lobby, a large, formal room with silk-covered furnishings and opulent bouquets, and the quiet, efficient desk clerks dressed in severe Nehru-collared uniforms. Once again we seemed to be the only guests for the weekend. If I had secretly hoped to be upgraded from the room I'd requested -- a standard room on a high floor with a view of the Hollywood Hills for a promotional rate of $295 -- that desire was rendered superfluous when we arrived at No. 815.
Although one of the hotel's smallest rooms, at 675 square feet it comfortably contained a studio apartment's worth of furnishings -- a king-size bed with gold silk coverlet, a wooden desk with two chairs, a built-in cabinet holding the television and DVD player, two upholstered chairs with an ottoman and a side table. There was also a door leading to a small balcony overlooking the hills.
Separated from the main room by sliding wood shoji screens, a hallway with a lighted bar contained an extensive selection of liquors and complimentary soft drinks as well as stemware from Champagne flutes to martini glasses. Behind another shoji screen was a dressing room with a makeup mirror, closet, safe and chest of drawers. Beyond yet another door was a palatial marble bath with an oversized tub and separate shower.
Amenities included four robes (two terrycloth and two waffle weave), two sets of slippers, five telephones and a fax machine. The toiletries, which included SPF 15 sunblock, were from Aveda. Then the doorbell rang: ah yes, a wooden bento box of chocolates and a handwritten note welcoming us.
Deciding to check out the gym just down the hall from our room, we discovered a health-club's worth of equipment and expansive glass-walled views. Small television sets were positioned at every machine, and in the locker rooms, steam rooms snorted full blast. Up one flight lay the pool deck -- a Roman-bath style retreat with cut limestone, pots of olive trees and bougainvillea, and teak-and-canvas chaises. The solicitous pool attendant who set up our lounges with fresh towels and supplied room service menus, suntan lotion and chilled bottles of Evian at regular intervals added to the country club atmosphere.
Only when we ventured down to the hotel bar and restaurant did L'Ermitage seem less than inviting. Although the staff -- from our waitress to the chef who kept sending out special additions to our dinner of striped bass and arctic char (oysters poached in sake; a verjus sorbet) -- could not have been more welcoming, the echoey domed-ceiling dining room did not exude the warmth or intimacy of the guest rooms.
But I quibble. The next day, after an evening watching "Carlito's Way" on our DVD player and a room service breakfast of fruit, muffins and granola that arrived 10 minutes earlier than promised, we called the front desk to ask about using the pool after check-out. No problem. Within a minute, the desk clerk called back to suggest that we simply "enjoy the room and the pool" and check out when we were ready. Even the fleet of beige-suited bellmen who ushered us to our car at 5 o'clock that afternoon couldn't top that for service.
L'Ermitage, 9291 Burton Way, Beverly Hills, Calif. 90210; (800) 800-2113 or (310) 278-3344. Double rooms, $325 to $448; suites, $780 to $3,800. Ask about promotional rates.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: The Harborside Renewal in Baltimore Widens

BYLINE: By CHARLES BELFOURE 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
OVER the last 20 years, this city's Inner Harbor renewal steadily progressed around the northern side of the inlet. The southern side, however, along the Locust Point peninsula, remained industrial and its waterfront was inaccessible to the public.
But this will change now that a $63-million renovation of a former Procter & Gamble soap factory has begun. The project will convert the 15-acre site into a high-technology business center. 
 The conversion will be the first major effort in Locust Point to recycle its many vacant factories and eventually link its waterfront to the successful Inner Harbor development, which began in 1979 with James Rouse's Harborplace.
In the 1960's, much of Baltimore's maritime activity moved out of the harbor basin to take advantage of deeper water and more land, which was needed for unloading container ships.
And despite the start of the Inner Harbor renewal, plant closings in the 70's and 80's resulted in a loss of 2,500 industrial and maritime jobs. In 1995, when Procter & Gamble closed its plant, an additional 550 jobs were lost. The plant was sold the following year to to A & E International, a Korean company that planned to make sake. But the Asian financial crisis forced it to abandon its plans.
Last April A & E sold the property for $6 million to Struever Bros., Eccles & Rouse, a Baltimore-based developer with extensive experience in recycling industrial buildings. The developer then sold off a parcel containing warehouses with a total of 275,000 square feet of space for $3.25 million, retaining a five-building site with a total of 370,000 square feet.
Carl William Struever, the president of SBER, is now completing a renovation financing package of $63 million, 55 percent of which will be a first mortgage financing with the remainder in historic-tax-credit equity -- 25 percent of the total package from the state and 20 percent from the Federal Government.
A developer earns historic tax credits by following Federal guidelines in the restoration of a historic structure. He or she may then sell these credits at a discount to an investor and thus gain financing for a project such as the conversion of the former Procter & Gamble plant, which is on the National Register of Historic Places.
The five buildings in the new development, which will be called the Point, will be named Tide, Dawn, Joy, Cascade and Ivory in honor of the former factory's products. The developer will take 25,000 square feet of space in the Joy building for its headquarters.
Built in 1929, all are four-story, steel frame and brick structures with windows 8 feet high and 12 feet wide, giving tenants an unobstructed view of the harbor and Baltimore's skyline. They are all connected by enclosed skywalks and on the front of each building is a circular recess with Procter & Gamble's stars and moon logo.
MUCH of the factory equipment will be retained and incorporated into the design of the tenant space, including some of the steel soap vats, which are 20 feet in diameter and 30 feet deep.
Imaginatively recycled factories play an important role in drawing computer-related companies, the kind of tenant Mr. Struever is seeking to attract. "The traditional smokestack industries that surrounded Baltimore's harbor can be replaced by computer- and information-related industries such as Web site design and software companies," he explained with great enthusiasm.
SBER's first tenants will be two Web site design and computer graphic companies -- gr.8,inc, which took the entire 110,000-square-foot Cascade building, and TeknoSurf.com, which took 35,000 square feet in the Ivory building. Annual rents are in the $14 to $18 range per square foot.
The Point will be completed in one phase, rather than several, due to strong demand, said Mr. Struever, addding the complex would have a parking garage with a total of about 600 spaces in addition to 650 surface spaces. Completion is expected by the end of next year.
To get to the project now, one has to travel through the streets of an adjacent row-house neighborhood. But in two years, according to Mr. Struever, the harborfront Key Highway will be realigned and extended, providing direct access to the Point.
While land access is important, transportation on the water is key to revitalization in this part of the harbor, said Caroline Moore, director of commercial development for SBER. A stop will be added to the current water-taxi service "to get you to the other side of the harbor in five minutes," said Ms. Moore. A dock with 12 slips for tenants will be built along with transient docking next to a new public promenade.
Some industrial activity will remain in Locust Point, most notably at the site of the Point's next-door neighbor, Domino Sugar. Tenants will look out of their windows and see raw sugar unloaded from huge freighters. "That's a lot more interesting than looking at the side of a high-rise," remarked Ms. Moore.
Across the harbor from the Point is SBER's most recently completed Inner Harbor project, the conversion of the American Can Company site. Completed in 1997 and totally leased, the site houses 60,000 square feet of retail space and 140,000 of office space, in part for an Emerging Technology Center, an incubator space for small high-technology companies. DAP, a maker of adhesives and sealants, moved its national headquarters there from Ohio.
Many consider the renovation of the American Can complex to be the catalyst in the turnaround of the surrounding neighborhood of Canton. It has become an extremely popular place to live, especially for young people and property values have risen accordingly, said William Cassidy, manager of Long and Foster Realty's Fells Point office, who lives in Canton.
"American Can definitely enhanced the whole neighborhood," said Mr. Cassidy, who is seeing the same thing happen in Locust Point. "Because of the P. & G. project, there's a heightened interest, which has already created a scarcity of houses, we're working with a developer who plans to build 41 town houses there."
The Locust Point community next door to the Point is much like Canton's, a working-class enclave home to generations of longshoremen and factory hands. It is best known for being the home of Fort McHenry, the bombardment of which inspired the "The Star-Spangled Banner," and the Baltimore Museum of History, which seeks to preserve the city's important industrial heritage.
The neighborhood is very supportive of his project, said Mr. Struever, because it means jobs to an economically hard hit area. Because it is situated in an enterprise zone, funds will be available for retraining residents for computer-related jobs at the Point.
Development still continues on the other side of the harbor, most notably with a 750-room hotel under construction by the Marriott Hotel Corporation. Port Discovery, an interactive children's museum, has recently opened and plans for an African-American Museum of History and Culture are under way.
The next important Inner Harbor development will be at the 27-acre Allied Chemical site at the edge of the water, where environmental remediation work has recently been completed. It is currently being marketed by its owner.
Mr. Struever, who came to Baltimore 25 years ago after graduating from Brown University with a degree in urban anthropology, has an almost religious fervor about urban redevelopment.
"The great hope for urban American is tapping the richness of city neighborhoods like Locust Point and Canton," he said. "The buildings there that once worked as environments for old industry can easily work for new industries."

LENGTH: 1743 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Downsizing The Broadway Musical

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
THE dancing corkscrew will still be there, as will the singing whisk and the graceful cheese grater. But there may be slightly fewer spinning plates and spatulas when "Beauty and the Beast" reopens on Nov. 12.
And over at "The Scarlet Pimpernel," which reopened Sept. 10, there are fewer people waiting to be executed in the guillotine scene. 
 "Beauty and the Beast" closed at the Palace Theater on Sept. 5 and is coming back in a slightly smaller version to the Lunt-Fontanne Theater on Nov. 12; the cast will drop by seven, including understudies and swings (who fill in for various roles). Similarly, "The Scarlet Pimpernel" closed at the Minskoff on May 30 and reopened at the Neil Simon after several weeks of touring, having scaled back its cast by 12 and its orchestra by 4.
Musicals are typically made more modest when they leave Broadway for the road. But it is unusual for a show to close in New York and then reopen there in reduced form, particularly at a time when the industry has increased the top ticket price to $80 from $75. And, taken together, these two examples suggest a potentially significant rethinking about how to produce shows for less when musicals increasingly cost more.
The producers of "The Scarlet Pimpernel" and "Beauty and the Beast" maintain that the changes are imperceptible and the shows have improved considerably as a result of scaling them down. "It plays better in an intimate space," said Robert Longbottom, the director of "Pimpernel." "This is a story about three people, and you can touch them at the Neil Simon. It's substantially less people onstage, but it doesn't feel that way."
Some of the scenery has also been simplified. What was previously a full stage elevator that simulated a ship is now a scissor lift. "It's the low-tech version of it," Mr. Longbottom said. "But it's absolutely as graceful and as magical."
Nevertheless, the downsizing raises questions that some in the theater industry will have to deal with if this practice gains in popularity. Might not such reductions ultimately compromise content? Won't other producers inevitably want to follow suit and try to sustain a run by revamping shows, conceivably at the expense of production values? What does this mean for theater audiences?
"Costs are just as important as quality," said Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters.
But what about the loss of jobs? The New York musicians union, Local 802, is contesting the reduction in the number of musicians in "Pimpernel" from 24 to 20, even though the union-set minimum drops from one theater to another. "The fact of diminishing the production and selling it for the same dollars, there is something wrong with that," said William Moriarty, president of the local.
While union rules require the Neil Simon Theater to use four fewer musicians than the Minskoff does, the union is arguing that the streamlined "Pimpernel" is the same production and therefore should maintain the same number of musicians. "Our contract says the orchestra is hired for the run of the show in New York City," Mr. Moriarty said.
He said his union had a meeting scheduled later this week with the grievance committee at the League of American Theaters and Producers. "This is a new set of circumstances so far as I'm aware," Mr. Moriarty said. "If it is the wave of the future, now is the time to address this issue."
Mr. Moriarty said he also planned to talk with the producers of "Beauty and the Beast" about making sure the orchestra for that show retains the same musicians from one production to the next.
Alan Eisenberg, executive director of the Actors Equity Association, the actors union, said he, too, was troubled by the scaling down of musicals.
"Somebody with a long time on a show can be downsized out with no kind of compensation for the commitment that they've made," he said. "There should be some recognition of seniority. Jobs are hard to come by." As it is, he noted that union members work an average of only 16 weeks a year.
Some producers are skeptical about whether downsizing can work. Tom Viertel, a Broadway producer, said he tried it unsuccessfully years ago with a show called "Sills & Company," moving to a smaller theater and reducing the cast to five from nine to save money. "Whether you can actually turn things around by tightening up, I don't know," Mr. Viertel said. "It didn't work for us. The audience tightened up too."
Others say the trend signals a healthy re-examination of how Broadway plays are produced, an approach that would be best adopted before a show opens rather than after it is up and running. "If this signals a kind of responsible reaction or need to have these productions come in at figures that can actually be economically feasible, I think that's terrific," said Margo Lion, a Broadway producer. "Hopefully, they'll be even better than they were before."
Tom Schumacher and Peter Schneider of Walt Disney Theatrical Productions played down the changes to "Beauty and the Beast" as little more than the kind of polishing that is always done with a show. In fact, they said, a song ("There's Been a Change in Me") was recently added, an unusual step four years into a show's run.
"We're not out there saying simpler, smaller, cheaper," Mr. Schneider said. "We're saying it's a move to the Lunt-Fontanne to keep it running longer."
Indeed, the people behind these productions seemed to bristle at the suggestion that their shows had somehow diminished in quality because they had decreased in size. "The producers had the option to end the run or to rethink it in a smaller house," Mr. Longbottom said. "And I think it has been overdramatized what that rethinking means. We simply have moved to a smaller home and in doing that, you sometimes have to throw out furniture."
Elizabeth Ward Land, who has been in "Pimpernel" since the beginning, said the show had benefited from becoming more compact -- there had previously been people on stage who didn't do much -- but that it was hard to see some of her colleagues go. "I think for the people who stayed, they were glad to have a job," she said.
Jed Bernstein, president of the producers league, pointed out that the reconfiguration of these productions has meant the preservation of some jobs rather than the elimination of all of them.
"In what other industry is there this notion that there are no efficiencies to be gained?" he asked, adding: "It isn't about the number of people. It's about what tells the story the best and that's what should govern, not some antiquated rule. And if you can save money, great, because it will give the show longer life and make it better for everybody."
There is a tradition of renovating long-running shows. In an extreme example, the producer Cameron Mackintosh replaced almost the entire cast of "Les Miserables" after deciding that the production had grown stale.
But the prospect of slimming down musicals is a new question for Broadway. Where until just a few years ago the idea of closing, reworking and reopening a show would have been financially prohibitive for most producers, corporate deep pockets have now made it possible to finance such transitions.
But both producers in this case say they did not scale down their productions mainly for financial reasons. They did it, they say, because of real estate; their theaters had been promised to other shows. "The Scarlet Pimpernel" had to leave the Minskoff because "Saturday Night Fever" was moving in. "Beauty and the Beast" had to leave the Palace for Disney's "Aida."
"Sure, economics are part of it -- it's a commercial venture," Mr. Schumacher said. "But at the end of the day, it's the quality of the show that matters."
Tim Hawkins, the executive producer of "The Scarlet Pimpernel," said moving was not a matter of choice or financial necessity. The show was grossing a respectable average of just below $500,000 a week before it closed, he said, and "the move and adjustments are happening because we're forced to move to a smaller theater."
Nevertheless, costs will be about 20 percent lower in the smaller theater. The Neil Simon not only has fewer seats (1,300 compared to the Minskoff's 1,700), but its total dimensions are about 60 percent that of the Minskoff, Mr. Hawkins said. He said "Pimpernel" had to scale down to adapt to that new tighter space.
And while die-hard fans may notice that there is no longer a crowd scene where there used to be one, Mr. Hawkins said: "We believe that the perception will be that nothing changed, that the show delivers now maybe even moreso than than it did in the Minskoff."
This will mark the third incarnation of "Pimpernel," a version its creators refer to as Pimpernel 3.0. The first overhaul, undertaken last year, was prompted by flagging ticket sales. "Pimpernel" had some loyal -- and wealthy -- fans in the Cablevision Systems Corporation, which acquired the musical in partnership with the financier Theodore J. Forstmann, one of the show's original producers.
After a period of rehearsing the new show during the day while performing the old version at night, "Pimpernel" reopened last fall with substantial changes: new lines, discarded scenes and moved songs.
Aside from some new choreography, the current revised "Pimpernel" has changed in that the total cast has shrunk from 41 to 29 . This reduction has meant more responsibility for each cast member. "An ensemble member may go from being a soldier in one scene to a maid in another scene to someone at the royal ball in the next scene," Mr. Hawkins said.
As to whether it was difficult to let some longtime cast members go, Mr. Longbottom said: "That's never easy."
The cast of "Beauty and Beast" has dropped from 39 to 32. And the show's producers said the lighting, sound and sets have been improved. For the big production number, "Be Our Guest," in which the kitchen comes to life in inviting Belle (Beauty) to dinner, the producers said the changes would be minor. "There will be some adjustments to the cutlery," Mr. Schumacher said. "But all your feature condiments containers are safe. They haven't been affected."
Whether self-justifying or not, producers say such efforts will ultimately make their productions measurably better, without making them perceptibly different. "It's like honey, I shrank the show," Mr. Longbottom said. "But because of the house that it's in, it looks just as big to me."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Peeking Inside Other People's Dream Houses

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
MODERN life is long, modern art is short. That's why art keeps getting better all the time. If you don't like it now, just stick around for a while. Eventually, something likable is bound to turn up.
It's a pleasure to report, for example, that the Museum of Modern Art's architecture and design department is back on track after several lackluster seasons. "The Un-Private House," a current show organized by the department's chief curator, Terence Riley, has been a popular as well as a critical success, so crowded at times that it's impossible to see the many fine works on view. "Different Roads," a show of concept cars organized by Christopher Mount, an associate curator, is not brilliant, but it has also been a crowd pleaser. Who doesn't like a car show? 
 And who doesn't get a voyeuristic thrill from peeking into private houses? That thrill is the subtext of "The Un-Private House," an exhibition of 26 recent residential designs (through Oct. 5). The supertext is the erosion of the borders between public and private realms, as seen from the homeowner's point of view. Media walls, open floor plans, glass walls, Moebius strip staircases, virtual chefs -- these are just a few of the devices used to blur or dissolve the oppositional relationship between public and private space. But the subtext -- the museum audience gazing into places designed for private clients -- is what gives this show its timely appeal.
After all, what would a self-respecting media wall have been showing us in recent years? A world convulsed by the performances of public figures in private places: President Clinton in White House corridors; Princess Diana backstage at the Ritz Hotel; John F. Kennedy Jr. in a single-engine plane. A world in which people may think they know JonBenet Ramsey's family better than the Ramseys know themselves -- better, for that matter, than they know the people living beneath their own roofs.
These convolutions, the endlessly televised discussions of them and the global hand-wringing over threats to privacy posed by the discussions have brought the show's theme to the table of mass culture. They have also embodied that theme, by bringing public discussion into the private living room. The show gives us an avant-garde rendering of issues that have already passed into popular consciousness.
The installation sets forth these issues with muted Pop Art flair. Drawings, photographs and wall texts are framed by strips of floral powder-room wallpaper. Tables, chairs, a bed. At the psychic center of the show is a conversation group of furniture, with a shelf unit containing books and periodicals. The arrangement is meant to evoke a private living room, but in fact it more nearly resembles a waiting room, crowded by individuals who do not converse, who have extra time on their hands and loads of glossy magazines to help them pass it.
With this interactive display as its focal point, the rest of the show begins to look like a series of bubbles over people's heads as they leaf through the pages of decorating magazines, fantasizing about what it would be like to live in such-and-such a showplace. And this image of collective solipsism -- of people losing themselves in other people's dream houses -- becomes a useful way to think about architecture today.
If the show were a story, the headline might read, "Housing Starts on the Rise in Ritalin Nation." "The Un-Private House" is a good illustration of what Richard J. DeGrandpre, the author of "Ritalin Nation," calls rapid-fire culture, a civilization hooked on constant sensory stimulation. In addition to the photographs, models and drawings, there are video monitors displaying computer animations. Spacy musical soundtracks twiddle away, their overlapping sonorities competing for attention.
Adjacent to the waiting room is a large round table, seating eight, with a Lazy Susan in the middle. The Lazy Susan holds plastic disks, one for each of the houses in the show. You take a disk, place it on a round spot on the table, and up pops a menu for an interactive tour. Information about the architects, comments by the curator and montages connecting pictures of the houses with highlighted sections of their plans are projected from beneath the table onto its translucent white surface.
All this has been designed to provide more information than is usually found in architecture shows, but the effect is rather the opposite. The works on view become a kind of disturbance, a distraction from the rapid-fire environment in which they are presented. I don't mean this as a criticism. Rather, the presentation reveals the extent to which architecture has accommodated itself to a distracted way of life.
The 26 projects in the show span a broad esthetic spectrum but are clustered around two extremes: Hot and Not. Not houses (Francois de Menil, Hanrahan & Meyers, Steven Holl) descend from the tradition of Arts and Crafts. They emphasize comfort, unpretentiousness and serenity, and often evoke the refined vernacular of the Japanese house. Hot houses (Herzog & de Meuron, Hariri & Hariri, Neil M. Denari, Diller & Scofidio, Rem Koolhaas) are the descendants of Italian Futurism. Startlingly unconventional, they make furious display of new materials, new technologies, new ways of organizing space.
Most of us would probably prefer to live in the Not houses. But what are they doing in this show? It's telling that such a question should arise. Modern audiences, at least, would rather have the sensory stimulation of the Hot than the familiar comforts of the Not.
Delivering shocks of the new has been central to the Modern's mission since its inception. Shows like "The International Style" (1932) and "The New Italian Landscape" (1972) are landmarks in the history of rapid-fire culture. The museum would be failing at its job if it didn't transmit the innovative spirit of the Futurists, the de Stijl group, the Bauhaus, the Constructivists and other nerve centers of the Modern Movement. In 1933, Alfred H. Barr Jr. famously compared the Modern's collection to "a torpedo moving through time."
"Different Roads," a show of recent and prototype cars, isn't strong enough to stand on its own, but as a complement to "The Un-Private House" it is very useful (through Tuesday). It may strike you, for example, that the cars look far more substantial than the houses. This is partly because the houses are represented by models and photographs, while the cars appear as themselves -- in person, so to speak. "Different Roads" also presents at rest objects that are designed to move. As displayed in the Modern's sculpture garden, the cars could pass for metallic pavilions.
Other factors make the cars look uncommonly down-to-earth. Though varied in concept, size and styling, they are all molded around common elements: wheels, doors, windows, seating, engine, instruments, safety features, head and tail lamps, aerodynamics, ergonomics and scale. Americans are primed to see the car as a spiritual home, the house as an extension of the garage. In a society economically rooted in the consumption of gas and in the cars that burn it, the house is a waiting room where people get to rest up between rides. In a twist on "The Un-Private House," "Different Roads" offers a look at the vehicle for injecting the private sphere into public space. The car phone, coffee holder, CD player and seats add up to a living room on wheels. It is the fulfillment of the Futurists' dream.
In the Modern's garden, you see people pressing their noses against the windows. This is partly just to check out the interior, but it is also because the appeal of driving resides mainly in being on the inside looking out: watching the world go by, passing other cars, choosing routes, speeds and music. It is about controlling the world of objective reality from within a subjective frame.
As Mr. DeGrandpre argues, Ritalin's function is to alter consciousness -- to modify subjective space. It brings perception into closer alignment with the objective reality of cultural acceleration. It is a short step, in other words, from the DaimlerChrysler Concept Vehicle to the ingestion of a Ritalin capsule. One capsule is driven, the other is swallowed. But both have the effect of speeding up consciousness so that people can remain in place.
"The Un-Private House" is so full of arresting visual images that the show's social content is easily undervalued. Why these rich people's dwellings? Why isn't the Modern leading the way with prototypes for affordable housing? In fact, this is one of the most socially informed architecture shows the museum has ever presented. It shows that there is a range of possible responses to rapid-fire culture, from Hot to Not. That range, more than any individual work, displays the pivotal role architecture plays in modulating the social, intellectual and psychological forces of contemporary life.
And the implications of this lesson extend far beyond the design of suburban houses. For if you turn the show's theme inside out, you arrive at the Un-Public City. You reach the metropolis in which many of us now dwell -- with its privatized services, its business improvement districts, mall-like festival marketplaces and public-private partnerships in major real estate developments.
But where is the architecture that responds with creative verve to the accelerating urban condition? That is the question to which "The Un-Private House" indirectly leads us. Thus far, what we've seen mostly are Not solutions. Retro theme parks like Battery Park City. Cheap cast-concrete versions of prewar stonework. Bishop's-crook lampposts, fearful interpretations of context, oom-pah-pah celebrations of formerly faded landmarks.
This slow-down mentality only masks the changes overtaking older urban centers. Like a gated suburban community, it keeps the reality of acceleration at bay. Masks can be witty, even profound. Wearing them is a perfectly reasonable option for people in a modern democracy. The problem is that the city isn't offering other options. Where are the office buildings, apartment towers, theaters and airport terminals that explore the changing boundaries between public and private space? Designs that deal with porosity, flexibility and subjectivity in the public realm? These options are seldom seen, or even contemplated. That's one reason modern life keeps getting worse.
