HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Reinventing the Campus of Bedford's Middle School

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: BEDFORD

 BODY:
THE architect of an ongoing construction project at this town's middle school calls it a "reinvention" of an unusual campus, which was originally designed as something of an educational experiment.
"It was really an architectural challenge in that we created new spaces, had to link them all together and, at the same time, keep the integrity of what was there before," said Peter Gisolfi, head of the firm that bears his name in Hastings-on-Hudson, which designed the school's renovation. 
 The $8-million project at the Fox Lane Middle School, which is expected to be completed next month, is one of a large number of construction projects now taking place in school districts throughout the county. But it is probably the most ambitious in that it changes the way the school operates and its approach to learning.
The school, which serves grades 6 to 8, is unusual for a middle school since it's not one building, but rather a minicampus inside a larger campus that also includes the high school. It was originally designed in 1966 by the Architects' Collaborative, a design firm in Cambridge, Mass., based on a pedagogical model developed by educators at Harvard University.
The concept was to build three academic "houses" in separate buildings, plus an octagonal central building. Each house would have students from all three grade levels, with many classes mixing students from each grade in an "integrated learning" approach.
"It worked better in the conception than in the execution, I think," said Mr. Gisolfi, explaining that the academic "houses" were built into the side of a hill. "They designed the buildings as if they were on a flat surface," Mr. Gisolfi said. "The students were forced to walk up hills and down in inclement weather. The school board wanted us to link the buildings and create more space for expanding enrollment. "
His firm's solution was to design covered walkways linking the academic buildings. "They all have glass walls on the interior court with windows on the opposite side," Mr. Gisolfi said. "This provides light and gives students a sense of protection from the outside world. But inside, they can see each other walking from building to building."
To address the space issues, the firm designed a new 12,000-square-foot library and cafeteria building, which now serves as the focal point of the campus. Moving both functions out of the academic buildings served to free up space to add more classrooms and other specialized spaces.
Previously all three houses had their own cafeteria space, which was just an open area right outside the classrooms. "With the old set-up, teachers would be trying conduct classes with kids outside making noise during their lunch break," said Judith Schuldenfrei, the school's principal. "It created a lot of tension. Now kids can have the space to relax and socialize, which is very important."
In addition, said Ms. Schuldenfrei, "children from other houses can now eat together if they have the same lunch period. Previously the houses were restricted and you could only eat with other students in the same house."
The old library is now a music suite, with a band and orchestra room, as well as several practice rooms. There's also a new fine arts center in the octagonal building. "With the reconstruction," Ms. Schuldenfrei said, "we now have whole areas devoted to the arts, which is great considering that the arts are being eliminated from many schools now due to cutbacks."
Joshua Zinder, the project architect who is overseeing the day-to-day construction, likens the project to an Italian hill town. "You know how an Italian town will have a wall around it," Mr. Zinder said. "There's an open piazza or center court. And in the center there's a church or temple. Well, instead of a church, we have a library."
The 6,000-square-foot library, on the second floor of the new building, sits at the top of a hill. With oversized windows and soaring ceilings, it now occupies the highest ground, and is meant to evoke a "temple of learning," Mr. Zinder said.
He added that it was important to work with the original design of the campus, which emphasized the modernist form "allowing structural engineering to shape the architectural form."
"We preserved that theme," he said. "There's an emphasis on exposed building materials, like grilles and pipes."
THE entire project is being funded by an $18 million bond that also includes work on the district's high school and its five elementary schools.
"What we're doing in the other schools is more standard, like adding classrooms and dining rooms," Mr. Zinder said. "The middle school was a very unique project, in that it's an unusual design to start with"
In addition to its work in Bedford, the Gilsofi firm is desgining three other school projects, said Janet Ladd, the firm's director of marketing. They are in Scarsdale, Mamaroneck and Irvington.
There are several other school projects in the works in the county, one of the most extensive in New Rochelle. In that city on Long Island Sound, voters approved a $38.6 million bond referendum last year to pay for rewiring all of its public school buildings and to "enlarge our space, " said Dr. Bruce Watkins, Superintendent of Schools. "Our enrollment is increasing at 3 percent a year -- we're bulging at the seams."
Dr. Watkins said there were several reasons school districts were embarking on such projects now. For one thing, the state has provided an additional 10 percent of aid for those projects approved after July 1, 1998.
"So many districts were waiting for that," he said. "Of the 700-plus school districts in the state, I think you'd find that most are now doing projects. The work, in most cases, is long overdue, the schools infrastructure has gotten tired out, enrollment is up and technology needs are increasing. It's essential for children's education that the districts keep up.
"Add to that the favorable economy, the fact that there's cheap money to borrow now, and with the 10 percent incentive from the state, it's created a unique environment for change, which is what we're seeing now."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY;
In a Tight Market, New Areas Bloom

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WHEN executives of Kenneth Cole Productions, a designer of clothing and footwear, decided to move the company's headquarters from Carnegie Hall Tower at 152 West 57th Street to 601 West 50th, at 11th Avenue, they gave up the ambiance of one of the city's premier retail streets for a neighborhood perhaps best described as Gasoline Alley.
Auto dealerships line both sides of the avenue, sharing the space with bars, diners and a full-block Con Ed electrical substation. The service entrance for Manhattan Chrysler Plymouth Jeep is just a few paces north of the front door of 601 West 50th. 
 But with annual office rents in the area in the range of $20 to $30 a square foot, compared with $60 and above on 57th Street, Mr. Cole stands to save a lot of overhead costs on the 126,000 square feet the company will eventually occupy.
"Price was a factor," said Barry Gosin, chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate of Manhattan, which brokered the deal. "Ken Cole is a guy who fights for every penny. But it is also a trendy location for all his young creative people."
Mr. Cole's decision to move to a neighborhood far from traditional office areas, along with similar moves by advertising agencies, architectural firms and new-media companies to formerly industrial areas, indicates that almost no Manhattan location is off-limits in the current real estate boom.
The shift to nontraditional areas reflects a strong economy in which employment gains have produced a tight market for office space in most areas of Manhattan and have spurred the construction of new buildings, notably in Times Square and the suburbs, particularly the New Jersey waterfront.
The effects of the strong economy go beyond the office segment of the real estate business. Retailers are jockeying for new locations and testing new parts of town on the East and West Sides. Hotel occupancy rates have fallen somewhat from the peak levels of recent years, notably for the most expensive rooms, but analysts say the business remains prosperous.
Indeed, veteran real estate executives say it is hard to see a cloud on the horizon, despite the historic cyclicality of the industry. The number of jobs in the city has been growing steadily, largely spurred by Internet-based companies, and most of the few new buildings that are planned or under construction are already leased.
"The real estate market is as healthy as I have seen it in three decades in the business," said Thomas P. Falus, president of Cushman & Wakefield of New York, the real estate services company.
He said downturns in the real estate business had usually come in reaction to excesses of the past, like the 17 million square feet of office space that came onto the market in Manhattan in the late 1980's and early 1990's. "Right now there is no excess," he said. "There is no overbuilding and no overpaying. Barring some unforeseen external calamity, I don't see any reason why the market will not stay healthy."
Real estate executives said economic pressures were forcing companies to look at previously neglected areas. "In this market," said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, the Manhattan real estate services firm, "traditional patterns are disappearing, the way they did in the late 1980's, when non-garment tenants started moving into the Garment Center. Now, industrial space on the West Side is not only acceptable, but is desirable."
An example of the phenomenon, she said, is the Starrett-Lehigh Building on 26th Street between 11th Avenue and the West Side Highway, where space has quickly become more expensive as high-technology companies replace the industrial tenants of the past. Martha Stewart recently signed a lease for 75,000 square feet in the building for editorial production facilities, including photo studios and workshops and, potentially, an Internet development site. Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia's main Manhattan office is to remain at 11 West 42d Street.
"Less than two years ago, you could have rented space there for $9 a foot," Ms. Tighe said. "Today it's more like $25 a foot, and people are lining up to get into the building."
She said many companies in creative fields are deliberately avoiding traditional office locations in favor of industrial buildings, whose expansive floors are easily adapted to open-plan layouts. "I could do better economic deals in pre-World War II buildings downtown," she said. "But many companies want an Internet environment, where they can quickly form teams to handle projects and solve problems."
Meeting the needs of the creative people who staff Kenneth Cole Productions' product and store display units and its internal advertising agency figured into the decision to move to the far West Side as much as saving money did, said Paul Blum, the company's chief operating officer.
"Everything we do is urban-inspired, so it would not be advisable to leave the city," he said. "We could have made a deal downtown, but that would have put us too far away from the wholesalers who are in the 40's and 50's and like to drop in and see what we are doing."
He said the far West Side is close enough to these customers, and affordable enough to give the company space to spread out. The pool hall on the ground floor will be replaced with a showroom, he added.
The current demand for flexible office space comes at a time when Internet companies, just a small presence a short time ago, are becoming an important force in Manhattan real estate. According to figures compiled by Colliers ABR, the brokerage and real estate services firm, Internet and computer-based companies signed 52 leases totaling 1.3 million square feet from January through the end of July, with 515,000 square feet of that on the West Side.
"Real estate is the second-biggest problem for these companies after raising money," said Paul J. Mas, senior managing director of Colliers ABR. "They need space to add bodies to grow, because if they don't grow, they get left behind. The standard growth rate is to double in size in one year and then double again in two years."
Cushman & Wakefield has reported that the number of jobs in the Internet and new-media fields in New York City is expected to reach 188,000 by next year, an increase of 80 percent since 1997.
With the continuing deregulation of the telecommunications industry, new types of telecommunications companies are bidding for space as well, creating another new category of tenant. According to Colliers, 31 telecommunications companies signed leases for a total of 784,853 square feet in the first seven months of the year. Six of those were in the old Port Authority distribution building at 111 Eighth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets, another industrial building that is becoming home to the trendy and high tech.
The growth of these new businesses, executives say, may provide support for the overall economy of the region and the real estate industry even if traditional business sectors in New York, like financial services, suffer setbacks. "People are starting to believe that this economy is different from the past, that the growth of the Internet and biochemical industries have changed the economic situation," said Benjamin V. Lambert, chairman of Eastdil Realty, a Manhattan real estate investment company.
He said capital markets have largely returned to normal after the turmoil of last year, when international events caused some forms of financing, like commercial mortgage-backed securities, to freeze. "There is a sufficient supply of capital available, but the providers of capital were sufficiently daunted last year that underwriting standards have risen," Mr. Lambert said. This means that developers need to find more equity to complete transactions.
In addition, the price of money is slightly higher this year than last because the Federal Reserve has increased interest rates, Mr. Lambert said.
Because of last year's credit market turmoil, putting deals together is more complicated, said Howard L. Michaels, chairman of the Carlton Group of of New York. "Before that, you could make one phone call and get 90 to 95 percent financing," he said. "Now you need to put two or three lenders together to complete a transaction."
For these reasons, the pace of property sales dropped well below the torrid rate of early 1998. Cushman & Wakefield reported that 16 major Manhattan properties with a total of 13 million square feet of space were sold for $2.1 billion in the first half of this year.
One of the most significant was Chase Manhattan Bank's sale of One New York Plaza to TrizecHahn for $390 million. The 2.1 million- square-foot building was thus valued at $185.38 per square foot.
More recently, the closely held W & M Properties sold the building at 1185 Avenue of the Americas to a group led by Goldman Sachs & Company for $195 million. The 1.1 million-square-foot building, on the southwest corner of West 47th Street, was valued at $177.27 a square foot.
The August vacancy rate in midtown office buildings was 7.1 percent, according to Colliers ABR, and it is expected to stay at about that level as the delivery of new buildings, like the 1.4 million-square-foot Conde Nast headquarters in Times Square, makes space available elsewhere. The average asking rent in midtown reached $42.74 a square foot in August, Colliers reported, an increase of 12 percent over the year-earlier level.
While the averages have come up, some individual deals have come up far more. Colliers reported that leases were signed at $80 a square foot at 9 West 57th and at 767 Fifth Avenue, the General Motors Building.
The midyear vacancy rate in midtown south was similar to midtown's, 7.2 percent, but asking rents were sharply lower, an average of $27.61 a square foot, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Although the average asking rent has increased 28.1 percent from year to year, midtown south remains the most affordable office market in the city.
The vacancy rate for Class A space in the downtown area has dropped to 4 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the lowest in 18 years. The overall vacancy rate downtown remained steady at 8.4 percent as the pace of leasing slowed. But following the pattern of the rest of Manhattan, the average rent rose to $32.31 a square foot from $28.14 a year earlier.
Downtown is handicapped by transportation problems and by the perception that it is remote from midtown, Mr. Falus said. "Downtown does not seem to attract a meaningful migration from midtown," he said. "People would rather go east or west than south. Somebody commuting in from Greenwich can get to Seventh Avenue in the 40's more easily."
Steadily rising rents and a diminishing amount of available space is good news for property owners. But the flip side for tenants is steadily rising costs and a lack of leverage in negotiations.
James Meiskin, president of Plymouth Partners, a tenant representative, said some landlords were playing prospective tenants off each other. "In the past, when you requested a lease, the space was taken off the market," he said. "Now they are not taking it off the market, and if a better deal comes along, they'll take it."
But Mitchell Steir, an executive vice president of Julien J. Studley, another tenant representative, said tenants and their brokers can employ strategies to probe for opportunities. For example, he said, savvy brokers can find out which space will be vacated over the next few years and use the information to their clients' advantage. "As you view the data, it is not technically available," he said of such space. But landlords likely to lose tenants soon may be willing to make deals now to prevent vacancies.
"There is usually more there than immediately meets the eye," he said.
 
The Suburbs Waterfront Space Is Much in Demand
Commercial tenants are bidding for space along the New Jersey waterfront as fast as construction projects are announced, said Seena Stein, president of Newmark of New Jersey. "I've never seen anything like it in 20 years," she said. "There is an unending flow of people coming from New York and some of them are bidding money over the asking price to get space."
Among the tenants that have signed deals for waterfront space are American Express, PaineWebber, Lord Abbett and U. S. Trust.
The Lefrak Organization, Hartz Mountain Industries, Mack-Cali Realty Corporation and SJP Properties are developing office properties along the waterfront.
The vacancy rate in the waterfront market was reported at 4.75 percent early this year by CB Richard Ellis, a real estate services company, which also said the average asking rent increased to $26.23 per square foot in early 1999 from $22.28 at the end of 1997. Statewide, the vacancy rate held steady at 9.7 percent while the average asking rent topped $21 a square foot for the first time since the 1980's.
Speculative office construction is resuming on Long Island, with Mitchell Rechler, executive vice president of Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville, reporting that his firm is planning a 550,000-square-foot project in Melville. The two 275,000-square-foot buildings are to be constructed next to the Long Island Expressway and are scheduled to be occupied in September 2000.
Mr. Rechler said several smaller projects by other companies, totaling several hundred thousand square feet of space, were also under way. He said most of the space available on the Long Island market was divided into small units and big blocks were unavailable.
CB Richard Ellis reported that the overall vacancy rate for Nassau and Suffolk Counties was 7 percent at the end of the first quarter and that company expansion was creating a need for additional office space. Average asking rents in the two counties reached $22.15 per square foot.
In Westchester County, most buildings are being constructed for specific customers, rather than on speculation. The same is true for Fairfield County in Connecticut. Westchester's vacancy rate was 18.7 percent at the end of the first quarter, according to CB Richard Ellis, while Fairfield's was 7.8 percent. The average asking rent in Westchester was $20.94 a square foot, while the average rent in Fairfield was $25.42 a square foot. Both represent a moderate increase over the year-ago rate.
 
Retail: More Interest Off the Beaten Track
As with office tenants, rising rents are forcing retailers to seek out locations on side streets they once would have avoided and consider parts of the city away from more traditional retail areas.
"People no longer feel they absolutely have to be on the main avenues," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services, a Manhattan retail brokerage. "We are seeing a lot of activity on side streets now. A lot of secondary spaces that used to stand empty are renting now."
Richard A. Seligman, president of Retail Development Partners of New York, said, "You are hearing a lot of talk about Nolita and NoHo these days," referring to the areas north of Little Italy and north of Houston Street. "They are going there because they don't want to pay $200 a square foot in SoHo."
He said asking rents in prime locations along avenues in SoHo had increased to $175 to $225 a square foot a year from $35 during this decade. "That's where Madison Avenue was seven or eight years ago," he said.
Madison Avenue in the 50's and 60's has, of course, changed as well. Top locations now command $400 to $450 a square foot, Mr. Seligman said.
This is pushing retailers to the outskirts of Manhattan. On the East Side, after decades of delay, parts of the Bridgemarket complex are due to open next month in the vaults under the Queensboro Bridge. The development is to include two restaurants operated by Sir Terence Conran, a Conran home furnishings store and a market-style Food Emporium.
On the West Side, Jeffrey, a clothing store, recently opened in a former warehouse on 14th Street close to the West Side Highway. Brokers say the proprietor, Jeffrey Kalinsky, might be able to be a little aggressive on his pricing because he is paying only $23 to $26 a square foot in rent, compared with the vastly higher rents in more established retail locations.
Big-box retailers, which stock a large variety of a few categories of merchandise, may find opportunities in the old industrial buildings of the West Side as well, said Robert K. Futterman, president of a Manhattan brokerage bearing his name. "Ikea, Home Depot and Costco have been hovering over New York for years," he said. Likely locations, he said, are along 10th and 11th Avenues in the 20's to the 50's.
 
Hotels: 7,500 More Rooms Expected by 2002
Occupancy rates have fallen from last year's record levels and room rates are not increasing as quickly as they were during the last few years, but travelers are still flocking to the city and many new rooms are being built to accommodate them, industry analysts report.
"Occupancy in the first six months was down, although it increased in July," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president with PKF Consulting, a lodging specialist in New York. "New York is clearly past the peak of this cyclical business, but a 79 percent occupancy is not bad."
Mr. Fox noted that four hotels with more than 2,000 rooms are under construction in the city. Three of them, the Sofitel on 44th Street, Planet Hollywood on 47th Street and the Doubletree on 41st Street, are in Times Square. "Between 1999 and 2002, an estimated 7,500 hotel rooms will be added in New York in addition to the 55,000 that exist now," he said.
Much of the weakness in hotel economics is concentrated in the upper end of the market, with travelers evidently balking at paying rates that have shot up quickly, observed Sean Hennessey, director of the hospitality and leisure practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. "The tourist class has held up well, but the deluxe and luxury segments are relatively weaker," he said.
The average daily rate for top-of-the-line deluxe has climbed to $485.86 a night from $355.45 a year ago, while the occupancy rate has fallen to 62.3 percent from 70.6 percent.
In the same period, the average price of a room in tourist hotels has risen at a significantly slower rate, to $119.10 a night from $110.07. Occupancy has slipped, but only a little, to 81.6 percent from 84.3 percent.

HEADLINE: The Airport Oh So Close to Home

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: HARRISON

 BODY:
LIKE many other residents here, Sam Fanelli Jr. has a love-hate relationship with Westchester County Airport. When planes soar over his home, Mr. Fanelli curses. But when he goes on vacation with his wife, Elizabeth, he always flies out of Westchester, even though that often means changing planes in Washington.
With a proposal to update the master plan of development for the airport now before the Board of Legislators, expressions of those kinds of mixed feelings are likely to become louder. 
 "I use this airport as much as I can," Mr. Fanelli said after he and Mrs. Fanelli returned from a vacation a week ago. He said he would rather travel from the clean, quiet and uncrowded terminal here than from one of the New York metropolitan region's more congested airports.
But talk to Mr. Fanelli about additional flights, bigger planes or any other expansion plans, and he answers: "No, leave what we have as it is! The airport is already too big, much bigger than I ever wanted."
In many ways his sentiments reflect the Board of Legislators' views. But business interests, while not clamoring for a major expansion, would at least like more parking and more hangars for company planes at the 700-acre airport.
The airport did grow just four years ago when a $21 million, 41,000-square-foot brick terminal was built to replace a rustic Quonset hut that served for decades as the passenger terminal. .
Now Democrats and Republicans are banding together, supporting a policy of no more growth.
Last year County Executive Andrew J. Spano rescinded a plan by his predecessor, Andrew P. O'Rourke, to build a 900-square-foot lounge for business travelers. Calling the project a "stealth expansion," Mr. Spano said the $413,000 executive lounge was not needed. Mindful of the impact of noise on residents, he has espoused a "good neighbor policy" when it comes to the airport.
Other environmental concerns are also an issue. Legislator Paul J. Noto, a Republican representing sections of this town, said that if the county were to build an airport today, it would never locate it so close to the Kensico Reservoir and the Rye Lake Watershed.
"We need to step up groundwater monitoring, limit commercial flights, maintain a voluntary curfew at night on flights and in every way consider the impact on the neighborhood," he said.
Not everyone, however, is in agreement that no growth is the preferred option. Some of those who favor at least some expansion, like Harold E. Vogt, the chief executive officer of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, have accused politicians of being motivated by panic.
"A lot of it is hysteria," Mr. Vogt said. "It's out of proportion to reality."
Mr. Vogt said that fears of chemical contamination from increased airport use have been overstated. Of particular concern is the impact of runoff like de-icing fluid on Kensico Reservoir, which supplies the county with 85 percent of its drinking water and also provides a majority of New York City's water. "There are ways to control chemical use, ways to collect runoff," he said.
Georgia G. Kalayjian-Murphy, the president and chief operating officer of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, said reason had not always ruled when it comes to the airport.
"It's a very sensitive and touchy subject in a county that prides itself on being suburban," she said. "From my point of view, it's a real balancing act between the tourists' needs, for example, and maintaining the quality of life, which is one of the main reasons the tourists come here in the first place."
The County Executive echoed that point of view, observing that many businesses come to Westchester because of the quality of life. Economic development, he has said, is tied to maintaining that quality and not allowing the county to become just another crowded metropolitan outpost.
But the answer to the question of whether Westchester is attracting or repelling new business depends largely on whom one asks.
Edward Doyle Sr., the head of the 35,000-member Westchester-Putnam Building and Construction Trades, an umbrella group for 17 construction unions, said that the county was in effect "chasing business out of here" by its no-growth policy at the airport.
Mr. Doyle used as an example a controversy last year during which the county and environmental groups eventually thwarted General Electric's efforts to build a hangar for some of its planes.
Mr. Doyle predicted that General Electric would end up going someplace else, like Stewart Airport in Newburgh.
General Electric currently has a lease with Westchester Airport and a spokesman would not not comment on future plans. "And eventually that kind of thing is going to have a domino effect," he said. "Other corporations, too, will leave."
The commercial airlines at the Westchester airport include U.S. Airways, Delta, Northwest, American and Continental Airlines. Affiliated airlines are Comair, Comutair and Business Express.
Corporations with a total of 104 private aircraft at the airport are International Business Machines, Pepsico, Philip Morris, Seagrams and Xerox.
"Everything at this airport is a hassle because the politicians are deathly afraid of losing votes," Mr. Doyle said. "Their jobs are on the line."
Earlier this year, Mr. Noto, who is also the Board of Legislators' minority leader, mounted the campaign to have the master plan updated, observing that the last revision came in 1986. "A lot of things have happened in the 13 years since the master plan was completed," he said. "We have a much more sophisticated understanding of the environment and its fragile points. We've also had large-scale residential and commercial shifts near the airport. The only thing we haven't had was an up-to-date planning document that integrates all these factors."
If the County Board approves the expenditure, $500,000 would be allocated to hire consultants and to gather information to revise the master plan.
Of that money, $400,000 would come from the Federal Aviation Administration and another $50,000 from the state's Department of Transportation. And the other $50,000 comes from the county.
Mr. Noto said that a vote on proceeding with a master plan will take place within a few weeks. Then work on the plan would follow, possibly requiring a year to complete.
Built in 1942, the airport was intended as an Army Air Corps base to be used to protect New York City in World War II. In 1947 the airport, called Rye Lake Airport, and surrounding property were handed over to the county for commercial and civil aviation use and renamed Westchester County Airport. The armed services still maintained a presence at the airport with a small Air National Guard contingent occupying its northeast corner.
In 1981, because of noise concerns and the addition of larger aircraft, the Air National Guard moved from Westchester to Stewart Airport.
Westchester County Airport is the New York metropolitan area's busiest suburban airport with about 85 scheduled arrivals and departures daily and 1.08 million passengers in 1997. By comparison, MacArthur Airport in Islip on Long Island has an average of 57 flights a day and handled 1.04 million passengers in 1997. Stewart International Airport which has 73 flights a day on average, served 843,000 passengers in 1997.
By contrast, the area's three large airports each handle about 27 million passengers a year, said Jeffrey Zupan, a senior fellow in transportation for the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit planning, research and civic organization in Manhattan.
When it comes to cargo traffic, Newark and Kennedy International -- not La Guardia, which is limited by its size -- handle the bulk, Mr. Zupan said.
Figures from the county's Department of Transportation show that Westchester Airport operations have actually decreased since 1985. For example, there were 245,140 flights out of the airport in 1985 compared with 196,426 in 1997. Wasi Talib, a spokeswoman for the department, said the decreased numbers reflected larger planes that were able to carry more passengers.
Mr. Zupan said that Stewart, Westchester and MacArthur Airports serve "basically in reliever roles" to the major airports and were unlikely to grow much more, although Stewart has "a tremendous potential as a cargo airport" because of its large area and proximity to both the New England Thruway and Interstate 84.
Westchester handles no cargo. Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for the County Executive, said that, among other things, the voluntary curfew on flights between 11:30 P.M. and 6:30 A.M. precluded cargo handling, which is mostly done at night.
While Mr. Noto predicted that the Board of Legislators would draw up a master plan that restricts new growth at the airport -- "Both parties and the County Executive are in agreement on this," he said -- other people are not so sure.
Ross J. Pepe, the president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and Hudson Valley, a professional and trade group representing 500 businesses, said he would press for a middle ground. "It will never become a major jetport," he said. "But this hysteria should not govern. Our view is that the airport should at least accommodate the level of business that exists in the county and not be restrictive."
And Joseph Tosto, the owner of Travel Network in Yorktown, said: "Maybe just a little bigger would be good, at least for those who don't want to travel to Queens or Long Island or Newark. Even a little expansion could go a long way."

LENGTH: 3139 words

HEADLINE: As an Industry Matures, East End Vineyards Yield a Burst of Growth

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
PRACTICED in professional optimism, the East End's winemakers are forecasting a good vintage: the earlier drought, which hurt many crops, benefited grapes, reducing crop loads and the volume of wine but intensifying flavors.
But at this moment, the greenbacks seem just as plentiful and ready for picking as the early-ripening red and white grapes now being gathered from the vineyards. Investment, growth and diversification are the main reasons why Patrick Wiles, an officer at First Pioneer Farm Credit's office in Riverhead, said that in 1999 the Long Island wine industry has experienced a "watershed year." 
 The 26-year-old industry's value seems to be multiplying as a result of a burst of estate sales, increased purchases of farmland for planting and wineries, rising production of wine, expanded tasting-room and off-premises sales and a swelling volume of day-tripping consumers.
Since January the sales of three estates -- Corey Creek for $1.5 million and Laurel Lake and Peconic Bay for $2 million each -- plus possibly pricier sales ahead for Bidwell and Hargrave have focused the wine world's attention on Suffolk County's investment potential.
"If you look at the common denominator of the purchasers, you see that they have deep pockets," said Charles Massoud, a proprietor of Paumanok and president of the Long Island Wine Council, an organization of owners. "It's very good news. People used to come out with wish lists, and now they come out with to-do lists. The banks want to lend money and are after us."
Because of the proximity and gaze of New York City, the world's most diverse wine market, the well-publicized North Fork, home to 21 of the Island's 25 producers, has become the most conspicuous Eastern wine destination, outdistancing larger competitors: the Finger Lakes upstate and Virginia.
This would not have surprised Henry Hudson, the first European to discover the Island, a 17th-century Arcadia of forests, fruit trees and wild grapevines husbanded by the longest, warmest growing season in the Northeast.
Today, first-time wine travelers discover an agricultural North Fork, under development pressures, that is striving to remain a sliver of semirural Iowa, with farm stands, iconic potato barns (some gussied up into wineries), plush-green and sod-busted fields, church suppers, Colonial headstones, whitewashed Tom Sawyer picket fences and Wagnerian sunsets.
The North Fork is less a wine region than a wine neighborhood, with its clustered producers only a few minutes' drive apart along two roads, Routes 25 and 48. Locals prefer it that way. "The challenge for us," said Mr. Massoud of Paumanok, "is how do we raise the sophistication of the North Fork without changing its character?"
Mr. Wiles, whose cooperative specializes in agricultural loans, said the East End wine industry had matured. "It has perhaps $25 million a year in income from sales and services such as vineyard management," he said. "I'd guess that 10 years ago the number would be half of that."
"Today, most of the people are versed in business," he said. "Most were dreamers 12 years ago; it looked like a novelty investment then, with a lot of tax-shelter interest. Today there is a tremendous amount of reinvestment."
 
Adding Even More Acres Or Starting With a Few
The prime example is Dr. Herodotus Damianos of Pindar Vineyards, Long Island's biggest wine estate. This summer, he spent almost $5 million to buy 267 acres of farmland in Southold to plant grapes, increasing his holdings by two-thirds.
The industry is also being remodeled by new enterprises like the $6.1 million Raphael winery, which is under construction; by heavily bankrolled vineyards like the newcomer Martha Clara Vineyards, owned by the former baker Robert Entenmann; the even newer operation being launched by the Florida-based entrepreneur Leslie Alexander, and by surprising gambles like an 11-acre pinot noir planting by Russell McCall, an Atlanta-based fine-wine merchant.
Dr. Damianos, who in addition to Pindar also owns the large-scale Duck Walk on the South Fork, seems undaunted by the wine business's famously low return on investment, often less than 10 percent in a particularly risk-riddled economic sphere. Acquisitions since Jan. 1, 1998, have elevated his holdings to 667 acres, 425 of them under vines. The No. 2 landowner, Macari, does not come close: 360 acres, 150 planted.
With 19 grape varieties planted and 17 kinds of wine for all wallets made last year, Pindar produced 63,000 cases, hopes for 70,000 this year and projects a down-the-road ceiling of 150,000.
But small-scale producers might proliferate, too, if a project being developed by Russell Hearn is successful. He and two investors are planning the Island's first full-time custom-production winery. Called the Premium Wine Group and based in Mattituck, it would make wine for label owners who raise or buy grapes but have no wineries. (Mr. Hearn, as a consultant, will remain Pellegrini's winemaker.)
Mr. Hearn hopes for customers like Bruce and Christiane Schneider, owners of Schneider Vineyards, whose chardonnay, cabernet franc and merlot wines have received favorable reviews. The young couple are what the French call negociants: They buy grapes and hire others, Bedell and Palmer, to make the wine. (In one of its initial investments, the new, profit-oriented venture fund of Columbia University's Business School is putting $250,000 in the Schneiders' business plan: the acquisition of possibly 20 acres this year and planting of 7 next spring.)
"I am Hearn's first customer," said Dr. Charles Sherwood Smithen, a clinical cardiologist in Manhattan who bought a 40-acre farm in Mattituck in the mid-1990's and, beginning in 1996, planted chardonnay and merlot. Pellegrini, among others, has bought his grapes.
"Our thought was to be an artisanal boutique vineyard," Dr. Smithen said. "For the time being we will not build a winery. Russell will make our first wine, this year, at Paumanok: 600 cases of chardonnay." The label will be Sherwood House Vineyards.
The conventional wisdom that chardonnay will remain the Island's white-wine calling card suddenly seems challenged. Four producers -- Martha Clara, Macari, Pindar and Bedell -- have recently issued promising viogniers. And while merlot is the signature red wine, stand-alone bottlings of cabernet franc suggest that this Loire grape, managed properly, can rival merlot in prettiness and outdo it in depth.
Consumer curiosity and excitement that in 1998 focused on the opening of the ranch-size, spare-no-expense Francophile Macari Vineyards has swiveled to its neighbor, Martha Clara, which is based on parcels that form Mr. Entenmann's 175-acre Big E Farm (with 112 acres under vines) in Mattituck and Riverhead.
Mr. Entenmann hopes to break ground for a $4 million, 25,000-square-foot tasting room in Mattituck next spring, to be followed by a $2 million or $3 million winery with a 20,000- or 25,000-case capacity. His first release, the '98 viognier, is scheduled for October.
The 250 cases were made by Roman Roth at the very European Wolffer Estate/Sagpond Vineyard in Sagaponack, on the South Fork, where he is the general manager. Mr. Entenmann hopes to produce 3,000 cases of various wines from the '99 vintage there.
His vineyard crew has planted 12 grape varieties, he said: In addition to viognier, such whites as chardonnay, sauvignon blanc, semillon, riesling and gewurztraminer, and such reds as merlot, cabernet franc, cabernet sauvignon, syrah, petit verdot and malbec.
Mr. Entenmann said that one reason he shifted from raising and training thoroughbred horses to wine was to put his daughter Jacqueline, who is to be married next month, "into a family-type business -- that's the way I grew up."
"There is romance to the wine business," he said. "There is no money. The distributors make it all. I think we can begin to make money in 8 or 10 years."
All the East End wineries are privately held and reluctant to discuss their profit pictures.
But clearly it's not all big budgets. Stephen Dzugas-Smith has a day job as a maintenance man at a nursing home; his wife, Donna, is the manager of Dzugas Vineyards, perhaps the Island's least-known wine.
Their 28 acres, financed by a settlement stemming from injuries she suffered in a fall, hold 5 of chardonnay and 5 of merlot, with 16 leased to an organic farmer. Bedell produces and bottles their chardonnay and buys grapes from them. Their '95 chardonnay is sold at the tiny winery Ternhaven Cellars in Greenport and a few local stores. The three subsequent vintages, at 400 cases each, await release, and a goal of 1,000 cases a year has been set.
They are spending $200,000 to build a tasting room on their Southold tract, with hopes of eventually adding a winery that will better support them and their three youngsters.
"We're a farm family, not rich or anything," Mrs. Dzugas-Smith said. "Living in the country is the best of all possible worlds. We're doing it on a shoestring."
 
A Big Spender Wants A Winery Close to Home
 High-rolling investors like Mr. Alexander, the owner of the National Basketball Association's Houston Rockets, can finance broader horizons. This summer, Mr. Alexander, who lives in Boca Raton, Fla., bought two farms totaling 86 acres, in Cutchogue and Mattituck, for a reported $1,481,500, and said he expected to close soon on a third, 68-acre farm in Mattituck.
With no commercial background in wine -- "I buy it and drink it," he said -- he plans to start planting vines next spring, to erect a winery and "to make great wine." What is the motivation? "I am building a home in Southampton," he said in a telephone interview. "I wanted a winery close to where I live, for the enjoyment of it."
Russell McCall, drawing on 30 years' experience in the wine business, is taking a different risk. Last year, he spent about $750,000 for 52 acres opposite Pellegrini, on Route 25 in Cutchogue, and has planted 11 acres of pinot noir, Burgundy's red grape, along with 10 of merlot.
Even in Burgundy, the pinot noir grape is notoriously mercurial, and the Georgia-based Mr. McCall appreciates the odds. A member of a fourth-generation Cutchogue family, he owns Atlanta Wholesale Wine, which imports and distributes premium wines. In Cutchogue, he said, "We are experimenting with four clones of pinot noir that were most successful in California and Oregon."
Finding land is getting harder, said David J. Saland, a Jamesport real estate broker. "Eighty percent of all farmland has been snapped up," he said. "A year or two ago, we had 40 to 50 farms available, and now we have 5." Flat farmland can start at $18,000 an acre and with houses and barns rise to $30,000, he said.
Alex and Louisa Hargrave, whose grapevine plantings in potato fields in 1973 also planted the seeds of the modern industry, decline to comment on negotiations for their 84 acres (20 owned and under vines), which have been for sale since early in 1998. The original asking price was $3.3 million, and the couple is said to be now asking more than $4 million.
Ever since Jess Jackson, the empire-building owner of Kendall-Jackson, visited Palmer last year and overnight wooed its winemaker, Dan Kleck, to Southern California, nonstop rumors of Jackson sightings, or interest, or negotiations, or land acquisition, have drip-irrigated North Fork speculation.
"Jess has looked at vineyards in New York," James Caudill, a Kendall-Jackson spokesman in Santa Rosa, Calif., confirmed. "But just that: looked. We haven't purchased something. The wines continue to get more notice. Anytime that happens anywhere, we are interested."
The rumors can be read as a collective wish for blue-chip investors like a Jackson, or a renowned French chateau owner, whose prestige might help upgrade the East End industry's image, as the Burgundian producer Robert Drouhin did when he founded an estate in Oregon in 1988.
The influential consultant's role being played by Paul Pontallier, the managing director of Chateau Margaux in Bordeaux, during the development of Raphael, an all-merlot winery scheduled to open next summer, serves that apparent desire.
So does a Chilean consortium's $2 million acquisition of Laurel Lake in July, the first foreign money significantly invested in any New York State wine property. Cesar Baeza, a principal and Hudson Valley vintner who now manages Laurel Lake, said its wines would be marketed worldwide.
 
Local Wine Criticized On Price and Quality
Not everything is coming up roses, however, especially on the price-vs.-value front. A commonly heard notion on- and off-Island is that the wines are second-rank. More than once, Thomas Matthews, who has just been named executive editor of Wine Spectator, has written that they are uneven. For two decades, the outspoken Michael Cinque, owner of Amagansett Wine and Spirits, a carriage-trade store, has heard complaints that local wines are too expensive.
"Somebody comes in with $20 to spend, I don't think Long Island wines," Mr. Cinque said. "I think Spain or Italy or South America.Long Island wines are darn good wines, but maybe they are not the best value for the money." Nonetheless, he said: "I carry 15 to 18 wineries. I sell 1,000 cases of Long Island wine a year."
"They are all new wineries, first-generation," Mr. Cinque said, explaining local prices. "Most wineries in Italy and France have been paid for generations ago. They don't have heavy mortgages and big start-up expenses. And on the East End, everything is expensive."
He also argued that producers say, "If I don't charge high prices, they don't take me seriously," and that "everybody prices wines against his neighbor or the rest of the industry. 'My neighbor charges $25, and my wine is better, so I'll charge $27.' "
Chardonnays may range from $7 to $25, merlots from $13 to $30; Pindar's '95 Mythology, a red blend, costs $37.
As for long-term cellaring, "No wine geeks I know lay in Long Island wines," Mr. Cinque said.
But short-term drinking hands Lenz a promotional strategy.
Since 1976, when in a now-legendary blind tasting in Paris upstart California wines outscored ancien-regime Bordeaux, shocking the wine world, similar contests have become a favorite tactic of American wineries. Call the strategy glitz by association.
For example, Peter Carroll, a Lenz owner, in April sponsored a competition at the American Hotel in Sag Harbor in which the 10 judges were told only that Lenz sparkling, white and red wines were pitted against unidentified French wines in the same categories.
Rigorous wine professionals hold that anything less than a blind tasting can influence a contest outcome. A judge in the Sag Harbor semi-blind tasting might have no trouble guessing which is the Lenz, but might score it generously to avoid wounding his host. That may explain why Lenz's '95 merlot, which costs $40, received an average 92 points while the '95 Chateau Petrus, which costs $950, was awarded 93 points.
"The scores are very close, and one can argue that they are essentially equal," Mr. Carroll wrote. "But an interesting way to reflect on the one-point difference is to ask whether it is worth paying $910 for the extra point!"
The answer, as expressed by wine auctions, seems to be yes. Unlike the great French chateaux, New York State wines are not perceived as time-proven long-term commodities.
"A young Lenz pitted against a young Latour would show better," Mr. Cinque said. "But in 10 years, the Lenz cabernet will be dead, and the Latour will just begin to show."
Or to view the glass as half full, Lenz reds can be good buys today if drunk within a year or two.
Islandwide, although new wine is bubbling in tanks, vats and barrels, the fermentation is not confined to the cellars:
Bedell expects to double the size of its tasting room and expand its barrel cellar this winter. Channing Daughters is experimenting with such early-ripening grapes as dolcetto and pinot grigio, rarities for the East End. Corey Creek's new owner, Michael Lynne, said he was contemplating further investment in the North Fork but declined to give details.
Duck Walk hopes to makes 25,000 cases this year, 2,000 more than last year; it has 68 acres under vines and hopes to have 85 by the end of next year. Gristina has bought 34 adjacent acres to bring its total to 87.
Jamesport is cultivating native yeasts in the winery and vineyard in order to produce wines, especially chardonnay and sauvignon blanc, with enhanced "natural character." Laurel Lake's Chilean owners bought 23 acres, 13 of them planted; it hopes to buy more and to have 38 acres under vines by the end of 2000.
Macari expects to release its first nonvintage sparkling wine soon. Just in time for the harvest, Osprey's Dominion hired a new winemaker, Peter Silverberg, who has spent the last six years as an assistant winemaker at the Golan Heights Winery, for 15 years Israel's top-ranked estate.
Palmer replanted eight acres, added new stainless-steel tanks for its red wines and purchased a new $45,500 press for the current vintage. Last year it made 16,500 cases, and this year hopes for 20,000, en route to an eventual 30,000.
Peconic Bay is converting a storage barn into a 300-barrel fermentation and aging room. "We have initiated more wine-related events for the tourists" and "increased our staffing," it said.
Pellegrini wines are actively distributed in six states, but this month became the first New York State wine marketed in 18 more states and Washington, D.C., through Virtual Vineyards, an Internet company with legal shipping arrangements.
Pugliese is going to double the size of its winery, enlarge the tasting room and build a sparkling-wine cellar.
Except for Italian great-grandfathers with grape presses in their garages, Kurt Eckert, the wine director of Jean-Georges Vongerichten's four Manhattan restaurants, may be the Island's micro Oscar winner. Last year for his "one-barrel project" he bought "one row plus a bit of another" of chardonnay -- "just over 1,000 pounds" -- from the oldest section of Wolffer/Sagpond vines, planted in 1988.
Working with Mr. Roth, the winemaker, he fermented it in a one-year-old French wood barrel to hold down the seasoning -- "I didn't want to plaster over the flavors" with new-oak intensity, he said -- and bottled it in July. Some of the 295 bottles, carrying a Cru Cellars label, will be sold at Jean-Georges for $70 to $75.
If he sold them all, he would clear $14,100. But he is not in it for the money, and plans to use some bottles for promotion.
Still, Mr. Eckert may be gripped by the Mondavi effect. This year, working with the winemaker Larry Perrine at Channing Daughters, he hopes to branch out into cabernet sauvignon.

HEADLINE: Q & A/Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr.;
A Doctor at Yale Spends a Lifetime Fighting Cancer

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
THE director of the Yale Cancer Center, Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr., is responsible for a large staff of cancer researchers and he spends hours raising money to fund their mission. He said he carefully uses data about cancer to stimulate giving to the center. Dr. DeVita once directed the National Cancer Institute where he found, "the policy was to lump all the incidence and mortality data together and show them both going up. Then when they went to Congress they would say there was an epidemic of cancer, give us more money."
He changed that policy to illustrate good news and bad news. He wanted to show that support was bringing down the incidence of certain types of cancers and asked for more money to battle other forms of cancer. Dr. DeVita, who is known as the discoverer of a cure for lymphoma, has turned his attention to researching drug resistance that requires a strong basic research foundation, huge amounts of money and many researchers. Of his staff of 320, about 120 are engaged in research. 
 Recently, Dr. DeVita discussed cancer and the urgent need for resources to fight it. Following are some excerpts from that conversation:
Q. What's the most common kind of cancer?
A. In the U.S., lung cancer is the most common form in both sexes. gastrointestinal and colorectal cancer are also common for men and women, breast cancer for women and prostate cancer for men. In men, prostate cancer is high especially now that we have screening with the PSA test.
We should look back at the turn of the century as we now get ready to turn another century. If we look at the rise in incidence of cancer the major external factor that caused the rise in the incidence of cancer is the use of tobacco. The incidence of lung cancer and death from lung cancer was very low at the start of the century. Starting in the '20's it began to rise. As cigarette smoking has fallen off, we have seen, and death from lung cancer was very low at the start of the century. Starting in the '20's it began to rise. As cigarette smoking has fallen off, we have seen, 10 years later, the decline of cancer.
In the world population, the commonest form of cancer is stomach and the second-most common is liver.
Q. Are breast cancer rates increasing?
A. Breast cancer rates are relatively flat. From 1980-90, the most recent data, there was an epidemic in breast cancer, but it was not an epidemic it was increased screening. We were picking up cases of breast cancer in earlier stages. Now the mortality for breast cancer is beginning to come down.
It occurs in one out of 11 women if you stop measuring at the age of 70. If you measure up to the age of to age 85 then it becomes one out of eight. It depends on how you want to use statistics. People use statistics for their own purposes.
Q. Can some types of food actually cause cancer?
A. We often fail to actually scale this. If we were to use a thermometer, saccharine would be very low and tobacco use would be through the roof. Nothing in this country carries a higher risk of causing a cancer than tobacco. If people stopped all smoking in 10 years mortality from cancer would drop 40 percent.
About a third of cancers are thought to be related to diet but the association between diet and cancer is often weak and controversial. There is no question that studies show that in women who migrate from Japan to Hawaii the incidence of breast cancer goes up. If they migrate from Hawaii to California the incidence goes up higher. When Italian women who have a relatively low incidence of breast cancer compared to us, migrate to Australia where a lot of Italians do migrate, the incidence of breast cancer goes way up. Australians eat a lot of fatty meat. Italians have a healthy Mediterranean diet.
The data looks like it's probably fat content of the diet. Can you actually reduce the incidence of cancer by reducing fat in diet? There is no real evidence that can happen.
Q. What about chemical causes of cancer?
A. We used to say in Washington that if you take all the chemicals in the environment, for example, nitrates, pesticides, PCBs, industrial chemicals and so forth, those chemicals caused 7 1/2 percent of all cancers. It has been revised downward to 5 percent.
The published perception is just the opposite. Remember Love Canal? News stories used to say "chemicals in Love Canal cause cancer and other diseases." The fact is there was no increase in cancer rates among the residents. There were increased numbers of neurological diseases. The chemicals did damage people. They didn't cause cancer.
Chemicals are not the dominate cause of cancer in this country. Radiation in the environment is actually a bigger risk.
Q. Are there other known causes of cancer?
A. The sleeper is virus. This is a tricky thing. We don't want people to think they can catch cancer. I think in the end we will find that up to a third of all cancers are viral related.
This is where genetic background comes in. Probably for the majority of viruses there is a genetic predisposition to cancer and viruses are just a cofactor in causing cancer.
The hepatitis B virus is probably the major cause of liver cancer. Hepatitis doesn't itself cause cancer, it creates the environment, the damaged liver, so that eventually cancer develops. Liver cancer is the second-commonest cancer in the world. We don't see much in this country.
Vaccines are reemerging as a new tool. They are often being used therapeutically. A person who has cancer gets the vaccine and it makes the disease go away.
Q. Does money buy ideas for identifying and treating cancer?
A. Money is very important. Research is expensive. Many times we have to leave things undone. Here we have $75 million in grants. That's a lot of money. On the other hand, we could take $150 million and spend it well. These are difficult times. We used to have clinical income that supported teaching and research. Now with the changes in the medical economy that support for institutions like ours often dries up.
We spend a lot of time raising money from people interested in cancer research. We get a million dollars from the Federal Government. It comes with lots of strings attached. If you get another idea you don't take the money and move it. If you get $100,000 from an individual and give it to the same program, that flexibility is like an amplifier, like turning on your stereo. The sound goes up five-fold. The structure is in place and the private money can be used to follow exciting new ideas to get data to send into the Federal Government for a new grant.
Congress gives the money with less strings attached to it than an agency which puts more strings on it. Private money is almost invariably less rigid.
There is also a great need today for clinical research support. We need to supply the fiscal support for the doctors who are doing the clinical side of the experiment. That's rapidly disappearing. They are a special breed of investigative oncologists. They are the ones who think experimentally and still provide the highest quality of care.
We are planning a fund to endow clinical investigators. Many of them are forced to leave the academic environment and go into private practice because there is not enough financial support for them.

HEADLINE: From a Pulpit to a College Presidency

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: OLD WESTBURY

 BODY:
THE busy inner-city streets of Harlem are worlds away from the shady horse trails of the estate country here, but the trip by car takes only about an hour. This week a dynamic leader from Harlem hopes to start making the unusual commute between that capital of American black culture and this Gold Coast enclave of fabled mansions.
He is the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, and he has Governor Pataki's backing to become the next president of the struggling State University of New York College at Old Westbury. The Governor wants the 16 university trustees -- all but one appointed by him -- to ratify that nomination at their meeting on Tuesday. 
 A spokesman for the Governor, Charles Deister, voiced confidence that "Calvin Butts will be the next president of S.U.N.Y-Old Westbury, where he will be an outstanding leader and advocate for a campus that for too long was treated as a stepchild of the S.U.N.Y. system in prior administrations."
Although opposition is brewing on the campus, Dr. Butts has said he was eager to accept the job. "I would say yes," he said when his name surfaced this summer. "I am excited about it." The post has a pay range of $112,000 to $142,000.
This is a turning point both for his career and for the future of the college. Dr. Butts, the pastor of Harlem's legendary Abyssinian Baptist Church, has talked of running for Congress and Mayor of New York City. But now he says he is shifting his focus to academia. And the college, whose very survival has been in jeopardy since it opened as an experimental school in 1968, is rethinking its mission and considering a major expansion under an authorization voted by the Legislature last month.
Something else that Dr. Butts has in common with the college is controversy, although he seemingly thrives on it while the college has been mired in it. One veteran of the faculty for 30 years, Dr. Rosalyn F. Baxandall, chairwoman of American Studies, Media and Communications, said: "Our college was founded by 60's rebels and has rebelled against every president."
This time is no different. Even before Dr. Butts's expected arrival, the college is in an uproar over the lightning speed with which he was nominated last month. College officials skipped the yearlong national talent search and consultation with the faculty and students called for by university procedures. Instead, the selection was made in eight days -- after news reports that Dr. Butts had the inside track.
"They flouted every single guideline," said the chairwoman of the Faculty Senate, Dr. B. Runi Mukherji. The Senate has written to the Governor and college and university officials demanding that they halt to the confirmation and start over with the full process. So far those calls have gone unheeded.
Supporters of Dr. Butts dismiss the procedural objections and contend that he is the perfect choice. "He is extraordinarily gifted," said the chairman of the State University trustees, Thomas Eagan. William R. Howell, chairman of Old Westbury's advisory College Council and of its presidential search committee, said: "We think he's going to be terrific. He's a proven leader, a visionary. Our consultants say we'd be lucky to get him, that he'd be on any short list."
Randy A. Daniels, a State University trustee and friend of Dr. Butts who has been instrumental in pushing his nomination, said: "The issue is not process. The issue is result. The point of the process is to get the best president, and this is the best president."
But some critics say that the designation of Dr. Butts is hardly altruistic. They say he is simply collecting a payback for having crossed political lines to hold prayer breakfasts for Mr. Pataki, a Republican, and endorsing his re-election last year. "He did Pataki a favor," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democratic chairman, "and now Pataki's returning it." Mr. Farrell argued that the Governor's policies have hurt minority residents, "so at the end of the day we see the damage Pataki has done to the community versus his help for the Reverend."
Simultaneous with the dispute over the presidency, critics are also up in arms over a plan to develop a third of Old Westbury's heavily wooded 605-acre campus, originally a baronial estate owned by an heir to the Singer sewing machine fortune, F. Ambrose Clark.
The proposal includes a Nassau County police academy, a criminal justice institute, an equestrian center, a stadium, a sports center, student dormitories, faculty residences, a business institute, a conference center and a day-care center. Proponents say that leases and donations for various projects would generate millions of dollars for the college.
But faculty and student leaders, with environmentalists and civic groups, say such development would ruin valuable open space and threaten the ground water of this state-designated protected area.
The harshest critics say the plan is misleading, was developed secretly, is rife with irregularities and smacks of political cronyism and conflicts of interest. "It smells," said Joseph H. Lorintz, a lawyer and preservationist from Jericho who says he is organizing a broad coalition of opponents. "It's one of the biggest open spaces left in Nassau County, and it's under siege."
Defenders of the plan deny those charges. Mr. Pataki's philosophy is to raise university standards and make it more self supporting, they say; the development will be done with great care and will benefit the college. "The primary goal is to enhance the college," said Mr. Howell. "All this stuff will have a synergistic effect."
For a decade Dr. Butts has headed the Abyssinian Church, a prestigious pulpit once occupied by United States Representative Adam Clayton Powell. But Dr. Butts, 49, has emerged as a leader in his own right. He is known as a magnetic preacher, an outspoken advocate on race relations and an organizer of major community projects. The church, nearly two centuries old, seats 2,000 and has two Sunday services to accommodate the crowds.
"His sermons are carried live on the radio," said Mr. Daniels, a member of the congregation. "Hundreds of visitors come every Sunday from all over the world, even heads of state. He brings to Old Westbury a national reputation. He's an proven fund-raiser, a proven builder, an educational reformer and a successful recruiter. He took over a troubled high school in Harlem and turned it around and worked with Rudy Crew on the Thurgood Marshall Academy. He took over the Harlem Y when it was bankrupt. He founded the Abyssinian development agency. He built the Pathmark on 125th Street, the largest private development in Harlem in 30 years, and is working on an $80 million office complex at 125th and Lenox with Forest City Rattner. He's built senior housing, low income housing and housing for the homeless." Other church programs range from a credit union to AIDS services.
Dr. Butts intends to retain his post atop the Abyssinian empire while taking on the college presidency. "The church is solidly behind him," said Mr. Daniels. "He had a church meeting and outlined his plans. The board of deacons has given him their approval."
Although Dr. Butts's plan to juggle the two positions has raised some eyebrows, Mr. Howell said he was not troubled. "He's going to continue to preach on Sunday," he said, "but he'll be living full time on campus." Mr. Daniels, however, said he expected Dr. Butts to also keep his home in Harlem. Assemblyman Farrell, who counts Dr. Butts as a constituent, said, "It'll be interesting to see which place he'll claim as his residence."
In the past, Dr. Butts has not shied from confrontation. He has jousted with Mayor Edward I. Koch and last year infuriated Mayor Rudolph Giuliani by calling him a racist. But this spring, Dr. Butts upset many other black leaders by publicly embracing Mr. Giuliani at a church in the aftermath of the fatal police shooting of an unarmed black man, Amadou Diallo. Mr. Daniels said of Dr. Butts, "Controversy is his forte."
Dr. Butts's prospective tenure at Old Westbury raises the intriguing possibility of extending his activism in politics, religion and race relations to the Long Island arena, while still keeping his power base in Harlem.
But at this delicate juncture, with his nomination pending, Dr. Butts is declining to discuss Old Westbury issues. "I think it's wise for me not to comment any further until there is some decision," he said. "I am not the president, and what my views are and what I might do are of no consequence or substance now. It's kind of premature."
The college, one of the State University's smallest institutions, was created under Governor Nelson Rockefeller. Its mission is to serve nontraditional students, especially women, members of minority groups and adults returning to resume their education.
The school's rocky history began with its inaugural year, when the entering class held sit-ins protesting the curriculum. The president resigned, and the college was reorganized under the recommendations of a special commission. The sporadic disputes over the years include the faculty's vote of no confidence in the last permanent president, Dr. L. Eudora Pettigrew, who left in 1998.
"We've been the lowly stepchild of S.U.N.Y. central for many, many years, neglected and chronically underfunded," said Dr. Mukherji. "Many legislators have told us we were on the hit list to be closed." Even the buildings are neglected. The Academic Village, constructed of concrete slabs, resembles a drab military bunker set in a splendid greensward.
But many people on campus resent much of the criticism directed at the college, like Mr. Daniels's calling it "a school that is failing" and saying that "we're saving an institution." Dr. Mukherji said: "I think we've been basically successful in fulfilling our mission. We have a large variety of ethnic representation on the faculty and the highest minority enrollment in all of S.U.N.Y." Old Westbury also boasts of having the highest percentage of its faculty honored as distinguished service professors in the state.
Old Westbury has 3,400 students and an annual budget of $45 million. Its admission requirements are modest: average grades of 80 or combined college entrance examination scores of 1000. Three-fourths of the students are commuters -- some following the same trek Dr. Butts plans to make. About 44 percent come from Nassau County, 22 percent from Suffolk, 30 percent from New York City and the remaining 4 percent from elsewhere. The racial breakdown is 36 percent white, 28 percent black, 15 percent Hispanic, 7 percent Asian and 13 percent unspecified. Women account for 57 percent. Ages range from 17 to 71.
"We're not changing the mission or turning our backs on it, but we are broadening it," said Mr. Howell, the council chairman: "We've got to be able to find our place in the marketplace and get more students."
But critics say they fear that Old Westbury's traditional role will be gutted. The chief justice of the Student Government Association, Owen R. Thompson, said he was dubious of Dr. Butts. "He's friends with Giuliani and Pataki. What better way to get rid of minorities than with another minority?"
The land issue has also raised suspicions. The plan was posed as a way of "preserving open space and historic buildings." Critics say they were disturbed to find a provision added to the legislation that authorized the Old Westbury Foundation, an affiliated agency that would control the land deals, to "stimulate the economy, both locally and throughout New York State." The legislation, appended to the state budget, was co-sponsored by Senator Carl L. Marcellino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, and Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, a Democrat from North Hempstead.
Critics say the plan was developed secretly -- even without the knowledge of the interim president, W. Hubert Keen -- by a former Pataki campaign fund-raiser, using unauthorized payments to hire an unapproved consultant, without competitive bids. They also question the propriety of an anonymous $113,00 donation to the foundation that was revealed to have come from a major contractor, Frederick DeMatteis, who they say wants to get work on campus projects. He did not return a call seeking comment.
"There are many dots on our radar, and when you connect them, they appear very ominous," said Dr. Mukherji.
Mr. Daniels and others heatedly deny improprieties and say that Dr. Keen was well aware of the evolving plans but changed his story to capitalize on the land issue in his unsuccessful bid to compete with Dr. Butts for the permanent appointment as president. Dr. Keen has developed a rapport with many students and professors, winning him considerable support on campus.
"There's a lot of misinformation being put out there by faculty members who supported the other candidate," Mr. Daniels said. He dismissed Dr. Keen's claim of being kept in the dark. "What you are hearing now is 180 degrees from what he told us," he said. "What we are seeing now is really duplicitous." Dr. Keen declined to be interviewed.
Dr. Butts's odyssey to Old Westbury actually began with his pursuit of a part-time teaching post. After talking with Mr. Daniels and visiting the campus, his aspirations grew. "This was my idea," said Mr. Daniels. His closeness to Dr. Butts has given pause to critics who say the two are too intertwined. Besides being a parishioner, friend and a university trustee, Mr. Daniels also serves as a senior vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, where Dr. Butts serves on the board as a Pataki appointee.
Most critics hesitate to attack Dr. Butts himself. "He's very bright and charismatic and has enormous skills and in fact may be the best person," said Dr. Mukherji. "That's not the issue. The issue is we have a right to help choose our president." Following a flawed selection process could unnecessarily damage Dr. Butt's credibility, she said.
But another professor disagreed. "We've had several legal searches and haven't gotten very distinguished presidents," said Dr. Baxandall. "I wish the faculty would give him a chance. Supposedly he has connections, and we need somebody with connections."
Despite the campus turmoil, the final decision will be up to the trustees, where no real resistance to Dr. Butts has emerged publicly. One member, Candace de Russy, who helped draft the presidential search guidelines, expressed "grave concern" about the process but added that her concern in no way reflected on Dr. Butts.
A trustee who lives near the campus, Dr. Harvey F. Wachsman of Upper Brookville, said he was disturbed about the land proposal. "I don't want to give it away," he said. "I don't want to rent it out. I want it used for the school in a positive way." But he had no reservations about Dr. Butts. "I love Calvin Butts," he said. "He's a super capable guy, in every way. He's just the right guy."
