HEADLINE: H & R Block's Risky Stab At Synergy

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
BY nurturing a reputation for integrity for 44 years, H & R Block became America's largest tax preparer. It is trusted by so many Americans with the intimate details of their finances that it filled out one of every seven income tax returns this year.
So what were they thinking here at the company's world headquarters, an airy concrete box, when Block agreed this month to pay $850 million in cash for Olde Financial, the parent of a discount securities brokerage with a history of accusations that it abused its customers and discriminated against blacks and women? 
 Wall Street reacted with revulsion to the Sept. 1 announcement, knocking down Block shares by 18 percent in two days, in the process reducing the company's value by a billion dollars. The shares have stayed down since, selling in the $46 range -- the same as they did five years ago.
Ozzie Wenick, Block's chief financial officer, said he was not surprised at the negative reaction because Olde is "this lady who in the eyes of the public is slightly tainted," and staid old Block "went out with her Tuesday and now has to explain it in church on Sunday." There is bound to be more explaining to do when Wall Street figures out that most of the purchase price will go to Olde's founder, Ernest J. Olde, who gave up his American citizenship last year, a common tactic for wealthy Americans seeking to escape taxes -- a fact that prompted Block to go to extraordinary lengths to insure that Mr. Olde pays his taxes on the transaction.
Still, Mr. Wenick said: "You have to look beyond the problem to what we can do with it. What happens if we take Olde's 600,000 clients and turn them into 1.8 million clients?"
The answer that Block is counting on, of course, is big profits -- including a steady flow of fees for managing the retirement accounts of some of Block's most affluent tax clients. Block is looking particularly at the most prosperous 25 percent of those customers -- four million households with an average income of $62,000 and a growing pot of Individual Retirement Account and college-fund money.
Frank L. Salizzoni, a veteran airline industry executive and Block director who in 1996 became the company's third chief executive in less than a year, said Block bought Olde cheaply. He projects Olde's 1999 pretax profits at $100 million, making the purchase price 8.5 times earnings, and says the acquisition will add to Block's profits immediately.
Executives here also point approvingly to Olde's network of 181 offices, its smooth back-office operations and its solid computer technology that can easily be expanded.
"If this works, the growth potential is incredible," Mr. Salizzoni said.
It's the ifs that give investors pause, because it has been a long time since the rest of the business world saw eye to eye with Block about its corporate strategy. For more than a decade, the company has stumbled into a variety of what it saw as synergistic combinations, only to reverse course and stumble out again.
Block tried to mass-market lawyering through Hyatt Legal Services, to put people in temporary jobs with its Interim agency and to provide data networking and on-line services with Compuserve. The company subsequently sold all those interests -- and others -- at a profit, but none helped it expand its core business.
THE Olde deal, Block executives say, is different -- an acquisition clearly intended to build on the company's base of 16 million tax-preparation customers and its network of 9,000 offices in the United States, plus an additional 1,500 offices in Canada, Australia and Britain.
The notion, the brainchild of Mark A. Ernst, 41, Block's president and chief executive designate, is to focus Block narrowly on taxes and what he calls its "only two natural extensions" -- mortgages and investment advice, because both are interwoven with taxes. (He said that there were no plans for a Block bank, but he did not rule one out, either.)
Last September, on his second day on the job, Mr. Ernst was told about a plan for Block to sell automobile insurance for Geico, the discount insurer controlled by Warren E. Buffett, a friend of Mr. Salizzoni's.
Mr. Ernst, a son of an Iowa tax preparer whose previous job was building a thriving investment business for American Express, quickly killed the plan. "I thought about my six sisters," he said. "They are H & R Block's customers. I wondered how auto insurance would play with them."
He said he saw no relationship between income tax returns and car insurance. Worse, he feared what would happen if Block tax preparers came to believe that the home office just wanted to push products like insurance. The preparers would "protect the clients from the company" by steering them away, he said.
The new strategy requires refinements in the company's existing holdings. For instance, Block is trying to sell Option One, its highly profitable mortgage wholesaler, because its size and capital needs distort the parent company's books. Block hopes to maintain a business relationship in which Option One buys home mortgages that Block originates.
And Mr. Ernst will impose limits on the possible synergies as he brings Olde -- a name that will disappear as quickly as possible, Block executives say, probably before year-end -- into the Block fold.
AT the 90 to 100 Block Financial Centers that the company plans to operate by early next year -- the first of possibly hundreds of offices where the mortgage and securities businesses will operate year-round alongside the seasonal tax preparation business -- tax clients will not be urged to put their income tax refunds into stocks and bonds.
Most Block clients see their refunds, which average $1,799, as "forced savings," Mr. Ernst said, and want to spend the money "on something they otherwise would never buy -- a car, travel, consumer durables."
"We're not going to try to persuade people to put their income tax refund money away, because that's pain," he explained -- and pain does not build the relationship that Mr. Ernst wants.
The painless way to save, he said, is through payroll deductions for a credit union account or a 401(k) plan. And when people are ready to open an I.R.A., or when they switch jobs and need to roll over their 401(k) money, Block will be there to help. It will also promote an Olde money-market fund that requires a $25,000 investment, but also pays about 5.5 percent interest, making it attractive to thrifty but risk-averse savers.
Middle-class Americans like his sisters are very much Mr. Ernst's target market. He is troubled, for example, by the 600 Block Premium tax preparation offices: Using the name "Premium" for the division, which was originally called Block Executive Tax Services and aimed at people with six-figure incomes, is demeaning to the company's core customers, Mr. Ernst said. He has not yet decided how to deal with the problem.
By contrast, Mr. Ernst is enthusiastic about the eight accounting firms that Block has recently acquired, intending to broaden its appeal to small corporations.
Olde has also focused on the middle class. It was established in 1971 as a brokerage firm serving blue-collar workers in Detroit, and was a pioneer in offering low-cost services after the system of fixed commissions for stock trades ended in 1975.
A big potential problem for Block is that Olde developed a reputation for taking advantage of its less-than-affluent clientele.
A year ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission settled charges of fraudulent sales practices and deceptive advertising against Olde. Mr. Olde, his company and three other executives paid a total of $7 million to settle.
Mr. Olde was also fined $500,000 by N.A.S.D. Regulation Inc., the regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers, and suspended from the brokerage business for 18 months. No admissions of wrongdoing were made by the company or its executives.
BUT that has not ended Olde's problems. One lawsuit, a class action by Arizona residents, contends that while Olde advertised commission-free trades, it secretly profited by marking up securities it sold to clients from its own portfolio. Jeffrey M. Slopen, Olde's lawyer and a company director, said the suit lacked merit.
Individual cases, in which investors say Olde brokers gave inappropriate advice and made unauthorized trades, are keeping lawyers busy in Indiana, Florida, California and other states. Mr. Slopen said securities firms have always faced such claims.
Olde quickly settled suits brought in 1995 by 14 women who were brokers at the firm. They contended that their valuable accounts had been taken away and given to men with less experience -- actions often accompanied, the women said, by pointed comments about a woman's place being with her children. In settling the cases Olde did not admit any wrongdoing.
Mr. Ernst said he was not worried about Olde's past or about litigation that might yet arise. To protect Block, he said, he negotiated specific, if confidential, terms.
"We have a clause in the contract to protect us," Mr. Ernst said, "and the liabilities were built into the price."
Randal J. Mudge, Olde's chief executive, said that when he took charge in 1995, he rebuilt Olde from top to bottom. That was not an acknowledgment of mistakes or wrongdoing in the past, he said, but rather a strategy to create a culture of integrity from which allegations of customer abuse and discrimination against employees could not arise.
Still, investors who worry that hidden liabilities lurk within Olde will take little solace in learning that Block discovered Mr. Olde's abandonment of his American citizenship only late in the negotiations.
Mr. Olde, who owns 92 percent of the firm, never mentioned it, Mr. Ernst said, during the several days they spent together at the Olde home in the Cayman Islands. (Mr. Ernst is the only Block executive who has met Mr. Olde.)
Nor did it emerge in the extensive due diligence work that Block executives describe with pride. In addition to poring over Olde Financial's books and legal papers with the help of its bankers at Salomon Smith Barney, Block brought in its own computer experts to examine Olde's technology and hired outside computer consultants as a further check. A Block lawyer quietly opened an Olde account to see what kind of advice he would get, while Block executives hunted for relatives who had Olde accounts to learn of their experiences.
Yet none of this research came across the fact -- published in the Federal Register on April 22 -- that Mr. Olde had renounced his citizenship. Instead, according to Mr. Ernst, it came to his attention in a contract document prepared by Mr. Olde and his lawyers.
Mr. Slopen, the Olde lawyer, said Mr. Olde did not give up his citizenship and alight on the Cayman Islands to avoid taxes, as other wealthy Americans have done. Rather, he said Mr. Olde, 61, had married a Caymanian citizen and spends nearly all his time there, because it is "a more controlled environment" than he can find in the United States.
Mr. Ernst put it differently. Mr. Olde, he said, gave up his citizenship because "he feels he was badly treated by the S.E.C." (Through Mr. Slopen, Mr. Olde declined to be interviewed for this article.)
IN any event, the public relations risks were obvious. Because Block is America's largest tax preparer, Mr. Slopen said, "they were concerned it would not be appropriate to pay someone who would not be paying his taxes."
"But Mr. Olde doesn't have any issue with paying his taxes," the lawyer said. "He always has paid, as much as $50 million in some years for Mr. Olde personally and Olde Financial, and he will pay his taxes on this transaction." Mr. Slopen confirmed that the tax bill will be about $157 million.
Block insisted on an escrow account for the expected taxes, Mr. Ernst said. "We have -- we obtained -- specific representations that he will pay his taxes," Mr. Ernst said.
For now, investors seem more concerned about what Block is paying for Olde. The $850 million price looks dear to Block's biggest shareholder, Harris Associates, an asset management firm in Chicago that owns 8 percent of Block.
The company sent one of its partners, Henry Berghoef, to Block's annual meeting here on Sept. 8 to ask pointed questions about the wisdom of the purchase.
With Block awash in cash from the 1998 sale of Compuserve -- the on-line service went to America Online and the digital network to what is now MCI Worldcom -- netting $1 billion cash after taxes, Mr. Berghoef asked why the company wasn't using its money to buy back shares. That strategy, he said, would raise earnings per share and lift the stock price.
"Is the board paying attention?" Mr. Berghoef asked at the meeting, saying that the Olde deal "doesn't make sense."
Moments later, after the meeting, Mr. Berghoef exchanged a few sharp words with Mr. Salizzoni in the aisles of the auditorium at the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art. Then he went to lunch with Mr. Ernst, who tried to persuade him that, in the long run, buying Olde was smart.
Afterward, Mr. Berghoef said he remained unimpressed. Brokerage is a cyclical business, he noted, adding that Block is buying at the top of the market. "When the market comes down, owners will be begging people to buy brokerages for book value, not the almost 2.5 times book Block is paying," he said.
Securities analysts gave the Olde acquisition plan mixed reviews. Alexander Paris Jr., an analyst at Barrington Research Associates in Chicago, said he was "bullish on Block, even if the market isn't." He said Block paid a fair price to acquire an infrastructure to jump into the securities business.
"Block is a conservatively run company that doesn't shoot from the hip," he said. "The question is the execution, how well they will integrate Olde into Block."
Martin Romm, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said he was not at all certain about the wisdom of the deal.
"Buying Olde injects an element of risk because of the volatility in the brokerage business," Mr. Romm said, noting that in the tax business Block has had steady, if slow, growth and predictable earnings.
He said a less risky, but profitable, strategy would have been to continue acquiring accounting firms that do business with small corporations.
BLOCK executives say the key to making the Olde purchase a success lies not in the price paid, but in how the brokerage is integrated into Block.
"For years and years," said Mr. Wenick, the chief financial officer, "we have been telling people how to minimize their taxes, and they have been whispering in our ear, 'Can you tell me how to save and invest?' And we've told them, 'We can't help you.' "
He said "the big change" wrought by Mr. Ernst is that "we were never focused on leveraging our customer base."
"Now," he said, "we are totally focused on it."
Mr. Ernst said his plan depended on persuading customers, and Block's army of tax preparers, that the company was there to help them, not shove products at them. To that end, he said, Olde's 1,200 brokers would be retrained in hopes of instilling Block's values into the brokerage organization.
"At Block, we cannot tolerate" any conduct that would harm its reputation, Mr. Ernst said.
Despite all the strategic zigzags, and even though Block has raised preparation fees for income tax returns by 17 percent in the past two years -- far above the rate of inflation -- Mr. Ernst said customers are loyal to Block. In the last two years, Block said 76.5 percent of its clients were repeat customers.
That is something that he will not be tampering with lightly.
"Have we pushed too far?" Mr. Ernst asked, before answering his own question. "Our customers absolutely love us. They feel we are one of the best companies around and that our services are a bargain. And, most importantly, they trust us."
 
Lessons Learned by a Tax Preparer's Son
TO understand Mark A. Ernst's plans for H & R Block, where he is expected to become chief executive in a year or so, requires understanding how his childhood and career prepared him for the job.
Mr. Ernst, 41, grew up in Bellevue, Iowa, a town of 1,200 families near Dubuque where his father, Robert, was a state tax auditor until he retired and started his own income tax preparation business in 1971.
Soon thereafter, Robert Ernst got a letter from H & R Block asking him to become part of its network -- and warning that if he didn't, the tax giant would open an office in Bellevue and compete for business.
The letter was a bluff: The elder Mr. Ernst held out, and Block never came to Bellevue. The son says that taught him a lesson: If your customers trust you, a competitor can't take the business away.
When Mark Ernst was studying finance and economics at Drake University and the University of Chicago, he spent two seasons preparing income tax returns in his father's office, a job that made him realize that "this is a very personal-relationship business."
"You are revealing to someone things you don't even tell your brother," he added.
He said he was "amazed that people would ask me what to do with their money -- how to invest it, how to save -- things that as a 19-year-old I had absolutely no idea about, but because I understood taxes, people thought I must."
Mr. Ernst said he was also amazed at how little money his clients had. "It gave me an appreciation of how these families were getting by, making ends meet, on less than you would imagine," he said.
After a brief stint as an accountant, he joined American Express in New York, but came to feel a bit out of place. "I had to re-orient myself to a clientele with higher incomes, with prestige marketing," he said. He moved to the company's Minneapolis office, where he worked on building several investment-related businesses, including a stock brokerage firm that doubled its revenues in two years. His final job at American Express was senior vice president; he developed ways to market mutual funds, brokerage services and annuities through third-party distributors.
He said he felt at home when he arrived a year ago at Block, a company whose chairman, Henry W. Bloch, put in for just $798 on his expense account last year, down from $959 in 1997.
 DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 5; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Happiness, By the Numbers

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
NOT too long ago in the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan, a king looking for a way to ease a medieval society into modernity decided that instead of hitching the country's aspirations to its Gross National Product, he would use a measure he called Gross National Happiness.
"That's extremely interesting, and also extremely difficult," said Ronald Inglehart, who has been studying what makes people happy and why some countries are a lot more cheerful -- or despondent -- than others. "I am extremely in favor of maximizing happiness, because that's what I think people are after," he said. "But it's not that easy. For different people, happiness is dependent on different things." 
 Can a whole country be happy, or at least happier than some other place? Professor Inglehart, the program director of the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan, says that surveys in dozens of countries seem to indicate that certain nations rank very high in what experts call "subjective well being," or, in everyday language, feeling good.
For a lot of nonscientific kibbitzers, it may be reassuring to know that those mental images of mournful Russians trudging through the snow or rosy-cheeked Dutch frolicking in the tulips coincide with statistics. The Russians are measurably miserable, while the Dutch are a statistically sunny bunch. These numbers don't explain, of course, why Strindberg's gloomy Swedes profess to be so happy, or why the Chinese, whom we persist in seeing as regimented, are actually relatively content with their lives.
Why national populations place themselves at a particular point on the happiness scale is unclear. Income is only part of the picture.
"Getting richer has a big return at the early stages, as you move from dire poverty and infant mortality of 50 percent and stuff like that to a sort of modest comfort like South Korea or Spain," Professor Inglehart said. "Beyond that it makes hardly any contribution."
The European Union, with whose experts Professor Inglehart began working in the 1970's, has been sampling the subjective well-being level for several decades. With great regularity, the Nordic countries -- Iceland, Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden -- along with the Netherlands and Switzerland top the charts. But Ireland, north and south, is up there, too, despite its legendary troubles. The Iberians are at the bottom, and Germany, France and Italy are somewhere in between.
Since 1981, Professor Inglehart has built up a team of experts in 65 countries to conduct broader surveys. They show Americans and Canadians about on a par with moderately happy Europeans. The Russians are joined by citizens of other former Soviet-bloc countries in the cellar, falling below Nigeria and Bangladesh.
THE worldwide findings, analyzed by Professor Inglehart and Hans-Dieter Klingemann of the Center for Sciences in Berlin, will be published next year in a book called "Subjective Well-Being Across Cultures." Their study is intended to question other recent research showing that people may be genetically programmed for upbeat personalities, a theory the authors conclude may be applicable within a society but cannot account for national differences.
"There are huge differences among nations and they are not at all random," Professor Inglehart said. "Virtually all stable democracies are much more likely to have high levels of subjective well-being. Virtually all countries that are low on subjective well-being are authoritarian." He said there are two readings of this. People who are basically satisfied with their lives "are much more likely to be supportive of democratic institutions, and I think it's mostly that," he said. "But the other reading is much more fun: If you become democratic, you live happily ever after."
The sense that they are living under a government they chose and control seems to make people in democracies feel better, research finds. That environment also allows people who have reached a comfortable economic level to turn to issues like the environment or women's rights. At that point, it becomes much trickier for governments to know what people want next. This is where a country like Singapore stands now. An authoritarian Government has made Singaporeans prosperous, but what next?
All this said, is there a case to be made for sadness? Melancholy can season the soul and inspire great literature or music. Culture in it broadest sense plays a big but not easily quantifiable role in emotions and impressions of well-being. In Russia and the Iberian countries, pain and anguish, even tragedy, may be an integral and acceptable part of psychological life.
"In Portugal," said Antonio Monteiro, the Portuguese representative at the United Nations, "we call our national music fado, and fado means fate, destiny." If you listen to the country's most famous singers, he said, "the song is always about something missing."
And the most romantic word in the Portuguese language is saudade, Mr. Monteiro said. "Saudade is when we miss something. But in a certain way you live with this feeling, and you live well with this feeling. It hurts you but comforts you at the same time."
Just ask someone on the street, How are you? "Culturally, nobody will tell you, I'm fine, I'm happy - nobody," he said. "That's the way the Portuguese are."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Now, Presidential 'Body' Politics;
But Seriously, Mr. Ventura

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NEITHER Vice President Al Gore nor Gov. George W. Bush of Texas is ripping his shirt off and wrapping a feather boa around his neck in the style of Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota. But barely one year after Mr. Ventura's unlikely election on the Reform Party ticket unnerved Democrats and Republicans, politicians have generally stopped joking about the professional wrestler turned politician.
Now they are scrutinizing Mr. Ventura's every pronouncement, assembling focus groups and even making pilgrimages to St. Paul, Minnesota's capital, searching for clues to a mystery that confounds even the most savvy politicians: How does a candidate excite the electorate and galvanize new voters when the public does not seem to be paying attention to politics? 
 The day he was elected, Mr. Ventura became the nation's foremost beacon for disaffected and independent voters. More important, after wrestling control of the Reform Party from Ross Perot this summer -- Mr. Ventura's candidate was elected chairman -- the Minnesota Governor has emerged as the institutional embodiment of national disaffection as well.
Last week, Mr. Ventura's role as the power broker in third-party politics was unmistakable. After Patrick J. Buchanan all but said he would abandon the Republican Party to try to run for President on the Reform Party ticket, attention turned to Mr. Ventura: Would he use his clout as the nation's only office-holder under the Reform Party banner to thwart Mr. Buchanan, whose conservative stands on social issues are at odds with Mr. Ventura's libertarian views? Would he endorse Donald Trump instead? Would he heed the entreaties and run himself for President?
"If Ventura has to stop Buchanan by being the candidate himself, his ideas will be thrust center stage on American politics," said Richard N. Bond, a former Republican national chairman. "That would be a powerful test to the two-party system."
Politicians and professional wrestlers are often guilty of hyperbole, so it is no surprise that Mr. Ventura holds a perhaps inflated view of his role. "Both of these parties want to say they're me," he said in an interview. "They're all telling the world, 'Yes, I'm a Jesse substitute.' I wish I could hand them a recipe, like your grandmother's spaghetti."
Mr. Ventura could well end up as a footnote, but for now, at least, his achievement should not be dismissed. By capturing 37 percent of the vote against established Republican and Democratic contenders -- and by carrying every age group under 60 -- Mr. Ventura underscored a political paradox: even in a time of economic contentment, Americans are yearning for blunt-speaking outsiders.
"Jesse Ventura put all of Washington on notice that the amount of cynicism and disengagement with politics as usual is very high in America," said Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican.
WHILE inside his state he has been attacked for failing to deliver on a big tax cut and other promises, Mr. Ventura has an impressive approval rating. Beyond Minnesota, he has drawn notice for emphasizing smaller government, campaign finance reform and bringing honesty to Government. He was a pioneer of using the Internet to convey his message.
"I'm a longtime critic of Perot, but I think Jesse could be the real deal," said Paul Begala, a former top aide to President Clinton. "He's an authentic populist in the way a billionaire just cannot be."
Senator John McCain of Arizona, who is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, happily compares himself to the former wrestler. "We have a lot in common," he said. "He and I were both in the Navy. I was a high school and college wrestler -- but I was mediocre."
For all the gushing, there is vigorous debate in Democratic and Republican circles over the staying power of the 48-year-old Governor. Some argue that he will be a transforming force; others say he will fade. Some argue that his success can be mimicked; others say he is a one-of-a-kind who was elected only because of his brash style and unconventional resume. After all, what other politicians have had toy action figures made in their likeness?
"He's been exalted to a rather prominent position by some circumstances that do not really add up to his being a long-term political leader of a third party movement," said former Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, who ran as an independent for President in 1980. "He's trading to some degree on his celebrity status."
Scoffing at the idea of Mr. Ventura as more than a fleeting sensation, Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, said, "People see him as a character, but not as someone they would sleep comfortably at night as head of the Government."
Senator Joseph R. Biden, a Delaware Democrat, predicted that Mr. Ventura would fade like Mr. Perot. "In four years, he'll be where our boy from Texas is -- only without the money," he said. "It's a predictable aberration; every four to 10 years in American politics there's a character like Rush Limbaugh or Jerry Falwell with something interesting to say who becomes a repository for despair within the existing system."
Told of Mr. Biden's comments, Mr. Ventura flashed the impudence that some find refreshing and others find disturbing. "Who does that guy think he is?" he said. "You can tell Joe Biden that if, indeed, four years from now nobody will know who I am, I'd still rather be an unknown than a career politician like him. Go out and ask your average teen-ager today who Jesse Ventura is and who Joe Biden is. What I've accomplished is more than he ever will."
Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, said politicians dismiss Mr. Ventura at their peril. "There is an arrogance among the old-fashioned political elite to reject what Ventura represents because it's so foreign to them and in a sense it's radical and even dangerous," he said.
Yet, realistically, established politicians who entered the political world in blue suits and red ties cannot suddenly make themselves over without the risk of appearing calculating -- not to mention loony.
"I've not seen any of my colleagues inclined to go into the wrestling ring," Mr. Specter said. "Also, you can't go through what the 535 of us have go through to get here without having fairly set ways. It would take a lot of planning to be as spontaneous as Jesse Ventura."
Even while he argued that his success is hardly a fluke, Mr. Ventura conceded that his candidacy was "a rather unique situation" that other candidates could not easily imitate.
"There is not one politician in America that could have done what I've done and gotten away with it," he said of his move from the wrestling ring to the political circus. "You can't be plain spoken and direct unless you are."
IM R. Ventura said there's no living politician like him. "I see myself closest to Abraham Lincoln," he said. "We're alike in many ways. We were both wrestlers. And we're both six-foot-four."
Not everyone rejects the idea of a President Ventura. "I've always had in the back of my mind that Jesse's gearing up for 2004," said Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican. "He certainly has the potential. I don't think you should ever underestimate him."

HEADLINE: The Hidden Message On Nassau Taxes

 BODY:
There has been a lot of dissembling coming from the top County Republican leaders about Nassau County's current financial crisis. Two months before the elections, they have finally stirred themselves into action to try to avoid tremendous defeat in November. Yet, recent comments from the three top Nassau County Republican leaders have me shocked, alarmed and worried for our future in what is already the most-taxed county in New York.
* The County Executive, Tom Gulotta, stated that "the problem is not overspending, it is the lack of recurring revenues to meet increasing expenses." Translation: "We're not spending too much. The taxpayers aren't giving us enough money. We need more." 
 Bruce Blakeman, the Republican majority leader of the Nassau County Legislature, was quoted as saying he will go to Albany to ask for a three-year extension of the "temporary" real-estate transfer tax to add structural stability to the county's finances. Translation: "I need to make this tax permanent. Kiss 1 percent of your home value goodbye forever."
* Joseph Mondello, the county's Republican Party chairman, was quoted as saying: "We're going to cut, cut, cut until we can't cut anymore. Then if we have to raise taxes, it will be better accepted by the people." Translation: "We're going to make a big show of fiscal responsibility so we can continue to raise taxes and keep this gravy train rolling."
Their intent is plain. In a time of plenty when Republicans in Washington and Albany are enjoying budget surpluses and are working diligently to cut our taxes, the Republicans in Nassau County have plunged us deep into debt and are scheming to raise our taxes yet again.
 
THOMAS SOBCZAK
Westbury

HEADLINE: On Hawaii, A Telescope Widens Orbit Of Japanese

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: MOUNT MAUNA KEA, Hawaii, Sept. 17

 BODY:
In a mountaintop ceremony bringing together a stately Japanese Princess and members of the Hawaiian royal order emblazoned in crimson robes, Japan today inaugurated what many astronomers expect will soon prove to be the world's most powerful land-based telescope.
Experts gathered under a dazzling sun at the 13,796-foot summit of Mount Mauna Kea, Hawaii's tallest mountain, said the 26.9-foot instrument, known by the Japanese name for the constellation Pleiades, or Subaru, would quickly help propel Japan from relative astronomical obscurity into the highest echelons of space-observing nations. 
 Moreover, many said, the $400 million telescope represented the first time that Japan had spent so heavily on a scientific project overseas. As such, they said, it represents a sort of scientific coming out for a nation whose scientific efforts have been devoted mostly to domestic well-being since Japan's defeat in World War II.
That the event took place in Hawaii, where a Japanese aerial attack on Pearl Harbor brought about America's entry into war in 1941, resonated strongly with the symbolism of Japan's reconciliation and close alliance with the United States.
The United States' Ambassador to Japan, Thomas Foley, alluded to this in his remarks at the ceremony. Using the original Japanese definition of the word Subaru, he said, "I find it particularly appropriate that this telescope is named Subaru, or uniting, coming together."
Cooperation with both the United States and other nations was necessary to build the telescope. But the Japanese scientists who will operate it make no secret of their ambition to have the world's best such instrument.
Proudly displaying pictures taken by the Subaru and by the Hubble space telescope, the Japanese astronomers said their telescope was the world's sharpest, and among the most capable.
Its extraordinarily sharp resolution is due in large part to design innovations that for the first time apply Japan's renowned skills in engineering, electronics and miniaturization to telescope building.
An array of 261 tiny, ultra-precise motors can adjust the huge mirror for minute distortions. The mirror is said to be of unprecedented thinness for its size, reducing the problem of wielding an object of immense mass. And scientists say the telescope is extraordinarily accurate in the tracking of distant objects.
It is also unusually quiet because of what the Japanese say is a unique casing that slews almost silently along with the telescope itself.
"We must still prove it, but I think that our telescope's design will allow us to make the best images," said Dr. Norio Kaifu, the director of the Subaru telescope. "We share our information with the other telescopes on Mauna Kea, and so far, without adaptive optics, our images have the highest resolution."
Mauna Kea is already home to perhaps the world's two greatest telescopes, behemoths of comparable size: the United States-owned Keck telescope, and the Gemini, which is the fruit of an American-led international consortium. Adaptive optics is a technology perfected in Hawaii that will eventually be used by all three of the telescopes and that allows for a dramatic correction of atmospheric distortions.
The construction of so many large telescopes at the peak of Mauna Kea, a native spiritual ground, has been a source of serious tension in Hawaii for years. And the addition of Subaru to this community was no different.
With a table of white cumulus clouds stretching below as far as the eye could see, members of the Royal Order of Kamehameha called the site "the place where the bones of my ancestors and the spirit of our people reside."
Once the inauguration got under way inside the telescope's frigid white dome, however, the Hawaiian traditionalists listened quietly.
The Japanese Princess, Sayako, made no reference to the local controversy in remarks she made as she stood before the American, Japanese and Hawaiian flags under the bright metallic blue of the telescope's superstructure. She referred instead to the use of the stars as navigating tools by the original Hawaiians and praised the international "cooperation of many people from many fields" behind Subaru's creation.
Ever since a broadcast of the telescope's inaugural test was relayed to Japanese television, the device has enjoyed almost celebrity status among the Japanese, more accustomed to observing and following than being pioneers in fields like astronomy.
"The feelings of the Japanese people are changing," said Takafumi Matsui, a professor of interplanetary physics at Tokyo University. "There are increasing numbers of people who feel that we should have contributed more to such kinds of learning during the bubble economy of the 1980's. And still now, people feel that we should be able to contribute more."

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Good Times Temper Desire For More Jobs

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: NORTH GREENBUSH, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE upper Hudson River Valley has been obsessing over its lost jobs and shuttered industries for so long that Jim Flanigan thought that getting the O.K. to bring a microchip plant and thousands of high-tech jobs to this town would be a walk in the park.
After all, the Governor, whose office in Albany is right across the Hudson River from here, had already dispensed $50,000 to help North Greenbush attract the plant, while the Senate majority leader, who represents the area, pulled millions more out of the legislative air to ease the way. 
 One might think that a region with such a history of economic desperation that the writer William Kennedy has made hard times a central theme of his Albany novels would be grateful for the attention.
But Mr. Flanigan, a town councilman, has discovered that the promise of jobs and investment is not as compelling here as it was when the Albany region consistently lagged behind the downstate area economically. Now the money is flowing here, too, the region's unemployment rate is below 4 percent, and the local school bus company is complaining that $10 an hour is not enough to attract drivers.
Mr. Flanigan is hearing an unusual refrain for this part of the state: "Enough."
"I hear a lot of people say, 'We don't need it anymore,' " Mr. Flanigan said. "And when you ask them to define 'need,' it is that they have a job and they're comfortable. But a few years ago they weren't so comfortable, and things could turn against us again."
No microchip plant is in the offing now, and no chip maker has even begun to commit to North Greenbush, which has about 11,000 residents. Instead, the idea is to make a site "shovel ready," with all licenses and environmental permits completed, so that a plant could move in quickly once a deal was struck.
Having the full force of state government pushing North Greenbush to approve a phantom plant has some residents digging in their heels. "People talk about the importance of jobs and growth, and I understand that," said Francis Rodgers, a retired public school administrator. "But I'm talking about preserving our rights against government cannibalism, which is when a higher level of government is trying to impose its policies on a lower level. Governor Pataki wants this type of plant in New York State, but Governor Pataki doesn't live in North Greenbush."
Christine LaPlante, a North Greenbush native and a professor of civil engineering at Union College, seemed to agree. "It's very political," she said. "It's coming from the highest levels of government, and they really want to see something like this happen in Rensselaer County. But why does it have to go to a virgin area? Why can't it go where people are used to industry?"
It looked as if the North Greenbush board would approve all the permits for the plant until the Rensselaer County Greens, an environmental group, recently raised objections. The Greens made "Silicon Valley" sound like a dirty word in a leaflet predicting that microchips would turn North Greenbush into "an endless parking lot, full of despair and lost kids, with a toxic cloud hanging in the air."
Residents jammed the public meeting that followed to recount cases of cancer in their families and to fret about the acids that chip makers use to etch the silicon. Suddenly, Mr. Flanigan said, supporters of the project started going into hiding.
"It's scare tactics," said Roy Wright, the town supervisor and the only other strong pro-chip voice on the five-member council. "It's mind-boggling that people would be against this kind of economic development."
Maybe they won't be for long, Mr. Flanigan said. Schenectady is still losing General Electric jobs, the Watervliet Arsenal recently announced a new round of layoffs, and the BASF dye works in the city of Rensselaer just disclosed that it was moving many local jobs to Europe. "Some of these folks arguably do feel rich and comfortable and maybe they don't need this plant, but what about their kids and grandkids?" he asked. "We're still exporting most of our graduates, because when you lose part of a GE or a BASF or a Watervliet they have to leave, or work in Wal-Marts."

HEADLINE: Swiss Turn an Unblinded Eye on Russian Funds in Their Banks

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: LUGANO, Switzerland, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Since the collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union, former citizens and their capital have flooded into Switzerland and into its banks. Now, as concern deepens that the money may be linked to organized crime, the banks and the Government are taking measures unusual by Swiss standards to try to ferret out any illegality.
In the early 1990's, Swiss bankers and Government leaders welcomed Russian money. The well-oiled Swiss economy was showing signs of strain, and the banks faced mounting international competition. 
 But since the arrest in 1996 of an allegedly major Russian crime figure who had taken up residence near Geneva, attitudes have changed dramatically. Steps to battle organized crime based in Russia or elsewhere in the former Soviet Union have come in quick succession.
Prompted originally by the embarrassment of the $500 million stashed in Swiss banks by Ferdinand E. Marcos the Swiss for the first time made money laundering a crime. They have since started to put those laws into force, created a police unit for Russian gangs and become more cooperative with Russian investigators.
In recent months Swiss prosecutors investigating money laundering at the highest levels of the Russian Government have traveled to Moscow to exchange information and question witnesses, and Russian counterparts have come to Switzerland. Swiss banks have been ordered to provide information about dozens of Russians with assets here and to freeze a number of bank accounts.
"The Swiss have always been very careful before making an investigation public," said a senior executive at a Geneva bank. The wide publicity and the large number of accounts frozen -- more than 59, he said -- demonstrated that the usually unflappable Swiss consider the Russian entanglement "a very serious matter."
Jean Ziegler, a member of the Swiss legislature's foreign affairs committee, said officials tended to view the arrival of the Russians and their money as having occurred in three distinct phases.
First, he said, came large flows of money from the Soviet Union, as Russians and others transferred their assets to safe havens abroad. Though there are no official figures, the Swiss authorities estimate that $40 billion to $50 billion in Russian capital is deposited in Swiss banks.
For the Swiss the money was something of a boon. They were feeling pressure from emerging offshore banking centers, as well as big commercial banks in the United States and Europe, which were becoming more involved in the traditional Swiss specialty of investing money for wealthy clients.
In addition, less money was moving into Switzerland in search of a safe haven. There was pressure against it from organizations like the International Monetary Fund, which sought to curb flows of illicit capital from the third world. There were also tougher laws in Western Europe against tax evasion.
By the mid-1990's, Mr. Ziegler said, a second stage followed, in which thousands of Russians began acquiring Swiss property, settling their families in Swiss cantons and sending their children to school here. By 1996 Switzerland was issuing visas to roughly 70,000 former Soviet citizens annually, compared with 4,000 two decades earlier.
Pressure for the liberal visa policy, officials said, stemmed from local cantonal goverments, which welcomed the free-spending Russians. But the banks, too, urged the Government to grant the visas. Refusal, they said, only provoked the Russians to refuse Swiss bankers entry into Russia.
Problems extended to other former Soviet regions. Late last year the Swiss police arrested a former Ukrainian Prime Minister, Pavel Lazarenko, and indicted him on money laundering charges. He was released on $3 million bail and fled to the United States, where he is now under arrest in California.
Mr. Ziegler said Swiss attitudes toward money from Russia and former Soviet republics began to change in 1996, with the arrest of Sergei Mikhailov, who is reputed to be the boss of the largest and most powerful criminal gang in Russia.
"Switzerland suddenly appeared to be harboring some of the headquarters of these people," said Mr. Ziegler, a sociology professor in Geneva. "We became alarmed."
Late last year Mr. Mikhailov, who had settled in a village near Geneva with his wife and two daughters, was tried by a Geneva court on charges of belonging to a criminal organization. He was acquitted for lack of evidence and returned to Moscow.
But Swiss fears had by then been deepened. There were suspicions that Mr. Mikhailov, who had begun buying up Swiss companies, had links to other bosses of the Russian underworld. These allegedly included Vyacheslav K. Ivankov, whom a Brooklyn court convicted of extortion in 1996, and Semyon Y. Mogilevich, a reputed boss of the Budapest underworld. The Ukrainian-born Mr. Mogilevich is now also suspected by the F.B.I. of having moved illicit funds through the Bank of New York, although he denies the allegations.
The Swiss response to suspicions about accounts held by former Soviet citizens and their companies has been streamlined by new laws. Legislation that took effect in April, for example, requires all banks and financial intermediaries to report suspicious practices suggesting money laundering. Previously laws prevented such disclosures.
Daniel Thelesklaf, director of a new office tracking money laundering, said about 160 cases had been reported to date, involving $220 million, up from 30 to 40 under the old legislation. Still, he concluded in a recent report that "the number of reports is still low, given Switzerland's importance as a financial center."
Last year the Swiss federal police set up a special unit to keep track of organized crime gangs from the former Soviet Union. Earlier this year a first report from the group traced a broad mosaic of Russian organized crime operating in Switzerland, with activities focused on the cantons of Geneva, Zurich and Ticino, and involving mainly money laundering.
The federal police spokesman in Bern, Folco Galli, said that for "insiders," the report was nothing spectacular. "It was the tip of the iceberg," he said.

HEADLINE: THE BIG STORM: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Names Disaster Areas In New Jersey

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

 BODY:
As homeowners in the lower Hudson Valley and northern New Jersey continued bailing water from their homes, President Clinton yesterday declared Federal disaster areas in four New York counties and eight counties in New Jersey.
The declaration makes homeowners and businesses in those counties eligible for Federal disaster relief, which could include housing, grants, low-cost loans and other assistance to speed recovery from last week's storm. 
 In New York, the declaration covered Orange, Rockland, Putnam and Westchester Counties. In New Jersey, the disaster areas were Somerset, Bergen, Essex, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Passaic and Union Counties.
About 125,000 homes in the two states still had no power yesterday, and tens of thousands have lost regular and cellular phone service. More than 200,000 people in 46 New Jersey towns were warned to boil water for three minutes before using it, after flood waters overwhelmed a treatment plant.
"This really was a major national disaster," Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday, speaking to reporters at a train station in Ossining, N.Y., where National Guard soldiers were shoveling mud and debris left by the swelling Sing Sing Creek. "A storm like this occurs maybe once every 200 years. It's something unprecedented."
"Now we need neighbor helping neighbor," he added. "We'll get through it. We'll come back strong. That's the way New Yorkers always are."
Meanwhile, under yesterday's seemingly incongruous late-summer sun and azure skies, teams of disaster specialists began wading through flood-ruined neighborhoods in New York and New Jersey, counting what is estimated to be hundreds of millions of dollars in damage caused by Hurricane Floyd.
Trains on the Harlem line of the Metro-North Railroad were operating only as far north as Chappaqua, N.Y. Railroad officials were still uncertain yesterday whether service to northern Westchester County would be restored by tomorrow. Amtrak, however, resumed service between New York and Washington.
In parts of northern New Jersey, National Guard troops kept increasingly desperate homeowners from returning to their flooded homes.
In Bound Brook, N.J., the waters receded and residents -- many of whom are veterans of earlier floods -- counted themselves lucky to have lost nothing more than their possessions.
"Light poles are down," said Mayor Frank Gilly, surveying the uncalculated devastation on Main Street. "Traffic signals are down. All the stores were full of water."
As floodwaters receded, search teams in Bound Brook went through 200 waterlogged homes to look for anyone who might still be inside.
"Now it looks like a big mudslide," Somerset County's emergency management director, LeRoy Gunzelman, said. "The water's gone, and there's mud and debris all over the roads. The structures have to be tested today to see if they're even safe enough for the search-and-rescue team."
Mr. Gunzelman said 700 evacuees were resting this morning in the emergency shelter at Bound Brook High School.
In New York State, about 600 National Guard troops and an equal number of State Department of Transportation workers were busy yesterday repairing damaged roads and electric cables, state disaster relief officials said.
Two-truck crews of utility workers slowly worked their way down rural lanes in Putnam County checking for problems and turning on power in increments, sometimes a few houses at a time.
"It looks like there's millions of dollars' worth of damage," said Dennis Michalski, a spokesman for the New York Emergency Management Office. "There's definitely hundreds and hundreds of homes in New York State that have been damaged."
The lower Hudson Valley, he added, "really got hammered."
But the most damage was clearly in the nine-county region of northern New Jersey, particularly in Bound Brook, Manville and Lodi, where some rivers had yet to crest, state and Federal officials said.
"Those will be probably the areas where we find the most damage," said Michael Dabney, regional operations director for the Federal Emergency Management Agency's office in New York City.
In Rochelle Park, N.J., high waters caused problems at a key telephone switching center. Nearly one million long-distance phone customers, mostly in Passaic and Bergen Counties, were without service on Friday because of water damage to the switching center, and even some A.T.M. and credit card transactions were temporarily shut down.
An AT&T spokesman, David Johnson, said tens of thousands of mobile-phone customers in New York and New Jersey were still without service yesterday.
Though crews were working around the clock to fix the damage, he said, it was not certain that service would be restored by tomorrow.
Several train lines in the region were slowly coming back to life. Amtrak's Northeast Corridor service, which had been suspended between New York City and Washington on Thursday evening because of flooding in the Trenton station, resumed operations on the route early yesterday morning, said an Amtrak spokesman, Rick Remington.
Amtrak trains were still not able to run through flooded areas of Richmond and several points south, however, Mr. Remington said.
Officials were also assessing damage in a handful of towns in western Roberta Hershenson for The New York Times
Connecticut. By far the worst damage was in Danbury, in northern Fairfield County, where about 350 homes were damaged by flooding, and the Danbury Fair Mall remained surrounded by water yesterday.
"The Connecticut River is taking runoff from all of New England," said John T. Wiltse, director of the Connecticut Office of Emergency Management. But he said flooding would not be severe.
About 5,000 residents remained without power in Connecticut, utility company officials said.

HEADLINE: Latinos Gain Visibility In Cultural Life of U.S.

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
Lucy Lopez is 72 years old, but she still remembers the name of her kindergarten teacher: Miss Jones. On the first day of school, Miss Jones put Lucy in a corner for not knowing how to count to four in English.
So when she had children, Lucy and her husband, Gabriel, both born in Texas of Mexican parents, gave some of them non-Hispanic names like Debra Susan and Adam Floyd. They spoke to the children only in English. 
 But for the third Lopez generation, there is less pressure to choose between two cultures. Sofia Angela Lopez, 16, a granddaughter, postponed her quinceanera, the traditional 15th birthday celebration, so she could have a Sweet 16 party instead. She sings alternative rock in English, and hymns at Mass in Spanish. When she debates history with her father, he sounds like a Mexican in Texas and she sounds like a Texan of Mexican descent.
"He sees America as, 'This was Mexico, this was our land,' that kind of attitude," she said. "I feel it was Mexico, but to tell you the truth, I don't really know how Mexico is. I'm more like, 'This is America now.' "
The America of Sofia Lopez is an increasingly Hispanic nation, home to 31 million people of Latin ancestry, a rapidly growing number that in the next five years is expected to surpass African-Americans as the largest minority group and will most likely make up a fourth of the nation's population in 50 years, a demographic trend that has provoked both debate and celebration. Even as Californians vote to end bilingual education, news magazines proclaim and applaud the Latinization of popular culture.
But what the growth has also done is help "Latinize" many Hispanic people who are finding it easier to affirm their heritage. And as they find strength in numbers, as younger generations grow up with more ethnic pride and as a Latin influence starts permeating fields like entertainment, advertising and politics, Latinos are becoming visible in ways that offer glimpses of what their larger presence may mean for the United States.
So right does Carlos J. Guerrero, 34, a Houston businessman and Texas native, feel about his heritage these days that he just ordered his first guayabera shirt, through the Internet. So right it feels to be Latino, said Nestor Rodriguez, 51, co-director of the University of Houston's Center for Immigration Research, that he no longer regards tacos as a "peasant's meal."
"It's not that we're regaining our culture," Mr. Rodriguez said. "It's that now tacos are everybody's meal."
Jose Alberto Medrano, 24, a political science student at the University of Houston and a legislative aide, has even stopped going by Albert, the name he used in grade school.
"It just didn't feel threatening to be Jose anymore," the Chicago-born Mr. Medrano said. "I used to feel I would be discriminated against, that it wouldn't be socially acceptable. It's cool to be Hispanic now." (Last year Jose replaced Michael as the most popular newborn boy's name in Texas and California.)
At Youth Engaged in Service College Preparatory School, the charter school Sofia attends in Houston, a group of classmates discussed what they rejected of their parents' culture. They tended to identify attitudes and beliefs: deep religiousness, or the sexism that limits the aspirations of girls.
"My mom thinks girls should not play sports," said Elvia Flores, 16, who came to the United States from Mexico at age 6 and who plays soccer.
At the same time, however, there was no trace of shame, no fear of appearing foreign for embracing other parts of the culture. They all spoke Spanish, although some of them admitted to speaking poorly. Sofia, who aspires to be "a lawyer or F.B.I. agent," said she planned to pass on to her children what she termed "sentimental" traditions, like observing the Day of the Dead. And they all find inspiration in the achievements of any Latino, whether Jennifer Lopez, the Puerto Rican movie star, or Sammy Sosa, the Dominican home run star.
Such comfort level with heritage is far higher than that of the previous generation. John Lantigua, a Miami journalist and novelist whose father was a Cuban immigrant and whose mother was a Puerto Rican, said his parents pursued the American dream in the 1950's by moving from the Bronx to the New Jersey suburbs and forbidding him to speak Spanish.
"I used to find scrapbooks in my house from the days before I was born, when my parents would go out to the Palladium and the Copacabana," Mr. Lantigua, 51, said. "I knew my parents had had this other life that I wasn't encouraged to have."
Many members of Mr. Lantigua's generation reacted by trying to recover what had been denied them, self-consciously immersing themselves in Latin culture.
"As I was planning my life, I knew I didn't want to live like that, with that lack of connection to a community," Mr. Lantigua said. "I've spent my whole adult life going back to it, to reconnect with that culture."
David E. Hayes-Bautista, 53, a Mexican-American who is director of the Center for the Study of Latino Health at the University of California at Los Angeles, also grew up with parents who "thought the best they could do was to protect us from being Latino."
"The Chicano movement was a reaction to that," Mr. Hayes-Bautista said. "We used to worry about whether a true Chicano would eat a hamburger. My children would say, 'What? That's crazy. Eat a burger if you're hungry.'
"They don't worry about losing anything. They are surrounded by people like them."
So much so that in the age of "Livin' La Vida Loca" and "Yo quiero Taco Bell," when the Hispanic presence is increasingly prominent in the popular culture, Sofia Lopez's parents worry that their daughter, who is growing up in a mostly Hispanic neighborhood and attends a mostly Hispanic school, will end up too Americanized.
"Our culture gets lesser and lesser as times change," said Sofia's mother, Oralia Lopez.
The phenomenon of assimilation alongside cultural affirmation is not unlike that experienced by other ethnic groups as they set roots in this country, some experts say. But the Hispanic population is likely to make its presence more deeply felt, these experts say, because Latinos make up the largest ethnic and linguistic group to arrive; they retain ties to their geographically close countries of origin, and the migration is continuing. All those factors reinforce Hispanic culture and the Spanish language while at the same time, assimilation dilutes them.
But because Hispanic people fall under many categories, many sociologists said, it is far from certain what kind of imprint their growth will make on the nation or how exactly they will broaden what it means to be an "American." With origins in 22 countries, some Latinos are English speakers and others are Spanish speakers; some are Americans with centuries-old roots here and others have just arrived.
What it means to be "Hispanic," a Census Bureau label as much as anything, is a matter of opinion. Today among the Lopezes here, in an extended family of more than 50 members, some describe themselves as white, some as Mexican, some as American Tex-Mex. So diverse is the Hispanic population -- in race, color and ethnic background, among other things -- that statistics on income and education are misleading, demographers say.
And despite a persistent image of Latinos as poor, Spanish-speaking immigrants, census figures show that more than 60 percent speak English fluently and are native born, and market researchers classify 75 percent of Hispanic households as middle or upper class. Latinos make up about 11 percent of the nation's total population, with Mexican-Americans accounting for more than 60 percent of them.
Many sociologists say that all evidence points to continuing assimilation, and some see no major changes beyond an expansion of the visibility that large Hispanic populations already have in the 10 states where they are concentrated.
But these states, particularly California, Texas, New York, Florida and Illinois, are also pivotal in Presidential elections. That fact helps explain why candidates like Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas find themselves struggling to speak Spanish. As the Hispanic population numbers translate into votes, some Hispanic organizations predict, issues like quality of education and wage minimums, which disproportionately affect Latinos because of their high percentages of young people and large families, will become more prominent.
Yet for all the media attention and the rapid growth of Spanish-language media, Hispanic organizations and business leaders still express frustration, saying that Latinos seem invisible in the mainstream culture.
As the media rave over pop stars like Ricky Martin, who is Puerto Rican, several Latino groups are calling for a boycott of network television this month to protest the absence of Latinos in major roles.
"It's black and white, white and black -- it's not black, brown and white," said Jeff Valdez, a Los Angeles television producer who is negotiating with investors to form a cable network for English-speaking Latinos to fill what he calls "a huge void." He added, "The reality is that there are more opportunities, but it's still got a long way to go."
Cecilia Munoz, policy director for the National Council of La Raza, a civil rights organization, said Latinos ultimately need economic and educational equality, which she said she hoped would come with increased integration.
"We've been discovered again," she said. "One hopes we reach a point when we're no longer being discovered anymore."
In San Antonio, Mike U. Villareal, 28, a computer company owner with a master's degree from Harvard University, is running for Texas state representative in the Democratic primary next March. As he walked the streets of his district recently on a "listening tour" of voters, Mr. Villareal said he wanted to be part of what he expected to be Texas's transition from "a Republican, Anglo-dominant" state to one that is more inclusive of the state's entire population, currently 28 percent Hispanic, 12 percent non-Hispanic black and 58 percent non-Hispanic white.
The country he envisions 50 years from now is not a lot different from that of today, he said, except for "different characters at the decision-making table."
"The growth of the Latino population is a wrench thrown into our system that will require us to make positive adjustments," Mr. Villareal said. "Issues that are on our minds will be in the minds of the rest of the country because we're all in the same boat."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
The Majors Are Still Leading All Leagues in Turnovers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With 17 teams changing hands in the 90's, Major League Baseball appears to be either such a poor investment that owners can't get rid of their clubs quickly enough, or such a good investment that prospective buyers stand in line and make offers the owners can't refuse.
Which way should a listener think Commissioner Bud Selig views the development? 
 "Do I find the turnover distressing? Yes, I do," Selig said after the owners met in Cooperstown, N.Y., last week. "We're desperately trying to find solutions that will stop all this buying and selling of franchises. When I came into baseball in the 70's, you had almost no turnovers."
Ah yes, the good old 70's. The first turnover of the 70's was executed by Selig himself, with partners, in their purchase of the Seattle Pilots and the team's move to Milwaukee on the eve of the 1970 season. That was the decade, too, in which George Steinbrenner and his limited partners (of whom nothing so limited ever existed) purchased the Yankees.
Brad Corbett bought the Texas Rangers, Ray Kroc the San Diego Padres, Bill Veeck the Chicago White Sox (again), Ted Turner the Atlanta Braves, Bob Lurie the San Francisco Giants, John McMullen the Houston Astros, Edward Bennett Williams the Baltimore Orioles, and a whole succession of businessmen -- three to be exact -- the Cleveland Indians.
The Indians, in fact, were turned over so often in the 70's that they alone kept the ownership committee in full-time employment.
The point isn't that Selig has selective memory or poor memory, but that the revolving changes of ownership in the 90's are nothing new. Increasing, yes, but new, no. From a dozen changes in the 70's to 15 in the 80's (including the sale of three teams twice each) to 17 in the 90's. Of course, if the owners last Wednesday had approved the sale of the Kansas City Royals and the Oakland Athletics, the 90's total would have reached 19. And that's not counting the pending sale of the Mets to Charles Dolan of Cablevision, the coming change at the Montreal Expos and the sale, yet again, of the Indians, though this time the owner, Richard Jacobs, is operating in a seller's market.
Baseball, however, isn't alone in the financial game of mergers and acquisitions. It's happening all around the nation, with media companies, accounting firms and investment outfits as well as other sports. The Knicks and the Rangers have been sold and bought so often this decade that the ink was hardly dry on some of the players' paychecks.
The proliferation of corporate owners in baseball will most likely add to the turnover, whether the commissioner and other officials like it or not.
Four teams that changed owners in this decade were ingested by corporations: the Braves by Time Warner in its purchase of Turner Broadcasting, the Los Angeles Dodgers by Rupert Murdoch and Fox, the Toronto Blue Jays by Interbrew of Belgium in its purchase of John Labatt Limited and the Anaheim Angels by the Walt Disney Company.
But just as typical of a giant conglomerate, Disney now looks to sell the Angels, as well as its hockey team, the Mighty Ducks. "I am very concerned about the Disney sale," Selig said. "I think the Disney sale points up exactly what I've been talking about here. Here's Disney, one of the great entertainment companies in the world. The fact that they're selling is a matter of concern."
But if Selig views Disney's plan as a commentary on the state of baseball ownership, Gary Bettman, the National Hockey League commissioner, has to have similar concerns. Or maybe it's simply that Disney, after getting a taste, has decided professional sports isn't the economic environment it wants to play in.
"There's a reason we've had the stunning turnover we've had since 1990-91," Selig said. "It's the deeper economic issues that are forcing it."
The commissioner sees those economic issues working on both sides of the deal. They are prompting owners to sell, he believes, but they are also making purchases difficult in some instances. He didn't have Murdoch's $311 million purchase of the Dodgers in mind.
"The game's economics have made the sale of clubs extremely difficult," he said. "Quite candidly, the smaller the market, the more difficult they are. We've had a huge turnover in ownership and therefore we're extremely sensitive. We have people who come in and a year or two later are ready to go back out. They say they wish they had known; nobody had told them."
Selig spoke about the problems in the context of the owners' decision to withhold approval of the prospective new owners of the Royals and the Athletics. He declined to offer specific reasons for the stance, but it was hard not to infer reasons from the comments he did make.
"No action was taken on the Kansas City proposed transaction," Selig said, "while additional alternatives are considered." Translation: the Royals should find a different buyer, one with fewer investors than the Miles Prentice group of 42 and with more money to spend on operations.
"The proposed sale of Oakland was tabled," the commissioner said, "pending receipt of the report of the commissioner's blue ribbon panel on baseball economics." Translation: the panel may propose that baseball abandon the Bay Area as a two-team market and recommend the Athletics move. "What we're trying to do," Selig said, "is make sure with each sale it is a long-term viable solution to baseball's problems."
By not approving the Oakland group, however, the owners might have invited legal action, if not by the prospective buyers then by the City of Oakland and Alameda County.
 
Losing 20 Games
This is a critical time for Brian Kingman. He has spent a decade rooting for himself, and now he is in the final two weeks of his quest. Steve Trachsel and his three possible starts are all that stand in Kingman's way.
"This has been a key year for me," Kingman said, "the last year of the century."
Kingman pitched for the Oakland Athletics and lost 20 games in 1980. No pitcher has been a 20-game loser since. "It was an embarrassment and a painful feeling at the time," Kingman said. "Then a few years went by and I said why isn't anyone else doing this? I decided I wanted to hold onto it and be the last one to lose 20 in the 20th century."
Trachsel has 17 losses. The Cubs' schedule would allow him to make three more starts, the last possibly on the final day of the season.
When Trachsel suffered his 14th loss July 24 at Shea Stadium, he seemed to be a lock for 20 losses. But he has lost only 3 of his 10 starts since then.
"He still has a chance; I don't want to celebrate too soon," said Kingman, now 45 and part owner of a check-cashing chain in southern California. "He could squeeze by. I wonder if he had 19 would they make him pitch on the last day of the year."
Kingman has made a study of 20-game losers. He found that Phil Niekro lost 20 the year before he did, that Cy Young was a 20-game loser three times, that Walter Johnson was a two-timer and that 19 pitchers in the Hall of Fame lost 20. Also, the same year Kingman lost 20 with a 3.83 earned run average, Dennis Leonard won 20 with a 3.79 e.r.a.
His worst memory of his career year might be that he reached his nadir playing for Billy Martin.
"If you could think of the worst manager to lose 20 for, it was Billy Martin," Kingman said. "He liked to have a scapegoat for any loss, umpires, coaches, whoever. That year it was me a lot."

HEADLINE: The Air and the S.U.V.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Sept. 15 Business Day article describes how car companies are promoting high-mileage light-truck versions of small cars in order to sell more high-consumption sport utility vehicles, since "surveys show that with gasoline prices low, consumers care very little about fuel economy." However, "as buyers have switched from cars to light trucks, fuel economy has declined, increasing the nation's dependence on imported oil and increasing emissions of gases that many scientists have linked to global warming." 
 Although I doubt there will be a sudden epiphany among S.U.V. enthusiasts over the dangers of global warming, surely they will listen to the warning about dependence on foreign oil. The American economy, however buoyant, is not bulletproof. The unlimited joys of the marketplace really do have limits, and we are reaching them.
 
LARRY SOLWAY
Toronto, Sept. 15, 1999
