HEADLINE: North Carolina Reeling in Hurricane's Aftermath

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: ROCKY MOUNT, N.C., Sept. 19

 BODY:
Three days after Hurricane Floyd struck eastern North Carolina, almost two-thirds of the state remained virtually paralyzed today, with entire towns inundated, the death toll mounting, and 300 roads, including long stretches of Interstates 40 and 95, shut down.
State officials, calling the destruction an agricultural disaster, said the farming terrain has become the tomb of at least 110,000 hogs and more than 1 million chickens and turkeys. 
 Today, under pristine skies washed by 20 inches of rain, no one could fathom the actual human death toll, officially 23, because no one knows what lies under the stagnant brown swill of rivers like the Tar, the Neuse and the Cape Fear, which have overflowed their banks and flooded thousands of acres of lowland even before they have crested. And more rain was forecast for Monday and Tuesday.
A state of emergency was declared in 28 counties; 3,000 National Guardsmen were on duty, and state officials called for reinforcements from the Marines. Officials estimated that agricultural losses could exceed $1 billion.
Officials pointed at the devastation that will greet President Clinton on Monday, when he is expected to fly to Raleigh and tour the flooded region where the hurricane's aftermath has been the most severe.
Mr. Clinton has already declared the eastern two-thirds of the state a disaster area, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which is providing guidance to homeowners who call its 800 number, will start setting up tents in cities like Rocky Mount, an old textile and tobacco city of 60,000 about 50 miles northeast of Raleigh, to take applications for loans and other forms of assistance.
Eight people in Rocky Mount alone were missing, Police Chief William Hogan reported, and one man apparently drowned there after trying to drive across a surging Stony Creek, which feeds the Tar River. A second body was found in the river today.
Mayor Frederick E. Turnage of Rocky Mount said six bodies had been brought to Nash General Hospital here, which serves Rocky Mount and the two counties the city straddles, Nash and Edgecombe. No one knew if the six were among those reported missing.
Among the 23 confirmed dead in the state were four members of a Pinetops family whose boat carrying 11 people capsized when they tried to escape their flooded home on Thursday. Two neighbors died with them, but the five others in the boat survived.
The storm claimed at least 49 lives from the Bahamas into New England. And beyond North Carolina, thousands of people were still without electricity and phone service in parts of Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New York.
With some North Carolina rivers still to crest and the forecast of more rain, officials warned about extraordinary environmental damage. They cited threats to public health from water supplies contaminated by chemicals from flooded factories and by the carcasses of livestock.
The Tar River at Tarboro, about 20 miles east of here, was already estimated at 43 feet and still rising. The old record was 34 feet, set in 1919.
A tropical depression that formed this weekend in the Gulf of Mexico became Tropical Storm Harvey today when its winds reached 34 miles an hour.
The storm, with winds of 45 miles an hour, was mostly stationary late tonight about 330 miles southwest of St. Petersburg, Fla., but was expected to begin moving to the northeast.
Forecasters expected it would bring only a half-inch of rain or less to the Southeast, but officials in North Carolina said any additional rain would hurt.
"More rain on top of what they've already experienced just compounds the problems and misery they've already been through," a state emergency management spokesman, Tom Hegele, said.
North Carolina, and in particular its eastern, storm-torn third, is the nation's largest producer of turkeys, its second-largest producer of hogs and its third-largest producer of chickens. Officials fear an economic toll on farmers exceeding the $872 million of Hurricane Fran in 1996.
National Guard helicopters searched for stranded people and shuttled food to stricken towns where grocery shelves were bare. Drinkable water had to be rushed to several counties where waste-water treatment systems had failed.
"We have a great big mess around there," said Donald Reuter, a spokesman for the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources. "We've got flooded waste-water treatment plants. We've got warehouses and industrial facilities that are leaking things. We have no idea what they are."
Jon Parks, a spokesman for the North Carolina Division of Emergency Management, said Interstate 40, running southeast from Raleigh, remained shut down from Newton Grove to the coastal city of Wilmington, more than 75 miles; Interstate 95, running north and south through Rocky Mount, was closed from Benson north into Virginia, almost 150 miles.
Mr. Parks said Sprint and US Cellular had reported about 100,000 customers without telephone service. Electrical power, which 1.5 million customers lost in the peak of the storm, had been returned to all but 133,000, he said. Other figures ran higher, to 147,000.
Storm victims have moved into more than 80 shelters.
Inland from the coast, the hurricane was a water storm more than a wind storm. In Rocky Mount, mobile homes, rendered to sticks in the highest winds, still stand. Road signs, bent in high winds, are nearly all intact.
But small roadside offices that seem to have survived have been flooded. Convenience stores in and near downtown, normally open on Sundays, were closed today, their shelves and floors swamped. Murky brown lakes have settled into acres of parking lots, fields and back yards.
Lawns are coated with wind-stripped leaves and small branches, but relatively few toppled trees. Those trees that fell lost their footing to the rampaging Tar.
A big blue sheet covers the roof of a Colonial house in the affluent neighborhood of West Haven. Shepard Yenney was talking to her father on the phone there when the storm hit. "I was saying, 'Gosh, Dad, we must be on the good side of this storm.' Then I heard something like a bomb go off."
Cabinets collapsed, cans covered the kitchen floor, and her boys, ages 4 and 8, screamed. The storm had dislodged the neighbor's huge white oak, which knocked out the Yenneys' chimney and their rafters.
Reaching from one end of the house to the other, Mrs. Yenney said, "It covered the whole house like a rainbow."
She said she was lucky.
"A friend of mine had to lower her three kids from their bedrooms to a boat," she said.
One man was standing on his roof firing his shotgun so someone would see him.
"Old folks had to swim out of their houses," Mrs. Yenney said. In a more affluent part of town, "you wouldn't believe the things floating by, like chairs used by George Washington."
The acres behind the Yenney house slope gently toward the bank of the Tar, hundreds of yards away. Built onto those acres is a cul-de-sac that today was a chest-deep lake with just the roofs of abandoned cars in front of the houses. The front door of one house was ajar, a sign of possible looting.
To prevent looting, city officials imposed 7 P.M.-to-7 A.M. curfews Friday and Saturday nights and were planning another for tonight. Mayor Turnage and the City Manager, Stephen Raper, estimated that hundreds of homes among Rocky Mount's 20,000 residences, including apartments, were ruined or heavily damaged.
"The water came up so quickly, so ferociously, it stranded people who never expect to see water," Mr. Turnage said.
Paul and Jolynn Melton, parents of a 6-year-old, an 11-year-old and an 11-month-old, had a view of the water, the gentle Tar, one lot removed from their small brick ranch house on Paul Road.
The walls and roof of their house stand, but the interior has been gutted. What there was of a lawn looks like a dry sea bottom now, the grass coated with mud, pebbles and debris.
The Meltons were loading a pickup truck today, salvaging two bicycles, boxes of clothes, the head and foot boards of a double bed, a rocking horse and a lawn mower.
"At 5:30 Thursday morning, there were 3 or 4 inches of water in the yard," said Mr. Melton, a warehouse supervisor for a store chain. "An hour later, it was on the porch. By lunchtime, it was halfway up the windows."

HEADLINE: Principals Quit New York City At Record Pace

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
New York City principals are leaving their posts in record numbers, propelled by a festering four-year contract battle with the city, higher salaries in the suburbs and a campaign by the Schools Chancellor to rid the system of what he considers failing leaders.
While other large cities across the country are also facing a shortage of principals, New York City is grappling with what experts say is the largest number of leaderless schools in its history. While some principals were dismissed in a drive to weed out poor performers, some of the system's most highly regarded leaders have left for other reasons. 
 The exodus comes at a time when the very top teachers' salaries will soon surpass those of most principals, when schoolchildren face the toughest promotional standards in decades and when the system has been thrown into confusion by flawed reading-test scores and the mistaken assignment of thousands of students to summer school.
"There are more vacancies for principals and a greater dearth of qualified candidates than I've seen in the last 40 years," said Seymour Fliegel, a senior fellow at the Center for Educational Innovation, a New York City research institute. "It's only going to get worse. If they care about the children, the city and the union will settle this right now."
When the school year began on Sept. 9, about 16 percent, or 195 of the city's 1,200 schools, opened without permanent principals, Board of Education officials said.
Neither the New York City Board of Education nor the principals' union, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, could provide exact figures on how many principals have left the system for the suburbs. But union leaders, who have been negotiating for pay increases, estimated that about half the vacancies were created when principals were lured away for higher pay.
School districts in Westchester County, New Jersey and Long Island pay principals up to $30,000 more than the city, which has a minimum average salary of about $70,000. New York City principals have not received a raise since October 1995 and have been without a contract since February 1996, widening the gap between what the city and the suburbs pay. When a new salary scale for teachers goes into effect in December, the most experienced teachers working in the new Chancellor's district of 40 failing elementary and middle schools will make $80,000 -- more than many principals.
City leaders, however, paint the exodus in positive colors, saying it reflects the efforts to rid the system of incompetent principals. Dr. Crew and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have been reluctant to sign an agreement with the principals' union, saying they believe the tenure system protects inept school leaders. Under the current system, which is written into state law, principals cannot be transferred without union permission and cannot be demoted or dismissed without what can become long disciplinary hearings.
The city has offered the principals' union a raise of 33 percent and three-year renewable contracts if principals agree to give up tenure and work a longer year. The union represents about 4,500 principals, assistant principals and other administrators.
But the city is in a bind. While trying to weed out underperforming principals by repealing the tenure law, it is losing principals like Arnold M. Goldstein, who left in June for an affluent school district in Long Island.
For five years, he was principal of one of the city's prized schools: Benjamin N. Cardozo High in Bayside, Queens, where almost all graduating seniors go on to four-year colleges. In 1998, Newsweek magazine listed Cardozo as one of the top 100 schools in the country.
Mr. Goldstein said that he was reluctant to leave, but that the decision was an economic one. As principal of Jericho High School in Jericho, N.Y., he makes about 50 percent more than the $80,000 he made in New York City after 25 years of service. Cardozo is more than six times larger than Jericho High, which has about 700 students.
"It was a difficult decision," said Mr. Goldstein. "It took me several weeks to decide to go for it. It was an opportunity to work in a small school, and the salary certainly was a factor. I had to take it."
Henry L. Grishman, the Superintendent of Jericho's public schools, was unabashed in his recruitment of Mr. Goldstein in March. "There is an awareness in the suburbs that principals are working in the city without a contract and are not well paid or highly appreciated," Mr. Grishman said. "That obviously makes it easy for me to recruit a top high school principal from New York City."
Saul Yanofsky, the Superintendent of the White Plains School District, said that New York City has some of the best trained public school educators in the country. This year, he hired two assistant principals from Community School District 2 in Manhattan as principals.
Last year, Melvin B. Katz left as principal of Middle School 141 in Riverdale, the Bronx, to lead Glenfield Middle School in Montclair, N.J. He now makes $92,500, about $12,000 more than he made in New York City after 33 years. "I left because of the money and low morale," Mr. Katz said. "There was less respect and increased responsibility, which I could have dealt with. I think you will find that true of almost all my colleagues who have left."
Not only are principals leaving New York City, but, in addition, few qualified teachers are willing to step up to the plate because it would mean a pay cut for a far more stressful job. Filling the 195 vacancies will not be easy. It involves committees comprising parents, teachers and union representatives, and can be a drawn-out process tainted by petty politics.
New York, whose school system was once the most prestigious in the country, is not alone. From Washington to Philadelphia to Los Angeles, school systems report a shortage of principals, said Vincent L. Ferrandino, the executive director of the 30,000-member National Association of Elementary School Principals, a nonprofit organization based in Alexandria, Va.
A number of factors have come together to make leading a school far less attractive than in the past. These include higher salaries for teachers, increased accountability, longer hours, a longer year and high-stakes testing, where one flagging performance by a school's students can cost a principal a job. While most cities used to provide principals with tenure, many, like Chicago, repealed the laws in the face of failing schools. Now, they offer renewable contracts based on performance.
The principal shortage is so pronounced that New York's crown jewel, Stuyvesant High School, which admits students based on a stiff entrance exam, received only about two dozen applications last year while searching for a new principal. That number was down about 75 percent from previous searches, including five years ago when Jinx Cozzi-Perullo was hired, Mr. Fliegel said. Ms. Cozzi-Perullo retired and was replaced this fall by Stanley Teitel.
"Superintendents all over the city are telling me they cannot get people who want to work as principals," Mr. Fliegel said. "Stuyvesant is the city's flagship school. Hundreds of people should want to work there."
Peter M. Comeau, a co-director of the Principals' Leadership Institute at Teachers College, Columbia University, surveyed about two dozen principals and about a half dozen superintendents last year when the fledgling group drew a weak response from people interested in the training.
"The lack of a contract was key," Mr. Comeau said. "They didn't talk so much about the money as much as they did about the loss of respect that seems to accompany the negotiations."
Over the years, principals became demonized as political hirelings. Some were handpicked by members of the city's 32 community school boards as favors to friends or relatives. But the 1996 school governance law removed the power to hire and fire principals from school boards and turned it over to district superintendents.
The aim was to stamp out patronage and corruption, and Dr. Crew was given broad new powers to remove underperforming principals, chiefly on charges of "persistent educational failure." When he failed to remove principals immediately, he was roundly criticized. Dr. Crew contended that the job protections of tenure forced him to place the bad principals elsewhere in the system.
But in June, Dr. Crew announced the dismissal of 58 principals at failing schools in the largest shake-up in the history of the school system. A majority had planned to retire anyway, and critics asserted that Dr. Crew included them in the tally -- which included even principals with distinguished careers -- to stanch criticism that he was not doing enough to remove failing principals.
Of the rest who were removed, some principals reverted to their previous job as assistant principal or teacher. About a dozen went to work elsewhere in the system, sometimes doing paperwork or supervising administrative projects at district offices, or at the Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn, said Jill Levy, executive director of the Council of Supervisors.
The reassignments underscore the city's need to do away with tenure, said Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, one of the city's largest business groups.
"Principal tenure is a bizarre self-defeating system for the very people who shouldn't need it," said Mr. Kiley, who was instrumental in helping to pass the school governance law. "A person's job should rise and fall based on the performance of a school."
Some principals have come to agree. Last year, a dissident group of about 200 high school principals announced that it wanted to break away from the Council of Supervisors and Administrators and give up tenure protection. Members said they wanted to exchange tenure for higher pay and greater authority over hiring and firing.
The group never mobilized to secure collective bargaining power. But Jesse Lazarus, principal of Transit Tech High School in East New York, Brooklyn, and president-elect of the organization, said he still supports modifications to the tenure law if the new process is divorced from internal and city politics.
Anna Switzer, principal of P.S. 234, the Independence School in TriBeCa, one of the highest-performing schools on the citywide third- and fourth-grade tests last year, also supports modifications to the tenure law if there is job protection.
"What I hear a lot from the Mayor and the Chancellor is they need a mechanism to fire bad principals," said Ms. Switzer, who has been in the system for 25 years. "They also have to pay attention to the fact that they cannot replace principals in New York City. The work conditions are hard, salaries are low, the system is under-resourced and the classes are big. Very many of us could work elsewhere. Anywhere else we go would be easy."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Web Sites Offer a New Lure for Writers: Wealth on Paper

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER and COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
Casting about for ways to raise its profile, Nerve.com, a little-known Web site billing its contents as "literary smut," last week sent out come-ons to 60 of the country's best-known writers, from Joyce Carol Oates to John Updike, offering them not just $2 a word for their contributions, but a package of stock options in the company.
Options, the speculative scrip given mythic status by the success of some Internet start-ups, are seeping into the literary and journalistic world, as Nerve.com has taken its cue from Web sites like Salon and TheStreet.com, both of which have used stock options to lure or reward freelance talent. 
 Never mind that Nerve.com is still romancing venture capitalists, and a long way away from an initial public offering or acquisition -- events that would eventually give the options whatever bankable value they may have. Rufus Griscom, 28, who is Nerve's editor in chief and chief executive, boasts that "next week we will have a Pulitzer Prize-winner" committed to write for the site.
Mr. Griscom's effort to find a name-brand literary asset to call his own -- and subvert the economics of the freelance writing business -- comes as name-brand writers are slowly turning up on the Web. David Talbot, the editor of Salon, the San Francisco-based Webzine, has Garrison Keillor and Camille Paglia as regular contributors. He said that he had offered stock options to about 10 of Salon's best-known freelance writers and illustrators -- but would not say which.
The options in Salon, which offered stock to the public in June for an initial price of $10.50, "allow recipients to purchase Salon shares for $1 or less in most cases," according to Todd Hagen, Salon's chief financial officer.
"I have used options for consultants and contractors for years," Mr. Hagen, who has handled the financial affairs of Web companies and software companies, said. "The concept of using options isn't unique. What is unique is that we as a media company are doing it with columnists and freelancers."
Scott Moore, publisher of Slate.com, an on-line magazine owned by the Microsoft Corporation, said he had not heard of the practice of offering stock options to freelancers. "There are plenty of fantasy stories of people hitting it rich off Internet stock option payments," Mr. Moore added. "But these offerings could be completely worthless, too." For Slate, he said, it would make little sense -- the magazine is owned by Microsoft, making the currency of options too valuable for this purpose.
Joyce Carol Oates, one of those who received the offer from Nerve, said: "I really don't write for the Web. I'm not a Web person." Gay Talese, another writer on Nerve's list, said: "I don't know why this would have any appeal. It has no appeal to me." He said he thought such a speculative deal "would have a one in 10,000 chance of working out."
John Updike said he had not yet received Nerve's offer, adding, "I probably would not have responded anyway." He added, "Young writers may be willing to gamble writing for stock options, but at my advanced age, I prefer to get paid in dreary old cash."
The approach of Nerve, Salon and TheStreet.com has its parallels in other Web ventures. In May, Atomfilms.com, a privately owned on-line film distribution company, which buys licensing rights for independent short films, began offering artists stock packages along with cash payment for licensing rights to their films, said Heather Redman, senior vice president of business affairs for Atomfilms.com.
"It shouldn't be the reason an artist chooses us," Ms. Redman said. "It's more like this is something to put in the back of your underwear drawer and pull out if we make it big one day. There really isn't any worth to it until we go public or we're acquired."
Last March, Alanis Morissette, the rock singer, received a stock package payment from MP3.com, an Internet company that posts recordings for free downloading by users. Ms. Morissette agreed to endorse MP3.com, allowing the site to post exclusive photographs from her current tour. In return, MP3.com agreed to help sponsor the singer's tour and to pay a total of 436,000 shares, roughly 2 percent of the company, to Ms. Morissette and Atlas/Third Rail, an entertainment company in which her manager, Scott Welch, is a partner.
"They said they couldn't pay us in the traditional sense," Mr. Welch said. "So we took a handshake and the stock. We didn't know what it would be worth, but it didn't hurt that the deal was in all the papers with Alanis's picture next to it."
MP3.com went public on July 21 at $20, and its value soared, closing the first day of trading above $63. Since then it has retreated, closing last Friday at $32.625. But that still makes the stake owned by Ms. Morissette and Mr. Welch worth a total of $14.2 million. Mr. Welch declined to discuss how soon the two are entitled to sell some or all of those shares.
Stock-for-words deals are not entirely unprecedented. In 1953, when Hugh Hefner was putting together the first issue of Playboy, he persuaded more than half the contributing illustrators and writers to accept stock in lieu of cash for their work.
In a 1998 Playboy magazine article, Mr. Hefner quoted one early Playboy writer, Burt Zollo, who accepted stock, as saying, "I sold it the first day it was traded and became a millionaire."
Jonathan Weber, the editor in chief of The Industry Standard, a magazine focusing on Internet commerce and culture, said he believed the phenomenon of options payments would not last. "I would be surprised if it were the beginning of a trend," he said. "It's very much driven by the current hype about options."
Those who are not there when the options are passed out, he added, may not be missing much. "Most people who get stock options do not get rich," he said.
Dave Kansas, editor of TheStreet.com -- in which the New York Times Company has a minority stake -- offered options to some key freelance contributors earlier this year, before The Street.com made its initial public offering in May. "It's a good way to reward important contributors and it's a good way to make sure they stick with you over the longer term," he said.
Mr. Hagen, the chief financial officer at Salon, said that most of the options offered its writers vest -- meaning that the freelancers gain legal title to the options -- in stages over a four-year period, beginning one year after the initial offering last June. the stock is currently trading at $6.
Michael Lewis, a contributor to several magazines, including The New York Times Magazine, has written about his decision to turn down The Street.com's offer of a 2.5 percent stake a few years ago in return for writing a weekly column.
The illogical speculation in Internet stocks has created its own logic, at least temporarily, Mr. Lewis said in an interview. "For this brief moment, perceptions are creating their own reality," he said.
Mr. Griscom is only too happy to peddle his perceptions. "Everyone knows people are making a huge amount of money off these Internet companies and they want to participate in that," he said. He added, "The only way we can make a more generous offer than a New Yorker or a Vanity Fair is to offer fat stock options packages."
Will it all last? Mr. Lewis said he doubted it. "There will be astonishing aspects of capitalism in the near future," he said. "But this particular astonishing aspect won't last. I don't think it's sustainable for journalists to become millionaires, unless they cease to be journalists. I don't think they are that valuable economically. Culturally they're valuable, but not economically."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1999, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about Internet companies' use of stock options to attract freelance writers misstated the age of Rufus Griscom, editor in chief and chief executive of Nerve.com, one of those using the incentive. He is 31, not 28. The article also misstated a description his site has used about itself in the past. The phrase is "literate smut," not literary smut.

HEADLINE: Don't Give Up On Russia

BYLINE: By Robert E. Rubin; Robert E. Rubin was the 70th Secretary of the Treasury. Michael Froman, a fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and a former Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary, contributed to this article.

 BODY:
This morning, the House Banking Committee is scheduled to open hearings on the Clinton Administration's Russia policy. This debate can be useful, indeed helpful, provided it takes into account three important factors.
First, we must realize that the United States has a critical interest in Russia's stability and economic success and in its transition over time to a market democracy. Second, we must recognize the obstacles Russia faces in switching to a market economy. And third, we must realistically assess the choices the West faces, given the conditions in Russia and our own interests. 
 American self-interest in a democratic, market-oriented Russia has been at the core of the Administration's approach to supporting economic reform in Russia over the last six years. Throughout this period, we were fully aware that Russia's transition would take a long time to complete, with many ups and downs along the way. We were also aware that all of our decisions involved probabilistic judgments -- weighing many possible outcomes and the consequences of each, based on the information available at the time. There were no guarantees.
While the Soviet Union's spectacular collapse in 1991 may have led some to expect too much, too soon, the Clinton Administration and the international community realized that Russia's path from bankrupt Communism to a vibrant market democracy would have to overcome enormous obstacles. Unlike many countries in Central Europe, Russia had no memory of a functioning market economy. Contract law and property rights would have to be created from scratch. Institutions to develop and enforce market regulations would have to be established. Judges to interpret the laws and regulations would have to be trained. And the rule of law would have to overcome the twin dangers of criminality and corruption, which were recognized from the start as critical impediments to a successful transition.
The rule of law is not established overnight. Nor is a market democracy. These are long-term objectives. In the short term, however, the United States had an enormous stake in providing the support necessary to create a stable environment in Russia, in promoting reform and in helping to ease the impact of this extremely difficult transition for the Russian people. Over time, reform itself is an important antidote to crime and corruption.
Given the challenges Russia faced, it would have been unrealistic to assume that Russia could shake 70 years of Communist baggage and become a full-fledged market democracy in less than a decade. Indeed, a successful transition is likely to take a long time to accomplish, and the United States, the other industrialized nations and the international financial institutions face no easy choices.
Obviously, great challenges lie ahead, but there have been important accomplishments. After a painful period of adjustment, basic elements of a market economy are in place. The United States and Russia have cooperated on foreign policy matters, including in the Balkans. And there have been significant achievements in other areas like arms control.
Clearly, Russia falls far short of the sort of market democracy we would like to see. But it might be useful to point out some of the other things Russia might have become, but did not. It's not a country whose policies are marked by virulent anti-Western nationalism. It's not a country that sank back into the sort of authoritarian state planning mode that characterized Communist regimes before 1991. And it's not a country that fell into total chaos or anarchy.
All of the things we've tried to accomplish could still come to pass. So could all the things we've tried to avoid. It is vitally in our interests that we do everything in our power to increase the probability of a constructive result.
In this context, engagement is a much preferred course of action to abandoning or isolating Russia. Engagement does not mean suspending critical judgment; quite the contrary. We need to be realistic about what can actually be accomplished, but we must also be prepared to deny Russia support, as we have in the past, if it fails to meet our conditions. Conditionality has to be an important part of any program.
In that regard, serious allegations have recently been raised about criminality, corruption and the possible misuse of International Monetary Fund money. Clearly, the appropriate authorities need to determine what the facts are and then respond appropriately. This is critical not only for Russia's economic future, but for our own efforts to combat international criminal activity.
This would be a complicated matter in any situation. But given our stake in Russia's success, we must approach it in a level-headed way. Only then will appropriate judgments be made about what course of action best serves the interests of the American people.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Dollar Slips,Cutting Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday as traders grew pessimistic when the dollar reversed course against the Japanese yen, declining after several days of gains.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 10/32 of a point to 100 26/32, sending its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 6.07 percent from 6.04 percent on Friday. 
 Yesterday's session was marked by quiet trading in which bond prices stayed within a tight range. Dealers attributed the slow day to the absence of many traders who were observing the Yom Kippur holiday and to a lack of new data on the economy.
Bond prices, as they had last week, followed fluctuations in the dollar against the Japanese yen. A week ago, the dollar fell to its lowest level in three and a half years against the Japanese currency. A rebound by the dollar late last week helped push bond prices higher. But yesterday, after gaining more ground early in the day, the dollar slipped back.
A falling dollar not only discourages foreign investors, but also makes imports more expensive in the United States, creating a degree of inflation pressure. Traders worry that the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee, which has already raised rates twice this year, may see a need for a third rate increase at its meeting on Oct. 5.
In the broader market, prices of short-term Treasury securities were up by 1/16 to 1/8, and intermediate maturities were up 7/32 to 5/16, according to Bridge Telerate, a financial information service.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were 4.65 percent as the discount rose 0.01 percentage point from Friday. to 4.53 percent. Six-month yields were 5.06 percent, as the discount rose 0.01 percentage point, to 4.86 percent. One-year yields were 5.24 percent, as the discount rose 0.03 point, to 4.97.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, rose to 5.19 percent from 5.06 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 9/32 , to 11229/32 . The average yield to maturity rose to 5.86 percent from 5.85 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Report by U.N. Agency Asks Trade Opening to 3d World

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Industrial nations must relax trade barriers and open their markets to the developing world, lest these third world countries be forced to rely on unpredictable foreign capital for economic growth, the United Nations trade and development agency said here today.
A study of some 40 developing countries showed increased trade deficits and declining economic growth, the agency, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, said in its annual report. It urged that the concerns of poorer countries be the centerpiece of forthcoming global trade negotiations, contending that market access, not foreign capital, was the key to growth. 
 Its concerns were seconded by the World Bank, which backed a far-reaching trade round today -- including agriculture and construction, areas of prime interest to emerging economies -- to start at the World Trade Organization's ministerial meeting in Seattle in November.
Joseph Stiglitz, chief economist for the World Bank, speaking to reporters at a meeting on developing countries that was organized along with the W.T.O., said that the "liberalization of agriculture should be a priority." Cutting back farm subsidies, a sensitive political issue, particularly in Europe, is on the agenda of the next round of trade negotiations, which is expected to last three years.
World Bank research indicated that a 40 percent reduction in global agricultural export subsidies would be as effective as an equal percentage reduction in manufacturing tariffs.
In the United Nations agency's annual review, Rubens Ricupero, head of the agency, said it had found that economic growth in the 1990's was an average of two percentage points below what it was two decades ago. At the same time, trade deficits were, on average, three points above their 1970's mark.
"Here we have the worst of two worlds," said Mr. Ricupero, a former Brazilian Finance Minister. "We have had a deterioration in trade balances, and a very sharp deterioration in trade deficits, whereas economic growth has been going downward."
 The "disturbing trend," he maintained, stems in large part from the sluggish growth in industrial economies, especially Japan and European Union nations. That, combined with other factors like trade barriers, has made it hard for developing countries to increase their exports enough to cover balance-of-payment deficits, which have been created by a surge of imports.
Predicted gains by third world countries from trade liberalization have not materialized in many cases, the 146-page report said. Instead, there has been increased poverty and unemployment.
Mr. Ricupero urged the advanced economies to "work harder to convince a sometimes skeptical public that there are direct benefits, in terms of more jobs and rising incomes, from expanding trade" with developing countries.
Opening market access to them means lowering tariffs and dismantling agricultural subsidies, which total some $350 billion -- twice developing nations' agricultural exports from 1996 to 1998, according to the report. It cited European Union producers of dairy products, who despite having the world's highest costs, have retained a 50 percent share of the world market.
Among other impediments to trade by third world countries, the report cited the use of health and safety standards to control imports, antidumping procedures and increasing export restraints.

HEADLINE: Battle Waged In the Senate Over Royalties On Oil Firms

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Oil companies drilling on Federal land have been accused of habitually underpaying royalties they owe the Government. Challenged in court, they have settled lawsuits, agreeing to pay $5 billion.
The Interior Department wants to rectify the situation by making the companies pay royalties based on the market price of the oil, instead of on a lower price set by the oil companies themselves. 
 A simple issue? Not in the United States Senate. Instead, it has become a textbook example of how Washington works. The battle over royalties shows how a senator can use legislation to right a wrong, in the view of Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican who is blocking the Interior regulations. Or it shows how Congress does favors for special interests, in the view of Senator Hutchison's opponents.
The issue could come to a vote this week, and it appears as if the Senate might side with the oil companies.
Senator Hutchison, who has received $1.2 million in contributions from oil companies in the last five years, has been winning the battle to block the pricing regulations since the Interior Department imposed them in 1995. The department estimates that oil companies are saving about $5 million a month, money that would otherwise be flowing to education, environmental programs and other projects.
Senator Hutchison calls the regulations a breach of contract and an unfair tax increase. She says she represents "the overwhelming majority of the Senate who want to do the right thing, who want fair taxation of our oil and gas industry."
For four years, she has placed amendments and riders into annual spending bills to keep the Interior Department regulations from taking effect. To do otherwise, she argues, would be "to let unelected bureaucrats make decisions that will affect our economy."
Senator Hutchison's chief antagonist has been Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat who has condemned the underpaying of royalties as a scheme intended to "rob this Treasury of millions and millions of dollars."
"We shouldn't have a double standard just because an oil company is powerful, just because an oil company can give millions of dollars in contributions," Senator Boxer said.
The Senate has never actually voted on Senator Hutchison's measure. It has been inserted into must-pass spending bills that provide a perfect vehicle for controversial measures that might attract public notice if they were openly debated.
This year, however, the Senate decided it would stop attaching such riders to appropriations bills. Now the Hutchison amendment has turned into a running battle on the Senate floor.
The Interior Department first proposed the regulations in December 1995, nearly 10 years after the State of California first began to suspect that energy companies were underpaying the royalties they owed on oil pumped from Federal and state land. The royalty is 12.5 percent for onshore drilling and 16.67 percent for offshore production.
For the industry's giants, the royalties are a small fraction of earnings. For the Exxon Corporation, they represent about one-eighth of 1 percent of company revenues. According to Interior Department figures, the new regulations would cost Exxon $8 million, an additional one-hundredth of a percent of revenues.
The money goes to the Treasury, which sends it to environmental and historic-preservation projects, and to 24 states, many of which use the money on education.
But instead of basing their royalties on the actual market price of oil, the energy companies have been using a price they set that has run as much as $4 a barrel less than the market price.
According to the sworn testimony of a retired Atlantic Richfield executive in a California lawsuit in July, the policy of his company and others was to pay royalties based on a price "at least four or five dollars below what we accepted as the fair market value." The retired executive, Harry Anderson, said his company's senior executives had decided "they would take the money, accrue for the day of judgment, and that's what we did."
The testimony was first reported by Platt's Oilgram News, a trade publication.
This practice allowed 18 oil companies, including Shell, Exxon, Chevron, Texaco and Mobil Oil, to avoid paying royalties of about $66 million a year, according to Interior Department figures published in the Congressional Record.
Sued by state governments, and now under investigation by the Justice Department, most of the major oil companies have signed settlements totaling about $5 billion with seven states.
But Ms. Hutchison says forcing the companies to pay royalties based of the true market price of oil amounts to an unfair tax increase.
"They are breaking a contract and saying: 'We are going to raise your taxes,' " she argued on the Senate floor this week.
"If we allow that to happen, who will be next?" the Senator asked. "Who is the next person who is going to have a contract and have the price increased in the middle of the contract? Contract rights are part of the basis of the rule of law in this country, and we seem to blithely going over it."
If the Hutchison amendment comes to a vote -- and it might this week -- it appears likely to pass, with support from almost all the Senate's 55 Republicans and a few oil-state Democrats.
If the Senate lets the regulations take effect, says Senator Frank Murkowski, an Alaska Republican who supports the amendment, the message will be clear: "We will be saying, 'Go ahead. Raise royalties and taxes. We, the U.S. Senate, yield our power.' "

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Issues Nudge Nasdaq Close to Its High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The big technology companies propelled the Nasdaq composite index within a point of a new closing record yesterday, capping a quiet session that left most stock indicators little changed.
The Nasdaq gained 16.53 points, or nearly six-tenths of a percent, to close at 2,886.15, just under its closing high of 2,887.06 set on Sept. 10. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average was up 20.27, or about two-tenths of a percent, at 10,823.90, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.11 point, or a hundredth of a percent, to 1,335.53.
But declining issues outnumbered those advancing three to two on the New York Stock Exchange, and the Russell 2000 index of smaller companies fell 1.25, to 433.20.
An array of technology companies pulled the Nasdaq higher. Sun Microsystems rose 5 7/8, to 94 9/16, after declaring a 2-for-1 split late on Friday. Aerial Communications, a maker of digital cellular phones, soared 6 5/8, to 26 5/8, after Voicestream Wireless agreed to acquire it for $3 billion in stock and cash.
Apple Computer rose 2 1/8, to 79 1/16, and Microsoft picked up 1 1/8, to 97 9/16.
After the close of the market, however, Apple announced that shipments, revenue and earnings for the current quarter would fall short because of smaller-than-expected deliveries of microprocessors from Motorola. Apple was lower in after-hours trading.
 The renewed strength over all in technology shares, however, provided a rare spark in one of the quietest sessions of the year, with many traders observing Yom Kippur yesterday.
Big Board volume was 568 million shares, compared with 842.63 million on Friday.
Analysts said that the dollar's fluctuations against the Japanese yen had kept the market somewhat off balance -- the dollar was up in the morning but closed down -- and that investors also appeared unwilling to take significant new positions in advance of the Federal Reserve's meeting on Oct. 5.
Stocks have been hurt in recent weeks by concerns that the Fed's Open Market Committee will raise interest rates for the third time this year. The committee raised rates twice this summer to avert inflation. With no significant inflationary data scheduled for release before the central bank meeting, some analysts say that stocks will remain in a narrow range.
"We expect the Dow industrial average will remain locked within a 10,500-to-11,500 range," said John H. Shaughnessy, chief investment strategist at Advest in Hartford. "Thereafter, we expect a very solid rally based on very positive earnings reports and growing investor confidence that future Fed rate hikes will likely be limited."
Philip S. Dow, director of equity strategy at Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis, said earnings reports, or advance notices of earnings surprises, would most likely be the inspiration for the market's next big move.
"Until then, it's hard to come up with any convincing arguments that the market should go way up or way down," he said.
Dole Food offered the latest evidence of investors' harshness toward companies that miss estimates. It fell 2 3/4, to 21 1/4, after the company said it expected to break even or record a slight loss for the third quarter, in contrast to analysts' predictions of earnings of 13 cents a share.
The strength in technology shares extended to the Dow yesterday. I.B.M. rose 4 3/4, to 130 1/8, and Hewlett-Packard was up 3 7/8, to 104 1/16, as both companies rebounded from losses on Friday.
General Electric rose 2, to 122, after a Merrill Lynch analyst, Jeanne Terrile, reinstated the stock as a Merrill Focus One issue, praising the company's Internet strategy.
Furon, a polymer manufacturer, which Norton has agreed to acquire for $25.50 a share, or about $472 million, was up 8 13/16, at 25 1/8. Norton, a unit of the French company Saint-Gobain, makes abrasives, ceramics, plastics and chemical-process products.
ZDNet, a unit of Ziff Davis, rose 3 5/16, to 21 7/16, on speculation that it would be acquired.
Priceline.com, rose 5 15/16, to 64 3/16. Warburg Dillon Read raised its rating on the stock to a strong buy from a buy, saying a recent selloff was too severe.
Another winner in the technology sector was Vitria Technology, which rose 2 3/8, to 50 5/8. Vitria, which had its initial public offering on Friday, makes software that allows companies to manage transactions and place orders over the Internet in real time.
Overseas, the Nikkei stock average in Japan rose 1.3 percent. The DAX index in Germany rose 0.9 percent, the FT-SE 100 in Britain was up 0.3 percent, and the CAC-40 in France closed 0.8 percent higher.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In Japan These Days, Few Speak Kindly of Central Bank

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan is under siege. At no time since the central bank was granted independence from Government control last year as part of a sweeping overhaul of the nation's financial system has it come under so much pressure.
International experts ranging from the United States Treasury Department to prominent private economists and investors want the central bank to loosen what the bank already considers a loose monetary policy. A looser monetary policy, they say, will help give the Japanese economy the jolt needed to loft it, finally, out of a decadelong slump. 
 Adding to the pressure is the unexpected strength of the yen, which hit a three-year high against the dollar last week, setting off concerns that it would derail the start of any economic renaissance.
The bank, however, says it can do little more to spur the economy -- having dropped interest rates practically to zero and injected large sums into the money markets, only to have produced little in the way of increased demand for money to spend and invest.
"Large amounts of excess reserves currently exist in the banking system," Kazuo Ueda, a policy board member, said in a recent speech. "Not a single bank has said that a further increase in reserves would increase their lending."
The wrangling has evoked a sense of the past among economists here. "It's very, very reminiscent of the bad old days," said Brian Rose, an economist at Warburg Dillon Read, "when the Bank of Japan had no independence and the press would announce its policy changes ahead of its own announcements, the Ministry of Finance ordered it around, and politicians felt free to weigh in as well."
The bank has resisted the appeals to do more, but on Tuesday, the policy board will hold its regular meeting, where monetary policy and the strength of the yen will undoubtedly be discussed.
Currency traders, the country's leading financial daily newspaper and others were betting today that the bank would capitulate and announce plans to increase the money supply that would work in tandem with some sort of foreign intervention to suppress the yen's rise.
Expectations of an announcement weakened the yen in Tokyo trading and contributed to a surge in the Tokyo stock market, where the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 1.34 percent today.
Japanese Government officials also think that the bank will move on Tuesday to ease monetary policy -- but in such a subtle way that the markets may miss it at the outset, and foreign governments may be disappointed.
The officials are betting that while the bank would not reverse any of its policies, it would begin increasing the money supply, probably by adding to the one trillion yen pile of money -- $8.9 billion at current exchange rates -- it leaves in the market every day.
Such an increase would achieve the same effect as the abandonment of Japan's "sterilized" currency interventions to influence the yen's exchange rate. In such interventions, the central bank offsets the surge in the money supply created by selling yen with other actions in the money market.
The United States and others who are concerned about the yen's strength have said such interventions have only limited effect. But the Bank of Japan does not want to be seen as caving in to the criticism.
The pressure on the central bank over yen intervention underscores the steadily rising tension between the central bank and its former masters, the Ministry of Finance and the ruling political party. That tension has been simmering since April 1998, when the bank was made independent.
There also is a continuing confrontation over Government bond purchases, with the Finance Ministry and prominent politicians urging the central bank to underwrite Government bonds and the bank refusing to take on that role.
The bank contends that that would give the Government unfettered ability to spend money at a time when the country's debt has climbed precariously. Central bank officials are still resentful that pressure to purchase Government bonds was perceived as the impetus behind its decision in February to reduce interest rates to one-quarter of a percent.
In its effort to defend its independence thereafter, the bank has further compromised the perception that it makes monetary policy solely on its own. "The Bank of Japan seems always to be driven into these untenable situations," a senior official said in frustration.
Last November, when it made moves to aid corporations with financing, it was seen as responding to political pressure at home, and in February, when it lowered interest rates, the bank was accused of bowing to the dictates of Robert E. Rubin, then the American Secretary of the Treasury, who had urged the bank to ease monetary policy.
"I'm sympathetic to their rationale for doing what they do, but markets and the political environment change rapidly and sometimes it's better to act pre-emptively," said a senior Finance Ministry official, who insisted that the ministry had not tried to strong-arm the central bank. "Unfortunately, they have tended to wait until the last minute before taking action, and thus appear as if they're being forced into it by those who have already advocated it."
At the moment, the bank evidently feels as if it has been backed into a corner. No one could have made that clearer than its Governor, Masaru Hayami, during comments after a meeting with Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa last Thursday.
Mr. Miyazawa's remarks were those of the seasoned politician he is. He said he had not discussed any specific issues regarding monetary policy with Mr. Hayami. "We had an important exchange of opinion," he said.
But he apparently angered Mr. Hayami by telling reporters that he had arranged the meeting, thus suggesting that once again, the Finance Ministry was trying to dictate to the bank.
Mr. Hayami subsequently declared that the bank had no intention of changing its policy on "sterilized intervention."
"The zero interest rate policy is already more than sufficient as a monetary easing step," he said, forgoing the even more nuanced language with which most Japanese officials speak.
But perhaps even more telling was the choice of the site for the meeting. Apparently, neither man wanted to be seen on his opposite's turf, and so they met in a hotel room in central Tokyo.

HEADLINE: A City Takes a Stand Against Hate

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

DATELINE: EAST PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
For years, the hard-working residents of this mostly white town on the eastern bank of the Illinois River did not take seriously the white supremacist views of Matthew F. Hale, 27, the son of a retired local policeman.
They recall trying to ignore his leaflets and appearances on public-access television. When he set up the headquarters of the World Church of the Creator in his parents' home, some thought it was a joke. 
 But after the Fourth of July weekend, when Benjamin Smith, a former World Church member, went on a two-state rampage against Jews, blacks and Asian-Americans, killing two and wounding nine before shooting himself, the laughter stopped.
"We were sickened," said Dennis Triggs, 54, the City Attorney. "We had the sense that benign neglect must come to an end."
Mr. Triggs called Morris Dees, co-founder of the Southern Poverty Law Center, a nonprofit civil rights organization, to ask what East Peoria could do.
Mr. Dees sent Mr. Triggs and Mayor Charles Dobbelaire, 59, a copy of the center's publication "Ten Ways to Fight Hate," and advised city leaders to do two things: Speak out immediately and form a broad-based coalition on race issues.
Mr. Dees also put leaders in touch with the Rev. David Ostendorf, a United Church of Christ minister in Chicago who leads the Center for a New Community, a group dedicated to fighting white supremacist ideas and organizations in the Midwest.
Mr. Ostendorf, who has said that "the only way this movement is going to be stopped is if communities stand up and say no and organize to oppose it," added a stop in East Peoria to a civil rights tour that retraced Mr. Smith's deadly trip through Illinois and Indiana.
On July 22, with members of Mr. Ostendorf's caravan and 200 local residents present, the Mayor announced that East Peoria, which has only a few dozen nonwhites in its population of 23,400, would set up a Human Relations Commission "to guide us in combating hate and teaching tolerance."
"We will not surrender the minds of our young to Matt Hale," Mr. Dobbelaire continued.
"I know that still today there are those who believe we should not attract attention to the hatemongers," he said. "They believe that if we quietly go about our everyday life, those who preach hate will fade slowly into the night. I ask you this: If we do not speak out, loud and clear, when the hate messages spewing forth from this so-called church lead to death, then when do we speak out?"
Mr. Dobbelaire's speech was followed by a prayer vigil in front of the Hale family home. On the other side of the ordinary, tree-lined street, a neighbor had posted a sign saying "Hate Has No Home Here."
The Mayor, who grew up in East Peoria and said racial issues rarely crossed his mind, appointed a new Human Relations Commission on Aug. 17.
"We're in this for the long haul," he said.
East Peoria has survived severe blows before, the worst being the closing of a Caterpillar tractor plant that had been its economic cornerstone. But it has enjoyed a comeback in recent years, with a new riverboat casino and jobs in entertainment, tourism and service industries.
The idea that their town might be seen as some kind of hate capital horrified the Mayor and the human relations commissioners.
"This is really causing a bad image for our tri-county area, not just East Peoria," said David Mingus, the commission chairman. "It's unfortunate and unrealistic. Our towns are good towns."
Mr. Mingus, 48, a mental health professional, said the commission intended to take a broad look at diversity and tolerance.
"We will keep it open to all areas," he said. "It's something nobody has on the scope all the time. We have to change attitudes."
Another member of the commission, Charles Randle, 53, who is black, said he had lived in an upscale neighborhood of East Peoria for 17 years with no difficulty. But Mr. Randle said he could not forget the searing experience of childhood on a cotton plantation in Mississippi, where two of his brothers, then young boys, were jailed for supposedly whistling at a white woman. To escape that life, their father, a sharecropper, moved his wife and 10 children to Peoria, where he worked at a slaughterhouse and then started a series of successful family businesses.
Mr. Randle, the director of economic development for Illinois Central College, said he saw the Human Relations Commission as a chance for East Peoria "to step outside the box and look around."
Other communities have made similar efforts.
In Boise, Idaho, several years ago, the state's image began to worry the staff at Hewlett-Packard, said Cindy Stanphill, the company's diversity and staffing manager.
"When we recruit, people know about Idaho potatoes and the Aryan Nations," Ms. Stanphill said. "The image does not necessarily represent the reality, but you have to deal with both."
For three years, the Hewlett-Packard staff has tried to find ways to insure that people they recruit and employ in Boise feel welcome at work and in the community. Staff members are now trying to organize an Idaho Inclusiveness Coalition, a group of major employers and human rights groups to promote tolerance and celebrate diversity.
In Pennsylvania, the state's Human Relations Commission has helped more than 50 communities form groups to do something about hate. One group started in Boyertown, a historically all-white community northwest of Philadelphia where the Ku Klux Klan distributed recruitment literature once a month.
Residents formed a unity coalition and asked citizens to pledge 5 cents to 50 cents for each minute the Klan spent in town. The money went to civil rights groups and helped organize the town's first rally to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
The head of the local Klan complained that the group, which was collecting $1,051 an hour, was using the Klan's name to raise money, said Louise Doskow, a member of the coalition. But the group persisted. "We have raised over $11,000," Ms. Doskow said. "We did it every month for 13 months, then they didn't show up again for a year. One person came to the corner at the end of June, so we did another collection."
The experiences of these communities and others, collected by Jim Carrier, a former reporter for The Denver Post, have been added to an updated version of "Ten Ways to Fight Hate." Mr. Carrier said the Southern Poverty Law Center would distribute a million free copies of the booklet and a companion, "Responding to Hate at School." The booklets will go to every school principal, mayor and police chief in the nation, as well as to human rights groups, religious leaders and interested citizens.
One group profiled, Coloradans United Against Hatred, was formed after an African immigrant was murdered by a skinhead in 1997. Seeing the use of the Internet by hate groups, the group set up its own Web site to offer an alternative.
"Are we making a huge impact?" said Anita Fricklas, the Colorado director of the American Jewish Committee, which helped underwrite the project. "It's hard to know. But an impact? Definitely."

HEADLINE: Possible Rift For Detroit In Labor Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 20

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s tentative contract with the United Automobile Workers contains company concessions that may create problems when the union demands similar concessions next from General Motors and Ford.
DaimlerChrysler agreed in the contract to hire more employees if the work force at any factory complex falls by more than 5 percent during the four-year contract for any reason except a downturn in automobile sales. 
 While DaimlerChrysler has a relatively young work force and has been hiring more workers to keep up with demand for its sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, the Ford Motor Company and particularly the General Motors Corporation have large, older work forces that they have been trying to reduce through attrition.
DaimlerChrysler also agreed to a so-called side letter that contained a surprisingly categorical ban on any move to get rid of unionized businesses. Over the years, the U.A.W. has sometimes allowed auto makers to have different side letters provided that they accepted identical labor contracts. But the DaimlerChrysler side letter represents a precedent for an effort by some in the union to stop Ford's planned spinoff of its auto parts division, which has $18 billion in annual sales.
Details of the contract emerged in a compendium of contract provisions prepared by the union as labor negotiations accelerated in Canada and the United States today.
Basil Hargrove, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, said today that the risk of a strike against Ford there on Tuesday night was receding, but that a 35 percent chance of a walkout remained. And Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, said that intensive talks with G.M. in the United States would start on Tuesday.
For the current labor contract, DaimlerChrysler and G.M. had proposed to guarantee the jobs of current U.A.W. members with at least 10 years of seniority. In exchange, both auto makers wanted relief from a provision in the previous contract, which expired on Sept. 14. The provision required DaimlerChrysler, G.M. and Ford to hire more workers if employment in any region of the United States fell by 5 percent or more from 1996 levels because work was moved to other factories.
But the U.A.W. rejected that proposal. The compendium of contract provisions released today showed that the union and DaimlerChrysler did not agree on job guarantees for senior workers. Instead, they retained the rule requiring new hiring and broadened it to require that workers be hired if employment fell sharply for any reason, and not just because work was transferred to other factories. The rule also appears to require new hiring if employment falls steeply at a single factory complex instead of in a region.
The new contract language is complicated, however, and has a few small pieces of good news for the auto makers. For example, the required drop in employment before new hiring occurs will relax somewhat over the four years of the contract. A 10 percent drop in a factory complex's work force will be required to lead to new hiring by the end of the contract in 2003. The provision could nonetheless pose problems for G.M. and Ford. G.M. had been hoping that up to 6 percent of its work force will retire each year for the next several years and would not have to be replaced. Ford has been reducing employment at its older car factories in Ohio while hiring workers at sport utility vehicle factories in Kentucky, and has run afoul of the "5 percent" rule in Ohio. Partly as a result, Ford has paid Ohio workers up to $45,000 apiece to move to Kentucky.
Yet the 1996 agreement also turned out to have important loopholes that still allowed G.M. in particular to continue shrinking its work force, although not quite as quickly as executives had hoped. Whether the current contract has such loopholes will not be known for months, but Diane Swonk, the chief economist at the Bank One Corporation, predicted that the auto makers would be able to continue downsizing somewhat under the new agreement.
Ford and G.M. declined to comment today on the DaimlerChrysler contract. DaimlerChrysler officials also refused to discuss it.
Regarding the side letter, the union's summary said: "The new letter states that DaimlerChrysler will not close, nor partially or wholly sell, spin off, split off, consolidate, or otherwise dispose of in any form, any plant, asset or business unit of any type, constituting a bargaining unit under the agreement."
While the union has always demanded that each auto maker accept virtually identical labor contracts, covering issues like wages and benefits, side letters are tailored to each auto maker's circumstances. DaimlerChrysler's side letter could nonetheless create problems for Ford, which is making plans to spin off or sell its auto parts division, Visteon Automotive Systems. The U.A.W. has left negotiations with Ford for last this year, and could ask Ford for a similar side letter.
While Ford has long had the best labor relations in the auto industry, the union is divided on how to handle Visteon, union officials said. While many want to prevent a spin-off of Visteon, others note that G.M. spun off its auto parts unit in May without reaching an understanding with the union first. Because in-house auto-parts divisions tend not to be competitive, stopping Ford from following G.M.'s example would result in the union's penalizing Ford for having tried to negotiate the issue.
The U.A.W. compendium of the contract also said that there had been no changes in DaimlerChrysler's prescription drug plan. Complaining of steeply rising costs, the auto makers had sought higher co-payments for prescriptions, particularly for popular medicines like Viagra, an impotence treatment.
Over the years, U.A.W. compendiums of labor agreements have tended to be accurate because misrepresentations could result in subsequent challenges to ratification votes.
In Canada, Mr. Hargrove, the Canadian union leader, said at a news conference this afternoon that he saw only a 35 percent chance of a strike when his union's current, three-year contract with Ford expires at 11:59 P.M. on Tuesday. Ford's initial offer on Friday had infuriated Canadian union officials, who dismissed it as inadequate, but Ford revised its offer on Sunday and negotiations since then have gone fairly well, Mr. Hargrove said.
"Our focus and energy is to try to do this without a shutdown of production," he said, while cautioning, "I'm reluctant to say we can avoid a dispute here."
James Hartford, a Ford spokesman, said "there are still a heck of a lot of things that remain on the table."

HEADLINE: Colombian Leader Says U.S. Won't Be Drawn Into War

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 20

 BODY:
President Andres Pastrana of Colombia insisted today that despite his Government's request for a huge new infusion of aid from abroad, the United States would not be drawn more deeply into Colombia's 40-year fight against leftist rebels.
"The times of intervention are over," Mr. Pastrana said in an address to the United Nations on the opening day of the General Assembly. "These are times of cooperation." 
 In an interview, Mr. Pastrana sought to reassure Americans about the Clinton Administration's deepening commitment to Colombia, saying military aid and training would be channeled mainly to special units like army battalions being formed to fight rebels who support the drug trade.
Mr. Pastrana indicated that his Government had decided not to ask the United States for sophisticated attack or transport helicopters. Instead, he said, Colombia will seek American authorization to buy such aircraft with its own money.
Colombia will seek United States aid to strengthen its radar and refurbish or replace many of its air force jets as part of a stepped-up effort to intercept planes involved in the drug trade flying into and out of the country, Mr. Pastrana said.
He said that Colombia, for the first time, had joined Peru in trying to shoot down such planes. American officials confirmed that the new policy took effect last year.
The Pastrana Administration is seeking at least $3.5 billion in international aid over the next three years to carry out a wide-ranging strategy to deal with leftist and rightist insurgents, a surging drug trade and a faltering economy.
Colombian officials hope that most of that aid will come from the United States, and they are using Mr. Pastrana's visit to New York and Washington this week as a diplomatic sales tour that will include meetings with President Clinton, Congressional leaders and others.
Privately, Colombian officials did not deny that they hope American help is well above the $1.5 billion that Clinton Administration officials cited last week as the high end of what they have considered providing to Colombia over the next three years. The United States is giving Colombia $287 million in the fiscal year that ends this month, according to State Department figures.
In the interview, Mr. Pastrana seemed to have no quarrel with the notion, widespread in Washington, that his year-old Government is in trouble.
"It has been a difficult year," he said wearily as he sat back in an armchair in his midtown hotel suite. In the next room, a pile of Colombian newspapers announced that leftist rebels had decided again to suspend their participation in peace talks.
But Mr. Pastrana pointedly challenged the American perception that the most serious new turn in Colombia's troubles is the growing alliance between drug producers in the south and the leftist guerrillas there who tax the producers' crops or protect their laboratories and fields.
While the guerrillas may be growing stronger and the traffickers are recovering from serious blows in the mid-1990's, Mr. Pastrana said, their violence is not as serious as it was a few years ago when rival drug cartels were still fighting ruthlessly against each other and the state.
"The security issue was much more serious in Colombia at the end of the 80's and the beginning of the 90's," he said. "What is happening now is that the security problem is becoming mixed up with the economic problem."
With the Government's debt burden at a critical level, commodity prices falling and unemployment on the rise, Mr. Pastrana said, the country simply cannot afford to fight its battles alone, particularly those against powerful cocaine and heroin traffickers.
"Colombia is ready to put up some cash, and we are putting it up, but we need international aid," Mr. Pastrana said. "This is a partnership in which all of us must contribute -- the Americans, the Colombians, the Europeans, the Asians."
American officials said the Pastrana Administration hoped to obtain at least $775 million in loans from international financial institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and that the total could rise to as much as $1.5 billion. But despite talk of "international cooperation," the officials said, Colombia will turn to the United States for almost all of the remainder.
While his aides said that about 55 percent of Colombia's proposed aid would be spent to fight drug trafficking, the leftist guerrillas and right-wing paramilitary groups, Mr. Pastrana also sounded frustrated with the lack of emphasis in Washington on social development, the substitution of other crops for drugs and trade programs.
"For the first time, we are looking at not just the police part of this; we are looking at the economic part," he said. "This is what we have to make people aware of in the United States and elsewhere."
Discussing details of his military aid request for the first time, Mr. Pastrana said he would not ask the United States to provide the Colombian Army with advanced UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters to use as troop transports, as American officials expected. Instead, he said he would seek American authorization to buy as many as 15 aircraft and arm at least some of them for use against the guerrillas. Such arms generally include small machine guns and rocket launchers.
The shift -- which officials said would also involve using smaller UH-1N helicopters to transport a new American-trained army antidrug battalion -- would probably mean less American scrutiny on the Colombian military's use of the helicopters as gunships against the guerrillas. The Colombians had previously considered buying Apache and Cobra attack helicopters, officials said, but had been discouraged in part by the difficulty they were likely to have in getting American authorization.
Mr. Pastrana also indicated that he would seek to expand a program under which the United States is soon to refurbish 10 of the Colombian Air Force's fleet of 14 A-37 fighter jets, installing radar in 5 of them. In a telephone interview from Bogota, the air force commander, Gen. Hector Fabio Velazco, confirmed that Colombian jets had shot down 4 drug planes since late last year, while hitting 11 others and forcing down 10.
The Colombian Defense Minister, Luis Fernando Ramirez, said that as part of the plan, Colombia hoped to create as many as four of the new counternarcotics battalions over the next three years in addition to the first such unit, which is expected to begin operations at the end of the year. He also said the Colombian military hoped to as much as double its contingent of 2,500 navy and army troops now fighting drug traffickers and their guerrilla allies along the country's rivers.
Clinton Administration officials said they were generally pleased with Mr. Pastrana's plan, which Colombian officials presented to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright last Thursday. But Administration officials are continuing to debate how they should seek financing for the plan to keep Republicans in Congress from cutting other foreign aid programs.

Custom Agencies in Accord
 By The New York Times
MIAMI, Sept. 20 -- The United States Customs Service and its counterpart in Colombia will sign an agreement on Tuesday that, customs officials say, will help the two countries investigate drug smuggling and money laundering.
Under the agreement, the officials said, both countries can obtain evidence and help in building cases directly from their customs counterparts, rather than through slower diplomatic channels.
 In particular, they said, the accord will help both countries investigate what he called the "black market peso exchange," which funnels some $5 billion in drug profits into Colombia every year.
With the signing of the agreement, customs officials in both countries will be able to exchange information on products and producers often used in the laundering scheme, officials said. In the past, such information was gained only informally or through diplomatic exchanges.
