HEADLINE: Federal Commission Predicts Increasing Threat of Terrorism

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The United States faces increasing threats from terrorism in the next 25 years and is likely to be compelled to intervene in other conflicts like Kosovo and East Timor even as its military shrinks, a Federal advisory commission warned in a report issued today.
The report makes grim predictions about crises and threats at home and abroad. The commission, headed by former Senators Gary Hart and Warren B. Rudman, warns in the 143-page report that the country "will be vulnerable to an increasing range of threats against American forces and citizens overseas, as well as at home," from terrorists or rogue states. 
 "While conventional conflicts will still be possible, the most serious threat to our security may consist of unannounced attacks on American cities" by terrorist groups using germ warfare, said a report summary. "Another may be well-planned cyber-attack on the air traffic control system on the East Coast of the United States as some 200 commercial aircraft are trying to land safely in a morning's rain and fog."
The commission predicted that the American military will increasingly be called upon to conduct humanitarian missions and what the Pentagon calls "operations other than war" in trouble spots around the world. But its status and influence will fuel resentment toward the United States, making it a target for attacks at home and abroad. In one of its grimmest predictions, the report added, "Americans will likely die on American soil, possibly in large numbers."
The commission said the United States is not prepared to defend itself against terrorist threats at home. That, its report concluded, will lead to more pressure on the military to expand its scope into domestic law enforcement as the line between foreign and domestic threats is blurred.
The commission's effort is the latest in a series of reviews undertaken inside and outside the Government during the last few years to try to assess threats to the United States in the post-cold-war era. Many of its findings echo those made by the Pentagon's own Quadrennial Defense Review in 1997 and a Congressional group, the National Defense Panel, which issued a report a year later.
Still the commission is expected to influence the debate over funding for the Pentagon and its programs for dealing with new threats, including a stronger focus on chemical and biological weapons and a missile defense system.
At a news conference last week previewing the report, Mr. Rudman said he hoped that the commission's work would ultimately lead to a rethinking of the organization of the nation's national security agencies -- the way similar reviews after the end of World War II led to the creation of the Air Force, the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Council. The commission stopped short of offering prescriptions, saying it would offer those in its subsequent reports.
In looking ahead, the commission was not entirely gloomy. The spread of democracy, advances in medicine and technology and new economic opportunities raise the prospect of increased stability and security around the world, it said.
But some of the same trends have less benign consequences. The increasing integration of the world's economy will mean that economic crises that were once local might spread, while scientific advances could hasten the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, as well as missiles to fire them.

NAME: Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev

SECTION: Section C; Page 25; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: Raisa Gorbachev, the Chic Soviet First Lady of the Glasnost Era, Is Dead at 67

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 20

 BODY:
Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev, who broke Kremlin tradition by sharing the spotlight with her husband, the former Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and did so with bold self-assurance and flair, died today in Munster, Germany. She was 67.
The cause was leukemia, aides to Mr. Gorbachev said. She had been under treatment in University Hospital in Munster since late July. 
 Mr. Gorbachev's rise to the leadership of the Communist Party in 1985 was the first sign of a seismic shift in the Soviet Union's calcified politics and economy. But it was Raisa Gorbachev who, both at home and abroad, soon came to embody the changes to come. She emerged as a First Lady who had her own mind, her own style and according to reports of a secret videotape that circulated after one of her foreign trips, her own American Express card.
None of this endeared her to the Soviet public, who began to grumble early in her husband's tenure that she was too pushy, too flashy and too influential. Her appearances on foreign trips and her cultural projects at home stirred debate in many Russian kitchens over whether the proper place for Kremlin wives was -- as it had always been -- at home, or at least in the background.
But since the beginning of this month, when Russians first learned that their former First Lady had been hospitalized in Germany with an advanced and rare case of leukemia, sentiments toward her in Russia began to shift. Favorable articles began to appear in the press, and thousands of letters and telegrams of sympathy arrived at the hospital in Munster, where her husband kept a faithful vigil that touched many Russian hearts. "It must be in the Russian character -- to run somebody into the mud, and them laud them to high heavens after a tragedy strikes," said Vladimir Polyakov, a Gorbachev spokesman.
President Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev's bitter rival in the early 1990's, sent a message of condolence today, and in a statement he said that a "wonderful person, a beautiful woman, a loving wife and mother is no longer with us."
In his autobiography, published in 1996, Mr. Gorbachev acknowledged that the resentment over his wife's high profile surfaced in letters written to the Communist Party's Central Committee. "Who does she think she is, a member of the Politburo?" he quoted one as saying. "The simplest answer would have been: 'No, she is my wife.' "
She first became known in the West in 1984 when she accompanied her husband, then a ranking member of the Soviet Politburo, to Britain, where they were received by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Diplomats and reporters, scanning the couple for clues about the next generation of Soviet leaders, quickly focused up on her wardrobe -- in particular her gold lame sandals with chain straps, a far cry from the dowdy shoes worn by other Kremlin wives. On a later trip to France, the French press labeled her clothes "elegant, but not chic."
On her foreign travels, she also became known for a haughty conversational style that bordered on the pedantic. During the 1986 summit meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland, she needled her tour guides with persistent questioning, adding didactic commentary of her own. Visiting the United States for the first time in 1987, she irked Nancy Reagan with lectures on subjects ranging from architecture to socialism, reportedly prompting the American President's wife to quip, "Who does that dame think she is?"
As she became more comfortable in her role as the Soviet First Lady, she loosened up and her wardrobe became more subdued. On a visit to Washington in 1990, she established more friendly relations with Barbara Bush, from whom she got a recipe for blueberry pie.
Born in the Siberian city of Rubtsovsk, Raisa Titarenko grew up as the daughter of a railway engineer. She graduated from school with a gold medal -- top honors in the Soviet system -- and went on to the prestigious University of Moscow. She was studying philosophy there when she met Mr. Gorbachev, then a law student. According to his book, he was smitten, but she was aloof.
"Our first meeting had not impressed Raisa at all," he wrote. "She seemed calm and indifferent -- judging by the look in her eyes." Not much later, at an impromptu party staged by Mr. Gorbachev's roommates for Raisa and her friends, "I wanted to impress her," he wrote, but "I think I made a terrible fool of myself. She was reserved and was the first to suggest breaking up the gathering."
After an intense courtship, the two penniless students were married in 1953, the year of Stalin's death. They had one daughter, Irina, born in 1956, who survives her along with Mr. Gorbachev and two granddaughters.
After the couple completed their college work in 1955, the family returned to Mr. Gorbachev's home region of Stavropol in southern Russia. There Mrs. Gorbachev completed a doctoral dissertation, entitled "The Emergence of New Characteristics in the Daily Life of Collective Farm Peasantry," based on an unusual amount of field research, which was accepted by the Lenin Pedagogical Institute in Moscow.
When her husband, then first party secretary in Stavropol, was promoted to Moscow as a Central Committee secretary in charge of agriculture, she returned to academics, taking a job as lecturer in philosophy at Moscow University, a position which she gave up when he became General Secretary of the Communist Party.
As the wife of the Soviet leader, she was enlisted as a board member of the Soviet Cultural Foundation, headed by Dmitri S. Likhachev, one of Russia's most distinguished academicians, which was created to promote the arts and to restore the country's cultural heritage.
In this role, she became one of her husband's conduits to the Russian intelligentsia, which was then rallying to his call for more "glasnost," or openness. As Soviet censorship eased, the Soviet people rushed to rediscover books and parts of their own history that had been buried under a rigid Communist ideology.
Mrs. Gorbachev's most traumatic moments came during the August 1991 coup, when the Gorbachevs were held hostage at a seaside villa in the Crimea while a group of Communist hard-liners tried to seize control in Moscow. The coup failed, and Mr. Gorbachev and his family returned to Moscow, visibly shaken. "Raisa Maksimovna took it very hard," said Mr. Gorbachev at a news conference after their return to Moscow.
In 1991, Raisa Gorbachev published a book of reminiscences, entitled in English, "I Hope," which she decided to write after a visit with Mrs. Bush in 1990 to Wellesley College where, she said, "the girls showered me with questions." Reviewers found the book self-serving in parts but also informative about the couple's intellectual journey as, together, they came to realize the flaws in the Soviet system.
In her last years, Mrs. Gorbachev started a club that drew together a dozen well-known and high-powered Russian women for conferences, charitable projects and informal debates. She described the group as an attempt to promote a civil society in Russia. Against her wishes, the club became known as the Raisa Maksimovna Club.
Lyudmila Telen, a deputy editor at the newspaper Moscow News and a member of the club, said her impressions of Mrs. Gorbachev changed as she got to know her better. "She set herself very high goals -- she felt she had to improve herself," said Ms. Telen. "Going from wife of a provincial first secretary to First Lady was a big jump.
"She wanted to represent the country in a new way. She understood that what Mikhail Sergeyevich was doing was a revolution, but she had many complexes, too -- a natural reserve and a Soviet way of behavior that she tried to overcome."
Ms. Telen said Mrs. Gorbachev was well aware of the resentment against her felt by many Russians. But she herself was never bitter. "She realized that people had been used to different women, different traditions, different leaders," said Ms. Telen. "She understood it. It hurt her of course, but I never heard her be mean or bitter about it."
As a couple, the Gorbachevs shared interests in philosophy and literature, theater and politics. Mr. Gorbachev on several occasions acknowledged that he often turned to his wife for advice. In his book, he recalled how the two would have their most serious discussions in the garden of their Government-provided apartment, beyond the earshot of K.G.B. eavesdropping devices.
Their close relationship was the envy of their friends. At a dinner in Paris in the fall of 1985, her host said she confided: "I am very lucky with Mikhail. We are really friends, or if you prefer, we have great complicity."
After the collapse of the Soviet Union in December 1991, when Mr. Yeltsin took over Mr. Gorbachev's office in the Kremlin, he became a political pariah in Russia, widely blamed for ushering in reforms that led to a decade of political and economic instability.
After a disastrous run for the presidency in 1996, he maintained a low profile at home, while Mrs. Gorbachev, who accompanied him on the international lecture circuit, became practically invisible until her recent illness.
With a diagnosis of acute lukemia, Mrs. Gorbachev was rushed to the hospital in Munster on July 25. News of her hospitalization became public only in early August.
According to Russian news reports, Mr. Gorbachev remained at her side day and night. "Dear God," the former Soviet President, visibly exhausted, told a Russian television reporter on Aug. 9, "for her to undergo such a drama these two days before my very eyes."

HEADLINE: Beginning a Bargain-Basement Invasion of Mars

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
Two American spacecraft are approaching Mars, the second wave of economy-class robotic orbiting and landing parties in an ambitious revival of exploration of the red planet.
One spacecraft, scheduled for arrival on Thursday, is to orbit the planet and study its atmosphere, prospect for water and generally observe weather through the seasons of a full Martian year (687 days). The second craft is on course for a landing on Dec. 3 at the edge of the south polar ice cap, where the terrain is thought to hold a layered record of the planet's climate history. 
 Mission officials at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said yesterday that both spacecraft, Mars Climate Orbiter and Mars Polar Lander, are in excellent condition and ready for their arrival. Last week, the orbiter fired thruster jets to fine-tune its aim on the planet.
Though relatively modest in cost and scope, the missions are integral steps in a long-term strategy of sending small spacecraft to Mars at each 26-month opportunity when the orbital relationship is right. Orbiters, landers, roving surface vehicles, balloons and miniaturized airplanes -- at all times over the next decade or more there should be a robotic presence on and over Mars. Their objectives are to map the entire planet and its resources and scout out clues to conditions there in an earlier, more temperate epoch.
Eventual objectives are to return samples of rock and soil, perhaps by 2008, and someday send astronauts for a long visit. Behind this methodical approach is the enduring question of whether life ever emerged on Mars and left some fossil traces, and whether it still exists in some moist recesses of this cold, arid world.
This is a far cry from the fictional travels to Mars that once fired the human imagination. In the marvelous tales of Edgar Rice Burroughs, also creator of Tarzan, the gentleman-adventurer John Carter simply closed his eyes and wished himself all the way to Mars (Barsoom in the novels), where he found spired cities, eight-legged beasts of burden and, not least, the beautiful Dejah Thoris, the princess he wooed and won.
Real-life exploration of Mars has proved to be tame stuff by potboiler standards. Long after the Martians of legend vanished, two spacecraft landed there in 1976 in search not of a princess but of the merest trace of microbial life in the red dust. Finding nothing, and under tighter budget limits, scientists have turned to the even more plodding operations of today.
"We're trying to do a whole lot more with less," said Dr. Sam Thurman, flight operations manager of the current missions. "The public and Congress have told us, 'Space is neat, but it's got to be done at less than a billion dollars a pop.' "
That was the price tag on the Mars Observer spacecraft, which failed just before reaching the planet in 1992. The failure was particularly devastating because the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had put all its eggs in one basket, and was left with nothing. The Viking life-seeking missions in 1976, though operational successes, cost more than $2 billion, a figure no longer acceptable.
By contrast, as a result of NASA orders to develop "cheaper, better, faster" science missions, the complete cost of the present Climate Orbiter and Polar Lander missions has been kept to $327.5 million, Dr. Thurman said. This represents a further paring of expenditures over the first two missions in the current program. The Pathfinder spacecraft, which landed with its little Sojourner rover two years ago, cost $270 million. Another $300 million went for the orbiting companion, Global Surveyor.
Global Surveyor is still going strong, returning the most detailed pictures ever for mapping the planet. The pictures of widespread water erosion and magnetic data showing that in an early period the planet churned with internal heat have further encouraged planetary geologists in their view that ancient Mars was a more Earthlike place, with abundant water, and could have supported the beginnings of life.
"We want to understand the history of that planet from a biological perspective," Dr. Charles Elachi, director of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory's space and earth-science programs, said in an interview with Sky & Telescope magazine. He has been in charge of developing the current Mars exploration strategy.
In an effort to answer some of the life and climate questions, the orbiter is equipped to examine the temperatures, dust and clouds in the planet's atmosphere, composed mainly of carbon dioxide, and especially look for water vapor.
"That's a very important part of trying to understand Mars's climate," said Dr. Richard W. Zurek, the chief mission scientist. "We want to learn how water gets into the atmosphere, where it comes from and where it goes."
Launched last December, the 1,387-pound Climate Orbiter is approaching the northern half of Mars. A 16-minute firing of the craft's main rocket should slow it down to enter a wide-ranging elliptical orbit. The spacecraft will loop around Mars once every 14 hours, at first dipping in no closer than 130 miles from the surface.
Then the craft will be maneuvered to a closest approach of 60 miles to use friction from the upper atmosphere to bring its orbit down to a low circular course. This technique, known as aerobraking, was first demonstrated by Mars Pathfinder in 1997. Its advantage is economic: the reduction in the amount of fuel needed for rocket braking means the spacecraft weighs less and could be launched on its journey by a smaller, less expensive rocket.
By the middle of November, the spacecraft should be settled in a 262-mile-high orbit and ready to support the Polar Lander's planned 90-day operations on the surface. During that time, the orbiter is to serve as a communications satellite, relaying radio transmissions between the lander and Earth.
The 1,270-pound Polar Lander, 3.5 feet tall and 12 feet wide, is targeted to touch down on a broad, gently rolling plain near the south pole. Specifically, the landing site is a rectangular area 125 miles long and 12 miles wide, at 76 degrees south latitude, 195 degrees west longitude.
At landing time, it will be the end of spring in the planet's southern hemisphere. The site will be in 24-hour daylight, critical to operations of the solar-powered craft's systems. The thick polar ice cap, in seasonal retreat, will be farther south. But drilling into the frozen surface, the spacecraft should be able to investigate subterranean water ice and the details of the layers of dust and ice deposited there.
"We believe this layered terrain is a record of climate change on Mars," Dr. Zurek said. "In a sense, digging into the surface will be like reading tree rings or layers in an ice core."
Dr. Ronald Greeley of Arizona State University, a member of the lander science team, said a study of the thickness and geometry of the polar layered terrain should test "some of our ideas of how the layers relate to the planet's climate history" over millions of years.
The lander's 6.5-foot-long digging arm will probably take two days to scoop up soil samples and deliver them to an oven. Gases from the heated samples will be analyzed for any evidence of water vapor, among other things. Then the lander's cameras and other instruments are expected to collect data on atmospheric conditions and weather patterns. A microphone is designed to capture the sounds of Mars, perhaps the whistling of winds on the robot arm's digging operation.
To supplement some of its own explorations, the lander is supposed to release two projectiles about 10 minutes before touchdown. These probes are to crash at 400 miles an hour and bury themselves beneath the surface, where they will draw soil samples for heating and another search for vaporized water ice.
By March, when the lander's operations should be ending in the approaching polar darkness, the Climate Orbiter is scheduled to begin its own primary mission. One of its two science instruments is an infrared radiometer for measuring temperatures, dust, water vapor and clouds in the atmosphere from the surface to an altitude of 50 miles.
The orbiter also carries a color imaging system, combining digital wide-angle and medium-angle cameras, developed by Dr. Michael Malin of Malin Space Science Systems in San Diego. The wide-angle camera will be used for daily global pictures of the Martian atmosphere and surface. The medium-angle instrument should provide more detailed pictures of surface changes related to weather and seasonal conditions.
Because temperatures on the planet rarely rise above freezing, most water there is probably stored in the ground, chemically and physically bound to the soil or as ice. This may be especially true in the polar regions. Wherever water is, the orbiter's mission is to investigate its distribution and search for possible surface and subsurface reservoirs.
Now, as the Climate Orbiter cruises toward its encounter, all is quiet for flight controllers. Their simulations are completed. All instructions for maneuvers have been radioed to the spacecraft's computers. And Polar Lander, with another two and a half months to go before its arrival, is essentially flying on autopilot.
Soon enough, the controllers will be busy operating two vehicles at once, and the Global Surveyor as well. As another concession to the budget crunch, said Dr. Thurman, the flight operations manager, the ground support team has been trimmed to 80 people. Seven years ago, Mars Observer had a team of more than 200. And in the 1970's, the Vikings had 500.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about missions to Mars misidentified the craft that first used atmospheric friction, or aerobraking, to achieve orbit around a planet. It was the Mars Global Surveyor. (The Mars Pathfinder made a direct descent to the planet's surface, also in 1997.)

HEADLINE: What Web Retailers Really Need Is a Whole Lot of Shelf Space

BYLINE: By JON CHRISTENSEN 

DATELINE: RENO

 BODY:
IN a clever advertising campaign promoting itself as "Earth's biggest bookstore," Amazon.com emissaries were portrayed earlier this year as searching for storage space in famously huge places like the Pyramids, the Taj Mahal and even the planet Mars. But about the same time, in the real world, the company was quietly settling into an anonymous-looking warehouse about 30 miles east of here.
The 322,560-square-foot warehouse covers seven acres of former farm fields, an area larger than seven football fields. That is a pretty big building, but not in these parts. Here it is just one of dozens of similar bland, boxy buildings scattered among the sagebrush hills on the outskirts of a city more famous for glittering gambling halls. 
 Hidden inside these otherwise unremarkable structures are the engines of a second economy for this region. In these high-technology warehouses, the virtual world of E-commerce is increasingly blending with the realities of commerce by any name: inventory, order fulfillment and delivery of products to customers.
Here and across the country, dot-coms may see their shares soar, but some of the most mundane types of businesses are benefiting more tangibly, in a little-noticed ripple effect. For the warehouse industry, for instance, E-commerce is already causing significant changes, said J. Eric Peters, a supply chain analyst with Andersen Consulting. "And it's going to get a lot bigger."
More than 80 percent of the nation's warehouses are wired with electronic management systems that keep track of products with bar codes and computerized databases, said Mr. Peters, who surveyed 200 warehouse managers last year. While only 22 percent of the warehouses were connected to the Web at the time, he said, that number is growing rapidly.
Most of the nation's 2.5 billion square feet of warehouse space (enough to cover Manhattan nearly four times over) was set up to store cases and pallets of products for wholesalers and retailers. But E-commerce is pushing the warehouse industry to get wired to meet the growing demand for speedy delivery of small individual packages. And it is pushing on-line companies to master the back end of their businesses.
These two trends meet in warehouses like those scattered near Reno. And inside these buildings, and in similar warehouses nationwide, experts say, some of the critical turf wars in E-commerce will be decided.
"It's fairly easy to put up a pretty neat storefront on the Web," said Dale Rogers, a professor of supply chain management at the University of Nevada, Reno. "But you need a good supply chain behind the store. And that is difficult. Order fulfillment is where a lot of the battles are going to be fought in the future."
Amazon.com moved into a building formerly owned by Stanley Works, a highly mechanized warehouse designed to supply retailers with packages of tools. But Amazon.com has had to reconfigure the inner workings of the building to handle the much more complex task of picking and packing products for individual customers.
Books, CD's and videos are being shipped from the warehouse, and by the end of the year, 300 people will be working there, according to the company. But the company declined to allow a reporter inside the building. Although Amazon.com is moving aggressively to expand its distribution network, it has been uncharacteristically quiet about this more mundane side of its business strategy.
When Amazon.com began in 1995, it had only 93,000 square feet of space for books at its headquarters in Seattle. In 1997, it leased a 202,000-square-foot warehouse in New Castle, Del. This year, it has expanded the back end of its operation almost tenfold, to 2.7 million square feet across the country, with two warehouses in Kentucky and one each in Kansas and Georgia.
Amazon.com shares fell in August after the company announced that it was spending heavily on the distribution centers, further delaying the time when the company will make a profit. The company has not released any details about the cost of the warehouses, but its fixed assets rose to $156 million in June from $29.8 million at the end of 1998.
According to some analysts, distribution was not part of Amazon.com's original business plan. But others say it is a logical and necessary step so that the company can compete effectively and continue to grow.
"It's a similar strategy to how Wal-Mart expanded," said Mr. Rogers, who noted that many Amazon.com executives once worked for Wal-Mart. "They've got cash because of the company's gigantic market capitalization. And they believe they need a lot of facilities with a lot of inventory around the country. And not just to sell books. They're planning to be a big store."
In many cases, experts say, the distinction between E-commerce and other kinds of commerce is getting harder to maintain as more companies conduct more of their business on line. Nowhere is that distinction being blurred more than inside a modern warehouse. Orders arrive by E-mail or on Web pages and electronic bar code readers and radio transmitters are wired to a database that keeps track of the contents. There is an increasingly seamless interface between inventory and information.
The Dell Computer Corporation, for instance, ships computer monitors to the West Coast from a warehouse near here. The computers themselves are built in Austin, Tex., and the two parts meet up on United Parcel Service delivery trucks on their way to customers in a dance choreographed by a Web-based computer tracking system.
More than 500 companies use Reno as a distribution center, including Michelin North America, the parts division of General Motors, J. C. Penney, the winery Kendall-Jackson and the wholesale book distributor Baker & Taylor. Barnes & Noble is looking for a warehouse near Reno after deciding not to pursue a bid to acquire the book distributor Ingram.
Reno has long been attractive as a distribution center because it is close to California and centrally located for shipments throughout the West. Space is cheap and plentiful. There is no inventory, individual or corporate income tax. And the railroad and Interstate 80 provide access.
U.P.S. has a large shipping center here, a crucial ingredient for companies that ship small packages to individual customers, and the United States Postal Service is planning to move a regional sorting center from Oakland, Calif., to the Reno-Tahoe International Airport.
These factors have begun to attract more pure E-commerce to the area, too, like Testwave.com, which sells analytical instruments, and Igo.com, which sells batteries and other accessories for laptops, cellular phones and other tools for business travelers.
Ken Hawk started Igo.com in 1991 when he was attending the Stanford Business School. The company, formerly known as 1-800-Batteries, grew so rapidly that Mr. Hawk found he had to move the business around the Silicon Valley nearly every year to find enough space.
"After four moves, my C.F.O. and I said, 'Why are we in San Jose?' " Mr. Hawk said. "One of the great things about a dot-com is that it can be located anywhere."
Mr. Hawk said he remembered the prediction of Faith Popcorn, the trend forecaster, that in the future people would live in places where they now take vacations, like nearby Lake Tahoe, and would go on vacation in places where they now work, like San Francisco or New York.
Mr. Hawk, who is an avid mountain biker, visited Lake Tahoe. He discovered that it got too much snow in the winter for reliable year-round shipping. But in Reno, at the foot of the Sierra Nevada, he found a place with enough space for his business to grow.
Igo.com is now paying 60 cents a square foot here compared with $1.70 in San Jose, Mr. Hawk said, and it plans to add 40,000 square feet to the 18,500-square-foot-warehouse it leases. The company has grown to 111 employees from 24 since it moved here in June 1997, and it plans to hire 30 more workers over the next six months.
With lower housing costs in the Reno area, Mr. Hawk said, most of his workers can afford to buy homes, something they could not do in Silicon Valley. Employee turnover is lower here, 1.5 percent a year, he said, compared with 30 percent to 50 percent in Silicon Valley. And Mr. Hawk can ride out the back door on his mountain bike into open space, one thing this area has in abundance.

HEADLINE: Can Defendants Cry 'E-Sanctuary' and Escape the Courts?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE prosecution of Kevin Jay Lipsitz, who was accused of trying to peddle magazine subscriptions from Staten Island, would have been a garden-variety consumer fraud case. But because it involved the Internet, it has become a watershed.
Mr. Lipsitz's solicitations for low-cost subscriptions came in the form of spam, group distribution sent through E-mail. But when 50 disgruntled consumers from New York and around the world complained that they never got their subscriptions or received fewer issues than promised, the New York Attorney General accused Mr. Lipsitz and his companies, including Krazy Kevin's Magazine Club and Tempting Tear-Outs, of violating the state's consumer fraud and false-advertising laws. 
 Mr. Lipsitz responded that the New York State court could not possibly have jurisdiction over the geographically limitless domain of the Internet and that, for similar reasons, it would be unconstitutional to apply New York laws.
But ruling in what she said was "a case apparently of nationwide first impression," Justice Diane S. Lebedeff of the State Supreme Court found that Mr. Lipsitz had sufficient connections to New York to enable the state's courts to adjudicate the consumers' claims and that the state's laws did apply.
"To place a realistic context on these matters and leave behind the rarefied air of cyberspace, the issues raised here would be the same if each involved a consumer individually sued in the Staten Island Small Claims Part," Justice Lebedeff wrote in June 1997.
"There is no compelling reason to find that local legal officials must take a 'hands off' approach just because a crook or a con artist is technologically sophisticated enough to sell on the Internet. Invocation of 'the Internet' is not the equivalent of a cry of 'sanctuary' upon a criminal's entry into a medieval church."
THE state of the law governing commerce on the Web is somewhere between the dusty streets of the Wild West and the decorous halls of the Supreme Court.
As path-breaking as the Lipsitz case has become for local law-enforcement and consumer groups, it has only scratched the surface of the legal questions that are arising with the explosive popularity of the Internet as the world's largest bazaar. While a trickle of court opinions in the United States and abroad has begun to define the commercial rules for the Web by applying analogies from older principles, the medium has created problems that defy easy answers.
Many other new technologies, like the telephone and television, raised a host of difficult legal questions. But the questions raised by the remarkably ubiquitous nature of the Internet are forcing an even more significant set of legal issues. In large part, these issues have arisen precisely because the law and the Internet are based on opposite notions.
The law is inherently based on geographic boundaries, historically an effective way to impose a socialized order on human behavior. But the Internet knows no such boundaries and has prospered because of a kind of anarchy. The law can only work when the government or a private plaintiff can identify a wrongdoer as defendant. By contrast, the Internet thrives on anonymity.
Economic realities have put a strain on the development of cyberspace law. Unlike the emergence of technologies like television or radio, the economic barriers to establishing a presence or business on the Internet are stunningly low. This has enabled many small businesses to use the medium to gain exposure to a marketplace that is potentially limitless.
Not surprisingly, these differences between the law and the Internet, and between the Internet and older technologies, have led to the emergence of some legal issues that the courts have never before confronted.
To take the case of Mr. Lipsitz, for instance, what would the judge have ruled if his business had been in New Zealand instead of New York, or if he had not concentrated on New Yorkers? If the court found a sufficient connection to apply its jurisdiction, whose laws should apply? And what kind of remedy would be available to New Yorkers for a business whose assets lay offshore?
More fundamentally, must a business that puts up a Web site abide by the laws and regulations of every jurisdiction around the world -- even those that may be inconsistent -- because anyone anywhere with a telephone, a computer and some basic software can theoretically read and respond to the site?
"The Internet presents a problem of both overinclusiveness and underinclusiveness," said Henry H. Perritt, the dean of the Chicago-Kent College of Law and the author of a legal treatise, "Law and the Information Superhighway" (Aspen Law & Business). "For the seller, there is the potential of much conflicting regulation. But there is also an underinclusiveness problem in that this patchwork may prove not to be efficacious in providing a remedy for victims."
At the Federal Trade Commission, the emergence of the Internet as a significant force in commerce has prompted a reassessment of every law and regulation to see how it could be affected.
Officials have also held a series of conferences and meetings with representatives of companies and consumer groups, and with foreign officials, to begin to make sure that American consumers have the same protections on line that they enjoy off line in every area from advertising that is deceptive to warranties.
But the F.T.C., which is widely regarded as being at the forefront of considering these issues, is only one small piece of a large, global equation, particularly because no international treaties directly address commercial issues and the Internet.
"Right now the battle is pitched, with industry asserting on one side that the law of the originator controls and the consumer groups screaming on the other side that it's the law of the consumer state," said Ronald L. Plesser, a lawyer at Piper & Marbury in Washington who is involved in international conferences on the issue and who represents companies that are confronting it.
"Both of those approaches have problems," Mr. Plesser said. "If you decide it's the law of the originator, then everyone will go to the state or country that has the lowest common denominator, putting their computer servers in those countries to minimize problems. But if you go with the law of the consumer state, you don't often know where that state is, and you wind up having to comply with a wide variety of different and conflicting rules."
He added: "So we're in this murky midlevel right now. The seas and the oceans are forming around us, but if this were viewed like the creation of the universe, we're in about the fourth day."
One way some companies have tried to avoid difficulties is by varying their Web sites. I.B.M., for instance, uses a different Web page for each of 167 countries, an approach that recognizes that the company has assets around the globe and that, by necessity, it must take steps to comply with many different rules.
Many popular auction houses offer to protect consumers by indemnifying them for a fee and acting as mediators in disputes.
Mr. Plesser and other industry lawyers have also suggested a self-regulatory approach through the establishment of basic rules for companies, which, if followed, would innoculate them from liability.
But consumer groups and law-enforcement officials, while applauding that approach as a good first step, say it will not be enough.
"We certainly welcome self-regulation and any effort by on-line businesses to be responsible corporate citizens in the same way they make those efforts off line," said Caitlin J. Halligan, the chief of the Internet Bureau at the New York State Attorney General's office, which expects to receive about 2,000 complaints this year about issues involving on-line dealings.
"But there are obviously situations where enforcement actions are appropriate when a company engages in fraudulent or otherwise unlawful activity," she said. "That's true whether the conduct is on line or off line."
AS for transactions either between two consumers in a chat room or between a consumer and a company, Ms. Halligan advises people to take the same basic precautions that they would ordinarily take, recognizing the possibility that even more problems than usual can arise because of the nature of the Internet.
"You also need to exercise the same, if not more, prudence than you do in an off-line transaction," she said, "particularly since you don't have the item in front of you while you are deciding whether to buy it."

HEADLINE: Coming Soon to a Web Site Near You: A Simpler Sales Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
IF you are hoping that the Internet will become a tax-free zone, dream on. Business leaders know that would distort the economy, creating an uneven playing field that would benefit some companies while damaging their competitors. Also, state and local governments are not about to concede a chunk of their single biggest source of revenue, sales and use taxes worth $189 billion last year.
But if you like the standardization that makes a Big Mac the same in Philadelphia and Provo, Utah, you will love what E-commerce is likely to do to your sales taxes. 
 The patchwork of rules that makes a can of soda a taxable nonfood item in Ohio and a tax-exempt food in New York is under attack from all sides in the debate over the taxation of electronic commerce.
"The only certainty about E-commerce is that we will get simplification of the sales tax system," said Robert Cline, a state and local tax expert with the accounting firm Ernst & Young.
Although the debate over Internet taxes is far from over, it is clear that the passage last year of the Internet Tax Freedom Act, which created a three-year moratorium on taxes specifically on Internet activity while a panel of political and business leaders studies the issue, has prompted new thinking about how a tax that arose in the Industrial Age can be made to work in the Information Age.
Sales taxes took hold in the 1930's, promoted as stable sources of revenue in the Depression to pay for the police, teachers and other services. Today, 46 states, 4,831 cities, 1,511 counties and 139 school and special-purpose districts impose sales taxes, Mr. Cline said, which is only about one-fifth of the 30,000 jurisdictions cited by many advocates of a tax-free Internet.
Nevertheless, Mr. Cline sees a serious problem because no map exists that matches every address to each taxing jurisdiction. Thus, a company selling over the Internet could have three customers in the same ZIP code, one of whom owes sales tax at the state rate, one who lives in a city with an added rate and one who lives in the same city and in a special district and owes a third level of tax.
E-commerce and mail-order companies that operate in one state and ship to others have no incentive to create such a sales tax map because under current law they cannot be compelled to collect sales tax. A few companies, like Gateway, the mail-order computer maker, routinely collect sales taxes from all customers.
Creating a sales tax map is possible. J. C. Penney, which has stores in all 50 states and as a result must collect taxes on all sales from its Internet site and its catalogue, has built a detailed ZIP code database to determine the sales tax rate owed by every customer, said Jim Evatz, a Penney tax-compliance manager.
"We feel that a level playing field is an issue," Mr. Evatz said of the advantage enjoyed by competitors who do not collect sales taxes.
Stuart Feldman, the director of the I.B.M. Institute for Advanced Commerce, said, "It is not a big deal for a large firm to keep track of, or to get access to, what the tax rate is for clothing in New Jersey or even in a water district."
The problem, Mr. Evatz and Mr. Feldman agree, is knowing which products and services are taxable. "No uniformity, no rhyme or reason, no plausible categorization," Mr. Feldman said of the sales tax. "When I lived in New Jersey, caviar counted as tax-free food, which I sort of thought missed the point."
How, he asked, is everyone in E-commerce business to know "that purple sweaters are suddenly tax free -- this week only -- in Ulster County."
One E-commerce committee of the National Tax Association, which has representatives from business, government and education, has suggested developing standardized product and services categories but allowing each jurisdiction to decide which will be taxed and by how much. Business members of the association said they wanted absolute national uniformity on what is taxed.
E-commerce raises questions that extend beyond differences among the states and that will become increasingly important as Internet sales become global. For example, American-style retail sales taxes do not integrate well with the European-style value added tax.
E-commerce also raises questions about who is to be taxed and where. In an age when tangible products were paid for at a cash register, the sales tax had the virtues of being obvious to the customer and easy to collect. E-commerce changes that.
CONSIDER the problems posed by the sale of a book over the Internet.
If the book is ordered from a catalogue and shipped across state lines, Congress could easily require a seller like Amazon.com to collect any sales tax and pay it to the state from which the book is shipped or where the bill is sent.
The Supreme Court, in two major sales tax decisions, has told Congress that it has the power under the Constitution's commerce clause to require businesses to collect sales taxes for states to which they ship products, but Congress has never taken the hint. Taxes must be paid if the buyer lives in the same state as the mail-order company, and many Web sites have a button to establish the tax payment.
People who have products sent by mail owe use tax, the individual equivalent of sales tax, but hardly anyone obeys these state tax laws. In New Jersey, for example, only one in 500 people pay use tax. No state has made a serious effort to collect the tax.
But where is the sales tax to be levied when a resident of Buffalo, while changing planes in Pittsburgh, downloads an electronic version of the book before flying to Oregon? Is sales tax due in Buffalo, where the bill goes? In Pittsburgh, where the product was acquired? Or is no tax due because the electronic book is read in Oregon?
And what happens when a business buys a database, stores it on a computer in one city and then has its employees across the nation use it?
Gerald D. Bair, the director of revenue and finance in Iowa, who has been involved with the National Tax Association project to define the issues on Internet taxes, said Congress would have to require companies to comply with all state and local tax laws, which he said would have to be simplified. Otherwise, he said, "states and local governments are going to have to stand up and attempt to enforce their use tax laws."

HEADLINE: Latest Hit on Campus: Crescendo in E-Major

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to offering degrees, the halls of academia are not immune to fashion. Colleges and universities bank on blue-blazer classics like history and philosophy. But they also like to try what's hot every now and then.
What's sizzling right now, given the successes of the dot-com crowd, is the E-commerce credential. In what many professors and administrators say is the fastest trend to take hold in the slow-changing world of higher education, colleges and universities nationwide are rushing to turn the study of business on the Internet into degrees, majors, minors, concentrations, specialties, certificates, fellowships and research centers. 
 "While the University of Alabama does not have an E-commerce program yet, we are working full speed to set one up," wrote Bill Gerdes, a university spokesman, in an E-mail response to a query about E-commerce degrees on the Tuscaloosa campus.
There are as many variations on E-commerce instruction as there are institutions offering it. Of the dozen or so programs now available, some focus on Internet technology, with training in Web-site design, electronic data interchange and authentication technology along with marketing and consumer services. Others concentrate on entrepreneurship and the basics of running a business on the Web, including keeping tabs on finances and inventory.
Some involve intensive curriculums and undergraduate degrees in subjects like computer science or finance. Others make fewer course requirements and would appeal to students who are not necessarily facile with computers.
Carnegie Mellon University's graduate business school in Pittsburgh just introduced a master's of science program in electronic commerce that combines instruction in business and in computer science. The yearlong program, which began last May, costs $38,000 and, the university said, should enable graduates to build and run a company's on-line system from the floor up.
The master's of science program at Marlboro College in Marlboro, Vt., which began in 1997, offers on-line instruction in basic Web design, marketing and strategic planning for Web businesses. The 11-month program requires students to be on campus every other weekend and costs $15,000. "We focus less on deep, technical infrastructure and more on teaching students to orchestrate Internet strategies," said Paul J. LeBlanc, the college's president.
At the University of Florida in Gainesville, a certificate in E-commerce as part of a two-year M.B.A. program is awarded after completion of seven E-commerce courses that cover subjects like pricing of information services and products and one-to-one marketing over the Internet.
Any student at LaSalle University in Philadelphia may qualify as an E-commerce "fellow" by attending two E-commerce courses; courses in other disciplines with an E-commerce component, or a seven-part lecture series. All fellows must write a 2,500-word research paper and work in the field -- for a company or a community service organization, for example -- for 40 hours. The fellowship designation appears on graduates' transcripts, and fellows walk away with portfolios of E-commerce work.
Student interest in new E-commerce degrees and programs has been strong, university administrators say. Carnegie Mellon said it had received 180 applications, from which it chose its initial 37 candidates. Paul R. Brazina, the executive director of LaSalle's new Electronic Commerce Institute, said that 470 students had shown interest in applying to the institute's fellowship program, which is beginning this month.
At Vanderbilt University in Nashville, 110 students, or a quarter of the M.B.A. candidates, have chosen E-commerce as either a concentration or specialty.
Corporations are even more enthusiastic about E-commerce training than college and university administrators. Many companies think that employees with an intimate knowledge of modern computer technologies and E-commerce strategies might give them a competitive edge. Some companies are helping to sponsor E-commerce research centers, sometimes as a means for converting their business problems into case studies that students can try to solve.
"The breadth of companies asking for E-commerce experience, from CS First Boston to General Electric, to start-ups, like Priceline.com, is amazing," said Robert F. Bonner, the director of the career management office at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "A few years ago, companies would say E-commerce experience on a student's resume was 'nice to have.' Now they are saying, 'must have.' "
Wharton, which started its Electronic Commerce Forum three years ago as a research center for corporations, students and faculty members, has stepped up plans to introduce an E-commerce major for graduate students this fall. School officials said they were also considering offering a master's degree in electronic business.
Changes in salaries reflect the growing demand. Five years ago, a new Wharton graduate with experience in E-commerce could expect a starting salary of $62,000, not including a bonus or stock options, Mr. Bonner said. Today, those offers start at $80,000, about $10,000 more than other business fields.
It is not just the computer literate who are making money. The academic foray into E-commerce has been profitable intellectually and financially. In most cases, the new programs have been a financial boon, bringing in tuition dollars and millions in grants to set up E-commerce research centers and faculty chairs.
At Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., a new M.B.A. concentration, known as E-business, and a graduate-level certificate in electronic business have become part of a shift to technology in the entire business curriculum. School administrators said the change in focus had brought in $500,000 in additional tuition this fall along with at least $7 million in related grants and contributions for program support and development.
Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta and Drexel University in Philadelphia have received $1 million each from corporations to establish E-commerce research centers. Both plan to offer E-commerce certificates or concentrations next year.
The new programs also give colleges, universities and graduate schools a drawing card to attract accomplished students who help to improve the overall quality of their applicant pools.
"E-commerce is moving so quickly that people don't have time to wait for experience to teach them," said R. M. Erik Gordon, the director of the Center for Retailing Education and Research at the University of Florida's business school. "The E-commerce credential sends the signal that someone knows something about E-commerce and that they've learned it in a focused and strategic way."
But many professors and business executives dismiss E-commerce degrees and programs as more marketing ploy than academically sound initiative.
"I object to the E-commerce degrees profusely," said Amit Pazgal, a marketing professor who teaches E-commerce at Washington University's John M. Olin School of Business in St. Louis. "I think it's a fad and that universities are just jumping on the bandwagon."
At the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Ryan Nelson, the director of the McIntire School of Commerce, said he turned down a professor's request to start an E-commerce program, arguing that the subject should be an integral part of the business curriculum. Edward A. Snyder, the dean of the university's Darden Graduate School of Business Administration, agreed. "E-commerce degrees are silly in the same way that teaching international business in a global economy is silly," he said.
HARVARD and Stanford have one or more courses devoted to E-commerce, but Harvard, at least, says it has no plans for a separate concentration or E-commerce degree.
"We have a good number of cases that focus on E-commerce throughout the curriculum," said Maura A. Byrne, a Harvard Business School spokeswoman. "But we are a school of general management. That's what it comes down to. Obviously, E-commerce is a hot and important industry to look at. But H.B.S. is about educating leaders and the best managers."
Other objections to starting more E-commerce programs include a shortage of qualified professors and of comprehensive, up-to-date textbooks. Because technology is advancing so quickly, the few E-commerce textbooks, articles and case studies available quickly become obsolete.
There is no shortage of faculty members willing to teach E-commerce courses, administrators say. They generally come from closely allied fields, like computer science or information technology; recent Ph.D.'s whose dissertations were in E-commerce; faculty "gear heads," who have pursued consulting or research on behalf of Web-based businesses, and "disciplinary migrants" -- young and midcareer faculty members looking for fields in which they can become pioneers and make their reputations. The challenge, administrators say, is finding faculty members who are more expert on computers than the students they will be teaching.
With the E-commerce programs still in their infancy, it is unclear what real value they will have, many professors and corporate recruiters say.
"Someone who has been exposed to a lot of dot-com successes and failures, even in an academic setting, would be viewed as more attractive, all things being equal," said Randall Kelley, a managing director with the executive search firm of Spencer Stuart in San Francisco and the head of its technology services practice.
Michael P. Sherman, the executive vice president of the Fingerhut Companies, said, "I don't know exactly what an E-commerce degree is, but if it means more skills in the E-commerce area, we are interested."
But Richard Alexander, who runs his own executive recruiting firm in Lawrenceville, N.J., said that until the E-commerce degree and its recipients established some kind of track record, "it has little credibility."
"It's ludicrous right now," he said. "It's not the Web-site person that companies are looking for. It's the person who has strategic experience and can apply it."
Still, students like James W. Walker see no downside to earning an E-commerce degree. Last May, Mr. Walker, a principal at American Management Systems, an information technology consulting firm in Denver, became one of five students from his company to join Carnegie Mellon's inaugural E-commerce class.
"I looked at the program and was amazed at what they were doing," he said. "I saw that I could further my knowledge of the Internet and acquire the soft skills that many engineers lack. Those are skills I need to move up in management."

SECTION: Section G; Page 22; Column 6; E-Commerce 

LENGTH: 442 words

HEADLINE: A Faster Way Of Shuffling The Data Cards

BYLINE: By STEVEN E. BRIER 

 BODY:
Al-go-rithm: 1. a repetitive procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing some end, especially by a computer; 2. the Veg-O-Matic of the data-mining world; it slices, it dices and it's faster than a speeding processor.
At its simplest, an algorithm is a set of instructions required to solve a problem. But at its best, an algorithm is a method of looking at information in ways that are not obvious to answer old questions better and faster, or to answer questions you didn't know you had. 
 "An algorithm is the teeny little engine that makes sense of masses of data," said Christopher Meyer, director of the Ernst & Young Center for Business Innovation in Cambridge, Mass.
Without algorithms, Mr. Meyer said, much of E-commerce would not be possible. Faster performance and unexpected results are what drive E-businesses, he said.
On-line businesses, and their marketing departments, collect mammoth amounts of data about their customers. What they looked at, what they bought, where they came from, where they went, where they live and dozens of other little pieces of information are tracked. Companies want to analyze that information and use it to tune their pricing, product lineup and welcoming screens.
"If you have to have a market analyst looking at every person and seeing what to market to them, it would not be economically feasible," Mr. Meyer said. "But if you can mine the data, you can make a business."
Mining those data requires more than fast processors, said William Pulleyblank, director of Deep Computing at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center. A well-designed algorithm can improve performance in a way that would take years through hardware.
Mr. Pulleyblank uses two methods of sorting 1,000 checks into numerical order to illustrate the improvement in performance that a clever algorithm can provide.
Version one requires rifling through the checks looking for the check with the lowest number and pulling it to the front, then going back and looking for the check with the next-lowest number and putting it behind the first. This would work, but you could end up comparing numbers on more than half a million pairs of checks. That is effective but time consuming.
Now try something different. Instead of sorting one big stack, divide the pile of checks in half. Then divide one of those halves in half again, sort each part and merge them. Now do the same with the other half.
Confusing? Maybe, but you just sorted the checks using only about 20,000 comparisons instead of half a million. And the savings in time grow exponentially with the size of the pile.
That's an algorithm in action.

SECTION: Section G; Page 26; Column 4; E-Commerce 

LENGTH: 1636 words

HEADLINE: A Ripe Target for Web Retailers, Teens Keep Heading to the Mall

BYLINE: By JULIE CONNELLY; Julie Connelly is a freelance writer based in New York.

 BODY:
TIM GEISENHEIMER, a computer savvy 15-year-old, has read most of the books of Iain Banks, the British novelist. But some of the surreal tales by the author are difficult to find in the United States. So a few months ago, the adolescent New Yorker checked in with Amazon.com, ordered what he wanted from England and paid for it with his mother's credit card. He gave his mother, Susan, cash when she received her statement. But she was aghast to discover the cost because the two paperbacks were shipped by air freight.
"Have you any idea what it costs to send books out from the U.K.?" she asked her son. "Before you do it again, let's talk about this." 
 So it is with teen-agers and the Internet. Many grew up wired and think on-line commerce is cool, but their parents, who worry about encouraging spendthrifts and protecting their own privacy, aren't as sure.
With Web retailing still in its infancy, most sites for teen-agers make money from accepting advertising and selling market research to manufacturers. "We don't sell names," said Dan Pelson, the chief executive of Bolt.com, which provides forums and information for teen-agers, "but we do sell trends. We have more data on teen preferences than anyone in the world."
According to Children's Business, a trade magazine, the sites encourage youngsters to "input information such as their names, ages, addresses, preferences, buying habits and even socioeconomic indicators" in an interactive format that doesn't always make it obvious that the teen-agers are taking part in a market research interview.
The potential customer base of teen-agers for on-line retailing is huge. There are 70 million children in the United States born to baby boomers since 1979.
Marketers know them and love them as Generation Y or the Echo Boom, a cohort that is more than 50 percent larger than the 45 million strong Generation X. Roughly 30 million are 12 to 19, a figure that will rise to 33.6 million by 2005. Their spending power is enormous. Teen Research Unlimited, a market research firm, says that teen-agers commanded $141 billion in spending last year, up 16 percent from 1997, and each youngster spent an average of $84 a week.
This teen-age population wave has crashed over the late 20th century's other big trend, the Internet. Find/SVP Research estimates that more than 20 million teen-agers will be on line by the end of the year. Once there, they will spend an average of a little more than seven hours a week on the Web, according to another researcher, Nielsen/Net Ratings.
How do they pass their on-line time? Chatting with their friends by E-mail, naturally -- two-thirds do that, consuming more than four of the seven hours.
Shopping has yet to command anywhere near that investment of time. Teen Research Unlimited surveyed 2,000 12- to 19-year-olds last spring, and of the 14 on-line activities they listed, checking out merchandise to buy at a store was 12th (26 percent of boys and 23 percent of girls did that), and buying goods on line was dead last (13 percent of boys and 7 percent of girls said they had done that). Rachel Geller, a partner at Geppetto, another market research firm, concluded that the Web accounts for a relatively small $1.4 billion of spending by adolescents.
Conversion rates, the industry term for turning an on-line window shopper into an on-line buyer, are still low. Web retailers do not release their figures, but across the Internet, the percentage ranges from one-half of a percent to 2 percent, meaning that only 1 in 50 browsers ultimately buys. Even so, like all Internet players, on-line merchants cannot resist extrapolating their growth into infinity, and sales estimates for the next century climb to 300 percent and 400 percent annual growth.
But what the retailers really do know is that half these youngsters have after-school jobs; they make money and are willing to spend it. "Teen spending is a very growing and important category," said Linda Freedman, the vice president for marketing at Fashiontrip.com, a site for teen-age girls. "They have high discretionary income because they don't pay taxes or rent."
The average on-line purchase is $38.35, according to Cheskin Research, and the goods that youngsters buy reflect what they buy off line at the mall: music, videos, accessories and clothing. Two of the most popular sites are Amazon.com and CDNow.com, though neither caters particularly to adolescents.
Music, however, is probably the easiest thing for youngsters to buy on line. They can sample the audio -- try it on, essentially, before they buy -- so there is less chance that they'll wind up with something that has to be returned.
Other popular Web stores are Delias.com, which has taken its famous catalogue for teen-age girls on line; Jcrew.com; Abercrombie.com, which has managed an amazing transformation from a frowsy purveyor of gun-check hunting jackets to a hip retailer for young men and women, and the ubiquitous Gap.com.
This assortment should not be surprising because there is no more brand-conscious consumer than a teen-ager. These youngsters may not have a clue who they are, but the brands they wear tell the world who they would like to be.
"For Christmas last year, my two brothers, who are 16 and 18, told me they wanted 'anything from Abercrombie & Fitch,' " said Renny Gleeson, the senior vice president at Iturf, the creator of Delia's on-line store. He noted that Brooke Shields and her Calvins brought name brands to the teen-age consumer 20 years ago, and brands have never looked back.
In theory, on-line retailing could turn mall rats into cyberrats, but marketers are hesitant to say so. Instead, they comment on the tendency for virtual merchants to become brick-and-mortar merchants to reinforce their presence on the Web. For example, Delia's, which has five retail stores nationwide, expects to expand to 12 to 16 by the end of the year. Moreover, the mall is still a gathering place. Unlike the Internet, which most youngsters troll from home, the mall is somewhere they go to when they need to get out of the house.
Ekaterina Walsh, a researcher at Forrester Research, said that while teen-agers say they plan to increase their on-line buying, less than 1 percent expect to forsake traditional stores.
In addition, Web shopping has drawbacks.
The most obvious is the one described by Mr. Pelson of Bolt.com: "Teens don't have the 16 digits." Only about 7 percent of teen-agers have their own credit cards. Everyone else has to borrow Mom's or Dad's. But Mom and Dad are worried about being scammed on line and prefer that their children order from catalogues over the telephone.
An on-line survey by Jupiter Communications this year of 2,000 households reported that safety concerns about the Internet are also rising. Seventy-six percent of parents said they were nervous about strangers their children might encounter in chat rooms or through E-mail, and 68 percent said they feared invasion of their privacy through direct-mail solicitations.
Concerns about protecting the personal and financial information of parents and children have given rise to a new solution for which retailers have high hopes, the "digital wallet." These sites let parents establish accounts from which children can draw to shop on line and limit the sites at which the money can be spent.
The big three are Icanbuy, Rocketcash and Doughnet. The average Icanbuy account, for example, is $50, and arrangements can be made for grandparents, aunts and uncles to contribute as well. Forrester Research reports that only 5 percent of teen-agers who buy on line have reached for the digital wallet, but the technology, a little more than a year old, is still in its infancy.
Shopping on the Web has other disadvantages. Purchasers can't try anything on, so they are frequently limited to accessories or items for which size doesn't matter. Even worse, teen-age shoppers frequently can't see what they are buying because the on-screen resolution, to use a technical term, stinks. A man's navy blue sweater at one on-line store was described as a V-neck, but the picture was so muddy, it looked like a crewneck, and shoppers have to take it on faith that the cargo skirt at another retailer has pockets. To rifle through a collection of dresses or khaki pants takes forever, because downloads plod along. Catalogues have much clearer photographs and drawings, and teen-agers can page through them faster.
But these are problems that newer chips and faster modems will eliminate.
The real experience that the Web cannot replicate is social. Shopping is something teen-agers do with their friends, especially girls who want to show each other how cool they look in the blue sweater they just found under a load of awful green ones.
"The Net kind of takes away the whole experience -- the hunt, the get and the buy," said Eva Kuhn, 13, of New York who browses on line but buys in the stores.
"Web shopping is just too perfect" she said. "You type in 'gray cords' and there they are. It's not fun. The fun is the hunt."
That's true, but the nature of the hunt changes on the Web. Teen-agers are extremely value-conscious shoppers, and they will comb the malls to get their favorite brands at lower prices. A growing Net-based economy is likely to push down prices because click-by-click comparison shopping is ultimately far less time-consuming.
"We're building the Bolt economy," Mr. Pelson said. "I can go to a cell phone manufacturer and say, 'I've got 10,000 teens who want your phones, but you sell them for $75 and they'll only pay $45.' That's pricing power as well as buying power."
That buying power exists, and teen-agers are just starting to flex it. Soon, the hunt will be on for the pricing power as well.

HEADLINE: For This Supplier, the Sum of Its Parts Adds Up to Success

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
PEOPLE looking for fast-paced, cutting-edge careers tend not to think about manufacturing valves, maintenance products and replacement parts for industry. Even less exciting would be cataloguing and distributing such mundane wares, which is how W. W. Grainger Inc. makes a living.
But Grainger is a good example of how even the most seemingly humdrum businesses are undergoing reconstructive surgery as E-commerce spreads through the economy. And Grainger's story shows how old-line industry stalwarts are not easy to shove aside in the business-to-business E-commerce sector, where reputations for reliability, speedy delivery and expert advice may be even more important than they are with consumer-product companies. 
 Middlemen like Grainger, which is based in the Chicago suburb of Lincolnshire and had $4.43 billion in revenue in 1998, prosper by making life more efficient or less expensive for commercial buyers and sellers. The company says that about 80 percent of all American businesses are within a 20-minute drive of a Grainger branch.
Grainger carries more than 4,000 different sizes and types of motors. It describes its lighting selection as "every light bulb known to man." In all, the company offers its 1.5 million customers about 210,000 products, and its red-covered catalogue (also in CD-ROM form), which runs to more than 4,000 pages, is one of the most widely distributed publications in business. Grainger consultants help businesses sort out purchasing policies, and some companies hire Grainger to make their purchasing decisions.
But even relative giants like Grainger own a small piece of the pie. Businesses spend $300 billion a year in the United States in Grainger's area of expertise: the equipment and services grouped into what is known as M.R.O., or maintenance, repair and operations. They spend $200 billion more managing the procurement offices, receiving operations and other activities that are needed to make those purchases.
No wonder Internet entrepreneurs have smelled opportunity. Although it has happened less visibly than in the book and toy businesses and other consumer markets, Grainger's blue-collar world is also on the menu for upstart companies that are built around powerful software and visions of a new, Internet-based order.
Investors clearly anticipate a revolution in business-to-business commerce. When Commerce One, which created an Internet marketplace for business buyers and suppliers, went public in July, its shares soared to $62 from $21 on the first day of trading. A few weeks earlier, its rival Ariba did even better, with its shares quickly jumping to $90 from $23.
The market is also being shaken up by business-software vendors. For example, Project Software and Development, which is known for production-management software, has set up an Internet marketplace at www.mro.com. By combining orders for its clients, Project Software expects to negotiate lower prices.
GIANTS like SAP and Oracle are also working on Internet-based procurement software that could streamline buying and encourage buyers to cut out middlemen whose computers cannot link to those software programs.
Another group of vendors, including Freemarkets Online, is using the Internet to set up custom auctions. Instead of contacting manufacturers individually or checking Grainger's catalogue for prices and delivery terms, a buyer could tell Freemarket what it needs and let Freemarket set up an auction in which qualified suppliers bid for the contract.
So, is Grainger, with its overhead of more than 15,000 employees and a network of more than 500 branches, in danger of being shoved aside?
Hardly. When it comes to business-to-business electronic commerce, traditional industry leaders have huge built-in advantages, industry analysts say. Businesses are much more varied in their needs than, say, the book purchasers served by Amazon.com or Barnesandnoble.com. Many companies place a high value on proven distribution systems like Grainger's, which their employees know how to deal with, and on the expert advice that experienced middlemen can provide.
"In the end, the bricks-and-mortar companies will win," said Barbara Reilly, the research director of E-business strategies at the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn.
That is, Ms. Reilly and other analysts say, assuming those companies adopt effective Internet strategies. Few have worked harder at doing that than Grainger, which has invested $35 million in a range of E-commerce initiatives.
"We're focused on leading the evolution," said Donald E. Bielinski, a Grainger group president who is overseeing electronic commerce. That wave is too powerful for Grainger to exert much control over, but analysts say the company is doing a deft job of riding it so far.
"At first I thought they were being defensive, but the more I look, the more I see offensive possibilities," said Russell Leavitt, an analyst at Banc of America Securities.
Grainger set up www.grainger .com, its "digital storefront," in 1995. On-line sales jumped to about $9 million a month this summer from a little more than $3 million a month in the first three months of this year.
Grainger calculates that 20 percent of the traffic on its site takes place outside normal business hours and that the average order is twice the size of the one received through traditional phone and fax contacts.
The company followed up its Web site by developing Orderzone.com, a marketplace where customers can order not just from Grainger but also from leading distributors in other business segments.
Orderzone leaves much to be desired for buyers who want E-commerce sites that are smoothly integrated with their own procurement-management systems. It offers one-stop shopping and payment but does not yet track deliveries, retain records of past orders or make it simple for buyers to compare competing products.
Grainger says that thousands of companies have registered since Orderzone.com went on line in mid-May but declined to release early revenue figures. Mr. Bielinski said that a surprising number of big customers had signed on, apparently seeking experience with what could be a step toward a full-service marketplace.
But the most intriguing piece of Grainger's E-commerce strategy has been its collaboration with many of the newcomers and large software companies like SAP, whose products and goals could make Grainger's life more difficult. Grainger has signed alliances aimed at insuring that as many software programs and Internet portals as possible link to its own site and to Orderzone.com.
IT is a risky approach. The other players may make it easy for Grainger customers to move to other suppliers or, by joining orders from many customers at a portal like MRO.com, pressure Grainger to cut prices. But Grainger has done more than sign on as a supplier; it has also taken stakes in several other concerns, including Project Software and Commerce One.
"Grainger is very Internet savvy," said Norman E. Drapeau Jr., the president and chief executive officer of Project Software. "They understand that some piece of their business may be cannibalized."
As Grainger sees it, though, the explosion in pathways to its doorway will give it more chances to exploit its brand name and distribution system.
"I have a real tough time with the word 'competitor' in the digital marketplace," Mr. Bielinski said. "There is so much room for cooperation. The potential payoff is huge."
