HEADLINE: City Calls Police Recruiting Drive a Success

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
A $9 million recruitment campaign that the New York Police Department began last winter with a goal of making the force more representative of the five boroughs yielded modest increases in the number of city residents and members of minority groups who signed up to take the police test, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday.
But some critics questioned whether the results of the campaign were dramatic enough to consider the recruitment drive, which was by far the city's largest and costliest ever, a success. A total of 15,200 people signed up to take the police test this year, up from 14,202 last year, Mr. Safir said. In past years, however, it was routine for more than 20,000 people to sign up for tests: 21,657 did so in 1997, and 31,986 did in 1996. The written test, to be administered this year on Oct. 2, is the first step toward becoming a police officer. 
 Mr. Safir brushed off the critics, saying this year's recruitment drive achieved its goals. "The whole idea of this campaign was to attract more city residents, which we did, and more people of color, which we have," he said. "What I find most amazing about all of this is that with the negative press that the N.Y.P.D. has experienced over the past year, in which the P.D. has been vilified by the press over and over again, it is even more of an indication of the success of the recruiting campaign."
The recruitment drive, which included television, radio and newspaper advertisements, as well as large outdoor rallies, was announced in February as the public outcry over the police shooting of Amadou Diallo mounted and many officials said they were concerned that the police force has a higher percentage of white officers than the city it serves. Some officials renewed their calls for legislation that would require police officers to live in the city.
Preliminary data indicates that 67 percent of the people who signed up to take the written exam this year live in the city, up from 64 percent of last year's group, Mr. Safir said. The number of black applicants rose to 25.9 percent this year, up from 21.1 percent last year, and the number of Hispanic applicants rose to 30 percent, up from 25.5 percent.
But critics questioned whether it was cost-effective to spend more than $9 million on a recruitment drive, considering the results: about 700 more city residents, about 800 more black applicants and about 800 more Hispanic applicants.
"It's incremental progress," said Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. "With all the resources and attention paid to this, one would have hoped that the increases would have been more dramatic."
As the economy has strengthened, urban police departments around the country have had difficulty recruiting officers. In New York City, candidates must complete two years of college or military service before they are eligible to join the force, which pays a $34,000 starting salary, with benefits factored in. Many police officials said that the job, with relatively low pay, difficult hours and its inherent risks, is simply a hard sell.
Patrick Lynch, the new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said that the city needs to improve the salaries and working conditions of officers. "I think they spent $9 million and wasted their money," he said. "The starting salary doesn't put food on the table. The best recruitment poster is a happy police officer, who goes home and tells his relatives and friends about the job."
Throughout the campaign Mr. Safir and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have referred to the drive as a campaign aimed at city residents, not at members of minority groups. But their statements have left little doubt that they were hoping to use the drive to make the department more racially diverse.
The New York Police Department is one of the nation's least racially diverse big-city departments. Whites make up 67.4 percent of the force, but only 43.4 percent of the city's population, according to figures from the Police Department and from the 1990 United States Census. Among the nation's 10 largest cities, the only two with a higher percentage of white officers are San Diego and Phoenix, where a far greater percentage of residents are white.
The percentage of officers living in the city has dropped in the last decade, to 54 percent from 60 percent.
Lieut. Eric Adams, of the group 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care, said the department will need better pay and better community relations if it is to attract more black and Hispanic applicants and city residents. "You can't buy this," he said. "You have to go out there and earn it one body at a time."
In addition to its advertising blitz, the Police Department gave out hundreds of pens and key chains with the department logo and opened a recruiting station in an empty storefront on a mall on DeKalb Avenue in downtown Brooklyn. One morning last month, shortly before Mr. Safir paid a visit to the station, a police officer approached a young man there.
"Interested in joining the Police Department?" the officer asked.
"I'm a gang member," the young man replied, walking on without stopping.
Mr. Safir said he expects the recruitment campaign to have residual effects as the Police Department prepares for its next drive in January, for a test in May. And he said he has no doubt that the numbers would have been much worse had the department not spent the time, money and energy in trying to attract applicants from the city.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Bank Clings to Monetary Policy

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The Japanese central bank voted today to leave monetary policy unchanged, defying Government officials and economists here and abroad who have been demanding that the bank take aggressive steps to reverse the yen's heady rise in value.
"Foreign exchange rates themselves are not an aim of Bank of Japan monetary policy," the bank said in a tartly worded statement. "The Bank of Japan has learned valuable lessons from the bubble years that connecting monetary policy to control of exchange rates" carries the risk of getting policy wrong. 
 About 5 P.M. here today, when the bank issued its statement, the dollar was selling at almost 107 yen. Twenty minutes later, it was worth 104, as traders surged into the market to buy yen and sell dollars on a bet that the Japanese currency would strengthen. Late in New York today, the yen settled at 104.87 to the dollar, compared with 106.38 on Monday.
 Early Wednesday, the yen was virtually unchanged. The Japanese stock market, though, fell sharply, down more than 3 percent in the first two hours of trading.
"Now, it's going to be the markets versus the Bank of Japan," a senior Japanese Finance Ministry official said. "The market was disappointed, and so were many people in the Ministry of Finance."
The ministry had been pressing the central bank to further loosen what the bank already considers a loose monetary policy -- in the interest of weakening the yen, which surged to its strongest levels in more than three years last week.
The yen's strength reflects a belief among global investors that Japan's economy is emerging from a prolonged slump, which has increased demand for the currency. But a strong yen also makes Japanese exports more expensive abroad and could forestall economic recovery.
"A stronger yen means exporters get hurt, they cut wages, their employees cut their spending and that hampers economic growth," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo.
The United States Treasury has also pressed the Japanese central bank for a looser monetary policy as a condition for American participating in any coordinated effort to weaken the yen.
The currency markets had been betting that the Japanese would move in some way to dilute the yen's value by expanding the money supply, perhaps by pumping more excess cash into the money market than the one trillion yen now available. That expectation had pushed down the currency on Monday and helped rally Japanese stock prices.
The bank did not, in fact, rule out an expansion of the money supply, but it repeated its official position that such additional liquidity would have a short-term impact at best. "The Bank of Japan cannot resort to policies if it cannot explain their effects," it said.
The central bank has steadfastly maintained that it has gone as far as it can to pump liquidity into the economy, but to no avail. It has pushed short-term interest rates close to zero, and still, commercial banks are reluctant to lend and prospective borrowers to borrow. It has intervened in the currency markets, selling yen nine times since June to push down the currency, and yet the yen has moved higher and higher.
Mr. Feldman said he thought the central bank would now begin laying the groundwork for an an easing of monetary policy, with the aim of expanding the money supply, but without appearing to make a 180-degree turn away from its stated opposition to such an approach.
"The issue of saving face for the Bank of Japan is quite important," he wrote in a report to investors. Referring to Masaru Hayami, the bank's chief, he said, "Governor Hayami has taken a strong stance against easing, and he must be satisfied that the Bank of Japan is not being bullied and does not appear to be bullied."
Mr. Hayami has charted an independent course for the central bank since he took over as head of its policy board last year, when the bank was declared free from the Finance Ministry and the ruling political party. But he has had to fight the bank's former masters every step of the way, and in the process, has been accused of stubbornness and inflexibility. There has been speculation Mr. Hayami will step down, but he seems firmly committed to his job.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Bill Is Blocked In Fight Over Minimum Pay

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Trying to force a vote on a measure to increase the minimum wage, Democratic senators today blocked Republican legislation to revamp Federal bankruptcy laws, at least for the time being.
The bankruptcy bill, a version of which was approved by the House of Representatives in May, is one of the few Republican legislative initiatives still in play this year. Strongly supported by the banking and credit card industries, it would make it harder for consumers to avoid paying debts by declaring bankruptcy. 
 Democrats, led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, want to attach an amendment that would raise the Federal minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour, to $6.15 in two 50-cent installments over the next two years.
"Raising the minimum wage is critical to preventing the economic free fall that often leads to bankruptcy," Senator Kennedy said today.
But most Republicans say raising the minimum wage would be devastating to some small businesses and would cost many jobs.
Voting along party lines this evening, the Senate rejected a Republican move to bring the bankruptcy bill to a vote by invoking cloture. The vote was 53 to 45, 7 votes shy of the 60 needed to halt debate. If cloture had been approved, the Democrats' minimum-wage amendment would have been foreclosed.
Behind the scenes, however, party leaders were meeting to try to negotiate a compromise. The prevailing view in both parties today was that a deal could eventually be worked out that would lead to passage of both the minimum-wage increase and the bankruptcy legislation.
The minimum wage issue has divided Republicans and Democrats for generations, and arguments have hardly changed since the minimum wage was introduced in the 1930's.
On one side are the Democrats and liberal economists who hold that market forces have failed workers in low-paying jobs. A fair minimum wage, they say, prevents sweatshops and rewards people who leave welfare rolls and go to work. These advocates maintain that the resulting job loss, if any, will be trivial.
On the other side, Republicans and conservative economists say that much of the benefit will go to teen-agers who do not really need the money and that some businesses, especially smaller ones, will go bankrupt, and others will raise prices, leading to inflation. Many poor people, the opponents say, will lose jobs because businesses will let them go rather than raise their pay.
Whatever the economic arguments, the political situation is clear: this is a good issue for Democrats, and Republicans are likely to switch rather than fight.
In the House, Republican leaders have conceded that they do not have the votes to defeat the Democratic bill. They are working on a compromise that would tie the minimum-wage increase to some modest tax breaks for small businesses.
Supporters of the legislation said today that despite the setback, they expected the bankruptcy measure to be introduced again, particularly since a similar measure passed in the last session by a vote of 97 to 1.
But even if it is adopted, the Senate legislation cannot become law until it is reconciled with a more stringent version that was adopted by the House last May.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
INDIA: POLLS PUT HINDUS AHEAD
An exit poll for the private Star TV said the Hindu nationalist-led coalition is heading for a sweeping victory in national elections that conclude Oct. 3. Another exit poll, broadcast by the state television network, put the coalition firmly in the lead, though not by such a large margin. A third, smaller exit poll, by a regional newspaper in the state of Maharashtra, showed the coalition narrowly ahead. Celia W. Dugger (NYT) 

PHILIPPINES: PROTESTS GROW
Transport strikes crippled four cities and more than 100,000 protesters marched to oppose President Joseph Estrada's plan to rewrite the Constitution. Warning against the return of dictatorship, church and leftist groups joined forces in demonstrations in Manila and major provincial cities. Jaime Cardinal Sin and other leaders fear that Mr. Estrada is pushing to remove a provision limiting a President to one six-year term. (Reuters)
 
JAPAN: LIBERAL LEADER RE-ELECTED
The Liberal Democratic Party re-elected Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi as its president, thus extending his term as head of the Government. Mr. Obuchi, who has been in office a year, has proven unexpectedly popular, using his political skills to cobble together a coalition that insures him legislative success and doling out money to push the economy. Stephanie Strom (NYT)
 
MALAYSIA: 3 ANWAR ACTIVISTS HELD
Three key opposition activists were arrested in what appears to be a new crackdown on dissent after a wave of protests in support of former Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who is hospitalized after allegations that he was poisoned. Four other activists were arrested on Monday. Meanwhile, the opposition coalition chose Mr. Anwar as its candidate for Prime Minister, despite his six-year prison sentence for corruption. (AP)
 
NORTH KOREA: MOVE ON CURBS WELCOMED
North Korea welcomed a partial lifting of United States economic sanctions and asked for remaining curbs to be removed. "It is a good development, though it is not comprehensive and came belatedly," the Government news agency said. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: GOALS TO END POVERTY
Elaborating on a recent pledge by Prime Minister Tony Blair to eradicate child poverty in Britain in 20 years, the Government set a series of measurable goals to improve housing, health care and education, increase jobs and incomes and counter bias. Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling said, "For the first time a Government is standing up to be counted setting specific standards against which we will be judged tackling poverty and its causes." Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: CLASHES CONTINUE
The rival Catholic and Protestant parties, Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists, met together with Senator George J. Mitchell in Belfast but continued to clash over whether the Northern Ireland peace agreement could go forward without any disarmament by I.R.A. paramilitaries. Senator Mitchell, chairman of the talks that led to the April 1998 accord, is in the third week of a mission to rescue the stalemated accord. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
GERMANY: VATICAN CURBS ABORTION
Bishop Karl Lehmann, the head of the German Bishops' Conference, has received a letter from the Vatican telling German bishops that the church can no longer hand out counseling certificates to women to enable them to get abortions. Under German law, a woman wanting to end her pregnancy must first receive a certificate saying she has been counseled by an advisory service. One-sixth of the 1,500 such services in the country are run by the Catholic Church. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
FRANCE: MUSLIMS' EXPULSION STANDS
The Government upheld a decision to expel two Muslim girls from their junior high school after they wore traditional Islamic scarfs in class. The Government commissioner upheld the education authority's decision at an administrative court in Caen. The debate has brought France's tradition of separation of church and state into conflict with freedom of religious expression. (AP)
 
FRANCE: NEW CHIRAC RIVAL
The already frazzled right-wing party of President Jacques Chirac suffered a new split when a sixth candidate, Michele Alliot-Marie, entered the race to head the Gaullist movement, the Rally for the Republic. This will make it even harder for Mr. Chirac to unite the party behind his effort to be re-elected in 2000. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
FRANCE, ITALY: ONE-DAY CAR BAN
Paris and Rome, and more than 150 other European towns and cities, will join to celebrate a pedestrians' day today by keeping cars out of urban centers. Many boulevards, avenues and squares will be accessible only to strollers, rollerskaters, joggers and pedicabs. Some will allow buses and electric vehicles. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: NEW EFFORT BY OPPOSITION
Fourteen academics and intellectuals who are trying to help eight opposition parties break the impasse in talks over forming a coalition for the July 2000 general elections said they were writing a new proposal for how the parties could pick a single presidential candidate. But Vicente Fox and Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the two main opposition candidates, exchanged icy greetings in a chance public encounter and both suggested that they are writing the coalition out of their plans. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: PROTEST ON U.N. ENVOY
Israel protested the selection by Secretary General Kofi Annan of a special envoy to the Mideast, saying Mr. Annan had expanded the title and functions beyond that of a coordinator of United Nations activities in the region. Terje Roed-Larsen was appointed Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process and Mr. Annan's personal representative to the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian Authority. Israel's United Nations mission says the title implies a role for the organization in peace talks and is "unacceptable to the Government of Israel." Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
IRAQ: JOURNALIST HURT IN ATTACK
A Swedish journalist was slightly hurt in southern Iraq when a missile apparently fired by a Western warplane landed within 50 yards of a car in which he was riding. Jan Arell, of The Goteborg Post, said the attack had been preceded by nearby antiaircraft fire. United States military spokesmen confirmed that American and British planes had been in action at about the time Mr. Arell was hurt. Douglas Jehl (NYT)
 
IRAN: RIGHTS RECORD DEPLORED
President Thomas Klestil of Austria expressed the European Union's "dismay and preoccupation over the human rights situation" in Iran after the death sentences handed down last week against four people said to have been behind student protests in July. Mr. Klestil was ending a two-day visit, the first in 20 years by a European Union head of state. (Agence France-Presse)
 
IRAN: CONSERVATIVES RETAIN CONTROL
Iran's conservative Council of Guardians has reasserted its right to bar election candidates from the ballot at will, a move seen as damaging to reformers' prospects in coming votes. In a letter to Parliament, the council rejected a part of the proposed new law requiring it to say in writing why a candidate was disqualified. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
SUDAN: OPPOSITION SUED OVER BLAST
The Government has filed lawsuits against opposition parties that took responsibility for an attack on a new oil pipeline in Government-controlled territory north of Khartoum. A presidential spokesman said prosecutors had been told to sue the opposition National Democratic Alliance and the Umma Party on charges of blowing up the line. Repairs are expected to be completed by today. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Raise Intervention Abilities, Clinton Urges U.N. Members

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton today urged other members of the United Nations to strengthen their collective capacity for intervening to prevent the kinds of mass killings and ethnic repression that ravaged Kosovo and East Timor, saying that there are limits to what individual nations can accomplish.
"Promising too much can be as cruel as caring too little," Mr. Clinton said in a speech to the General Assembly. "But difficulties, dangers and costs are not an argument for doing nothing. 
 "When we are faced with deliberate, organized campaigns to murder whole peoples, or expel them from their land," he continued, "the care of victims is important, but not enough. We should work to end the violence."
But the President offered no specific proposals for helping the United Nations take responsibility for peacekeeping, even though its efforts in that regard have been hobbled by the failure of the United States to pay what it owes the world organization.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton waited till the end of his speech before turning to the subject uppermost on the minds of most of his audience: the $1.6 billion that the United Nations says Washington owes in back dues, interest and other assessments.
The President described the United Nations as "indispensable" and said that "the United States also has the responsibility to equip the U.N. with the resources that it needs to be effective.
"As I think most of you know, I have strongly supported the United States meeting all its financial obligations to the United Nations, and I will continue to do so," he said. There was polite but unenthusiastic applause at the end of his speech. President Clinton's spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said there has been "obvious and articulated concern from many quarters" about the unpaid debt, but he described the response to Mr. Clinton's speech as positive and appropriate.
"It's not like a basketball arena where people are standing, loudly cheering," Mr. Lockhart said.
President Clinton started his day by discussing the arrears with Secretary General Kofi Annan.
A senior Administration official said, "The President again indicated that this was a high priority for him and that he was very much going to work hard to try to see if we could resolve this problem this year."
Under the United Nations Charter, the United States could be stripped of its vote in the General Assembly at the end of 1999 unless it pays sufficiently on its arrears. In a July report, the General Accounting Office estimated that the United States would need to pay about $153 million in addition to the $508 million the State Department expects to pay before the end of the year.
The Senate approved a bill in June authorizing payment of more than $800 million to the United Nations, but it attached conditions cutting the American share of the budget from 25 to 20 percent and its share of peacekeeping expenses from 31 to 25 percent. The House has yet to vote on the measure.
Several diplomats and representatives of non-governmental organizations said President Clinton had lost credibility in terms of his ability to get the American dues paid.
In his remarks about stopping mass killings and ethnic cleansing, President Clinton acknowledged the United States' reluctance to get drawn into other deadly internal conflicts like those in Africa.
"I know that some are troubled that the United States and others cannot respond to every humanitarian catastrophe in the world," Mr. Clinton said. "We cannot do everything everywhere. But simply because we have different interests in different parts of the world does not mean we can be indifferent to the destruction of innocents in any part of the world."
Mr. Clinton defended the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's decision to begin an air war against Serbia, saying that it followed a consensus in the Security Council that Serbian atrocities against Kosovo's ethnic Albanians were unacceptable.
"Had we chosen to do nothing in the face of this brutality, I do not believe we would have strengthened the United Nations," Mr. Clinton said. "Instead, we would have risked discrediting everything it stood for."
His assertion was implicitly contradicted by the Russian Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, who said that the United Nations' authority had been "seriously and painfully tested" by the crises over ethnic cleansing in Kosovo and weapons inspections in Iraq. Russia objected to military action in both.
"We have managed through joint efforts to bring the settlement of the Kosovo problem back within the legal and political framework of the United Nations," Mr. Ivanov said.
Mr. Clinton proposed two other long-term goals for the United Nations: first, eradicating poverty and disease and helping poorer countries join the global economy.
"We must refuse to accept a future in which one part of humanity lives on the cutting edge of a new economy, while the other lives at knife edge of survival," he said.
The second goal was stopping the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.
President Clinton, said cooperation was especially needed to keep weapons of mass destruction out of the hands of terrorist groups.
"They may have weaker capabilities than states, but they have fewer compunctions about using such weapons," he said.
After his speech, Mr. Clinton heldmeetings with several other leaders, including President Andres Pastrana of Colombia, whose country has been destabilized by guerrilla warfare and drug trafficking.

HEADLINE: Ford in Pact With Canada's Auto Workers

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 21

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company reached a tentative, three-year contract this evening with the union representing its Canadian workers, three hours before a threatened strike at midnight.
The agreement was similar to the generous deal that DaimlerChrysler A.G. negotiated with the United Automobile Workers union last Thursday, although that contract is for four years. 
 Both deals call for workers to receive annual wage increases of 3 percent plus annual cost of living adjustments nearly equal to the inflation rate. With Canadian inflation running at close to 2 percent, the union said that this would mean total annual wage increases would be roughly 4.5 percent.
Both deals also provide large increases in pension benefits, to encourage older workers to retire, partly to make way for younger workers and partly to allow auto workers to reduce their work forces slowly so as to become more competitive. The Canadian retirees will receive an immediate, 13.5 percent increase in monthly pension payments.
"This is an excellent agreement," said Basil Hargrove, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, which represents 13,300 Ford workers in Canada. The union's members will vote on the agreement on Sunday; similar ratification votes in the past have been easily approved.
The final issue in the negotiations involved the union's contention that Ford planned to move the production of minivan seats in 2002 from a unionized supplier, the Lear Corporation, to Magna International Inc., which is not unionized. Mr. Hargrove said that this issue had not been resolved, and would be the subject of further talks with Ford.
The Canadian union plans to ask the General Motors Corporation and DaimlerChrysler to accept similar deals. Mr. Hargrove said that the union had not chosen which company would come next in the negotiations.
Tonight's peaceful settlement is a coup for Ford. Canadian auto workers have a militant tradition of going on strike against at least one auto maker each time a labor contract expires; the contract in force for the last three years expired at midnight. The union has checked its records back to 1970 and found a strike every time that a contract expired except in 1993.
Jane Armstrong, a union spokeswoman, said that she believed that there had also been strikes after every contract expiration before 1970, going back to the first contracts in the late 1930's, although the union has not checked its records back that far. The Canadian Auto Workers union split off from the less militant United Automobile Workers union and became independent in 1984.
The Canadian workers have almost always struck the first company with which their leaders have sought a deal. An exception to that rule came on the last contract, in 1996, when the Canadian workers staged a three-week walkout against General Motors after reaching a pattern-setting contract with what was then the Chrysler Corporation.
Despite the frequency of strikes, auto makers have been willing to expand their operations in Canada. While auto workers used to earn the same on both sides of the border, the weakness of the Canadian dollar in recent years has made auto workers' wages and other costs there a third lower than in the United States.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Growth in Trade Deficit Prompts Concern for Dollar
Another leap in the United States trade deficit in July fueled fears that a continuing surge in imports is threatening the health of the dollar.
The Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit for the month hit $25.2 billion, higher than the June imbalance of $24.6 billion, confounding expectations that the deficit would start to shrink as economic growth picks up around the world. Imports from China, Western Europe and Japan all hit new highs, well above the projections of most economists who have followed the trade flows with increasing concern. Page A1. 

Stock prices were pulled down by a further slide in the value of the dollar against the yen, warnings about third-quarter earnings, worries about the earthquake in Taiwan and the trade deficit. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 225.43 points, to 10,598.47. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 27.95 points, to 1,307.58. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 65.05 points, to 2,821.10. C10.
 
Goldman Posts Strong Results
Goldman Sachs Group reported surprisingly strong earnings in its first full quarter as a public company, a striking reversal from a year ago when fallout from Russia's economic woes forced the investment banking firm to postpone plans for its initial public offering of stock. Goldman, which went public with an offering of $3.7 billion on May 4, said it earned $638 million, or $1.32 a diluted share, in its fiscal third quarter, exceeding the expectations of Wall Street analysts. C2.
 
Disparity in Minority Credit Ratings
Even in the current flush economic times, with home ownership rates reaching record highs, a disproportionately large number of minorities, chiefly blacks, have poor credit ratings, according to a new study. C5.
 
Pension Fight Moves to Congress
The fight over cash-balance pensions has moved to Congress, where lobbyists and Congressional aides say the dispute over I.B.M.'s pension switch will probably help spur legislation to rein in the plans. C4.
 
Japan Monetary Policy Unchanged
The Japanese central bank voted to leave monetary policy unchanged, defying Government officials and economists who have been demanding that the bank take aggressive steps to reverse the yen's heady rise in value. C3.
 
Venezuela Plans to Make Payments
President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela, in an effort to reassure foreign investors, said his Government would make all its debt payments while at the same time working on a market-friendly proposal that would allow it to pay off its current debt over a longer period. His comments came as investors keep a close watch on emerging markets throughout Latin America. Ecuador is struggling to avoid a default on its foreign debt and Brazil is still working to come back from the devaluation of its currency in January. C3.
 
Hewlett and Oracle to Collaborate
Hewlett-Packard strengthened its Internet presence with the announcement of a deal with Oracle to collaborate on developing and selling Oracle's electronic-commerce software on Hewlett-Packard computers. C6.
 
U.S. Suit Against Tobacco Industry
The Justice Department is about to file a civil suit against the tobacco industry and try to recover billions of dollars in health-related expenses, a Government official said. A1.
 
3Com Earnings Beat Expectations
3Com attributed its strong first-quarter earnings, which exceeded estimates, to strong growth in hand-held computing products and improved operating efficiency. C8.
 
HarperCollins Announces Cuts
HarperCollins, which recently acquired William Morrow & Company and Avon Books, announced a series of moves to consolidate its imprints, which resulted in layoffs of 74 employees and the departure of top executives from Morrow. C8.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AUSTRALIA;
TAXES TO BE CUT

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Australian Government plans to cut business and capital gains taxes to make the nation more attractive to investors. The business tax rate will be cut by six percentage points, to 30 percent, on a par with Germany and below the United States, the Treasurer, Peter Costello, said. The Government will also cut the highest rate of capital gains tax for individuals by half, to 24 percent, and exempt United States and British investors from paying capital gains tax on venture funds.

HEADLINE: Man Emerges, Still Breathing, After E-Cave Confinement

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
AS humanity moves to the 21st-century method of grocery shopping -- over the Internet -- I see key limitations of old-style, walk-in markets. For one thing, they never told me that the banana is considered an herb because it lacks woody tissue.
I pick up that fact when I click on "banana" while strolling the produce section of Webvan, an on-line grocer that advertises same-day delivery. As I fill my virtual basket, I bask in the advantages of on-line shopping, like copious product information, and in the absence of time-consuming shopping hassles, like finding a parking space or wearing pants. 
 It is a Sunday night, and I have just sealed myself into an E-cave. For the next five days, I will order all sustenance and entertainment from the Net. I will hunker down in a bachelor pad in Palo Alto, Calif., armed with credit card and mouse. I will become the worst nightmare of OPEC and the makers of deodorant soap.
I click my way to Webvan's checkout aisle to schedule a delivery time. Tomorrow morning would be great. Then, crisis. I'm told that deliveries are first come, first served. Webvan can deliver the same day, but the next available appointment is Wednesday night. Wednesday? By Wednesday, I could walk to the nearest market and back -- on stilts. I could buy groceries and take a two-day seminar on "The Banana: Animal, Mineral or Herb."
E-commerce has revolutionized the selling of books, compact disks, travel and financial services and computer hardware and software -- commodities shoppers don't need to squeeze and prod to get a handle on. But will the on-line bazaar work for everyday survival, and as a means for daily upkeep of heart, soul, body, mind and, foremost, stomach?
Or, put another way, as I stare at Webvan's offer of a delivery in 72 hours: When E-commerce fails to deliver, which parts of my computer are edible?
 
Monday
Learning to Order Food In an Australian Accent
In his quest for food, primitive man faced disease, pestilence and the woolly mammoth. I face slothlike delivery schedules. Undaunted by my Webvan disappointment, I set out on Monday morning to hunt and gather 21st-century style. I soon spot prey.
A Web search turns up 69 sites offering "grocery delivery," including Groceronline, Netgrocer and Electrolley. I pop into and register at several sites, then head down the virtual aisles.
But each time I go to check out, I learn delivery is either not available in my area or will take 3 to 10 days. Electrolley serves only Perth, Australia. Internet Home Delivery focuses on Florida's North Pinellas County. A harsh reality dawns: either I wait a week for food or move to Australia.
By noon, frantic I'll star in the sequel to "Alive," I change strategies. I search on "food delivery, Palo Alto" and am led to Waiters.com, a service that takes on-line orders for local restaurants. At one spot I know, the Good Earth, I point and click through the menu. But I make rookie E-commerce errors, neglecting, for example, to complete registration forms. I inadvertently hit the browser's back button while trying to order a Danish. Two hours later -- it's 1:30 in the afternoon -- my $32 order arrives from the Good Earth. Hungry and having not seen another human being in nearly 24 hours, I practically hug Louis, the Waiters.com driver. This prompts some advice. "If I were you," he says, "I would have ordered over the phone. It's easier."
If he only knew. All day, I have battled not just delivery schedules but a debilitating injury. I have hurt my left pinkie. I jammed it in a recent basketball game, and it's swollen and purple, like a mini-eggplant.
If this sounds melodramatic, consider that in evolutionary terms, there is little worse than a crippled typing finger in the E-commerce age. I'm like a cave man unable to carry a club, a tiger without claws. I wince each time I type Q or A, two-thirds of the mother lode of all pertinent information on most sites. I speak of the "FAQ."
I divine an answer: the cybermedic. A search for "medical advice" returns the names of dozens of doctors who offer virtual consultations. I even find a specialist, a sports orthopedist named Stuart Zeman. "Most people dread going to the doctor," his site says. "It can be expensive, inconvenient and stressful." Dr. Zeman's alternative is an E-mail consultation for 10 bucks.
Not only is he inexpensive, he's also concise. You get one paragraph to describe your malady, and the virtual physician's response runs only a few lines. (Somewhere, an H.M.O. executive is taking copious notes.)
And so by the end of the day, I have scored several small E-commerce victories, including the fact that late in the afternoon, I have discovered an on-line grocer called Peapod. It was recommended not by a search engine but by Louis from Waiters .com. I arrange for a Tuesday delivery.
When I go to bed, I have fed my brain with food, and I have tended to my corpus with medical advice. Tomorrow, feeling more seasoned in the ways of E-commerce, I will feed my soul. I will buy a golf course.
 
Tuesday
Living Room Is Perfect For Sinking a 9-Footer
Well, not an entire golf course, but at least an indoor putting green. This will permit me to test my E-commerce mettle, alleviate the boredom that accompanies an on-line, in-house life style and address one of life's pressing concerns, improving my golf game.
My search-engine request on Yahoo spits out nearly 40 possible merchants, with names like Eagle Putting Greens and Chip-n-Putt. There are synthetic putting greens for the backyard, the home, the office, the home office and the backyard office. There are do-it-yourself kits, synthetic grass sold by the yard and pictures of children playing on elaborate miniature golf courses that can be constructed on large estates.
It occurs to me that the Net is the world's biggest mall, a discount shopping strip that stretches from Finland to Fresno. But it's a double-edged sword; the vast product choices can make for a bottomless shopping experience. An obsessive-compulsive comparison shopper may wind up being carried away in a padded van.
I settle on a shop called Big Moss Golf. This is partly because it feels like a local store and partly because it promises to bring my handicap out of the stratosphere. And partly because it has a toll-free number for customer service, and I'm starting to get a little lonely in the E-cave.
"You'll have to work that out yourself," Tony Terisco says. He's the owner of Big Moss Golf who sells me on the Big Moss Original, a $159, nine-foot-long piece of carpet simulated to feel like grass with a golf hole at one end.
"This will do more for your game than anything else in the golf industry," he promises.
It dawns on me that it may be even more instructive to play actual golf. But I'm in no mood to quibble. I pay an extra $30 for overnight delivery.
Just then, I receive a house call from my on-line doctor, Stuart Zeman. "You must get an X-ray," he prescribes in no uncertain terms.
Leave the house? Never! I've got a reputation to uphold. I decide to seek a second opinion. I fire off an E-mail to Dr. Michele Moore, who runs a site called www.askyour familydoc.com. She will give me a virtual bedside counsel for $25.
As dusk settles, I'm feeling ever more optimistic about my E-commerce prowess. Except for one nagging concern: Have I started to go a little stir-crazy? Does part of me long for casual conversation in the express checkout lane, a little flirtation with the waitress, even an exchange of angry words at a stoplight?
I quickly dismiss the notion. Frankly, I'm as sane at this moment as I've ever been. I am totally in control.
 
Wednesday
An On-line Warrior Victorious in Battle
Help. Send Prozac. Otherwise, I may torture and kill my neighbor. She's a nice enough young lady, but she's been practicing the piano for hours, repeatedly crashing down on the keys with hands like anvils. I look frazzled, with hair like Mozart's.
But I will combat her, E-commerce style. My weapons are earplugs and aspirin. My destination is pharmaceutical sites. I settle on Planetrx.com and Drugstore.com, which are battling it out to be the next millennium's Long's and Walgreens, but without the bricks and mortar.
I register at each site and check their delivery schedules. Then I take my budding skills to the next level -- I engage in a bit of hard-core price comparison. I open two browser windows and compare the sites side by side, checking response time, prices and product information. It is as if I were walking down an aisle with the products from the respective stores on each side of me. I am voting in real time with my mouse.
The arrows favor Planetrx. Minutes later, I "walk out" with earplugs and Advil, opting for overnight delivery for an additional $10. While I'm at it, I check out the stores' aisles of bandage tape for my injured digit. Drugstore.com offers eight pages of athletic tape and gauze products.
This is when I realize I've E-volved into a wily E-commerce veteran. I'm in and out of the drugstores in 10 minutes, far less than it would have taken to drive to a pharmacy. I've learned that E-commerce success depends on equal parts computer and modem but also confidence and experience. When I look in the mirror, I see a mouse-toting warrior, albeit one whose hair is standing on end, who is clad exclusively in boxer shorts. No shirt. No shoes. No problem.
Flush with success, I endeavor an E-commerce challenge with an Olympic degree of difficulty. I'm going to use my modem to get my cat to stop throwing up. I've tried the normal remedies, like giving her soft foods and beer, but frankly, I inherited the cat from an ex-girlfriend and I never could figure her out -- the cat, I mean.
I find a veterinarian to consult by E-mail. But then I ascend further, pinpointing a service that in and of itself may illustrate just how far this new commerce medium has come: Kay Cox, on-line pet psychiatrist, www.getnet.com/petcouns/. Ms. Cox, a self-proclaimed "pet therapist and talent scout," offers on-line consultation for $40 an hour. I send her an electronic missive and assure the cat it will be O.K.
Meanwhile, my own psychological salve has arrived -- my putting green. John Tuggle, the U.P.S. deliveryman, takes one look at me and says, "I think you need to get out of the house and go to the shopping mall."
Hardly. I'm on a roll. I've used the Net to gather my food, tend to my body, my soul, my own sanity and that of my pet. Now I will endeavor the final frontier. I will tend to my heart. I will find love.
 
Thursday
The Moment of Truth: Searching for Love
"They" say it's hard to meet good people these days. "They" say it's tough to find a soul mate amid the cacophony of modern life.
Well, they've never met Kitten664.
This is the woman I am paired up with by Matchmaker.com. The on-line service concluded we may constitute a love connection by comparing our answers to about 50 questions like personal hobbies, income, height and weight and reading habits. Kitten664 and I matched on 54 percent of our answers, like the fact that we're both avid readers and own sport utility vehicles.
Plus, we're both 5 feet 8 inches tall and weigh 160 pounds. It's true: I soon realize that among the criteria the company matches are our height and weight, which doesn't seem like a quality that either sex typically wants in a mate.
In a second attempt at a dating service, I fill out a questionnaire on a site that promises to help me find my soul mate. But when I finish, it takes me to an advertisement for free, on-line pornography. I don't think this is a site I'd like to bring home to my mother.
But there is good news on my penultimate day in the E-cave. The swelling in my pinkie has gone down. This is partly thanks to E-mail from Dr. Moore, who advocates icing and elevating the finger.
Also, I've ordered lunch with ease from Waiters.com -- without even needing to register because my registration is already on file. Plus, the cat has quit vomiting, even though the pet psychiatrist hasn't returned our E-mails. Sometimes the very suggestion of therapy inspires healing.
And I'm starting to sink my putts. OPEC is in real jeopardy.
 
Friday
A Little Wisdom Gleaned From Living Life on Line
Just when I am feeling as if I may never need the outside world again, fate intervenes. My office calls and tells me I must go on an urgent assignment. My week in the E-cave is cut short. I will put down the mouse and pick up the car keys.
As I do so, I reflect on the four days gone by. I have discovered that with a little practice and experience, the Net can yield some powerful dividends. Product information and diversity are unparalleled. The next time I need a sweater for my Irish setter and a pet sitter in matching attire, I'll toss aside the Yellow Pages and let my modem do the walking.
Plus, there is extraordinary capacity to compare prices. When my local retailer advertises "the lowest prices on the planet or we'll give you your money back and buff your car," I'll print out some prices from the Net and drive them over.
Then there's the downside. The on-line experience can be an isolating one. Some very important sense of community develops from shopping in the flesh, despite the hassles of driving, parking, fighting crowds and arguing whether you really have 10 or 11 items in the express lane.
There are other bugs, too. Like sometimes an E-commerce site just freezes up, and frequently a site won't answer customer service E-mails for days. In either case, it's like walking up to a sales clerk in a store, asking a question, then having him glower at you before turning around and walking away. "Hey, I'm talking to you," I shouted at one point during the week to a frozen site. I may need a pet therapist myself.
Ultimately, I conclude there are two basic and unassailable tenets of the E-commerce life: (1) you can order anything under the sun over the Net -- and in greater selection than in any other single venue on the planet, and (2) plan ahead, or you'll starve to death.
One more thing. Once you do hunt and gather your food, once you navigate the registration and saunter confidently into the virtual checkout line of life, make sure to include one key facet of the old economy: find someone to eat it with.

SECTION: Section E; Page 2; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 962 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
With Mencken Around, Politicians Didn't Have a Prayer

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman 

 BODY:
Every so often, usually in the slough of a political campaign, I find myself returning to the works of H. L. Mencken. It is not any ideological affinity that draws me but the inimitable effervescence of the man's language. Particularly in the current combat, with so many Presidential claimants sporting religious credentials, Mencken, who died in 1956, remains as impertinent and as pertinent as ever.
The journalist assigned to cover the campaigns of George W. Bush, Al Gore or Elizabeth Dole, of Gary Bauer, Patrick J. Buchanan or others must perforce tread carefully when the candidates allude to alliances with religion. Who in the press is about to express public skepticism about anyone's faith? Even the most impudent critics, who feast on financial finaglings and sexual indiscretions, shy away from questioning or giving offense when it comes to professions of piety. 
Mencken had no such compunctions. Religion, particularly as practiced by American go-getters, was his specialty, and skepticism was a commandment. He hailed the skeptical approach as "socially very valuable, immensely more valuable, in fact, than any known sort of faith." He rarely acknowledged that politicians might be sincere about their religious beliefs, and, anyway, for him sincerity was no excuse for what he deemed outlandish notions.
The booboisie, as he liked to call his fellow Americans, provided him with "unfeigned delight," and in any period of campaign smog his prose was an air purifier. For readers unacquainted with his range, spirit and invective, here, from a 1922 essay, is his summary of American public manners: "the unending procession of governmental extortions and chicaneries, of commercial brigandages and throat-slittings, of theological buffooneries, of aesthetic ribaldries, of legal swindles and harlotries, of miscellaneous rogueries, villainies, imbecilities, grotesqueries and extravagances." He wrote, "Only a man who was born with a petrified diaphragm can fail to laugh himself to sleep every night."
What he called "theological buffooneries" occupy many pages of his work. The exhibitions of religious fervor as primaries approach sometimes bring to mind the knee-bendings of football players who seem to believe that God cares who scores a touchdown. Many assuredly must be in earnest, but it is not always easy to sort faith from ambition.
Although Mencken evinced little admiration for the practices of Roman Catholics and Jews, as a specialist in genus Americanus he directed most of his animadversions at various manifestations of Protestantism. In his book "Treatise on the Gods" he boasted that he could invent any number of new sects "and all of them would be 10 times as plausible" as any then in existence.
Mencken's views of religious fundamentalism became famous through his dispatches on the 1925 Scopes "monkey trial," but he went beyond the creationists when he took on "the corps of evangelical pastors . . . a body devoid of sense and lamentably indifferent to common honesty." He tells a story of a Frenchman who was leaving the church of his fathers. When asked what variety of Protestantism he planned to patronize, he replied, "I have lost my faith but not my reason."
Since then it has become impermissible for members of one denomination to come out so rudely against the competition. But Mencken, that ecumenical insulter, would surely have mined laughs from a President's taking counsel with his pastor about his relations with a young intern or of a Vice President's sudden appreciation of generous Buddhists.
Why has Menckenism gone out of style? One reason, of course, is a deficiency of talent. Few journalists have written so bitingly or humorously about public figures. But probably more important, by the time of his death America's constraints on his sort of invective had become more severe, and there were signs of further constriction on the way.
The casually disparaging cracks about selected groups to which Mencken was prone had gone out of style. After the Holocaust it was harder to make jokes about Jews, and as the civil rights movement gained force, the nation became more considerate about references to blacks. So, too, did sensitivity increase about Asian-Americans and Latinos, the gay and the disabled.
Even admirers of the Mencken spirit can welcome the increased shows of tolerance, respect and diversity in America. Most people take pride in the ability of different races and religions to live together in reasonable tranquillity, well worth the loss of a little easy humor. And yet, particularly when the political juices are flowing and language turns to jelly, Mencken is missed.
In his gentler moments Mencken could praise the Old Testament for its literature and Christianity for its spirit of charity. But mostly, by his accounting, the religious squadrons were composed of con artists and their gulls. When it came to politicians, he found religion being pressed into service "as a sanction for moral theories, for political and economic dogmas, for reforms (or opposition to them) in laws and manners, for social protests and revolutions and even for purely private enterprises, including the commercial and the amorous."
Getting elected must be among the less discreditable of those goals, but not even the naughtiest pundit these days is about to echo Mencken's opinion that in America, religion "is used as a club and a cloak by both politicians and moralists, all of them lusting for power and most of them palpable frauds."
All right, that's a broad-brush judgment, unfair and typically Mencken. But in these months of piety ascendant, with politicians and athletes and actors competing for heaven's support, it comes as a breath of refreshing irreverence.

LENGTH: 379 words

HEADLINE: Job Site Is to Work On Line and Off

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
AS any trend-tracking economist will tell you, most employees don't have jobs anymore; they have careers. Few people expect to use one set of skills for the rest of their lives. Fewer still expect to stick with one employer.
On-line job boards are paying attention. What began as simple databases of classified advertisements have been transformed into on-line career counselors, combining equal parts practical advice and training and dime-store psychology. 
 The latest entrant in this field is Brass Ring, based in New York. It announced yesterday that it would offer training tools, on-line and off-line career fairs, job listings, information and hiring software for companies to use to sort and manage the resumes that come their way.
What makes the company stand out from other job-board sites is its corporate pedigree. Brass Ring combines the resources of several companies: Kaplan Educational Centers, which runs career fairs and professional training centers; The Pavement, a Web site that offers career information for college graduates, and Hire Systems, a company that develops hiring-management software.
"This was built under the belief that the world will not work exclusively on line or off line," said Jonathan Grayer, Brass Ring's chairman and chief executive. "People lead fluid lives" that require a combination of person-to-person communication and on-line efficiency, he added.
Mr. Grayer envisions that once the Web site (www.brassring.com) is complete, it will be able to assist people with all career decisions.
For example, a computer programmer who is considering a career shift from C ++ programming to network administration could go to the site to determine what skills would be required and then take an on-line assessment. The site would provide test results, links to on-line training classes, job searches and resume services. Job seekers can even meet potential employers on line before sealing the deal at sponsored job fairs.
Marissa Gluck, an analyst at Jupiter Communications, said that other sites were also trying to add training options or combine services for employers and employees. But Brass Ring has the benefit of a large cash infusion from its corporate investors, which most other sites are missing.

SECTION: Section F; Page 4; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1456 words

HEADLINE: O Spacious Skies, With Nary a Power Pole in Sight

BYLINE: By FRED BERNSTEIN 

DATELINE: TONOPAH, Ariz.

 BODY:
FROM the highway, it is six miles to Brenda Black's house, along a dusty road through boulders and saguaro cactus. For the first four miles, a power line parallels the road. But then the necklace of wooden poles and black cables -- the reassuring accompaniment to millions of miles of American highways -- ends. The house is still 1,000 feet away.
And yet, as a visitor discovered after pulling up next to the Honda and the Chevy Blazer in Ms. Black's driveway, she is not lacking for appliances. One of four television sets was on; so was the "movie star lighting" over the bathroom sink. The kitchen boasted not only a microwave oven, but also an electric grill. Indeed, Ms. Black's house in Tonopah, some 60 miles west of Phoenix, is typically American, which means it is jammed with stuff. 
 In Arizona, it is becoming easy for ordinary families to live "off the grid" -- that is, without a hookup to electric lines -- and not sacrifice comfort. For $270 a month (about $1 a kilowatt hour), Arizona Public Service will install a backyard unit consisting of solar panels that produce enough power for most domestic uses, a generator that kicks in automatically when there isn't enough sun, and a propane tank to fuel the generator. The company guarantees the equipment, promising that it will keep power flowing around the clock.
"I've had them out here in the middle of the night," Ms. Black said.
A result? "It's solar power for the fast-food generation," said Katy Hundelt, an off-grid customer near Sedona. "If we didn't tell you, you'd come in the house and never know we had solar," she said. "We have everything everyone else has."
Indeed, living off the grid, an option that was once available only to the rich or the intrepid, is going mainstream, at least in this sunniest corner of the country. Arizona Public Service has yet to advertise the program. Even so, Pete Johnston, the company's manager for technology development, said, "It's taking off." There are now 30 families hooked up, he said, and "we're adding at least one a month."
To be sure, solar systems have been available for decades. Dan Reicher, the Assistant Secretary of Energy for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, said, "A surprising number of companies make, supply and even finance solar systems," although he added that the majority of such systems augment company-provided power.
Arizona Public Service has big hopes for its off-grid program. "There are a lot of people moving from California to Arizona, people with a fair amount of money," Mr. Johnston said. "They want to build on dramatic sites. And until now, their only options were propane generators or do-it-yourself solar."
The workers who developed the no-fuss system see themselves as environmentalists. And in trying to limit reliance on fossil fuels, they are.
Yet, the program may prove to have an environmental downside, as new homes, untethered to power lines, turn up in some of the state's most pristine locations. Ms. Hundelt's house occupies just such a spot. "We've got a whole mountain for a backdrop," she said.
Vern Swaback, a Scottsdale architect responsible for some of the largest suburban developments in Arizona, said that everyone there has had the experience of discovering that a favorite mountaintop or butte is suddenly dotted with buildings. "Too often," he said, "people are under the illusion that what they're looking at is preserved open space, when it's just land that people haven't gotten around to using."
Anne Verner, an off-grid customer outside Prescott, in northern Arizona, worries that "the open land may get chopped up."
William Riebsame, a professor at the University of Colorado who studies land-use patterns in the West, said the 90's have seen an explosion of home building in remote areas, where obtaining electricity is often a challenge. In Arizona, hooking up can cost $50,000 or more -- sometimes much more -- for each mile off the grid. Most off-grid customers, said Herb Hayden, the program's coordinator, are more than half a mile from the nearest power line.
"Independence from the grid, with reliable power for everything from family entertainment centers to pool and spa pumps, would be a further enabling force for even more rural and near-wilderness development," Mr. Riebsame said.
Mr. Reicher, the Assistant Secretary of Energy, disagreed, noting that for most people, the costs of building roads and bringing in water are even more daunting. "I don't see solar as a big factor in where people decide to build," he said. Moreover, he noted that state and local laws on land development were the traditional way to control land use.
In Bisbee, a small mining town in the southeast part of the state, a California company is turning a canyon lined with cholla, agave, cottonwood, yucca and pinyon into a development called Bisbee Ranch. The land, which has been described as "national park quality," had not been developed, in part because bringing in electricity was prohibitively expensive. That was before Arizona Public Service made a deal with the developer to provide the off-grid system to those who will buy the 60 40-acre plots.
The other utility -- telephone service -- ceased being a stumbling block when cellular technology came in. (Even in cell-less areas, radiotelephones work fine, as the reporter interviewing homeowners for this article found out.) Wireless Internet connections will be next.
No wonder the developer of Bisbee Ranch, Joe Pinsonneault, said of the off-grid system: "This seems to be the ticket to the future. It's really the millennium system."
He may not be far off. It has been about a century since electrification came to America, with the resulting patterns of habitation, where even rural houses were built in proximity to the grid. Now, the off-grid system, at least in the Sun Belt, could result in a new development model.
The technology the off-grid customers are using isn't especially new. Photovoltaic panels capable of powering a house (at least in the Southwest) have been around for decades. Prices have been dropping steadily. Assistant Secretary Reicher said that in 1980, the cost of producing a kilowatt hour with photovoltaic cells was about $1; now it's down to about 15 or 20 cents in some cases. (That compares to an average cost of about 9 cents a kilowatt hour for power from the local utility.) "It's a wonderful technology," he said, "with no moving parts."
Until now, a family hoping to rely on solar power had to do its homework. The Real Goods Trading Company, a leading purveyor of residential solar generators, markets systems similar to those offered by Arizona Public Service. But they start at $5,000, and $17,000 is about the lowest price for a unit that will handle "problem loads" like a laser printer or an adjustable-speed ceiling fan, the company says. Plus, as Real Goods warns in its Internet catalogue, its kits "require substantial time, expertise and small parts to install on site."
It is true that the off-grid system is more expensive than a conventional hookup (the average residential electric bill in Arizona is $92 a month), but it's much less expensive than bringing in a power line. Other options -- including wind turbines and hydrogen-powered fuel cells -- are not yet economical enough for residential use, said Doug Livingston, the technical products merchandise manager for Real Goods.
Generators are more affordable, but they tend to be problematic. Ms. Verner, the off-grid customer near Prescott, made do with a diesel generator on her family's cattle ranch for almost 20 years. The equipment was smelly and expensive, she said, and the power wasn't steady enough for a computer. Now, her teen-age children have no problem doing their homework on the family's PC.
And in the old days, she said, "I had to wait till nighttime to do wash" when there were fewer demands for power. "Now," she added, "from about 10 till 3, I have electricity coming out of my ears."
Arizona Public Service's off-grid customers generally do not have air-conditioners, but they do have energy-efficient evaporative coolers. Otherwise, normal appliances are O.K. The company recommends using mainly fluorescent lights.
In Tonopah, Ms. Black has noticed that if she leaves the microwave on too long, the back-up generator kicks in, consuming propane. So if she has to cook for six minutes, she may do it in three two-minute stretches.
But that's her biggest problem with the off-grid system, which is why Ms. Black is the envy of neighbors who haven't yet signed up. "Some of the other people who live out here, they've just got generators," she said. "And when the generator breaks, they've got nothing."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. Global Forecast Is Mostly Upbeat

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
Declaring that global economic conditions have "improved markedly," the International Monetary Fund released a generally upbeat forecast today for economic prospects for the world through the year 2000.
But I.M.F. officials warned that unforeseen shocks, such as a sudden plunge in America's highflying stock market or a steep drop in the value of the dollar, could disrupt the new-found optimism. 
 Citing a stronger-than-expected American economy and more vigorous and quicker rebounds in Asia than previously expected, the I.M.F. predicted that the global economy would grow by 3 percent this year -- up from a forecast of 2.3 percent in May -- and predicted an even better 3.5 percent rate next year, up from 3.4 percent in May.
The I.M.F. forecast predicted that the gross domestic product in the United States would increase by 3.7 percent this year before slowing to 2.6 percent in 2000, numbers that would fit a hoped-for "soft landing" in which interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve slow growth enough to prevent inflation without causing a recession.
Michael Mussa, the fund's chief economist, said the I.M.F. was making its forecast for next year "with increasing confidence." Among the reasons he cited were: "a clear end to the recession" in Japan, the world's second-largest economy, and shallower-than-expected recessions in Brazil and Russia.

HEADLINE: Fed Report Says Economy Keeps Expanding

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
The United States economy is expanding at a brisk pace with tight labor markets and few price pressures, the Federal Reserve said today.
The Fed's latest regional economic survey, which is commonly known as the beige book, cited rising retail sales and accelerating business at the nation's factories as evidence that the economy is not slowing much as the expansion, now almost nine years old, stays on track to set a record for longevity early next year. 
 "All district economies continue to exhibit overall strength, with most experiencing moderate-to-brisk rates of growth," the Fed report said.
Consumer spending is strong, with most districts reporting that retail sales are rising from their levels a year ago, the report said. "Retail sales are generally up in most districts," the Fed said. "Industrial activity is on the rise in most parts of the country, with orders and production both up."
Even so, the survey said, "price pressures at the consumer level remain mostly calm," adding that "where they are apparent, they are categorized as temperate."
Price pressures at the wholesale level, however, do appear to be "somewhat greater," the Fed said, with "numerous districts reporting significant increases in some materials prices" and manufacturers reporting higher raw material costs.
Around the country the demand "continues to outstrip the readily available supply of labor in most areas," the report said. Retailers and manufacturers reported problems finding workers, though "several districts have noted a slackening in the demand for labor," it said.
In all, "there are few reports of acceleration in nominal wages and salaries," the report said, though several banks reported increases in the employer costs of health care benefits.
The latest edition of the beige book was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Information was gathered before Sept. 13.
Today's report will help form the basis for discussion on the target interest rate on overnight loans between banks at the Oct. 5 meeting of the Fed's policy-setting panel, the Federal Open Market Committee.
"Wages and prices are the focus now," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, who does not expect a rate increase next month. "The Fed wants to see whether companies are able to raise prices because they need to offset higher wages."
At its last meeting, Aug. 24, the Open Market Committee voted to raise the overnight bank lending rate -- the Federal funds rate -- by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent, the second increase in two months. The central bankers said then that with global growth rebounding and United States labor markets remaining very tight, the economy no longer needed additional stimulus.
The increase in the Federal funds rate "should markedly diminish the risk of rising inflation going forward," the committee members said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Nielsen Joining Internet Venture

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 22

 BODY:
The A. C. Nielsen Corporation, the world's leading market researcher, said today that it would buy 10 percent of Netratings Inc. for $12.5 million as the companies form a joint venture to measure Internet audiences worldwide.
The venture, to be called A. C. Nielsen Erating.com, will measure on-line audiences in Europe, Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and Africa. 
 Nielsen, which measures television viewing in countries outside the United States and Canada, said it and Netratings would spend $50 million in the next two years to establish the on-line service. The company is looking to capture the measuring business overseas, where Internet use is growing faster in some countries than it is in the United States.
Nielsen will own 80 percent of the venture, while Netratings will own 20 percent.
A. C. Nielsen was spun off from the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation in late 1996. Nielsen Media Research Inc., which also was spun off from Dun & Bradstreet, provides ratings data in the United States and Canada.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Yen Continues Its Rally Against the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Japanese yen strengthened yesterday for a third consecutive session, extending its gains against the dollar amid signs that Japan and its allies would take no immediate action to curb the currency's rise.
On Tuesday, the Bank of Japan voted to leave monetary policy unchanged. The decision has bolstered expectations that the Group of Seven industrial nations, whose finance officials meet this weekend in Washington, will not join with Japan in a cooperative effort to sell yen. 
 "The perception of the G-7 is that they're not going to do anything definitive on the yen," said Anne Parker Mills, senior currency economist with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
Demand for yen was strong yesterday even after Japanese stocks fell 3.4 percent, as measured by the benchmark Nikkei index. The yen strengthened to 103.77 yen to the dollar, before paring gains as United States stocks recovered from early losses.
In New York, the dollar settled at 103.93 yen, down from 104.9 yen on Tuesday. Trading may be muted today, with Japanese markets closed for a national holiday, Autumnal Equinox Day.
So far this year, the yen is the best- performing currency against the dollar, up 9 percent. For the week, the yen is up 3 percent.
But the dollar gained against the euro and the British pound yesterday. The euro fell to $1.0448, from $1.0485 on Wednesday, and the pound fell to $1.6284, from $1.6311.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Quake Next Time

 BODY:
In October, world population will reach six billion, or just slightly less than double the population in 1960. That population increase has not been distributed evenly, of course. Humanity has crowded the coasts and clustered along the seams between tectonic plates. It has made itself uniquely susceptible to disaster.
Much was done in Taiwan to mitigate the effects of Tuesday's earthquake, thanks to good and apparently well-enforced building codes. But the simple proliferation of human beings dictated that thousands would die. In the United States we have been lucky, so far, that an economic toll from earthquakes is unmatched by a toll in human lives. 
 But such luck is not likely to continue forever. Even where the best technology is enforced by the most able bureaucracies, it seems inevitable that one day the mass of humans will outweigh the protective infrastructure. In the developed world, we have been absolved, to a striking degree, from the natural consequences of our numbers. But as the world population continues to grow, to push into crowded cities erected atop fault zones, to settle in flood plains and low-lying coastal areas, we will be forced to witness our own immensity in the immense casualties that follow upon disaster. We will have to recognize that some regions impose a harsh, inflexible limit to further population growth.

HEADLINE: Philip Brownstein, Federal Housing Advocate, Dies at 82

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Philip N. Brownstein, a top Federal housing administrator in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations who fought discrimination by builders and landlords and who expanded Depression-era housing laws to widen home ownership among minority groups, died on Friday in a hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 82.
In 1963, Mr. Brownstein was named commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, which became part of the Department of Housing and Urban Development when the department was created in 1965. He continued to serve as F.H.A. commissioner and as Assistant Secretary for Housing in the new agency. Under his leadership, Federal housing policy broadened its reach to include previously forgotten groups. 
 Mr. Brownstein's influence persisted for 25 years after he left office for a private law practice.
At the Federal Housing Administration from 1963 to early 1969, Mr. Brownstein administered an agency created during the Depression to cope with bank foreclosures on homes. The agency insured mortgages, thus giving banks the confidence to buy them. The cost of the insurance, which was passed on to individual home buyers, ended up being a very small part of their monthly payments.
As a result of the original law, longer mortgages, of 30 and 40 years, began to be written, and the concept of home ownership was saved. But as the principal author of amendments to the original law, Mr. Brownstein strove to extend these benefits to blacks and other minority groups.
The new programs involved subsidized loans to minority members moving into white suburbs and urban slum areas. In such areas, Mr. Brownstein argued, lending institutions should abandon the "excessive caution" that he said had thwarted "restoration of the inner cities."
At his swearing in ceremony, William C. Apgar, the current housing commissioner, called Mr. Brownstein his model. "I said that I was honored to have a job he once held," Mr. Apgar said.
Richard Ravitch, who worked as a private developer with Mr. Brownstein in 1965 to develop a block in Harlem before holding several high positions in New York's state government, said one of Mr. Brownstein's major accomplishments was making sure insured home loans were more widely available "at probably the most prolific period for the creation of new housing."
Mr. Ravitch said Mr. Brownstein was also an indefatigable champion of New York City during its 1970's fiscal crisis when he worked to rewrite mortgages on which the city had defaulted. "It was worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the city as that time," Mr. Ravitch said.
Mr. Brownstein was born in the farming town of Ober, Ind., where his father was a shop owner.
While in high school, Mr. Brownstein was forced to put aside his law school ambitions after his father became ill. In 1934, he moved to Washington, D.C., and worked as an assistant truck driver at the Federal Housing Administration.
He graduated from George Washington University and received his law degree from Columbus University, which later became part of Catholic University. He also received a master's degree in law from Columbus.
During the Korean War, Mr. Brownstein served in the Marines in South Carolina. After the war, he joined the Veterans Administration, where he worked until 1963, administering the agency's housing loan program. In that job, he first urged financial institutions to consider human needs in lending decisions, saying this was the basic intention of the veterans' home loan program.
"The notice of intention to foreclose should not be given until it is determined that no amicable solution exists," he said in a speech to the Mortgage Bankers Association in 1949.
President John F. Kennedy appointed Mr. Brownstein commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration in 1963, and President Lyndon B. Johnson added the title of Assistant Secretary for Housing when HUD was created.
In those posts, in addition to pushing housing for the needy, Mr. Brownstein worked to prevent the waste of Federal money. In 1965, for example, he sent auditors to 100 low-rent projects after suspicions were raised that families earning more than the maximum were living there.
Although President Richard M. Nixon asked him to continue in his housing posts, Mr. Brownstein left the Government in 1969 to become a private lawyer. He specialized in housing cases for developers and others, but continued to be active in promoting affordable housing for the poor and middle-class. From 1969 to 1996, he was director of the National Housing Conference and was a director of the Center for Housing Policy from 1993 until his death.
"There wasn't a committee or working group he didn't volunteer to serve on," Mr. Apgar said.
In addition to his wife, Esther, Mr. Brownstein is survived by a son, Michael, of Rockville, Md., who is a research scientist and Laboratory Chief at the National Institutes of Health. Like his father, he has spent his career in the Federal Government. Three granddaughters also survive him.
