HEADLINE: So Many Mannequins, So Little Time;
Saks Tries to Balance Tradition and Risk

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
In a fall window at Saks Fifth Avenue's flagship Manhattan store, a certain fashion dissonance was on display.
The background suggested a genteel Tuscany picnic -- replete with baskets of grapes, Chianti Ruffino in a straw bottle holder and denuded tree branches. It was a setting that the store's most loyal customer, a well-kept woman in her late 40's, might know well. 
 But the clothes seemed cut for another silhouette completely -- maybe a 20-something actress attending a post-movie-premiere party at the downtown nightclub Moomba. In one window, a mannequin posed noncommittally in Dolce & Gabbana hot magenta floral hip-huggers and electric-orange leopard print pinpoint heel pumps. In another, the mannequin lounged in a vinyl camisole with a 3-D print secured with Velcro straps.
"How'd that look on me, John?" joked a well-dressed tourist to her husband as the two ogled the display in early September. "I could wear it to the beach."
Last week Saks Fifth Avenue, the venerable clothier to the ladies who lunch, turned 75, but a placid old age is not in the cards. Even with America in the midst of a consumer spending boom, Saks Fifth Avenue -- along with Neiman Marcus, the other luxury department store chain -- is struggling to make the kind of profits Wall Street demands of retailers these days.
The secret to high-fashion success has always been finding the right balance between nurturing cutting-edge design and stocking enough money-making name brands to satisfy traditional customers. But for Saks today, under new and very bottom-line-oriented management, that balancing act has turned particularly precarious.
A year ago, Saks Holdings Inc. -- the store's owner -- was bought by Proffitt's, a fast-growing Southern retailer. And R. Brad Martin, the chief executive of Proffitt's -- since renamed Saks Inc. -- had lofty expectations for his catch. He had made his company an investor darling by gobbling up regional department store chains like McRae's, Younkers and Carson Pirie Scott, and then squeezing out big savings by consolidating mundane back-office functions like real estate and ordering office supplies.
But with earnings slumping, Mr. Martin "does not have unlimited patience," said Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst with A. G. Edwards, who met with him recently. "He is not going to stand by if the performance continues to lag -- he will make changes."
At the beginning of the year, Mr. Martin had predicted 6 percent growth in sales and nearly 35 percent growth in earnings. To investors worried that Saks Fifth Avenue, with its high concentration of couture brands like Bill Blass and Yves Saint Laurent, would not mesh well with the rest of his empire, Mr. Martin scoffed. And he said that all fashion decisions at the Saks Fifth Avenue chain would continue to be made by its impeccably groomed longtime chairman and chief executive, Philip B. Miller.
But in mid-August, Saks Inc., which is based in Birmingham, Ala., rocked Wall Street by lowering its earnings estimates for the year to $1.80 a share from $2.10. During calls with analysts, Mr. Martin admitted that roughly 8 cents, or about one-quarter of the shortfall, could be traced to lower margins from Saks Fifth Avenue, which now accounts for about 40 percent of Saks Inc.'s revenue. Analysts and investors responded by pounding the stock, which in February went as high as $39.50, sending it to a new low of $15.375 yesterday..
Did performance really suffer, or did Mr. Martin expect too much? Mr. Miller's blue eyes flashed with anger at the suggestion that Saks Fifth Avenue had lost its way. Ensconced in his paisley-wall-papered office, Mr. Miller insisted that sales growth was above that of the rest of Saks Inc., which will be about 4 percent for the year, and that he beat out other luxury merchants, notably Neiman Marcus, as well. "We have taken real market share from the competition," Mr. Miller said. "We may not have met expectations, but we certainly did not embarrass ourselves."
Still, designers who sell to the company, as well as analysts who cover it -- many of whom have had heart-to-wallet conversations with Mr. Martin recently -- see real trouble in the gap between Mr. Martin's expectations and the chain's performance.
Part of the problem seems to be that there was a general softening in the luxury market over the summer. While plenty of the highest-end merchants, like Gucci and Tiffany, have reported strong sales recently, Neiman Marcus Group Inc., Saks Fifth Avenue's most direct competitor, posted disastrous results last month. With anemic sales growth of less than 1 percent forcing Neiman Marcus to make steep markdowns, profits plunged 83 percent.
But Saks also faces the matter of getting the right merchandise mix. Some of this might be easily remedied. For example, analysts say Saks Fifth Avenue is still heavy on formal business clothing, particularly expensive men's suits like Hugo Boss and Brioni, while much of America has long since moved to casual workplace attire. Also, Saks Fifth Avenue's private-label clothing -- which Mr. Martin is counting on to lift profits in the future -- is still too expensive for its quality. Fine-gauge white T-shirts for men that might be a buy at $40 instead go for $78.
Most serious is the assertion by Wall Street that Saks Fifth Avenue cannot manage its high-end designer fashions. "In an effort to have a compelling assortment, things got away from them," and they went too far with riskier designs that did not sell, said Christine Kilton-Augustine, a retail and apparel analyst with ING Baring.
High-end designer apparel accounts for 15 percent of Saks Fifth Avenue's revenue and probably only about 6 or 7 percent of its profits, but it sets the tone for the entire store.
Established couture and career lines from Chanel, Max Mara and Prada have a devoted following at Saks. But while these big brands bring in a steady flow of revenue, that money comes with a lot of strings attached. Many of those brands have developed their own stores, which compete for business. Some do not allow Saks Fifth Avenue to display the entire collection, and many make demands about merchandising.
The latest styles from emerging designers like Alexander McQueen and Issey Miyake take up less space, but have the potential to play a more important role, attracting younger, more adventurous women. These customers may spend less on clothes but will purchase cosmetics, like the $75 lipsticks offered by the Saks house brand By Terry, or spend $150 for a faux diamond choker.
By supporting such brands when they are still relatively unknown, Saks also gambles on a richer payoff if they suddenly become popular. Executives are hoping for the next Dolce & Gabbana -- "the next big hit before it gets too big," explains Ike Lagnado of Tactical Retail Solutions Inc., a consulting firm in New York.
The problem is that small designers take a lot of effort, and money, to nurture, and they have unpredictable sales. Unlike the big brands, lesser-known names offer stores nothing in the way of support -- like advertising dollars or money back if sales fail to materialize -- so a bad season for enough small designers can have a serious impact on the bottom line. Analysts say that is exactly what happened at Saks Fifth Avenue this past year -- and that the new owners may not have the stomach for it.
It is hard for an outsider to discern to what extent emerging designers are in trouble at Saks Fifth Avenue -- everyone from the store to the designers, who have few other places to sell their goods, has a stake in painting a rosy picture -- but some troubling issues have emerged. Ellen Carey, who represents the Australian designer Collette Dinnigan in the United States, has only praise for Saks Fifth Avenue, which has put Ms. Dinnigan's designs in 12 stores. Mr. Miller has been tremendously supportive of the brand, she said, but added that the chain cannot give designers the intensely hands-on maintenance that a much smaller specialty store like Barney's offers.
"Saks has sophisticated owners and sophisticated shoppers, but the sales staff needs to be brought up to par," Ms. Carey said. She said Ms. Dinnigan has managed to sell roughly 60 percent of her collection at full price each season because she ships her entire collection at once, so that it is obvious how to display it. Other designers sometimes ship trousers one week and blouses another, leaving it to the store staff to assemble outfits for customers.
Several designer representatives were even more worried. They fault Saks Fifth Avenue not for lack of trying, but for being part of a discouraging cycle in luxury. For years midlevel, or "bridge," designer wear has been suffering because department stores, pressed to compete with discount and specialty stores, have been marking down such goods steeply. Now the same cycle is happening to luxury, which had previously been immune.
"They mark down very early, and don't give the merchandise the time to perform," one designer representative complained. "Last fall, our winter goods hit the floor in October, and by November they were on sale."
Sure enough, on an early-September afternoon, the markdown racks were overflowing. An Armani denim jacket had been slashed to $372 from $1,245, and a Chloe basket-weave skirt in royal blue was going for $600 off its list price of $1,050.
For now, Mr. Martin insists that he has no intention of meddling in Saks Fifth Avenue's designer business and that he has full confidence in the chain's luxury strategy. "I believe absolutely that this economic model can be profitable," he said. "Designer is at the heart of who we are and a key element of our future strategy."
Even so, Mr. Martin has already made back-office changes at Saks Inc. that could hurt the chain's ability to attract luxury customers. For example, he has cut its renovation budget by 20 percent -- a Saks spokesman said that the savings all came from efficiency moves, not cuts in projects -- and forced the retailer to reduce inventories.
Designers lament that they have already felt the impact of the merger and Saks Inc.'s overriding concern with profitability. Many say they are being forced to reach sales goals for full-price merchandise that would be difficult for one speciality store, let alone for a 59-store chain.
But Mr. Martin made no apologies for his determined approach. "We expect an extraordinary return on capital invested," he said, "and Saks Fifth Avenue's portfolio will give us that return."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Used to Chaos, Business Stays Put in Russia

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 22

 BODY:
In the last month, Russia has been through what people in other countries would call mayhem. A low-level war broke out on the southern border in Dagestan. Then came money-laundering investigations in the United States and Europe that have implicated high-ranking Kremlin officials. And in a two-week period, five terrorist bombings in Moscow and two other cities have left hundreds dead.
But to foreign businesses, especially those that have been in Russia for several years, upheaval seems to be part of the landscape. Despite all these disturbances, foreigners trading and manufacturing in Russia have decided to stay put. Portfolio investors in the Russian stock market have been more skittish, but few have sold their holdings. 
 "Business people here have seen a lot worse in Russia," said Charles Hecker, a specialist on the former Soviet Union with the Control Risks Group, a British corporate-security firm. "They've seen tanks in the streets in 1993, and they've survived. The foreigners who've been here a while are usually from pretty hardy stock."
If they were not, the foreign executives would have left long ago. In the last three years, the period when many corporations began expanding here, Russia has weathered a politically fraught presidential race, followed by similarly fraught presidential quintuple-bypass heart surgery. The nation's currency collapsed. Its Government defaulted on $40 billion of debt, half of it held by foreigners. Six Cabinets and four Prime Ministers have come and gone, the latest one, Vladimir V. Putin, beginning his tenure only in August.
Last year, Russia was ranked as one of the 10 worst places to do business by Transparency International, a Berlin-based anticorruption organization.
Most businesses in Russia had been in a holding pattern long before the recent events. The breakdown of the economy in August 1998 badly damaged investment, and as a rule, businesses are delaying any new projects until after the presidential elections next year.
Typically, the stock market is more sensitive to individual events than direct investors. The RTS Index, a stock benchmark, stood at 80.14 at the end of trading today, down 45 percent from the 52-week closing high of 147.37 on July 8.
Peter Boone, research chief for the Brunswick Warburg brokerage house here, attributed the decline to Western investors' nervousness about emerging markets in general.
But the market decline has deepened since the news of the bombings. And while hedge-fund investors have not sold their Russia holdings, few seem to be buying either.
The bombings have frightened foreigners much more than the financial scandals, even though the latter seem to have more to do with business. The accusations of money-laundering and suggestions of high-level corruption may be revelations to people outside Russia, but foreigners here reconciled themselves long ago to the murkiness of business and upper-echelon politics. "For those of us who are ground-level managers of businesses, this has made very little difference," said Eivind Djupedal, head of Cargill Enterprises in Russia. "The operating environment has never been easy here anyway."
Despite assurances by law enforcement that the bombers will be found and punished, few investors seem to believe that. "There's no confidence among people who know Russia well that the presidential administration or the Government can, or will, solve these problems," Mr. Boone said.
Instead, executives worry that the Kremlin could use the instability from the bombings and the money-laundering scandal to impose a state of emergency and cancel the presidential elections. It is widely believed that there are people in Boris N. Yeltsin's inner circle who fear facing prosecution when a new president comes to power and therefore have an interest in trying to persuade Mr. Yeltsin to halt the elections.
But the Government has been careful throughout the troubles to stress that elections will go forward.
Some businesses are willing to believe the official line until they see otherwise. "People are looking to elections and thinking, 'Will they go well or not?' " said Scott Blacklin, head of the American Chamber of Commerce. "That's what will determine what businesses will do in Russia."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Rebates could smooth the way for a Medicare reform plan.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein; This is Michael M. Weinstein's final Economic Scene column. He is returning to The Times' Editorial Board.

 BODY:
IS a flawed experiment in redesigning Medicare better than no experiment at all?
No, says Karen Ignagni, who represents managed care plans that are fighting to block demonstrations intended to foster competition. The problem, she says, is that the demonstrations, scheduled to begin in 2001, "leave out the Government's fee-for-service plan, tilting competition unfairly against private plans." 
 Len Nichols, an economist at the Urban Institute and a member of the committee of independent experts that designed the demonstrations, disagrees. He acknowledges that the proposed competition, at Congress's instruction, is far from ideal. But, he says, the demonstrations "can still yield invaluable lessons for Congress as it ponders a national fix of Medicare."
Private plans and physicians are lined up behind Ms. Ignagni. Economists line up behind Mr. Nichols. Congress is on the verge of siding with the industry, putting the demonstrations on hold. But Mr. Nichols thinks he has a way out of the impasse if Congress acts soon.
Congress ordered the Administration in 1997 to create demonstrations to test ways to make Medicare competitive. The competition that already exists between private managed care plans and the Government's fee-for-service plan is crimped because the Government decides how much to pay private plans. Sometimes it pays too little, driving private plans out of local markets. Sometimes it pays too much, creating waste at taxpayer expense. The demonstrations would use market forces to reveal the right price rather than letting the Government flail about for the right price.
Congress prohibited the committee from subjecting the Government-run plan to competition. That, says Ms. Ignagni, "means that private plans will be paid less than the Government plan, forcing the private plans to crimp on benefits while the Government plan goes unscathed."
"That's unfair competition," she said.
That is no doubt true. The issue that separates Mr. Nichols from Ms. Ignagni is whether the flaw is fatal.
The committee chose Phoenix and Kansas City as the first two demonstration sites. Political opposition exploded. In many regions, the cost of fee-for-service medicine is sky high because doctors are in the habit of prescribing costly drugs, tests and procedures. In these high-cost regions, the Government automatically dishes out more money to private plans. The plans use the revenue windfall to draw the elderly away from the Government plan by offering them additional benefits, like drug coverage and low co-payments.
The plans are delighted with the cozy arrangement. So, too, are their physicians and patients. But the plans are understandably petrified by competitive bidding, flawed or otherwise. Once firms are driven to compete for business by setting low premiums, the largess under the current system could evaporate. The committee's goal is to reduce premiums to a level sufficient to cover guaranteed benefits and not a penny more. That is Ms. Ignagni's worst nightmare.
Mr. Nichols provides a powerful rejoinder to Ms. Ignagni. The demonstrations, he said, "can still reveal how to create vigorous competition among plans and provide an inkling about potential savings from competition." He compares the demonstration to the methods used by major employers to control health care costs. "Take a General Motors that decides to add managed care to its fee-for-service offering," Mr. Nichols said. "It would not think to tie payments to managed care plans to the bloated costs of running fee-for-service. Instead, it would solicit bids. That is what the demonstration proposes to do."
But Mr. Nichols acknowledges that under current law, private plans have too few tools to attract enrollees. Toward that end, the committee met last week and decided to ask Congress to allow plans to offer rebates -- in the form of lower monthly Medicare premiums. Rebates can provide powerful recruiting tools and perhaps give beneficiaries in demonstration sites something tangible if the demonstrations go forward. That could dissolve some of the opposition.
The notion of providing rebates to enrollees who choose low-cost private plans is hardly heretical. It lies at the heart of President Clinton's plan as well as the plan proposed by Senator John Breaux of Louisiana and Representative Bill Thomas of California. The prominence of those plans might soften Congressional opposition to the idea.
It is ludicrous for Congress to overhaul Medicare without first testing its ideas. Yet it looks increasingly clear that political opposition from vested interests will continue to block demonstrations. Last week's initiative by the committee offers a way to convince beneficiaries to become allies rather than opponents of reform. If so, then the Congressional delegations from Phoenix and other demonstration sites might turn a tad less resistant to a first, important step in redesigning Medicare.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq, but Dow Falls 74 Points

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
High-technology stocks powered the Nasdaq composite index higher yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average was down as investors sorted through a confusing barrage of information and rumor.
Some expressed fears that the dollar would skid further against the yen, while others focused on a reassuring economic survey by the Federal Reserve or on a partial rebound by the Dow Jones industrial average after it fell to about 10,500. 
 "There's concern about money leaving our markets and going abroad," said Tim Woolston, a portfolio manager at Boston Advisors, referring to the consequences of the dollar's fall on foreign exchange markets.
The Dow closed at 10,524.07, a loss of 74.40 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Twenty of the 30 Dow components lost ground, with Union Carbide, Procter & Gamble, United Technologies and I.B.M. each down around 2 points.
"We just haven't gone down enough to turn the buyers on," said Alfred Goldman of A. G. Edwards.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.93 points, or slightly more than two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,310.51. But much of its strength was in the high-technology sector. The broader malaise was reflected by a decline by a majority of index stocks, 255, while 225 rose and 20 were unchanged.
Over the longer term, there has been "an extremely broad-based pullback," said Timothy M. Stevenson, a senior portfolio manager at First Capital Group. More than half the S.& P. 500 companies show declines for 1999, he said.
According to a tabulation by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, more than 3,700 New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq stocks have shown an average decline, unweighted by capitalization, of 24 percent from their 52-week highs, producing what some are calling a "stealth" bear market.
The bright spot yesterday was the Nasdaq composite index, which climbed 37.06 points, or 1.31 percent, to 2,858.16.
A better-than-expected profit report Tuesday by the 3Com Corporation, the most active issue yesterday, helped send its shares up 1 5/16, to 28 5/8, and set a good tone for the computer-related sector. Microsoft rose 1 7/16, to 96 1/16; Qualcomm gained 7 13/16, to 190 1/8; Yahoo jumped 9 15/16, to 179 1/2; Ebay climbed 8 1/2, to 149 1/8, and America Online, 6 1/8, to 91.
Turnover on the Big Board swelled to 822.2 million from 785.3 million Tuesday as new 52-week lows swamped highs by 262 to 23. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones, 1,711 to 1,248.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bonds Little Changed
 (By Reuters)
 Treasury securities, after barely budging for most of the day, ended marginally higher yesterday, with the price of the benchmark 30-year bond up 2/32, to 100 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.08 percent from 6.09 percent on Tuesday.
"There is nothing to motivate anybody," said Kevin Logan, senior market economist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson North America L.L.C. Volume was very light and well below average at $41 billion.

HEADLINE: Regulators Say Miami Defrauded Bondholders

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The City of Miami, already besieged by scandals involving election-law violations and political corruption, was accused by Federal regulators yesterday of defrauding its bondholders by deliberately concealing a financial crisis that engulfed city government in 1995.
The accusation, which the city denies, was contained in an administrative complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the city and two former city officials. 
 The regulators said the city's misleading actions affected the sale of $116.5 million in tax-exempt bonds issued in 1995 to finance pensions, sewer construction and a public building project. The commission is arguing, in effect, that the bond market might have demanded a higher interest rate or greater protections if it had known the true state of the city's finances.
The risk to bondholders is unclear because the case may affect Miami's overall credit rating, which can influence the prices at which bonds trade in the market.
The commission, while not seeking any monetary penalties, is asking an administrative law judge to find the city at fault and require accurate reports on its finances in the future.
The case is the latest skirmish in a five-year campaign by the commission to force cities, counties and other municipal bond issuers to keep investors informed about significant changes in their financial health, just as publicly traded corporations are required to do, said John C. Mattimore, the assistant regional director in the commission's office in Miami. Such cases have been filed against Orange County, Calif., Maricopa County, Ariz., Syracuse, N.Y., and several small towns in Mississippi.
The Miami case is likely to be closely watched by local officials across the country because, if it is successful, it will expand the traditional limits of the Federal regulators' jurisdiction in the municipal bond market.
Like the earlier cases, the Miami complaint accused the city of issuing misleading bond documents in connection with the sale of specific bond issues. But in this case, the city is also accused of providing inaccurate financial statements to investors months after the bonds were sold.
Such subsequent reports have not been cited in earlier cases, said William R. Baker, an associate director of the security commission's enforcement division.
"Although such statements are not required by any S.E.C. rule or regulation, what we are saying in this case is that whatever you decide to disclose must be truthful," Mr. Baker said.
Specifically, the commission has accused the city of failing to disclose publicly that its cash flow had precipitously declined after the close of its 1994 fiscal year, raising the possibility that it would not be able to cover its operating expenses and pay the interest on its outstanding bonds during the 1995 fiscal year.
Miami is fighting the charges. Thomas Tew, a lawyer for the city, said Miami officials fully discussed the 1995 budget problems to its auditors, Deloitte & Touche, and followed Deloitte's advice in preparing its financial reports.
"We do not believe that we violated the securities laws," Mr. Tew said. "We relied upon our auditors."
Ellen Ringel, a spokeswoman for Deloitte, said the firm had cooperated fully with the regulators. A ruling in favor of the commission "should put an end to the city's claim that it was unaware of its true financial condition, and to its efforts to shift responsibility to others," she added.
For Miami, the complaint is the latest in a long series of corruption cases. In the past six years, state charges have been filed against at least 270 public employees, as the city has wrestled with hectic growth, ethnic divisions and drug-dominated crime problems.
The other defendants in the S.E.C. case include the city's former city manager and its former director of finance, who deny any wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
A Quarterback With the Drive to Succeed

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 22

 BODY:
On the printed page, the game-winning drive looks neat and clean: 10 passes, 10 completions for quarterback James Perry to lead Brown to a 25-24 victory over Yale in the Ivy League opener last Saturday. But on the field, and on the videotape, the march and its immediate aftermath is a wacky pastiche of skill, luck, nerve, danger, hubris and comedy that reminds a football fan of how exciting this regimented sport can be when things get frantic.
Perry, a senior from Andover, Mass., passed for 379 yards against Yale to raise his career total to 6,418. That puts him 1,431 behind John Witkowski, who set the Ivy League record of 7,849 with Columbia from 1981 through 1983. The Bears, a contender for the conference title, play their home opener on Saturday against Lafayette of the Patriot League. Should Perry continue to pass at this pace, he would approach the league record late in the 10-game season. 
 But it will be difficult for any game to duplicate last Saturday's drama at the Yale Bowl, when Perry's 38 completions set a school record, when the winning drive displayed his poise and resilience under pressure. Perry had already thrown two touchdown passes when Brown got the ball at its 37-yard line with 3 minutes 32 seconds left and trailing by 7 points. Six consecutive completions moved it to the Yale 20. Turning his head both ways and shouting signals from the shotgun formation, Perry was surprised by an object hitting his knee. It was the football, snapped accidentally. He recovered it for a loss of 5 yards and called a timeout.
"Miscommunication," Perry said. "I was talking to the receivers."
After another completion moved the ball to the Yale 16, Perry rolled out to the right but was slammed from behind by a blow to the head from a Yale tackler. He fumbled the ball, but an official's blown whistle prevented a turnover. Perry called another timeout to clear his head and talk with his coach, Phil Estes.
"A little head whip," Perry said of the tackle. "They hit hard. Give them credit for that."
Two more completions brought the ball to the Yale 7, fourth down and 1 yard to go, the clock ticking from 30 seconds to 25 seconds to 20 seconds, the crowd of 17,398 roaring. Under heavy pursuit, Perry drifted to the right and flicked a short forward pass with the underhanded motion of an office worker throwing a paper wad into a waste basket. David Brookman, a tight end, caught the ball between two defenders and ran into the end zone to reduce the deficit to 1 point with 14 seconds left.
"Kind of off balance, a little flip," Perry said. "Sometimes you just throw it any way you can." Afterward, Brookman said to him: "Holy cow! Where did you throw that one from?"
Then things got really crazy. Kneeling in place-kick formation, Perry caught the snap and held the ball for the extra-point attempt to tie the game. The kick was blocked, saving Yale's lead. "I thought, 'Oh, geez,' " Perry said. But Brown's Michael Powell grabbed the loose ball and ran to the right. As several Yale tacklers surrounded Powell, he pitched an ad-lib option pass to Rob Scholl, a fullback, who carried it over the goal line for a 2-point conversion and a 1-point Brown lead.
Then it got even crazier.
Thinking the game was over, some Brown players began a celebration that included the taunting of some Yale players. The officials called not one but two penalties. Instead of kicking off from its 35, Brown kicked off from its 10. Yale moved the ball to the Brown 30, and with six seconds left, with the wind favorable, Yale tried a 47-yard field goal that would have won the game.
Happily for Perry and the Bears, the kick fell short. The game ended in a Brown victory, a lesson learned and confidence gained from experience. "We've done two-minute drills four times and scored on all four," Perry said. "It's strange. We're pretty experienced at it. It's weird. I don't have time to be nervous."
He is the son of two schoolteachers, the youngest of seven children, five of them boys. "I got a lot of practice in listening," Perry said. One brother was a quarterback at Harvard, another an assistant coach at Brown. Perry is majoring in economics and taking premed courses.
In terms of professional football potential, Perry's biggest drawback could be his size. At 6 feet 1 inch and 200 pounds, he is smaller than some, but not all, National Football League quarterbacks. "He's like Doug Flutie in the way that people underestimate his size and they say he doesn't have a strong arm," said Estes, who noted that N.F.L. scouts have inquired about Perry. "James Perry just makes plays. He's a very instinctive quarterback. He sees the field so well."
Perry would like the opportunity to play professionally, although he is not overconfident. "Lots of times, at Ivy League schools, they don't even think you have any chance," he said. "I'd love to play. I'll do everything I can. But, if I don't play, I've had the best of both worlds here at Brown, a great time and a good education."
Some Ivy quarterbacks have reached the N.F.L. recently, including Princeton's Jason Garrett at Dallas and Dartmouth's Jay Fiedler at Minnesota. Sean Morey, Perry's top receiver last season, now plays for the New England Patriots.
If he does not play professional football, Perry said he might want to become a general practitioner, specializing in family medicine. "They are in dire need of a more personal touch," he said of general practitioners. "My nature would be good for that."
Perry learned medicine firsthand last season, when a knee injury reduced his mobility. Off-season surgery repaired the damage and restored his ability to move and make things happen, some of them very entertaining.
"It feels good to run around again," Perry said. "I love to run. We pass a lot. We'll keep getting better. I'm very fortunate."

HEADLINE: Panel on 2000 Finds News Largely Good

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Although serious concerns remain, especially in health care, small businesses, local government and education, the United States is largely prepared for Year 2000 computer problems, according to the committee that has been the Senate's chief watchdog on the issue.
At the same time, the committee said, it has become increasingly worried that lagging preparations overseas could lead to economic disruptions severe enough to hurt American businesses and generate pleas for international aid. 
 The publication of the committee's report with just 100 days left until Jan. 1 was one of many public and private sector Year 2000 events this week, most with generally positive overviews larded with caveats.
"There is probably more complacency that will come out of this than we would like," said Senator Robert F. Bennett, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Senate Special Committee on the Year 2000 Problem. "We are in much better shape than I would have anticipated a year and a half ago, but people who go through the details of the report will find plenty of indication that there is still much work to be done."
The computer problem stems from representing the year in electronic dates with just two digits, like 99 for 1999. Faulty devices and programs can malfunction when they read 00 as 1900 instead of 2000 or simply fail to recognize it as a valid date.
Year 2000 flaws have been popping up for years in software -- a separate report out yesterday said that 82 percent of large companies had already encountered them -- but the first weeks of January are expected to bring the most malfunctions.
The report on large companies, which is sponsored by CAP Gemini America, an information technology consulting company in New York, said that although nearly half did not expect to have all of their critical computer systems fixed before the end of the year, only 12 percent expected such vulnerable systems to pose a "significant business risk."
The survey also reported that 44 percent of the Year 2000 malfunctions to date occurred in systems the companies had fixed. Computer experts say it is common to introduce errors when debugging software, which is one reason contingency planning for breakdowns is an essential part of Year 2000 preparations.
"We can't say everything is fine and rosy," said James Woodward, head of CAP Gemini America's information systems management group.
But many recent reports and presentations are emphasizing optimistic expectations. Perhaps more strikingly, a National Association of Manufacturers survey of vital concerns of small manufacturers published yesterday did not even pose a question about Year 2000. Earlier this year, the manufacturing group had seen the threat of Year 2000 problems and lawsuits as so important that it made legislation restricting litigation one of its main policy objectives.
Yesterday's Senate report, which is available at www.senate.gov/ y2k/documents/100dayrpt, contained no major surprises for computer experts and others involved in Year 2000 activities.
The committee's biggest areas of concern were generally in sectors where information about preparations has been hard to obtain. In the $1.5 trillion health care industry, the committee praised Year 2000 programs at drug companies, distributors and major hospitals but expressed grave concerns about the readiness of computer systems in the nation's 50,000 doctors' offices and 15,000 nursing homes.

LENGTH: 163 words

HEADLINE: How the Economy Keeps Booming

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Floyd Norris (Business Day, Sept. 17) argues that the United States is living beyond its means because of the large current deficit in its external accounts -- a measure of how much we pay foreigners for goods and services compared with how much we collect from them. But this deficit is partly an outgrowth of the United States economy's global strength. The American economy has been growing faster than the rest of the world economy, pulling in imports and keeping other economies afloat. 
 As other areas of the world grow faster, they, too, will accelerate imports. As they accumulate dollars, they will buy our securities. So long as economic growth, both at home and abroad, is soundly based, the private markets will find the right balances among the trading nations and in the currency markets.
 
LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., Sept. 17, 1999
 
The writer is a retired assistant vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: How the Economy Keeps Booming

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The solution to the mystery of how the economy sustains growth with low unemployment and little inflation (Business Day, Sept. 16) is staring at us. Yes, American consumers are spending at an unprecedented rate, but they are spending on foreign goods. Money that would have fueled inflation at home has gone to Asia and Latin America, helping to bail out economies there. 
 Globalization has altered the old economic formulas. Investors may wonder how long it will last, but for now, American consumers can spend with a clear economic conscience.
 
MARTHA CURTIS
New York, Sept. 17, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 151 words

HEADLINE: How the Economy Keeps Booming

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 18 Arts & Ideas article on the failure of economics to deal with reality skated past the source of the problem. Virtually all of the mathematical derivations favored by economists rest on the premise that the invisible hand of markets is omnipotent and omnipresent, making it unnecessary to observe reality, since all answers are predetermined. 
 If employers have more power than employees, if monopolists have the power to set their own prices, if there are spheres like law and medicine in which consumers are unable to judge prices and quality, economists dismiss the problems with the remark that in time "the market" will correct everything. Were economists to observe how people, businesses and countries actually behave, their recognition of the marginality of the ivory towers would be devastating to them.
 
ART HILGART
Kalamazoo, Mich., Sept. 18, 1999

HEADLINE: Analysts See A Lost Chance In State Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 22

 BODY:
As they approved the new state budget last month, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders called it a model of sound judgment, a plan that raised spending at a modest pace and put last year's large surplus into a reserve fund rather than spending it.
But a range of fiscal experts, from Wall Street analysts to private watchdog groups to the State Comptroller, have come to a strikingly different conclusion: that despite a continuing economic boom that has left most states in their best financial shape in decades, New York's new budget actually worsens the state's long-term outlook. 
 They point to several factors they say will make it harder to keep the budget balanced in years to come:
*Spending is expected to rise faster than income this year, because enormous tax cuts enacted in past years are keeping state revenues nearly flat.
*The budget increased the use of "one shot" revenue sources that cannot be repeated in the future, reversing Mr. Pataki's record of cutting back on them.
*New tax cuts were enacted this year that will lower state revenues in the future.
*While other states are using surpluses to pay off debts, this budget will increase New York's debt, already the highest in the nation.
These experts say the steps taken by the state were not egregious, but that many were the sort of questionable maneuvers that states usually make to get through hard times, not when they are swimming in cash. The experts share a fear that time may be running out to take advantage of the nation's long-running expansion to get New York's finances in order.
The most detailed and stinging criticism of the budget came today, in a 58-page report by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. Mr. McCall projected that the state's $37.4 billion General Fund will face a $2.8 billion deficit next year, a $4.6 billion deficit the following year, and considerably larger gaps after that.
The deficits might not materialize if the economy continues to grow at the blistering pace of the last three years -- something economists do not expect -- but otherwise, they can be closed only by cutting spending or raising taxes.
"What's most distressing about it is they had a unique opportunity to do some things that would have a positive long-term impact, and they did the reverse," said Mr. McCall, a Democrat, who did not lay blame specifically on the Governor or the Legislature. "They made the long-term problems more difficult."
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said: "I haven't seen his report, but the budget is an excellent budget. It's soundly balanced and preserves the entire $1.8 billion surplus."
In addition to major spending increases on education and the environment, he said, "it continues us as leading the nation in cutting taxes."
Still, the administration's own core conclusion is not much different from the Comptroller's. Mr. Pataki's office recently predicted a $1.9 billion deficit next year, and that assumes that state agencies will find $500 million in "efficiencies," which most analysts are unwilling to credit.
So the administration's true deficit projection is $2.4 billion, not far from Mr. McCall's $2.8 billion. By comparison, a year ago, Mr. McCall was predicting a $1.8 billion deficit one year into the future.
And Mr. McCall is far from alone in his criticism.
State lawmakers "went into the process with a long-run problem and came out with a somewhat bigger long-run problem," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group that closely studies the city and state budget. "This budget was just focused on getting through this year and next year."
Frank J. Mauro, director of the left-leaning Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit group in Albany, said: "This budget is incredibly short-sighted. It tries to take care of the next couple of years -- though even those will be difficult -- and after that we go over the precipice."
As home to legions of stock traders and wealthy investors, New York has benefited heavily from the bull market, in the form of rising income tax payments. Yet Wall Street rating agencies give it the second-lowest bond rating of any state, ahead of only Louisiana.
This year, over the objections of the Democrats who control the Assembly, the Governor succeeded in having the entire $1.8 billion surplus that accumulated during the 1998-99 fiscal year set aside, rather than spent, in 1999-2000.
But that money is already spoken for, because the state plans to use it over the next two years to pay for property tax cuts that have been put into law, but are taking effect in stages. That reserve is projected to run out in two years, and while Mr. McCall does not project the state's finances beyond two years, he and other analysts said that it is safe to assume the predicted deficits would balloon beyond that point.
In their defense, administration officials pointed to a brief report issued last month by Standard & Poor's, one of Wall Street's major bond rating firms, that said the state's finances were generally better than they were three years ago, a point no one would dispute. But Standard & Poor's barely commented on the outlook beyond the end of this fiscal year, now just six months away.
Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's main competitor, is preparing a more detailed report for publication next month that executives there said will take a dimmer view of the budget. Moody's declined any comment for the record until then, but one executive noted that both the Governor's and Comptroller's office are projecting much larger deficits one year into the future than they were at this time last year, adding, "that kind of speaks for itself."
Analysts have made many gloomy predictions for New York's finances over the last few years, and each time were proved wrong, thanks to extraordinary growth on Wall Street and in the economy at large. The expansion has allowed the state to cut taxes deeply and raise spending at the same time.
The new budget totals $73.3 billion, a 3.8 percent increase over last year, but much of that is money -- like Federal welfare and Medicaid payments, and tuition paid by State University of New York students -- that has no direct effect on state finances. When those elements are stripped out, what is left is the $37.4 billion General Fund, the portion of the budget generated by state taxes and fees, and the part that analysts focus on.
"Revenues are barely growing because they're taking all the revenue growth we would be having and using it to cut taxes," Mr. Mauro said. "That's why spending is rising faster than revenues. It isn't some structural problem that can't be helped. We have a deficit by choice."
In the past, Mr. Pataki has acknowledged as much, saying that he believes government should lower taxes to impose discipline on spending, rather than allowing spending to dictate the level of taxes.
The Governor has claimed that General Fund growth, at 2.4 percent, is within the rate of inflation -- a contention many economists would dispute -- yet it is still higher than the projected 2 percent increase in revenue. But even that 2.4 percent figure was arrived at through accounting moves that simply declared some revenue and spending to be outside the General Fund. When those gimmicks are accounted for, Mr. McCall said, General Fund spending is actually up 3.6 percent. Mr. McCall also criticized the use of one-time revenues, like selling assets or taking surpluses from little-noticed accounts, that, by his count, total more than $500 million.
Reliance on one-time sources of money to pay for continuing needs throws the budget farther out of balance in the future.
The Governor has long been a critic of "one shots," and in his first five years in office, he steadily reduced the state's reliance on them, to just $62 million in last year's budget.
The final budget contained tax cuts that, when fully implemented, will cost the state $250 million a year in revenue, though that is a tiny figure compared to the tax cuts worth billions that have been enacted under Mr. Pataki.
During his re-election campaign last year, Mr. Pataki's opponents assailed him for the state's growing debt, and the Governor began this year with a plan to rein it in, but the new budget authorizes almost $300 million in new borrowing.

HEADLINE: Kaufman & Broad Earnings Climb 36%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, the nation's second-largest home builder, said yesterday that its earnings for its fiscal third quarter rose 36 percent, beating expectations as the company continued to benefit from a strong housing market.
The company, based in Los Angeles, also said it was considering selling its operations in France, where it is one of the biggest home builders. 
 For the quarter ended Aug. 31, Kaufman & Broad's net income rose to $38.2 million, or 78 cents a share, from $28.1 million, or 68 cents, a year earlier.
Excluding a previously disclosed charge of $18.2 million for losses from unauthorized trading by an employee in its mortgage unit, Kaufman & Broad said net income would have been $1.02, above average estimates of 90 cents a share. Revenue increased 60 percent, to $1.06 billion.
Kaufman & Broad and other home builders are reaping the benefits of low interest rates, low unemployment and high consumer confidence, which has the housing market on track for another record year.
Even so, the shares of home builders are down on concerns that the boom will not last much longer.

HEADLINE: Worse Odds Than Roulette: Buying Trump Casino Stock

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
DONALD TRUMP, the latest would-be Presidential candidate, was bragging.
"The political people like me because I do well in polls," Mr. Trump said in a chat this week. "In Manhattan real estate, my name is a huge positive." He brandished a chart showing that Trump condominiums cost at least 79 percent more than non-Trump condos. "This is the real Trump factor." 
 So why does the stock in Mr. Trump's casino company seem to be about as popular with investors as Pat Buchanan's musings on Adolf Hitler are with voters? "People don't understand this company," Mr. Trump moaned.
Whether or not they understand Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, investors don't seem to like it. The stock has fallen about 85 percent from its peak amid worries that Mr. Trump runs it as if there were no public shareholders. In conversation, he uses the word "I" when talking about himself, and he uses the same word when talking about the company.
That public shareholders have done poorly with Mr. Trump should not, perhaps, be a surprise. They suffered mightily during his first venture running a public company, after he took control of the Resorts International casino company back in 1987.
All three of Mr. Trump's Atlantic City casinos later went bankrupt, but he managed to keep control of them and, in 1995, Trump Hotels was organized to own two of the casino hotels.
It went public at $14 a share and leaped to $35.50 in 1996.
But then Mr. Trump decided that the company should buy his third Atlantic City casino from him. The price seemed high to many, but public shareholders voted their trust in Mr. Trump, and the company bought the Trump Castle, since renamed the Marina.
Investors soon concluded that the company had badly overpaid, and the stock price collapsed. Unfortunately for Mr. Trump, his 42 percent stake in the company was pledged to secure a loan. So Mr. Trump borrowed $25 million from the company, and used some of that money to repay the loan.
Needless to say, no other shareholder facing a margin call on Trump Hotels stock received similar treatment. But Mr. Trump says the company is doing well because he is paying the prime rate -- now 8.25 percent -- which is more than the company could get if it put the money in a bank.
At the same time, the company goes deeper and deeper into debt, paying high junk-bond interest rates. Its bonds trade at yields around 15 percent.
Mr. Trump says he will repay the loan next summer and voices confidence that the company will be able to refinance its debts at lower rates. He says the Castle purchase was a good one.
Not all the blame for the company's problems can be assigned to Mr. Trump. Competition has hurt all casinos, but Wall Street has penalized Trump Hotels more than most. Its share price, now at $4.44, is not climbing even though the casinos' financial results are improving.
As New York's most famous property developer toys with seeking the Presidential nomination of the Reform Party his popularity appears to be highest among those who have not invested in his company.

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. on Creative Accounting Spree

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Creative accounting by Congress reached new heights today as House Republican leaders, desperately seeking money for their spending bills, used budgetary devices to manufacture nearly $17 billion out of thin air.
First they ordered appropriators to tap $12.7 billion from the budget for the year after next, the 2001 fiscal year. Then they declared $1.1 billion for a long-established program to help the poor pay their heating bills as an unforeseen "emergency," taking the money off the official ledger. 
 And then, apparently breaking a pledge made by the former Speaker Newt Gingrich, they moved to rescind $3 billion in welfare funds for state governments.
The moves were part of a plan to help finance a bill for labor, education, health and human services programs that nonetheless cuts or eliminates so many health and education programs that President Clinton vowed tonight to veto it.
The leadership's effort to take back welfare money provoked protests from the nation's governors, Republicans and Democrats alike. They issued a statement calling it "a drastic departure" from a deal between Congress and the states.
That deal, sealed by Mr. Gingrich in a letter on June 5, 1998, pledged that the Republican-led Congress would not touch the welfare money, known as Temporary Assistance for Needy Families.
"I gave you my word that T.A.N.F. funding will be guaranteed for five years," he said. "Rest assured that I will stand by that commitment."
There had been talk in Congress last year of a similar plan to tap into the states' welfare coffers, and Mr. Gingrich's letter sought to quell the governors' suspicions.
The chairman of the National Governors' Association, Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a Republican, said the current Republican leadership in Congress had privately assured the governors that Mr. Gingrich's word was still good. "We took them at their word and still hope they'll maintain the integrity of their decision," Mr. Leavitt said.
The loss would be temporary, Republican leaders say. They promised to replace the funds in the 2001 fiscal year. "It's just a temporary relocation," said John P. Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert. "They'll get the money back."
Congress has completed work on only four of its 13 spending bills. It appears certain to fail to complete them, with one week left until the new fiscal year begins on Oct. 1.
But Congress is on track to drain a projected $14 billion surplus for the 2000 fiscal year and to break the spending caps it imposed on itself. It looks increasingly likely to tap into surplus Social Security payments to finance its spending bills, something the Republican leadership has said repeatedly that it will not do.
The Republicans' deepening dilemma was apparent in the moves to borrow heavily from the 2001 budget, to declare a 24-year-old home-heating program an unforeseeable emergency, and to try to take back the welfare money.
Congress has used borrowing from future years, a process called forward funding, in the past. But it has never used more than $12 billion in a single year for all Government programs combined, let alone a single spending bill, the Senate Budget Committee said.
And it has not declared programs like home-heating assistance to be fiscal emergencies, a category usually reserved for wars and natural disasters, not the coming of winter.
Nor has it asked the states to give back welfare money. At least 38 states would be affected if the welfare recession becomes law. New York would lose $508 million in welfare funds in the fiscal 2000 year, and California would lose $417 million.
The $89 billion bill for labor, education and health and human services was approved today by a House appropriations subcommittee on a party-line vote, with eight Republicans in favor and six Democrats opposed.
The subcommittee's chairman, Representative John Edward Porter, Republican of Illinois, made it plain that the creative accounting measures to finance the bill had been dictated by the Republican leadership. "I work with what they give me," he said. "Decisions have been made that I'm not a part of."
In other legislative action, negotiators from the House and the Senate worked toward a compromise that would require more flight tests for the F-22 fighter plane, a $70 billion program, before allowing the plane to begin production. The House voted to withhold $1.8 billion to build the first six F-22's; the Senate wanted the planes built next year.

HEADLINE: Leader Tries to Brighten Algeria's Image

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
When leaders gather here each year to set out policies and debate world issues, some use the spotlight to draw attention to their countries.
This year no one seems to be working harder at that than Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was elected President of Algeria in April after the country had endured seven years of fighting between Islamic militants and an army-backed Government in which tens of thousands of people were killed. 
 A week ago, Algerian voters overwhelmingly endorsed an amnesty plan devised by Mr. Bouteflika that was intended to persuade militants to surrender so that the country could begin to rebuild. And now, Mr. Bouteflika, who fought against French colonialism and later served a radical leftist Algerian Government as foreign minister, is in New York talking to business groups, courting investors and promoting free enterprise.
Before arriving, Mr. Bouteflika was building bridges closer to home. Algeria, now chairman of the Organization of African Unity, recently was the host to a conference of African leaders, which went smoothly in a country considered too dangerous to visit a year ago. Earlier, Mr. Bouteflika surprised people by greeting Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel when they met at the funeral of King Hassan II of Morocco.
"When people shake hands, it's not a world event," he said this week in New York.
"I have no problem with a market economy," he said in an interview today. "We had our socialist experience, which was excellent. But at a certain time it reached its limits, and it could only go backward. We are moving to a market economy because we have no choice.
"When you have a bazaar economy, as we do, with trafficking and corruption -- 90 percent of our commercial operations are conducted illegally -- taxes are not paid, or customs duties," he said. He has begun a drive against corruption, not a popular measure for a President whose election was contentious. All six other candidates dropped out saying that Mr. Bouteflika, who had the support of the military, would win unfairly.
That crisis now seems to have passed. Violence has been reduced, although at least 5,000 armed militants remain, belonging to two groups that did not accept the amnesty plan. The largest force, however, the armed wing of the Islamic Salvation Front, has decided to work with the Government.
Mr. Bouteflika has rejected calls for investigations and trials for those in previous Governments and in the military who have been accused of rights abuses, including his predecessor, President Liamine Zeroual. The military still wields substantial political and economic power.
When he was asked about prosecuting Mr. Zeroual, Mr. Bouteflika cut off the questioner with a curt remark: "You know absolutely nothing about Algeria!"
Algeria, one of Africa's largest countries in area and a population of 30 million, ranks in the middle of the world's nations in terms of development, according to a 1999 United Nations Human Development report. Algerians are slightly better off than Moroccans and slightly less so than Tunisians, their neighbors to the west and east.
Mr. Bouteflika said the message he was telling potential investors is that he represents "a country, a huge country, with great human and material potential." He said he was asking them to look beyond Algeria's oil. "There is agriculture," he said. "We have the high plateaus and one million acres in the Sahara that can be worked. We have minerals that just need some know-how to develop."
Economic growth is important, he said, because the middle class has been weakened, "and the middle class is supposed to insure stability in society."
Mr. Bouteflika said Algeria remains culturally close to France.
"Relations between Algeria and France are always important," he said. "When they are bad, they are important. When they are good, they are also important."

HEADLINE: A Resignation Is Expected From Chrysler'sPresident

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS and KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
Just 10 months after the trans-Atlantic merger that created DaimlerChrysler A.G., the president of Chrysler is about to resign in the wake of a bruising management clash, company executives confirmed last night.
The resignation of Thomas T. Stallkamp, who was the top American executive in charge of integrating Chrysler into its new German parent, will be announced today after a meeting of DaimlerChrysler's supervisory board in Frankfurt, officials said. 
 The move is part of a larger shake-up of DaimlerChrysler's management board, which will be reduced to 13 people from 17 and comes at a time when the company's stock has been slumping badly.
The shuffle has shocked employees at Chrysler, and reports of the move rattled investors. DaimlerChrysler's shares plunged $3.9375, or 5.6 percent, to $66.25 yesterday, mainly on worries about management turmoil.
But the departure of Mr. Stallkamp also signals serious tensions between Daimler's American and German executives and perhaps over basic strategic issues as well.
Though it remains unclear exactly what led to his resignation, it is clear that Mr. Stallkamp clashed with Daimler's chairman, Jurgen Schrempp, and that his departure was not on friendly terms.
German company executives said Mr. Schrempp wanted to create a "stronger" and a "younger" management board. They also argued that Mr. Stallkamp's effectiveness as a chief executive had been exaggerated by his American supporters.
Though rumors of Mr. Stallkamp's departure have been gathering strength for the week, it is a big surprise and a puzzle.
Mr. Stallkamp was the leading American executive in charge of integrating the operations based in Stuttgart with those in Auburn Hills, Mich.
Daimler executives acknowledged last night that he had been successful in that role. Mr. Stallkamp also represented one of Chrysler's biggest strengths: its system for purchasing parts. Before becoming president of Chrysler, he had been the head of procurement and built up a system that was more cost-effective and efficient than Daimler's.
Company executives said last night that Mr. Stallkamp would be replaced by James P. Holden, who is now head of sales and marketing for the North American brands.
Several other executives, some from Daimler, will lose their positions on the management board as well. Kurt Lauk, head of Daimler's truck division, is expected to step down along with with Heiner Tropitzsch, Daimler's personnel chief. Theodore Cunningham, a Chrysler executive who is currently in charge of Latin American sales, will also lose his seat.
Company executives say Mr. Schrempp, who has been extremely frustrated at the steep decline in DaimlerChrysler's stock this year, was determined to inject new blood into top management and make it less unwieldy.
With 17 members, Daimler's management board has been one of the biggest in Germany. The board was supposed to reflect the idea that Daimler and Chrysler had formed a "merger of equals," even though Mr. Schrempp put himself in charge from the first moment.
Robert J. Eaton, the former chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, shares the title of co-chairman with Mr. Schrempp. But Mr. Eaton insured a subordinate position for himself at the time of the merger by announcing that he would only serve for three years before retiring and letting Mr. Schrempp serve as the sole chairman.
Europeans also outnumber Americans, 14 to 6, on the supervisory board, which controls who sits on the management board.
Another senior American executive, Thomas Gale, DaimlerChrysler's executive vice president for design, may leave the company as soon as this winter but is not likely to depart in the management shuffle today, those close to the company's deliberations said. Mr. Gale has been unhappy with Chrysler's loss of autonomy, they said, and rival auto makers are planning to woo him.
Mr. Gale, one of the industry's best-regarded designers, has overseen the development of innovative automobiles like the PT Cruiser, which will go on sale next spring.
The departures of Mr. Stallkamp and possibly Mr. Gale would leave DaimlerChrysler with few of the executives who rebuilt Chrysler after the 1991 recession, turning it into one of the most profitable auto makers. Robert A. Lutz, Mr. Stallkamp's predecessor as DaimlerChrysler's president, retired last year.
The loss of so many top executives makes it more likely that their proteges in the next layer of management will also leave, said Greg Salchow, an auto analyst at Roney & Company, a Detroit brokerage firm.
In a meeting with reporters just before the formation of DaimlerChrysler, Mr. Stallkamp may have foreshadowed his own difficulties when he contended that "acquisitions are easier than mergers, and we're running this one as a merger."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stocks Plunge Over Remark On Microsoft

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices, already weighed down by fears about interest rates and the dollar, fell hard yesterday after the president of Microsoft said high-technology companies like his were considerably overvalued.
A session in which most prices were meandering lower was quickly transformed into a steep decline, with the technology-dominated Nasdaq market absorbing a loss of 3.79 percent, its biggest since April. The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 205.48 points, or 1.95 percent, closed at 10,318.59. That put it more than 1,000 points below its record set on Aug. 25. 
 Yesterday's selloff contributed to a rebound in the bond market as investors redirected money from stock sales into fixed-income securities. The yield on 30-year bonds retreated below 6 percent to 5.98 percent from 6.08 percent on Wednesday.
But while voices on Wall Street itself were talking down tech stocks, it was Microsoft's president, Steven A. Ballmer, who had by far the most effect. Addressing a conference in Seattle of the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, he cited what he called a "gold rush" mentality that had driven the shares far too high. "It's bad whenever reality is out of line, and you get distortions which are not healthy," he added.
"There's such an overvaluation of tech stocks it's absurd," Mr. Ballmer said. "And I'd put our company's stock in that category.". The shares of Microsoft, the market's most highly valued company, skidded 4 7/8, to 91 3/16, reducing Mr. Ballmer's personal stake by some $1.2 billion. "I love our company," he responded. "I don't sell my stock." William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, who owned one billion shares before recent gifts, had a paper loss yesterday that approached $5 billion.
The slide contributed to a 107.67-point plunge in the Nasdaq composite index, to 2,750.50.
Another depressant was a Salomon Smith Barney analyst, Bill Rafftery, who said that Intel and Apple were overpriced.
Stocks also suffered from the dollar's slide against the yen, which resumed after Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary, seemed to rule out any chance the United States would join any effort to halt the yen's appreciation, 14 percent against the dollar since June.
The dollar's weakness has made investors fret that stocks and bonds issued in the United States could lose their appeal, although the American currency has held up against most other currencies.
Still, according to Timothy M. Ghriskey, a senior portfolio manager at Dreyfus, the market is more worried about the possibility that the Federal Reserve will ratchet up interest rates once again to avert inflation -- a move that tends to buoy the dollar -- than it is about the dollar's performance against the yen.
"Japan's not out of the woods yet" in restoring economic growth, Mr. Ghriskey contended. "Their currency will correct."
Financial stocks, which had been among the stronger groups early in the day, were caught in the selloff, with J. P. Morgan, Chase Manhattan and the Bank of New York each down more than a point and Morgan Stanley losing 3 3/16, to 86 3/8; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette 3, to 39 7/8, and Merrill Lynch 2 9/16, to 68 1/4. Lehman Brothers fell 1 7/8, to 53 3/8, despite reporting higher-than-expected profits and winning a "strong buy" recommendation.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 30.10 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,280.41.
The Dow industrials also disappointed technicians. After rebounding a bit Wednesday from a support level of 10,500, the blue-chip barometer moved decisively lower. Its decline was the second this week of more than 200 points; it lost 225.43 points on Tuesday.
Lesser market depressants seemed to be President Clinton's veto, albeit entirely expected, of the Republican tax-cut bill and the Labor Department's report that first-time applications for unemployment insurance fell last week to the lowest level since 1974, a move magnified to some extent by East Coast floods that prevented some people from reaching claims offices.
Although drug, oil and airline stocks began the session with gains, no major group survived the afternoon meltdown.
Some of the biggest individual losers among prominent companies were Georgia Pacific, down 5 13/16, to 38 13/16, after the resignation of its chief financial officer; Rite Aid off 2, to 12, on accusations of overcharging, and Gillette down 2 1/16, to 37 3/4, the second consecutive decline after an analyst cut her profit projection.
Among technology stocks, Hewlett-Packard was the biggest drag on the Dow industrials, sliding 4 5/16, to 94 3/8, with I.B.M. down 3 3/16, to 122.
Elsewhere, Ebay plunged 10 7/8, to 138 1/4; Amazon.com 3 3/4, to 62 1/4, and Intel 5 5/16, to 77 1/2.

Bond Prices Soar
 By The Associated Press
Bond prices soared yesterday, pushing the 30-year bond yield below 6 percent for the first time in nearly four weeks, as a selloff in stocks sent investors seeking the safety of Government-backed securities.
Bonds also got a push from a growing consensus among analysts that the Federal Reserve will leave interest rates stable at the Oct. 5 meeting of its policy makers.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 12/32, to 101 30/32, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, down to 5.98 percent from 6.08 percent late Wednesday.
The last time the yield on the long-term Treasury closed below 6 percent was on Aug. 27 at 5.97 percent.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 4.79 percent, while six-month yields fell to 5.01 percent. Yields are the interest the securities pay by maturity.

HEADLINE: Odds Worsen in Hunt for Low-Income Rentals

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
In a negative side-effect of the robust economy, more people with low incomes are struggling to find rental housing that they can afford, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.
From 1995 to 1997, the number of "struggling renter households" increased by 3 percent, to almost 8.9 million from about 8.6 million, the department said. A struggling household was defined as one whose income was at or below 30 percent of the median income for its region. 
 At the same time, the supply of affordable rental units for such households has declined. Using the latest figures available, the department said affordable rental units decreased by about 5 percent, a drop of 372,000 units from 1991 to 1997.
"The sad truth is that more and more people working at low-wage jobs, as well as older Americans living on fixed incomes, are being priced out of the housing market as rents rise," Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo said. "We felt that the rental situation was getting worse. These numbers document that in a painful way."
The Secretary said rents had been rising for several years as landlords charged what they thought the market would bear in times of prosperity. In 1997 and 1998, rents rose twice as fast as general inflation, Mr. Cuomo said. The rent-rate increase was 3.1 percent nationwide in 1997, compared with a 1.6 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index; in 1998, the respective figures were 3.4 percent and 1.7 percent.
Mr. Cuomo said the report issued today was based primarily on data from the Census Bureau's latest survey of American housing trends. He said the release was not timed for political reasons, though he seized upon the report as supporting the need for the 100,000 new rental-assistance vouchers called for in President Clinton's budget for the fiscal year that begins next week.
The Government estimates the nationwide median family income at $47,900: that is, half of American families have incomes over that figure, and half under. In or near big cities with high housing costs, incomes tend to be higher, and therefore the gap between "struggling households" and people with enough money to live comfortably is wider.
In New York City, the "struggling household" ceiling for a family of four is $16,000, the report said, meaning that $16,000 is about 30 percent of the median income for a New York family of four.
The department said about 116,000 people are on waiting lists to live in public housing in New York City, and about 203,000 are on lists to get rental-assistance vouchers. The wait for each category is about eight years, the department said.
The department said that it could not immediately determine how much the New York waiting lists had increased in the last two years but that a nationwide survey of 40 big-city housing authorities showed waiting-list increases of 10 percent to 25 percent over that time.
Nor do such numbers tell the whole story of hardship, Mr. Cuomo said. The Government assumes, in general, that a family can spend up to 30 percent of its income on housing without undue hardship. Mr. Cuomo said more than five million American families are spending half or more of their incomes on rent and getting no assistance.

HEADLINE: After Touring Bronx, First Lady Urges Congress to Raise the Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
After briefly touring a commercial neighborhood in the Bronx and praising the borough's economic redevelopment efforts, Hillary Rodham Clinton urged Congress yesterday to raise the minimum wage.
Her remarks staked out a strong Democratic position on a hallmark issue that could draw a contrast between herself and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is her likely Republican opponent in next year's United States Senate race. 
 Mrs. Clinton in her remarks yesterday expressed strong support for an initiative sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts that would raise the minimum wage 50 cents a year over the next two years, bringing it to $6.15 an hour. On Tuesday, Democratic Senators seeking to force a vote on the Kennedy measure temporarily blocked Republican legislation to revamp Federal bankruptcy laws.
"There are some things that we know will help," Mrs. Clinton said, standing outside Kleener King, a dry cleaner in the Fordham section, "that will make a difference in how much more we can create good jobs and grow the economy right here in the Bronx and in the city. One thing we know will work is to raise the minimum wage and there is a policy proposal currently pending in the Senate to do just that."
 The First Lady chastised Senate Republicans for blocking Mr. Kennedy's initiative. "Unfortunately, the Republican leadership in the Senate has just blocked an effort to raise the minimum wage," she said. "And I would call upon Republicans and Democrats alike to speak out on behalf of an increase in the minimum wage today."
If Mrs. Clinton's comment seemed to be a veiled challenge to Mayor Giuliani to take a stand on the issue, the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, who accompanied the First Lady yesterday, got directly to the point. He called on Mr. Giuliani to take a position and to influence his supporters, some of whom are in the leadership of the Republican-controlled Senate, to pass the Kennedy measure.
"We now know where Hillary Rodham Clinton stands on the minimum wage," Mr. Ferrer said as Mrs. Clinton stood at his side nodding. "My suggestion is that you ask the supposed Republican candidate for Senator where he stands on the minimum wage and what he will do with Republican Senators who have already endorsed him to unblock this important legislation and come to a vote on the Senate floor."
On Wednesday, the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, joined Mrs. Clinton at a news conference in lower Manhattan to criticize a Republican tax cut proposal in Washington and to chide the Mayor over his conditional support of it.
Mr. Giuliani has not taken a position on the minimum wage proposal and said yesterday that he needed further time to study it, so it remains unclear whether the issue will become a matter of debate in next year's Senate race. But he said that raising the minimum wage could lead to a loss of jobs if employers choose to dismiss workers rather than pay them more.
"The raising of the minimum wage always sounds like a good thing," he said. "But the thing you have to look at is, how many jobs is it going to cost you? And what is it going to do at a time in which you are involved not only in New York but all throughout America in a major welfare-to-work effort?"
