HEADLINE: Campaigning Under Onus of Super Wealth

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 23

 BODY:
Jon S. Corzine, the retired investment banker, had barely finished announcing his formal candidacy for the United States Senate today when he was asked the $300 million question:
Why on earth would a man who had just made $300 million as a co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company want to subject himself to the rigors and relentless public scrutiny of running for the Senate? 
 Mr. Corzine smiled, paused, then responded to the television reporter by talking about his interests in health care, education, gun control and civil rights.
"For me," Mr. Corzine said, "the reason to go to the United States Senate is to be an advocate for meeting our society's most important challenges."
The rookie candidate's polished response suggests that Mr. Corzine, 52, was well prepared for the question. But with the race for the Democratic nomination beginning to gain momentum, it is a question he is likely to hear frequently in the coming months. Many Democratic insiders were surprised several months ago when Mr. Corzine first began to surface as a possible candidate for the Senate seat being made available by the retirement of Senator Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat.
Although Mr. Corzine (pronounced kore-ZYNE) has made financial contributions to several candidates over the last decade and has been active in a number of civic organizations, he is hardly a political player, and did not even vote in several Democratic primaries. Nonetheless, his impressive business credentials, support from several powerful county chairmen in northern New Jersey and willingness to finance his own campaign have made Mr. Corzine one of the three leading contenders for the Democratic nomination.
And now that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has announced that she will not run for the Republican nomination, Democrats have grown more optimistic about their chances in the general election, so the tenor of the primary campaign has intensified.
In recent days two other leading candidates -- former Gov. Jim Florio and Tom Byrne, a former Democratic state chairman -- have tried to blunt the power of Mr. Corzine's affluence by proposing voluntary spending limits in the campaign.
Mr. Corzine said today that it was unfair of candidates who are already well known to limit a newcomer's ability to put out his message.
Announcing his candidacy outside his stately home in a Summit, N.J., neighborhood of soaring chestnut trees and neatly trimmed lawns, Mr. Corzine talked about his humble beginnings as an Illinois farm boy who worked on construction jobs to pay his way through school.
Accompanied by his mother and his wife, Joanne -- who was a classmate of his in kindergarten -- Mr. Corzine staked out positions on a variety of issues that leave him decidedly to the left of most of the Democratic contenders.
He favors strict gun control, an increase in the minimum wage, and the establishment of an inner city investment bank to aid the redevelopment of urban areas. He will advocate universal preschool programs and support a plan that would entitle any student with a B average to a free education at a state university.
"All of our children will live in a new knowledge-based economy," Mr. Corzine said. "So it is time for universal access to four years of college or a quality vocational or technical education."
Mr. Corzine also pledged to work to improve the health care system by expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs, and by working toward providing universal long-term care for the elderly.
Mr. Corzine said he would offer detailed plans about the costs and financing of his proposals in the coming months.
But recent public opinion polls indicate that fewer than 20 percent of voters recognize his name.
As he made his announcement in Summit, four gardeners working across the street stopped to listen to his speech. None of them had heard of Mr. Corzine, and when they were told of his background in high finance, the crew's foreman, Nelson Gomez -- a Newark resident and registered Republican -- laughed.
"So he wants to go to the Senate for what -- to make more money?" he asked.
But Mr. Corzine said in his speech that his business background would help expand the current economic prosperity and that his personal wealth gave him the freedom to act on his own convictions, without being swayed by financial contributors.
"I won't owe anything to anyone but you," Mr. Corzine told the crowd.

HEADLINE: The Yen Rises a Little; Japanese Stocks Fall Hard

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Asian and Pacific stock markets opened trading this morning under pressure after Thursday's drop on Wall Street and indications that the United States would not back joint international efforts in the foreign-exchange markets to limit the strength of the Japanese yen.
Currency markets are expected to be reasonably quiet today, adopting a cautious stance ahead of the meeting in Washington this weekend of finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrial nations. In early trading, the United States dollar moved back above 104 yen. 
 Stocks in Tokyo, however, opened sharply lower, with the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues falling through the 17,000 level for the first time since June 15. The slide came after losses in the Nikkei futures contracts for December in Chicago and on Wall Street.
The key index was down 512.65 points in Tokyo, or 2.96 percent, at 16,813.11, while the benchmark stock index here in Australia was down more than 1.2 percent, at 2,891.8.
"It was a pretty ordinary night offshore, obviously," said Richard Herring, a Burrell & Company broker here, "and after holding up for two days, it is not surprising to see a bit of a selloff here this morning."
The Asian slide came in the wake of a decline in the Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday of 205.48 points, or 1.95 percent, its lowest finish since April 9. The Dow had lost 225 points on Tuesday.
There are concerns that while the yen's strength reflects improving conditions in Japan, too rapid a rise could imperil an economic recovery.
Traders' hopes that Washington would support joint intervention by central banks at the Group of Seven meeting were dashed by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. He said on Thursday that Japan should use whatever measures it could to buoy its economy.
The dollar sold at 104.48 yen in early Asian trading, lifted by bids from Japanese investors, compared with 103.95 yen late in New York on Thursday. But if the Group of Seven meeting produces no signs of agreement to stem the yen's strength, then it is expected to rally strongly next week. "I think after the meeting, the risk is that we do go lower and do move toward that 100 level next week," said Tim Moloney, Deutsche Bank's currency strategist here.

HEADLINE: Clinton Vetoes Tax Cut but Seeks Accord

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton vetoed the $792 billion Republican tax cut today, but called on a skeptical Congress to reach a bipartisan compromise with him on taxes, domestic spending and the long-term financing problems facing Medicare and Social Security.
With Congress and the White House headed for a showdown in coming weeks over spending priorities for next year -- and with time running out for his legacy-minded Administration to make substantive progress on big issues -- Mr. Clinton urged both parties not to "throw in the towel" this year before trying again to reach a broad budget deal. 
 The President said Congress and the Administration had an obligation to try to assure the financial health of Social Security and Medicare and to provide an adequate amount of money for education, environmental programs and health care while still making progress in reducing the national debt.
"In the days ahead, I will ask the Republican majority to work with me to fulfill these fundamental obligations we have to our children and to our future," Mr. Clinton said before vetoing the tax bill at a ceremony in the White House Rose Garden. "If we can work together to meet these objectives, we can also work together to pass tax relief we can afford, affordable middle-class tax relief that reflects the priorities of both parties and the values of the American people."
Although he said he was flexible, Mr. Clinton made no specific new offers and he did not call for direct negotiations. And his effort to engage Congress drew a stiff arm from Republican leaders, who have said for weeks that they would not be lured into last-minute budget negotiations with a President they distrust.
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said their goals for now are to block demands by the White House for increased Federal spending and higher taxes, and to pass the appropriations bills needed to operate the Government without dipping into the portion of next year's budget surplus that comes from excess Social Security revenue.
"We want to work with the President," Mr. Hastert said in a statement. "But we will not work with the President to raise taxes, raid the Social Security trust fund or pile on more debt on the American people."
The fiscal dueling illustrated how both parties are increasingly intent on reaping political gain by blocking the other side's initiatives rather than on compromising and passing legislation, despite the opportunities created by projections of mounting budget surpluses.
The White House staged today's veto with all the trappings of a victory ceremony. The Marine Corps band played. Cabinet secretaries and senior Administration aides were gathered in the sun-drenched Rose Garden, representatives of interest groups were invited, and Mr. Clinton sat behind a desk on a platform to wield the veto pen with the same flourish he might have used in signing a favored bill into law.
The President had made clear even before it was passed by a sharply divided Congress last July that he would reject the $792 billion tax cut, which over the next decade would reduce personal income tax rates, provide a break for many two-income couples, cut capital gains taxes, repeal the inheritance tax and give corporations and special interests a variety of provisions they favored.
Mr. Clinton said the tax bill used too much of the projected surplus, would require deep cuts in domestic spending, did nothing to stabilize the big social welfare programs and risked a return of crippling budget deficits.
"I will veto this bill because it is wrong for Medicare, wrong for Social Security, wrong for education and wrong for the economy," Mr. Clinton said.
Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said later that the Administration was willing to provide more time to work out a deal on the budget issues by signing a two-week temporary budget that would keep the Government operating in the all-but-certain event that Congress would not pass all its spending bills by the start of the new fiscal year on Oct. 1, eight days from now.
Most members of both parties in Congress, though, see little hope for any broad budget compromise this year. They said Republicans were eager to use tax cuts and spending restraint as issues in next year's elections, while Democrats viewed Medicare and to a lesser extent Social Security as powerful issues working in their favor.
Still, there are a few optimists in both parties who think some kind of limited deal might be struck.
One vehicle for progress might be a package of routine tax provisions that the House Ways and Means Committee will draw up on Friday. The provisions include an extension of a credit for corporate research and development costs, credits for companies that hire workers from welfare rolls and rules that limit the effect of the alternative minimum tax on low and middle income taxpayers.
Some members of both parties think there is room to expand the package to include provisions with bipartisan support like a cut in the marriage penalty, which hurts many two-income couples.
White House officials think their best chance for bipartisanship rests with efforts in the Senate Finance Committee to draft legislation shoring up Medicare and adding a prescription drug benefit to the program.
But an effort to develop a bipartisan approach to Medicare collapsed earlier this year, and the issue is so complicated that prospects for a deal before Congress adjourns later this year appear slim.
The chances of reaching a compromise on shoring up Social Security seem even more slender. Despite nearly two years of efforts to find a middle ground, most Democrats remain wedded to keeping the current system of retirement benefits intact, while most Republicans want to move toward a system under which workers could invest part of their payroll taxes in the stock market.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE;
EUROPEAN RATES HOLD

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
At a meeting, the European Central Bank held interest rates at record lows, giving the recovery in the 11-nation euro economy more time to take root before raising borrowing costs. Though growth is accelerating in the three biggest economies, Germany, France and Italy, annual inflation in the region stood at 1.2 percent in August, well below the central bank's 2 percent ceiling. Officials have stressed that inflation is likely to remain quiescent, cooling concern they will follow the United States Federal Reserve and the Bank of England by raising rates soon.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2608 words

HEADLINE: A Big Birthday Finds the Chinese Prospering

SERIES: A HALF-CENTURY IN CHINA: Two Families Remember

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
In 1949 Yang Yuena was an illiterate 17-year-old peasant, living in a straw hut and farming for an absentee landlord, when the Red Army entered her rural hometown. This month, dressed in fashionable silks, she feted a U.C.L.A.-bound grandson in the family's second home, a lavish apartment in Beijing with a television that takes up an entire wall and a bar stocked with wine and cognac.
For her the twists and turns of a half-century of Communist rule add up to a raging success: a rich businessman for a son-in-law, exotic teas and plump shrimp at lunch, two family members accepted into the Communist Party. But for other families, like the Lings of Shanghai, the equation is far more complicated. 
 Ling Qiang, 87, is a former low-level functionary in pre-Communist China. He uses the Queen's English as he describes his family's persecution under Mao, pointing to two discolored patches in the walls of his yellowed one-room apartment, smashed in the 1960's by marauding Red Guards in search of Western books or bourgeois valuables.
Those ugly memories have faded with a bit of prosperity and the more relaxed political atmosphere of recent years. And his grandson, 27, a fledgling engineer who shares his room, gives little thought to that turbulent past, spending his spare time on the Internet, trading stocks or E-mailing his sister in Chicago.
The stories of these two families are the story of the revolutionary experiment that Mao initiated 50 years ago on Oct. 1, an experiment that in some way upended and uprooted virtually every family in China, leaving millions dead or broken, but ultimately easing the survivors into the relative prosperity of today.
Some families have had more material success than others, but all have passed the same landmarks: the revolutionary hopes and ideals of the early 1950's, the brutality of Mao's political campaigns from the late 1950's until his death in 1976, and the diversity and economic opportunity in the last two decades of reform. And each stage has placed its stamp on its generation.
Today, as China prepares to celebrate the anniversary of the People's Republic, most people have a sense of progress and pride, despite an uncertain economy and grumblings about politics.
Still, as the two families illustrate, many have traveled a road of painful and bizarre switchbacks.
The Communist troops came in late 1949 to Yuhuan, a remote coastal village in southern Zhejiang Province, where Yang Yuena's family was surviving, just barely, by a mix of fishing and farming.
The family was too concerned with subsistence either to support or oppose the approaching Communists in their battle against Nationalist troops, Ms. Yang said, though fighting raged for months in nearby fields.
But they were fed up with the corruption of the Nationalist Government, she said, and quickly found reason to embrace the victors in China's civil war. Officially classified by the Communists as "poor peasants," Ms. Yang's family was given land when the new rulers carved up the property of local landlords and rich farmers.
"Of course we were extremely happy -- everyone was happy -- we got land!" she said. As a bonus, the Communists' policy against arranged marriages meant that she was able to choose a husband -- although it proved hard to find one given her "bad" background: an uncle had fled with the defeated Nationalists to Taiwan.
Good will toward the Communist authorities ran deep in Yuhuan, even as they organized farmers into work teams and a few years later fully collectivized farming -- taking back the land previously handed out.
"We all believed in the Communist Party," Ms. Yang said. "The peasants were excited and happy. It was a time of great faith that we were about to enter Communism."
In the 1950's, in Shanghai, Ling Qiang also found the landscape thoroughly transformed. In this once cosmopolitan city, cafes and dance halls quickly shut. No one dared wear jewelry because it was considered bourgeois -- although gold bullion still functioned as currency underground.
And if Mr. Ling, a former official in the Nationalist Government's salt monopoly, did not share the peasants' sense of giddy anticipation, he did not, he says, feel besieged.
After returning from a brief exile in Hong Kong to rejoin his wife, he used a gold bar to buy rental rights to the one-room apartment that is still his home and began teaching English at a Jesuit school that had been taken over by the party.
Mr. Ling, with his Western-style education and Nationalist connections, was obliged to take part in a weekly political study group to remold his thinking, and was shipped out for a summer of Marxist "re-education." The Communist Youth League rejected his son's application.
"But over all, it was not bad," Mr. Ling said. "I was not a capitalist, so was not so affected."
After 10 years, he said, he and his wife even began to embrace Communist idealism. When, in 1959, Mao called on youths in Shanghai to move to the countryside to acquaint themselves with peasant life, Mr. Ling enthusiastically encouraged his 18-year-old son to sign up.
But in the late 50's Mao's most sweeping revolutionary campaigns started. They would soon buffet the lives of the emerging second generation.
 
The Turmoil
Decades of Changes Large and Larger
For centuries women in Yuhuan had tended the home while the men fished or tilled the fields. But with the Great Leap Forward in 1958, Mao smashed these traditions, insisting that all grain be turned in to the Government, forbidding individual fishing or planting, and requiring every man and women to work to meet grain quotas in exchange for rations in communal canteens.
Worse still, scarce local grain was siphoned off to feed China's cities, creating dire shortages.
"By 1959," Ms. Yang said, "the peasants were exhausted, and couldn't or wouldn't work more because the system took everything away. By 1960 we'd stopped planting. And then the grain ran out."
Her future son-in-law, Wang Yicai, now a rich businessman, lived in the same township and was only 5 years old at the time. But he recalls chronic hunger, eating coarse bread and sweet potatoes -- supplemented by leaves -- to survive. Many died in Yuhuan, including Ms. Yang's mother, in a famine in 1960-62 that killed tens of millions across the country.
Then, in 1966, just as Yuhuan was recovering, Mao unleashed the Cultural Revolution, closing schools, sending armies of urban youths to the countryside and anointing students as "Red Guards," giving them license to destroy any traces of China's bourgeois past. They smashed ancient relics and persecuted people deemed to harbor counterrevolution.
For Mr. Wang it marked the end of his formal schooling, at 9. He became a Little Red Guard and spent his days studying Marx, Communist operas and revolutionary songs.
"In a way it was interesting and exciting," he said.
But he also felt he needed more of an education, and quietly borrowed textbooks from teachers to teach himself writing and math. Still, when Mao died and the Cultural Revolution ended, Mr. Wang, then 20, was ill prepared for China's free-market future, having been in school just four years.
During this same turbulent time, Ling Huakang, of the Ling family's second generation, also found his life upended by Mao's campaigns for radical change. In 1959, instead of going to college, he volunteered to serve the party in the fields of rural Anhui Province.
"I thought it was an honor to be sent down -- that I should respond to the call of Chairman Mao," said Mr. Ling, now a jovial middle-aged state factory administrator. "I had no idea that my future would be so messed up."
He had gone to the countryside, he said, to uplift the peasants and was disappointed to end up a farmhand. Then, a few months later, after Mao announced that the future of China depended on steel as well as grain, Mr. Ling was transferred to a newly established rural steel factory.
He, too, remembers the famine of the early 1960's: grain rations that never arrived; eating dried sweet potato slices and cabbage soup for weeks on end.
Still, he says, he retained an underlying faith in the party. And he was thrilled when selected to attend a college of metallurgy in preparation for an assignment at one of the country's biggest steel plants.
"Even then I still felt idealistic," he said with a laugh.
In fact, a few years later he named his children Gang (steel) and Liang (grain), to express his devotion to Mao.
That faith was again challenged by the Cultural Revolution in 1966, when the Lings abruptly became hapless targets of hatred.
In the steel foundry Mr. Ling was accused of bourgeois tendencies, in part because of his father's middle-class background. Red Guards smashed his RCA radio and, upon noticing an alarm clock made in Canada, accused him of worshiping foreign enemies.
He was the object of "struggle sessions," criticized by 30 co-workers crammed into a room. He recalls the fear that moved him to rub the initials off an old U.S. Army surplus blanket. But he also remembers the shame he felt as he wrote his self-criticism.
"I thought 'Yes, I do have a very serious problem,' " he said. " 'It's terrible. I'm infected with bourgeois ideals.' "
Back home in Shanghai, his father was locked in his school for a month and interrogated incessantly by students. Groups of Red Guards ransacked the apartment and tormented his mother, who was "totally terrified," Mr. Ling said.
So terrified was she that one day she took the family's few remaining heirlooms -- jewelry, gold, silver dollars -- and tossed them into a sewer. His father, who had studied Western literature in college, collected his precious paintings and books and, believing them tainted, turned them in
It was only in the 1970's, when the children of the third generation were born, that the political radicalism started abating.

The Prosperity
Fading Fears, Rising Hopes
Wang Yicai's big break came in 1973, in the waning years of the Cultural Revolution, when the central Government decided to let villages like Yuhuan set up small enterprises. He became a salesman, ultimately assigned to live in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province.
With cash to spend, he married a woman from Yuhuan and built a brick house, the first in his family with electricity.
More important, in Nanchang an older professor got the bright young man admitted to an aeronautics college. By the time Mr. Wang completed his studies, rejoining his wife and new son to become a factory manager in 1979, the Cultural Revolution had ended. Deng Xiaoping had announced China's "opening and reform," paving the way to the development of private business.
That prospect was appealing to Mr. Wang, who calls Mao "ignorant about economics" and regards Deng as a hero. But having witnessed the wild political swings of the 1960's, he -- like many others of his generation -- had learned to be deeply cautious.
"There was a huge and powerful change under way," he said. "But in the late 70's China was still not that stable, and I wanted to make sure the new policy would last."
Only in 1983 did he "jump into the sea," as the Chinese put it, joining with eight partners to start the company, the Yuhuan Qingma General Machinery Factory.
The factory made car and motorcycle parts just as China was starting to motorize. Company growth has been exponential, sending the Wangs on an upward spiral.
In 1990 the local Communist Party invited the budding entrepreneur to join. Large factories must have a party cell; Mr. Wang could form one or have it created for him. "I'm a party member now," he said, "because you really can't separate business and politics in China at this time."
For Ling Huakang in Shanghai, the reforms of the past 20 years have had less to do with the pocketbook than the spirit.
"Over a number of years, the fear faded very slowly," said the second-generation Mr. Ling, who in 1982 was transferred to the Baoshan Iron and Steel Plant in Shanghai. "We only gradually came to re-evaluate the Cultural Revolution and to see how ridiculous it was." He still lives at the factory.
When he first returned to Shanghai, half a day of each week was still devoted to political study, a practice that faded over the following four years. In a world increasingly focused on economics, the family's negative political background was slowly forgotten. Their two children tested their way into good high schools and, later, university.
Though never prosperous, the Lings slowly accumulated the trappings of a modernizing China: a television, a large refrigerator, an electric ceiling fan. In a sign of the times, in 1984 the Lings modified the way their son Liang's name was written, changing it from the character meaning "grain," to another with the same sound, meaning "good."
The third generation of both families has come of age in a different world, one in which politics no longer defines the core of Chinese life but merely sets its limits.
They never experienced the turmoil of their parents' lives and are too young to have been caught up in China's last great political upheaval, the 1989 Tiananmen protests.
In their short adult lifetimes, grain coupons have given way to supermarkets and Marxist study sessions to pop concerts. They no longer wait for state job assignments, instead suiting up for interviews at foreign companies. They are pragmatic, materialistic and international.
"Because I studied history I can communicate with my father's generation," said Wang Dong, part of the third generation of the family from Yuhuan village. "But many young people can't." He spoke just before leaving for U.C.L.A., the first family member to travel outside China.
An earnest young man holding a cell phone and wearing sneakers and jeans, Mr. Wang could pass for a Western graduate student. His father, whose company makes 20 percent of car transmissions in China, is proud that his son is attending graduate school in the United States.
Still, the younger Mr. Wang plans to return to China after he gets his Ph.D. in political science. Two years ago he followed his father into the Communist Party.
"I want to participate in the future of China," he said, "and for that you have to join -- both to develop the country and your career."
But his concerns seem utterly removed from the politics of yesteryear, centering on the economy, foreign relations and China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
These are the concerns of most young Chinese, who have little emotional connection with the past though they are often tightly bound to their families.
So it is that Ling Liang, the youngest man of the Ling family, sleeps each night on a cot next to his grandfather's bed -- and surfs the Internet in the room's other corner.
Ever since he graduated from college in 1994, his life has been about choice: he chose his girlfriend; he chose his job with a foreign company. He makes a higher salary than his father and has introduced air conditioning and a microwave oven to the room -- even though it still lacks plumbing.
He is happy to cook for the grandfather who raised him but betrays impatience with the anxieties of his elders. At a recent Sunday lunch, his mother reminded him of the Mao-era campaigns, as she often does, and he quickly silenced her.
"No, no," he said. "I don't worry at all about that. We don't live for the cause of Communism. We live for living better."

Chart: "China's Revolution"
 
The Republican Era
1911-12 -- Qing Dynasty overthrown. Sun Yat-sen, right, becomes President of the Chinese Republic and chairman of the
Nationalist Party.
1921 -- Founding meeting of the Communist Party in Shanghai.
1925 -- Sun Yat-sen dies. Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Nationalist Party.
1927 -- Nationalists purge Communists in Shanghai and elsewhere.
1931 -- Japanese seize Manchuria.
1934-35 -- Communist forces, under Nationalist pressure, retreat to north China in the Long March.
1937 -- Japan begins full-fledged invasion of China. Nationalists and Communists form United Front.
1941 -- Japanese attack Pearl Harbor. United States becomes China's ally.
1945 -- Japan surrenders.
1946-49 -- Civil war ends in Communist defeat of Nationalists.
 
Communist Victory
1949 -- Mao Zedong, left, proclaims the People's Republic of China.
1950-1953 --Korean War pits China against United States.
1957 -- Intellectuals who criticized the party during the Hundred Flowers movement are persecuted in the Anti-Rightist Campaign.
1958 -- Great Leap Forward is initiated to achieve Communism through rapid economic development.
1960 -- Soviet Union withdraws advisers from China.
1960-62 -- Economic and social dislocations of Great Leap Forward result in widespread famine and deaths of millions.
1964 -- China carries out first nuclear test.
1966-1976 -- The Cultural Revolution engulfs the country in political turmoil and violence.
1971 -- Beijing takes over China seat in the United Nations, previously held by Taipei.
1972 -- President Nixon visits China.
1975 -- Chiang Kai-shek dies.
1976 -- Mao Zedong dies.
1977 -- Deng Xiaoping, right, purged twice during the Cultural Revolution, returns to power.
 
Beginnings of Reform
1978 -- Communist Party ratifies market-based reforms in the countryside.
1979 -- United States transfers diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. Special Economic Zones created along China's coast to spur economic change and attract foreign investment.
1989 --Demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen Square end in a military crackdown with hundreds killed.
1995-96 -- China launches missiles near Taiwan in apparent attempt at intimidation. Nationalist leader, Lee Teng-hui, becomes Taiwan's first directly elected President.
1997 -- Deng Xiaoping dies. Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule.
1998 -- Presidents Clinton and Jiang Zemin exchange visits.
1999 -- New tensions with Taiwan as President Lee declares relations with Beijing should proceed on a 'state-to-state' basis.
(pg. A10)

HEADLINE: RACING: NOTEBOOK -- BELMONT PARK;
Vosburgh to Be Key Test For Breeders' Cup Sprint

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO 

 BODY:
It will be a shakedown race for the Breeders' Cup Sprint, and seven speed horses were entered in it yesterday at Belmont Park, led by the favorite, Crafty Friend. But to his trainer, John Kimmel, it was not yet certain that the $250,000 Vosburgh at Belmont Park tomorrow would lead the 6-year-old star to the $1 million Breeders' Cup championships five weeks later.
 Kimmel's caution comes from two things, the trainer said yesterday: the timing and the distance. Crafty Friend prevailed by a nose over Affirmed Success in a fierce duel in the Forego Handicap at Saratoga on Labor Day, and may need more than 19 days of rest to run his best race tomorrow. And his preferred distance is seven furlongs, not the six furlongs of the Breeders' Cup Sprint. 
 "Any time you run back in less than three weeks," Kimmel said, "it's a little bit of a concern, especially coming off the kind of effort he gave in the Forego. And as I've said all along, six furlongs is a little short for him. It would be a tough assignment. He would have to draw favorably, probably an outside post position."
 Kimmel said he had an alternative. If Crafty Friend, who has won three of his last four starts, cannot make the Breeders' Cup on Nov. 6 at Gulfstream Park, he can wait for the Cigar Mile at Aqueduct on Nov. 27.
 "We'll see how we do here," he said, "and, if we don't like the way things are going, we could point to a race like the Cigar."
 The field of seven in the Vosburgh includes Artax, who gave a record-setting performance in the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct last spring and who flew three furlongs in 35 seconds yesterday morning in his final workout.
"He's an amazing horse," said his trainer, Louis Albertrani. "The races don't take anything out of him. He doesn't turn a hair. It's like he just went out for a gallop. I think he really enjoys what he does."
 
TURFWAY PARK
Five Star Day Pick In Kentucky Cup
 They will also be sprinting at Turfway Park tomorrow, with Beau Greely's Five Star Day the horse to beat in the Kentucky Cup Sprint.
 Five Star Day ran second to Forestry in the King's Bishop at Saratoga last month, and they are now considered perhaps the two top sprinters, followed closely by Crafty Friend and Affirmed Success, winner of the Vosburgh last year. But Affirmed Success is sitting out the Vosburgh this year because his trainer, Rich Schosberg, feels that the Forego may have taken too much out of his horse.
 So, he is keeping him in the barn tomorrow while the other sprinters run for the gold. But they should all meet in the Breeders' Cup shootout on Nov. 6.
 
N.Y.R.A.
 
Saratoga Purses Set A Record
 In a valedictory to six booming weeks at Saratoga this summer, the New York Racing Association reported yesterday that purses at the upstate track reached record levels along with its high marks in attendance and betting handle.
 Total prize money gained about 12 percent to $18 million; the average rose to $527,000 a day, the highest at any New York track. No wonder the big horses came running: Victory Gallop, Silverbulletday, Lemon Drop Kid, More Than Ready, Forestry and the rest.
 "Our basic belief," said Terry Meyocks, president of the racing association, "getting down to the economics of racing, has always been that the best purses attract the best horses, and the best horses attract the fans." JOSEPH DURSO
 
LITTLE BROWN JUG
Blissfull Hall Wins In a Race-Off
 Less than an hour after fading down the stretch to lose his first shot at winning, Blissfull Hall redeemed himself with a strong closing quarter to take the Little Brown Jug at Delaware, Ohio, in a race-off yesterday and move within a victory of capturing pacing's triple crown.
 Blissfull Hall, winner of the Cane Pace this month at Freehold, N.J., will shoot for the triple crown and a $250,000 bonus in the Messenger Stakes on Oct. 16 at The Meadows at Meadow Lands, Pa.
 It was the second year in a row that Ron Pierce drove the Little Brown Jug winner.
 A year ago, he got a late gift when Mike Lachance elected to drive Artiscape in the second heat instead of the favored Shady Character.
 Pierce was given the ride and ended up winning while Artiscape finished fourth.
 Blissfull Hall coasted to victory in the first elimination in 1:53, winning a showdown with the leading money-winner, The Panderosa. The Panderosa broke stride in the first few seconds and finished last.
 In the second heat, which in the Little Brown Jug format brings back the top three finishers in each of the first three eliminations, Pierce took Blissfull Hall to the rail early and appeared to be in command heading into the stretch of the one-mile race at Delaware County Fairgrounds.
 But Blissfull Hall faded badly and dropped to third behind the upset winner, Looking for Art, driven by the Ohio native Eric Ledford in his Jug debut.
 A horse must win two heats in the Jug's quirky format and Looking for Art's stunning victory forced the four horses who had won races to come back in a race-off to decide the Jug winner. (AP)

HEADLINE: Exile Says U.S. Plans Genocide Charges for Saddam Hussein

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
A leader of Iraq's opposition movement in exile said today that United States officials are planning to pursue genocide and war-crimes charges against Saddam Hussein.
Ahmed Chalabi, a member of the interim presidency of the Iraqi National Congress, a coalition of exile groups, said that he and other Iraqi exiles discussed prospects for prosecuting President Hussein during a meeting in New York on Monday with David Scheffer, the Clinton Administration's Ambassador at Large for War Crimes, and Harold Koh, the Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor. 
 "They told us the United States has a long-term policy to seek the indictment of Saddam Hussein," Mr. Chalabi said.
Several American officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity confirmed that the meeting had taken place and did not deny that the prospect was being considered.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright also met on Monday with the delegation from the Iraqi National Congress. Congress has authorized $97 million to be used to assist such Iraqi opposition groups.
The United States has accused Mr. Hussein of destroying more than 3,000 Kurdish villages, killing more than 5,000 Kurds with poison gas, killing Shiite Muslim clergymen and forcibly relocating civilians in southern Iraq, and executing more than 2,500 prisoners in the last four years.
It was unclear how Washington would pursue a case since an international criminal court does not exist to bring the Iraqi leader to trial. Such a step would also require a measure of support from the Security Council.
A diplomat familiar with the issue said that a commission of inquiry could be set up to gather evidence against the Iraqi leader, creating legal grounds for the kind of prosecutions that led to the detention of the former Chilean dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, in Britain last year.
Mr. Chalabi said that exile groups have been asked to collect material to buttress the case against President Hussein. He said that Washington already has about 5.5 million individual documents from Iraqi security police records, many of them captured by Kurdish forces since the Persian Gulf war, and that some single out specific villages and individuals that became targets of repression.
The question of Iraq preoccupied the Foreign Ministers of the five permanent members of the Security Council -- Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- who were unable to bridge their differences today on a resolution opening the way for United Nations weapons inspectors to return to Iraq.
After meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan, the Foreign Ministers issued a statement saying they wanted to find "a way forward" to adopt a comprehensive resolution that would take into account "the disarmament and humanitarian objectives" of the Security Council.
The split has developed over how to assure Iraq's compliance in disclosing the full extent of its nuclear, biological and chemical weapons and long-range missile programs, as Security Council resolutions have repeatedly demanded since Iraq's defeat in the 1991 gulf war.
Differences have also arisen over the extent to which economic sanctions should be loosened to alleviate suffering among the Iraqi people.
A draft resolution being circulated by Britain and the Netherlands reiterates the Council's position that sanctions cannot be lifted until Iraq has demolished its weapons of mass destruction. The resolution is supported by the United States and eight other members. But France, Britain and China, who all have veto power, want a less stringent yardstick applied for Iraqi cooperation.
The draft reportedly also proposes raising the cap on Iraqi oil output to allow purchases of more food and medicine under United Nations auspices. Other provisions would suspend sanctions on some other Iraqi imports, but with tight financial controls and renewable periods of four months or so, conditional upon Iraq's compliance. Baghdad said it would not accept any plan that does not lift sanctions.
The Foreign Ministers' joint statement today said that they were instructing their representatives on the Security Council to resolve the remaining differences and reach agreement on a new resolution as soon as possible.
"I don't think we expected to reach agreement this week," James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said. "The fact that the Ministers discussed it and urged that agreement be reached should give a boost to the effort to reestablish the Security Council consensus on the critical issue of getting inspectors back into Iraq."

An article yesterday about President Saddam Hussein of Iraq misidentified one of the three permanent members of the United Nations Security Council that want less stringent conditions for easing sanctions on his country than those being advocated by Britain and the Netherlands. The member, along with France and China, is Russia, not Britain.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Walesa Pay Tribute to Kirkland

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton eulogized labor leader Lane Kirkland today as a "giant of a man, a true hero" who rejected political labels and fought for workers around the world.
"He demanded dignity and stood up for the little guy," Mr. Clinton said at a memorial service at Georgetown University for Mr. Kirkland, who was president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. from 1975 to 1995. "It was his ideology and his way of life -- passionate about the things he knew to be right." 
 Mr. Kirkland died on Aug. 14 of lung cancer at his home in Washington. He was 77.
He led a confederation of most American labor organizations in a difficult period for American workers when plants closed, jobs were lost and union membership shrank.
An ardent anti-Communist who recognized the importance of the emerging global economy, Mr. Kirkland played a vital role in the success of the Solidarity movement in Poland by urging unions in the United States to supply money and material to Solidarity. He took pride in the fall of the Soviet Union, the end of the cold war and the rise of democracy in South Africa, believing that the A.F.L-C.I.O. had been instrumental in those events.
Mr. Clinton noted that Mr. Kirkland had been drawn to the labor movement after witnessing working conditions at textile mills near his childhood home of Camden, S.C., in his remarks at Georgetown, Mr. Kirkland's alma mater. The audience included former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Lech Walesa, whose leadership of Solidarity earned him the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize.
Mr. Walesa, through a translator, said he and Mr. Kirkland were "true friends," although they did not speak the same language.
"Lane Kirkland has not died completely," said Mr. Walesa, who was president of Poland from 1990 to 1995. "He has left in each of his friends a little fragment of himself."
John J. Sweeney, the President of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., captured Mr. Kirkland's legacy with his own words. Quoting from Mr. Kirkland's last keynote address at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in 1993, Mr. Sweeney said: " 'We are, indeed, the positive agents of change. Our mission is, as it has always been, to humanize and to harness change to the service of many, rather than the few -- to assure that it means progress rather than dissolution and decay.' "
Mr. Kirkland's daughter, Lucy Kirkland Schoenfeld, closed the service by repeating advice imparted by her father. He encouraged her to remain always irreverent and "to never cross the picket line."

HEADLINE: Existing-Home Sales Decline; Rising Mortgage Rates Cited

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Rising mortgage rates dampened Americans' demand for existing homes and pushed sales down in August, but sales are still headed toward another record year.
Sales of existing single-family homes decreased by 2.8 percent in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.25 million units, the National Association of Realtors said today. It was the second monthly decline after sales hit a record annualized high of 5.63 million in June. 
 Despite the August decrease, association officials said they expected sales of existing homes to post another record year in 1999. Last year's record was 4.97 million units.
The August rate of 5.25 million is about 9.2 percent higher than the sales level of August 1998, the association said.
The August sales level was the lowest since May, when the annual rate was five million units. The 2.8 percent decline in August followed a 4 percent drop in July sales.
The drop in August's sales came mainly from rising mortgage rates, economists said.
"The dampening in growth was due to higher mortgage rates, but it's going to take much higher mortgage rates to really slow down the strong housing market," said Clifford Waldman of Waldman Associates in Arlington, Va.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 7.94 percent in August, up from 7.63 percent in July and 6.92 percent in August 1998, the association said, citing figures from Freddie Mac, the mortgage company.
"Recent jumps in interest rates, coupled with the fact that many consumers spend August vacationing rather than home shopping, are factors that will typically impact sales," said the association's president, Sharon Millett.
The national median sales price for existing homes rose 5.3 percent in August over the corresponding month a year earlier, to a record $137,700, the association said.
Fred Flick, the association's vice president for economic research, attributed the increase to strong demand, a healthy economy and the fact that the unemployment rate hit a 29-year low. "People can afford to pay," he said.
Sales in the West took the biggest hit, falling 12.1 percent in August, to an annual rate of 1.31 million units. Sales were also down in the South, by 1 percent, to an annual rate of 2.05 million units.
Sales were flat in the Midwest, unchanged at an annual rate of 1.18 million units. But they were up by 7.6 percent in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 710,000 units.
The real estate association released its figures a week after the Government reported that construction of new homes and apartments had risen four-tenths of a percent in August, leaving analysts marveling at the continued strength in housing despite rising mortgage rates.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL REVIEWS;
Talking to Mother and Other Totems

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
The notion of an intrinsic national or regional character is investigated in "Sicilia!," Jean-Marie Straub and Daniele Huillet's austere and pretentiously minimalistic screen adaptation of Elio Vittorini's celebrated 1939 novel, "Conversazione in Sicilia" ("Conversations in Sicily"). The Sicilians who discourse in the film, sometimes casually and sometimes in intense personal conversations, tend to speak in cadences that echo the fervency of Italian opera. The culture they evoke is proudly earthbound, its values rooted in long-standing pre-modern traditions of honor and warfare and a stereotypically Italianate machismo. 
 These impressions are filtered through the travels of an unnamed man (Gianni Buscarino) who is returning to his native Sicily after living for many years in Bologna. In the film's centerpiece, the traveler engages in a probing conversation with his widowed mother (Angela Nugara) about everything from the raising of crops to her disappointment in her husband, who was more of a poet than a man's man and who could never live up to the heroic image of her father. His biggest failure, this formidable woman remembers, was his inability to help her when she was giving birth because he was so frightened.
The conversation, filmed in high-contrast black-and-white, is punctuated with pregnant pauses in which the camera pulls back to observe the mother and son impassively silhouetted against a stark white wall as if they were strangers in the same room.
"Sicilia!" has many similar moments that make you aware of the camera in a way that underlines its detachment. In the radically austere films of the Straub-Huillet team, who had two earlier movies, "From Today and Until Tomorrow" (a screen version of Arnold Schoenberg's 1929 light opera) and "Class Relations" (an adaptation of Kafka) in the New York Film Festival, the camera rarely editorializes. Here, at odd moments, it pans slowly back and forth across a particular setting as if to emphasize the filmmakers' blank emotional and editorial slate. For in the Straub-Huillet esthetic, truth is to supposed to be revealed as much through accident, inference and subtext as through what is actually said.
The movie, which the New York Film Festival is showing tomorrow afternoon at 4:30 at Alice Tully Hall, is divided into four movements. The first finds the traveler conversing casually with strangers while waiting in a port. The main subject of conversation is the diminished market for oranges and the bleak economic consequences. The film then jumps ahead to the traveler's boisterous conversation with a group of men on a train. In the boldest challenge to our attention, the camera turns away to cast its gaze for several minutes at arid landscape outside the train window. The third movement reunites him with his mother.
In the finale, our traveler is captivated by the spiel of a knife-sharpener whose honing stone is attached to the wheel of a stationary bicycle. Like the traveler's mother, this hardy wayfarer is a timeless figure virtually untouched by modernity, plying a simple trade that goes back for centuries, if not millennia.
 
SICILIA!
Written, directed and produced by Jean-Marie Straub and Daniele Huillet; in Italian, with English subtitles; based on the novel "Conversazione in Sicilia," by Elio Vittorini; director of photography, William Lubchansky. Shown tomorrow at 4:30 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall as part of the 37th New York Film Festival; with a 17-minute short, Jean-Marie Straub's "Machorka-Muff." Running time: 66 minutes. This film is not rated.

HEADLINE: Good Fortune by the Cupful;
Brazil Coffee Producers Turn to the High-End Market

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: ALFENAS, Brazil

 BODY:
At an air-conditioned compound carved out of the rolling green hills of southeastern Brazil, the headquarters of the coffee plantation overseen by Washington Luiz Alves Rodrigues buzzes with the kind of intensity one expects at an Internet start-up.
"We're emerging from the Stone Age," Mr. Rodrigues, 39, said in his glass office here. Nearby, a few dozen casually dressed employees of Ipanema Agricola, one of Brazil's largest coffee producers, hunched over a single table with computers updating bean analyses, weather dispatches and real-time prices. 
 The company, Brazil's first producer to create a product for Starbucks Coffee, is at the forefront of a wide-reaching transformation in this country's coffee industry, the world's largest. Lured by the market for high-end coffees that has spread from Europe to the United States and is now growing in other countries, many Brazilian producers are focusing for the first time on quality instead of quantity.
Since Brazil produces roughly a third of the world's estimated coffee output of 106.8 million bags -- each bag weighs 132 pounds -- the shift in priority to better-quality coffee could be savored by fans of java around the globe. And together with a parallel quest to increase efficiency, which is resulting in higher yields on Brazilian farms, better coffee could also mean cheaper coffee in coming years.
"The stage where Brazilian coffee is at is similar to where the California wine industry was in the 1970's," said Michael Nugent, head of Merrill Lynch & Company's coffee desk in Napa, Calif. "Back then sweet wines were the thing and dreamers started to create a quality market that was almost nonexistent. The eventual dividends were huge."
Although analysts agree that it will take a while for changes on Brazil's coffee farms to trickle down to the consumer, a look at how companies like Ipanema have reinvented themselves and at how many other Brazilian producers are following suit, may provide some insight into where the global coffee industry is heading.
The newfound emphasis on quality is a departure from the industry's primary objective, which is supplying large processors like the Procter & Gamble Company, which sells the Folgers brand, or the Philip Morris Companies, which markets Maxwell House. Shipments of instant coffee, in which distinctive taste is not necessarily a plus, are also a priority.
"For more than a century Brazil has produced the most, so there was no need to make the best," said Steven Topik, a professor at the University of California at Irvine who is writing a history of coffee.
Although most Brazilian coffee is still sold to large international processors, the crumbling of bureaucratic structures that sought to prop up Brazil's status as the world's leading producer through agreements aimed at controlling production has had much to do with the changes washing over the industry.
In 1989, with much of the world ushering in freer markets, the International Coffee Organization's accord, which used export quotas to help determine prices, was dissolved. Subsequently, the state-controlled Brazilian Coffee Institute, which tried to control production, was abolished in an early effort to limit government interference in the economy.
"It was a big thing for growers to realize that there are actual consumers out there, not just faceless institutions to deal with," said Marcelo Vieira, the international director of the Brazilian Specialty Coffee Association, an organization formed by a dozen producers in the early 1990's.
As growers scrambled to adjust to this new reality, they began visiting countries like neighboring Colombia, the world's second-largest producer, where cultivation on small, mountainous farms has resulted in some of the world's most prized coffees. A delegation of farmers also scoured cities like Seattle, where the specialty coffee craze was in full swing.
After observing the way farms in smaller countries supplied the burgeoning market for specialty coffees in the United States, Ipanema, which is half-owned by Julio Bozano, one of Latin America's richest individuals, shifted its strategy to the cultivation of quality beans.
Soon the company won important contracts with clients in Germany, France and Japan. Its biggest coup, though, came with a product called Ipanema Bourbon, which the company says is made from the same acidic beans that were favored by Brazilian coffee barons at the turn of the century, a time when Brazil's weight in world coffee markets was even greater than it is today.
After several years of being wooed, Starbucks, which shunned Brazilian coffee except for use in some of its blends, said a few months ago that Ipanema Bourbon would be its first coffee from Brazil sold straight.
"It became clear to us that here was a coffee detached from Brazil's generic past," said Marc Schonland, Starbucks' vice president for green coffee.
Part of the reason it has taken so long for Brazilian producers to tap high-end markets abroad has something to do with the way coffee is consumed in Brazil, which has higher per-capita coffee consumption than the United States, even though the United States has the highest total coffee consumption. In recent years, Brazil has overtaken Germany as the second-largest coffee-consuming country, leading producers to focus more on domestic demand.
In Brazilian homes, coffee is consumed throughout the day in small cups with copious amounts of sugar or hot milk, which obscures the original taste. And in business meetings or social gatherings, a handshake or a kiss on the cheek is almost always followed by an offer of a small cup of sweetened coffee. To refuse, even late at night, is to raise eyebrows.
That coffee never developed into a luxury beverage in Brazil is no surprise to Roberto DaMatta, a Brazilian anthropologist at the University of Notre Dame. "Coffee is the comma of cultural grammar, the small, informal pleasure," said Mr. DaMatta, who is planning to write an essay on the place of the coffee break in Brazilian society.
When Brazilians buy coffee publicly, it is usually done standing up at a bar or restaurant counter and is downed quickly after adding sugar, much the way tequila is emptied from a shot glass. Little attention is paid to the origin of coffee served in restaurants, although the growing popularity of espresso blends and sit-down cafes in large cities like Sao Paulo is throwing light on quality.
For instance, a recent study by the Brazilian Coffee Industry Association showed that a quarter of the coffee sold in Brazil was found to contain additives like corn, wheat or fruit rinds that allow producers to cut costs. The outcry that ensued prompted the association to increase the standards for the purity seal it grants to additive-free coffees.
As Brazilians wake up to the allure of higher-quality coffees, a parallel transformation is shaking the country's coffee industry. Many farmers are migrating from southeastern Brazil to the country's midwest and northeast, as a new agricultural frontier opens on the region's highland savannas.
There, in a vast, virtually frost-free area known in Portuguese as the cerrado, producers are using new irrigation and mechanized planting techniques that have resulted in the world's highest-yielding coffee farms. In western Bahia state, the center of the new coffee frontier, high-density planting methods allow up to 2,000 trees to be cultivated on each acre, compared with about 400 on older farms.
"This is a frontier in the physical and technological meanings of the word," said Leon Yallouz, a former employee of the United States Agriculture Department, whose estimates of Brazil's coffee crops are closely followed by analysts. Mr. Yallouz said that efficiency gains could allow Brazil to produce 40 million bags of coffee a year under optimal weather conditions -- or 50 percent more than the 26.5 million bags some coffee analysts are forecasting for 1999-2000.
No one knows exactly what impact a potential increase in Brazilian production could have on coffee prices, since there are so many other unpredictable factors -- like weather, politics and ebbs in the production and consumption in the world's 60 other coffee-producing nations. But recently consumers in the United States got a taste of what could happen after Brazil's largest crop in 11 years was absorbed in the market.
Last month Procter & Gamble said it would cut the price of its coffee to accompany a decline in the price of raw beans. After the company said the price of a 13-ounce can of Folgers would fall by 10 cents, to $2.20, Philip Morris followed suit with its own price cut. Similar price cuts could occur if, as some organizations have warned, a coffee glut results from unrestrained exports by producing countries.
Brazil, for example, exceeded by more than 6 million bags a target of 15 million bags for the year that ended in June; the target had been agreed on with the Association of Coffee Exporting Countries.
Although Brazil's output is expected to fall in the coming year because many trees are in an off year of a two-year production cycle, some experts expect production to bounce back and continue rising. And with unemployment concerns riding high, with the economy forecast to register its second year of no growth, authorities hope the coffee industry, which already employs more than 3 percent of the population, will provide some relief.
"I think jobs in Brazil's coffee industry should increase as production also increases," said Rubens Barbosa, Brazil's Ambassador to the United States and a former chairman of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries.

HEADLINE: After the Tax Cut Veto

 BODY:
Now that President Clinton has vetoed the Republicans' $792 billion tax bill as expected, Congress and the White House can settle down to the difficult business of negotiating on next year's budget. Time is short. With the budget year starting officially in less than a week, few of the spending bills needed for the start of the fiscal year have even passed Congress. Washington seems poised for another last-minute showdown or a series of continuing resolutions to keep the Government going.
Mr. Clinton, who rejected any tax cut before other more pressing matters are resolved on Capitol Hill, reflected how much the political world has changed in recent years. Tax cuts were once as popular as kissing babies and knowing the words to "The Star-Spangled Banner." The problems with this tax bill became obvious in August when members of Congress went home to find that for many people their anti-tax rhetoric had a stingy ring to it. Cutting taxes for the already rich began to sound like cutting benefits for everybody else. Moreover, stimulating a booming economy with a tax cut could stir fears of inflation and trigger higher interest rates, economic developments that can cause near panic in millions of people who watch the Dow like a relative's heart monitor. 
 This week the President noted correctly that the Republican bill he vetoed was "too big, too bloated," burdening the economy while rewarding the rich, the lobbyists and campaign contributors. The veto, however, was the easy part. The President now has a far more difficult task of finding common ground with a Congress that prefers the politics of Clinton-bashing. It might help that Mr. Clinton's veto statement had less venom than expected, an unwritten White House invitation to focus on a decent budget package and a more reasonable use of the Federal surplus. Congress and the White House should find some agreement on how to preserve Medicare while relieving prescription drug costs for the elderly, protect Social Security, retire debt and, as political dessert, offer any modest tax cut with what is still available. Mr. Clinton's veto message Thursday rightly urged Congress not to "throw in the towel" or go home early while these more complicated matters, especially Medicare and Social Security, remain untouched.
Senator William Roth, a Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and New York's Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the committee, could push for a "down payment" on Medicare reform. It would offer Mr. Moynihan a crowning achievement before next year's retirement and provide Mr. Roth with a crowing point for what is expected to be his toughest re-election campaign. The season for working out areas of agreement on these matters is now, while the President has the budget bills as leverage and before next year's elections turn complicated issues into political bumper stickers.

HEADLINE: North Korea Says It Will Halt Missile Tests During U.S. Talks

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 24

 BODY:
In a terse announcement that seemed to confirm recent diplomatic advances, the North Korean Government today publicly stated that it would refrain from further missile tests while talks with the United States are underway.
The statement, carried by the official Korean Central News Agency, said the halt in missile tests had been decided "in order to create a more favorable atmosphere." It appeared to bolster assertions by the Clinton Administration that the recently announced easing of American sanctions against North Korea was justified by a new North Korean commitment to ease tensions by suspending the country's missile tests. 
 At a news conference here today before receiving word of the North Korean statement, William J. Perry, the former United States Defense Secretary who is President Clinton's special adviser on North Korea, spoke of the missile test moratorium and the easing of American sanctions as initial gestures in what promises to be a long road toward ending the cold war on the Korean peninsula. Washington's recent moves have included lifting a ban on trade between the countries, allowing American airlines to land in North Korea, and promoting higher level diplomatic contacts.
"Each step of the negotiations ahead of us could be frustrating and difficult," he said. "But if we are unsuccessful in persuading North Korea to remove the threat, we must take actions that are even more difficult, we must take actions to contain that threat."
The announcement of an agreement between the United States and North Korea to relax sanctions and halt missile testing after talks in Berlin earlier this month received mixed reaction in Washington, with some critics maintaining that the Koreans were being wrongly rewarded for easing a crisis of their own creation.
In response, Mr. Perry said today that making the improvement in relations between the countries meaningful would require a "change in behavior" by the North. Failing that, he said, the sanctions could be restored "in a day."
Talks are scheduled to resume in early October, and are expected to involve the visit of a senior North Korean official to Washington for the first time.
In recent years, with its economy in a shambles, North Korea has suffered what many experts say may rank as one of the century's worst famines. According to some estimates, as many as two million people may have died of starvation and famine-related disease. Under these circumstances, economic aid and the remittances of Koreans living in Japan, and more recently, receipts from a booming, if tightly controlled, tourist trade with South Korea have become vital sources of income for the Government of President Kim Jong Il.
Although South Korea has pressed ahead with a strategy of engagement, Japan reacted to a missile test last year with a suspension of most economic aid and a threat to end the lucrative remittances. Japan has taken the most cautious approach to North Korea of any of Washington's regional allies. And Tokyo's skepticism could be heard even today after the North Korean announcement.
"We continue to monitor North Koreas statements with keen interest," said one senior Japanese diplomat, who said his country supported Mr. Perry's diplomacy. "But everyone is hopeful there will be more from North Korea. And so on the basis of just a couple of sentences, I think I should stop there."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Big Selloff Eases, but Investors Remain Concerned

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
After a volatile day of trading during which all the major indexes were down sharply, stocks rebounded yesterday and finished off slightly. But while the market held together after a big selloff Thursday, a host of concerns, including higher interest rates, a weaker dollar and overvalued technology stocks, will continue to trouble investors.
The declines for the week left the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks just a fraction from a 10 percent decline since its July 16 high and pushed the Dow Jones industrial average off 9.2 percent from its high of Aug. 25. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index is 5.1 percent below its Sept. 10 high, but that is after a 13 percent decline from July 17 to Aug. 10. 
 Where the market goes from here is difficult to say, but investors have many reasons to be jittery. The Federal Reserve could raise interest rates for a third time since June when policy makers meet on Oct. 5. The rebound of economies in Asia and Europe is making those markets more attractive, which could drag investors away from the United States.
The rush of foreign investors back into Japan is the main reason for the dollar's sharp slump against the Japanese yen over the last 10 weeks. Although the dollar is off 15 percent against the yen, it is not significantly weaker against the world's other major currencies. But a continued slide against the yen could still help pull stocks lower, as Americans fear a flight of Japanese investors back home.
The so-called confessional season on earnings is also under way, and more negative announcements about missing earnings estimates could rattle the market in the current environment, even though earnings growth for the third quarter is expected to be strong. Apple Computer and the FDX Corporation are among the major companies that have recently issued warnings.
But this wave of concern has not reined in all the exuberance that had sent stocks so high. Another new issue of an Internet stock took off yesterday, with shares in Alteon Websystems leaping from their initial offering price of $19 a share to $74.9375. Several other I.P.O.'s also did well yesterday.
The Dow finished at 10,279.33, down 39.26 points, or four-tenths of a percent, after falling as much as 131 points in the afternoon. The S.& P. 500 dropped as much as 16 points before ending down 3.05 points, or two-tenths of a percent, at 1,277.36. The Nasdaq composite index fell 9.42 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 2,740.41, after being down as much as 65 points.
For the week, the Dow was down 524 points, or 4.9 percent, its worst weekly performance in a year. It is now 1,046.71 points below its all-time high, reached Aug. 25. This week the Dow also broke through the bottom of the trading range in which it had been since mid-May. It is now back to where it was on April 9.
For the year, the Dow is still up 12 percent and the Nasdaq 25 percent. But the S.& P. 500 is now up only 3.92 percent, and if that rate holds it will have its poorest annual performance since 1994. The poorer performance of the S.& P., which is a broader index than the other two, reflects how this year's rally has been concentrated in a few technology and other big-name and big-company stocks.
Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore, said the market was in a valuation correction, a decline that occurs when stock prices far outstrip their promised earnings. He said he did not think the bottom had been hit yet, but that "we are a lot closer to it than some people might think."
Mr. Cripps said the market will have returned to a more secure footing when more than 50 percent of the stocks in the S.& P. 500 index have declined 10 percent or more from their 52-week highs. As of yesterday, 43.6 percent of the S.& P. 500 was in that category. Another sign that stock valuations were back in attractive ranges, he said, would be if 20 percent of the S.& P. 500 stocks were down 30 percent or more from their 52-week highs. Slightly more than 10 percent of the S.& P. stocks are in that category now.
One benefit of the recent decline, Mr. Cripps said, is that the Federal Reserve is much less likely to raise its interest rate target a third time. "The fact that the stock market has cooled off takes away a reason to act," he said.
Fed officials have said repeatedly that the rally in the stock market this year has helped fuel the consumer spending that is keeping the economy growing at a faster pace than policy makers would like.
This week's stock selling has given a lift to the bond market, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond below 6 percent again. As more investors chose the relative safety of bonds yesterday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 102 7/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.96 percent, down from 5.98 percent on Thursday. The yield on the 30-year bond has crossed the 6 percent level more than a dozen times since June.
The price of the two-year note, which is more sensitive to Fed interest rate moves, was unchanged as the yield remained at 5.53 percent.
In a surprise, the dollar rose against the Japanese yen for the first time in five trading days. The small rally came despite comments made on Thursday by the Secretary of the Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers, that seemed to rule out any effort by the United States to help support the dollar against the yen.
The dollar inched up to 104.17 yen from 103.95 Thursday. The euro, the 11-country European currency, rose slightly against the dollar, finishing at $1.0464 from $1.044 Thursday.
But currency analysts expect the decline in the dollar against the yen to resume because the Bank of Japan has apparently decided not to move to slow the Japanese currency's rally, even though it could be a threat to Japan's economic recovery.
In Japan, stocks fell yesterday, with the Nikkei index of 225 stocks dropping 454.03, or 2.6 percent, to 16,871.73. In the last two trading days the benchmark stock index has fallen 5.9 percent. After a rise of 33.9 percent this year, this selling could be a signal that some investors are worried that the strengthening yen could trip up Japan's emerging economic recovery.
Merck & Company, the Intel Corporation, MCI Worldcom and Pfizer led the market lower. And it took most of the day for the technology sector to shed the hangover from Thursday, when Steven A. Ballmer, the president of Microsoft, set off a rapid afternoon selloff by saying technology stocks were overvalued.
A three-point jump in I.B.M., which fell 3 3/16 on Thursday, helped the Dow rebound from its lows. Internet stocks and other technology stocks also rallied. Amazon and Ebay were both up after falling Thursday. Microsoft, which fell as much as 2 5/16 during the day, finished down 1/4.
