HEADLINE: Clinton Tries to Reassure Party on Gore Candidacy

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
In a passionate political speech, President Clinton today tried to reassure his fellow Democrats that Vice President Al Gore was a strong Presidential candidate, that Mr. Gore had an unusually positive economy to run on and that it was way too early to worry about his prospects.
"Be of good cheer," Mr. Clinton urged the party faithful at a Democratic National Committee meeting here. "It's a long time between now and November of 2000. In June of 1992, you know where I was in the polls? Not behind. Third! Third!" 
 Mr. Clinton, mindful that the party is officially neutral in the primary season, did not mention Mr. Gore directly or the potentially bruising primary battles he faces with former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey. Nor did he mention the latest bad news for Mr. Gore, a CNN poll that showed Mr. Bradley and Mr. Gore in a statistical dead heat in New Hampshire. The same poll showed that Mr. Clinton himself is a giant drag on Mr. Gore.
But Mr. Clinton has been raising money for his Vice President and campaigning on his behalf, and he wanted to give a lift to Gore supporters today, telling them not to become disheartened by early polls or distracted by matters that have little effect on real people.
"This is not an election yet," he said. "I mean, the election may be going on in the newspapers every day, but here, in the minds of the American people, they still think we should be drawing a paycheck to work for them."
At the same time, the Gore and Bradley campaigns were negotiating over a joint town-hall appearance in New Hampshire for Oct. 27. Gore advisers have long believed that a debate format plays to Mr. Gore's strengths, and they hope this will provide an opportunity to help short-circuit any Bradley surge.
The Democratic committee meeting, where both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley are speaking on Saturday, is also perceived as a good venue for the Vice President. It is stacked with Clinton/Gore supporters and will become even more so after Saturday, when it officially installs Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia, a longtime Gore backer, as the new general chairman.
But that devotion was tested today in a behind-the-scenes wrangle over a resolution the committee is to consider on Saturday. It opposes re-opening debate on the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the landmark law prohibiting discrimination based on race, religion or sex in employment and public accommodations.
Last week, Mr. Bradley said he supported amending the 1964 law to include gay men and lesbians as protected groups. But several black and gay officials, some supporters of Mr. Gore, denounced the idea, saying any changes would provide an opening to Congressional conservatives to weaken the law's existing provisions.
When the resolution surfaced this morning, it bluntly called for opposing any changes to the 1964 act. Mr. Bradley's campaign attacked the resolution as an effort by the Gore camp to divide the party and turn blacks against Mr. Bradley. After much wrangling, the two camps agreed on modified language saying that the act should not be re-opened for debate or amendments "that diminish its existing protections."
The dispute was a signal that Gore allies were willing to raise concerns about Mr. Bradley on racial matters, the core issue of his candidacy. Still, Mr. Bradley showed surprising strength in fighting the Gore camp to a standstill.
Several of those attending the meeting expressed support for Mr. Gore. Martin J. Dunleavy, political affairs director for the American Federation of Government Employees, said he was not too worried about Mr. Gore's fate in primaries.
"It's early, and people like to second-guess the Vice President," Mr. Dunleavy said. But he added that the party needed to be careful about the nation's natural desire for change after eight years of Democratic power.
"Even though I think the Democrats have done a great job," he said, "there's a natural desire to re-examine the course of the country."
Mr. Clinton spoke to this underlying yen for change, acknowledging that it was aimed in part at him.
"As you go into the next election, don't fight with people when they say, 'We need a change,' " Mr. Clinton advised. "Tell them: 'We certainly do. We always need a change.' "
But, he said, "the question is not whether we're going to change, but what kind of change we're going to make? And are we going to change based on all of the good things that are going on in America now? Or would we instead take a U-turn and go back to the stuff that got us in so much trouble before the Vice President and I came here and got the help of the fine members of Congress and others who have worked with us?"
In offering a glowing assessment of his Administration's record, Mr. Clinton said the economy had been going so well for so long that voters might forget that it was worse under the Republicans, and he warned against a "collective amnesia" that would gloss over these differences.
Bradley supporters at the committee meeting were in the minority, but fervent nonetheless. One was Jackie Stevenson, a longtime party official from Minnesota. "The question is, Can Gore overcome the Clinton problem?" Ms. Stevenson asked, referring to Mr. Clinton's impeachment and Mr. Gore's belated effort to separate himself from the Clinton scandals. "It may be too late at this point."
A playful Mr. Clinton took a swipe at Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican front-runner, for supporting the Republican tax-cut bill, which Mr. Clinton just vetoed, and for proposing to increase defense spending at the same time. The President said his veto had spared Mr. Bush and other Republicans some embarrassment.
With the tax cut, he said, "there'd be no money to pay for all these things they're out there promising the voters."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

George Plans to Continue But With Two Fewer Issues
George magazine, the political magazine whose founder and editor was John F. Kennedy Jr., will continue publishing next year, but will reduce the number of issues to 10 annually from 12. 
 The magazine's appeal for both readers and advertisers has faded this year, admitted Jack Kliger, the president and chief executive of Hachette Filipacchi Magazines, owner of George along with Random Ventures. Total paid circulation, at 405,153 for the first half of the year, was down 3.4 percent from the period in 1998; single-copy sales from newsstands declined 11 percent, to 90,058. Page C4.
 
Existing-Home Sales Fell in August
Sales of existing single-family homes decreased by 2.8 percent in August, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.25 million units, the National Association of Realtors said. It was the second monthly decline after sales hit a record annualized high of 5.63 million in June. Even though mortgage rates have been rising recently, sales are still headed toward another record year. Last year's record was 4.97 million units. C3.
 
College Board in For-Profit Spinoff
The College Board, the nonprofit organization that administers college-entrance and other standardized tests, reacted to the threat of competition from the burgeoning on-line industry that helps students prepare for and select colleges, by voting to spin off its first for-profit enterprise. It plans to create a full-service Web site with advertising. A1.
 
Bank of New York Sued by Holders
Shareholders of the Bank of New York have filed a lawsuit against the bank and its directors, accusing them of allowing Russian organized crime figures to launder billions of dollars through the bank illegally. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeks damages on behalf of the bank itself. C4.
 
Polish Workers Seek Higher Wages
Exhausted by 10 years of economic difficulty in the transition from Communism, some 30,000 Polish farmers and workers marched through Warsaw demanding better wages and job security. A4.
 
Allstate Predicts Lower Earnings
Allstate said that its profits for the rest of the year would fall from the levels of a year earlier and would not meet expectations, because of pricing pressures and higher losses from Hurricane Floyd and other catastrophes. The announcement sent shares of Allstate and other insurers tumbling. An insurance industry group estimated that insured damage from Hurricane Floyd, which affected virtually the entire East Coast, would be $1.3 billion. C4.
 
Grupo Mexico Makes Bid for Asarco
Grupo Mexico, the Mexican mining and railways company, bid $26 a share to acquire Asarco, topping a previous bid made by Phelps Dodge. Grupo Mexico, which is fighting to gain a larger share of the world's copper production, already owns a stake of 10 percent in Asarco. C14.
 
Profit Warning Hurts Kroll-O'Gara
Shares of Kroll-O'Gara, the security and private-investigation company, fell 44.6 percent after it said it was considering selling itself and warned that third-quarter earnings would miss estimates. C3.
 
Yahoo to Offer Web Service in China
Yahoo, the Internet search service, said it would create an Internet directory site tailored for Web users in China. C2.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
N.H.L. Seeks Aid to Keep Canada's Sport in Canada

BYLINE: By TARIK EL-BASHIR 

 BODY:
In a bid to keep hockey, the Canadian national sport, in Canada, the National Hockey League has asked the Canadian Government to subsidize the country's six major-league hockey teams by more than $30 million a year.
The owners of four of the six teams say that they are in dire financial straits and that most of them could be be forced to sell their teams or move to the United States unless the Canadian Government steps in. 
 "We have no other choice," said Rod Bryden, chairman of the Ottawa Senators. "We can either leave or go bankrupt. We won't sit here and die. We'll go somewhere else -- the States -- where we can thrive. I don't think Canadians realize how desperate the situation is."
The proposal from the N.H.L., which if approved would involve a government more directly than ever before in the everyday operation of professional sports in North America, calls for the Canadian Government to give the league a share of the revenue from provincial lotteries that are based on the outcome of N.H.L. games. It is part of a package of recommendations from the league to help the Canadian clubs compete financially with their American counterparts and to prevent some of them from migrating to American cities.
The league has been talking with national and provincial officials in Canada for the last 18 months about the economic strains endured by most of the Canadian franchises. These include the amount of taxes on property and income and the weakness of the Canadian dollar compared to the American dollar. These forces have put at least four of the six Canadian teams in jeopardy. The Montreal Canadiens, hockey's most fabled franchise, say they pay more in property taxes each year than all 22 of the American N.H.L. teams combined.
In an attempt to move the talks forward, the league presented a formal proposal to the Canadian Government last week. The eight-page plan asked for significant tax relief and 20 percent of the money raised by the existing and quite popular provincial lotteries that are based on N.H.L. games. Last year, revenue from those lotteries totaled $170 million.
Relief from local taxes is common for most American professional teams, as is government aid in building stadiums. In one sense, the Canadian hockey teams are asking only for the tax advantages now enjoyed by nearly all their American competitors.
Government officials in Ottawa are reviewing the plan and have not formulated a response, said Jennifer Sloan, a spokeswoman for the Canadian Industry Minister, John Manley, who has been overseeing the talks between the national Government and the N.H.L.
But the proposal has already sparked a spirited debate in Canada. Proponents contend that because hockey is an essential part of Canadian culture, the Government should step in to keep the six teams in Canada. Opponents argue that the lottery revenue should continue to be used for health care and social services, not for millionaire players and owners.
Hockey has been a vital element of Canadian culture for decades, and most N.H.L. games are broadcast on Canadian television to large and enthusiastic audiences. Yet in the last four years, two major-league teams have left the country for more economically appealing locales in the United States: the Quebec Nordiques moved to Denver, and the Winnipeg Jets went to Phoenix.
Of the six remaining Canadian teams, the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Montreal Canadiens are unlikely to leave. Both have deep roots; for 25 years, until the N.H.L. expanded to 12 teams from six in 1967-68, they were the only two Canadian teams in the league. Moreover, Toronto is Canada's largest city, and the Maple Leafs are ranked among the top third in the league in revenue because of a solid fan base and a brand new arena, the Air Canada Center, which opened earlier this year.
But for the four other Canadian teams -- in Ottawa, Vancouver, Calgary and Edmonton -- matters are different. Bryden, the Senators' chairman, said economics could force the team to shut down or move. "The real, hard fact is that if we don't get a tax regime that is tolerable, we'll leave," he said.
Some Canadian teams in other professional sports, including baseball and basketball, are experiencing similar financial hardships. Like the hockey teams, these franchises find it hard to keep high-priced free-agent players in Canada, where income taxes are much higher than in the United States.
The N.H.L. and the six Canadian teams say that governments at the local, provincial and national levels must all pitch in to help the teams become more competitive financially. They ask, in their formal plan, for abatements on property taxes and the elimination of some provincial taxes, like a 10 percent amusement tax in Ontario that treats N.H.L. games as non-Canadian entertainment.
Bryden said the Senators paid more than $37 million in taxes last year. That was in addition to the cost of maintaining the Corel Center, which was built entirely with private funds, as were roads leading to the arena.
The league's proposal also calls for something entirely new: annual operating support. It would come from the sale of lottery tickets based on the outcome of N.H.L. games. League officials say the teams deserve a share of the $170 million annual pot because the games are the intellectual property of the N.H.L. and its teams.
They say that a 20 percent take would provide $34 million to be shared among the six Canadian teams. The American teams would get no share of the money under the N.H.L.'s proposal.
In Ontario's hockey lottery, the country's most popular, someone must choose at least three games, picking the winners or predicting a tie. There is no limit on how much money can be wagered on each ticket, but all three choices must be correct to win. The provincial government sets the odds.
William Daly, the N.H.L.'s senior vice president for legal affairs, said the league opposed the lotteries when they were created in the early 1990's. He bristled at the suggestion that giving the league a share of the lottery revenue amounted to a government subsidy.
"We think hockey subsidizes the Canadian Government, as we subsidize the lottery," he said.
In discussions, governmental officials have appeared willing to consider the lottery proposal, Daly said. "We think politically it's the most feasible proposal," he said. "It's a voluntary tax, so to speak."
In return for the new revenue, the league is offering to allow the provincial lotteries to use league and team logos to promote lottery sales. The N.H.L. has also promised to keep the six Canadian teams in place for the next five years and to continue several existing league programs, including one that helps Canadian teams keep their own players from being lured away by American teams. The league has provided more than $42 million to the teams since 1995, helping to offset the difference between the weak Canadian dollar and the stronger American dollar.
The early response to the N.H.L.'s plan has been mixed. Some newspaper editorials in Canada have condemned it, saying the money from the lotteries should continue to be used only for medical care and charities. Other editorials have criticized the idea of tax relief but endorsed the sharing of lottery revenue.
Ernie Eves, the Ontario Minister of Finance, who oversees his province's lottery, wrote a letter to Industry Minister Manley opposing any reduction in provincial revenue. Eves said the province could not afford to shift money from nonprofit groups to the owners of professional teams. "If the federal Government wants to provide direct cash support with the money already given to them by the provinces," Eves wrote, "that is your decision."

HEADLINE: Asians Worry About Cost of East Timor Role

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Trying to extricate themselves from a long-running financial crisis, Indonesia's Southeast Asian neighbors are concerned about how long their presence will be needed in East Timor and what their participation in the international force will cost them, Thailand's Foreign Minister said today.
The Foreign Minister, Surin Pitsuwan, who is in New York for the General Assembly debate, has been meeting with United Nations officials who are drawing up plans for future assistance to East Timor as it moves toward independence from Indonesia. 
 President B. J. Habibie has pledged to honor the East Timorese vote to end its relationship with Indonesia, but it is not clear when the results of that referendum will be formally recognized by the Indonesian Parliament, which assembles early next month, or whether there will be efforts by the President's political opponents to block action.
Thailand has provided the deputy commander of the force now in East Timor, Maj. Gen. Songkitti Chakkrabhat, and is likely to field the largest contingent of troops after Australia. General Songkitti was formerly Thailand's military attache in Jakarta, speaks some Bahasa Indonesia, the national language, and knows Indonesian Army leaders.
Indonesia, a member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, has said from the start that it would like to see troops from neighboring countries prominent in the international force.
In addition to Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Singapore are also contributing to the international force, but in much smaller numbers and often with specialists rather than soldiers.
Each country made its own decision because getting a consensus from the association could be complicated, said Mr. Surin, who as Thailand's Foreign Minister is the current chairman of the group, known as Asean.
"We certainly respond to the call of the international community, of the U.N. Security Council, and of Indonesia because we are in the region, because we are part of the family, as President Habibie said," Mr. Surin said in an interview.
"But the parameters must be clear -- political parameter, division of responsibility, time frame, the expense. All these have to be defined as soon as possible."
Mr. Surin said that Thais, with a strong free press and many political parties, were already asking questions about the international force and what will follow it when the United Nations takes over administration of East Timor until it can hold elections and install a government.
Costs of the interim force are expected to be borne largely by Japan and Australia, but fielding military contingents can nonetheless be a drain on national treasuries, even with outside help.
"Thais are asking about the uncertainties," Mr. Surin said. "In a free and open society, this is very legitimate."
Next week, United Nations officials will get a chance to speak about East Timor's future with the East Timorese independence leader, Jose Alexandre Gusmao, who is known as Xanana. He will be in New York next week to meet with Secretary General Kofi Annan and others.
Mr. Gusmao, a guerrilla leader arrested by Indonesia seven years ago and released last month, first sought refuge at the British Embassy in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, fearing an attack by Indonesia gangs opposed to relinquishing the territory.
Last week, he moved to Darwin, Australia, and announced that he hoped to return soon to East Timor to set up an interim government.
Mr. Surin, a Harvard graduate who once worked as a visiting fellow on Capitol Hill as a legislative aide to Geraldine A. Ferraro when she was a Representative from New York, said that Southeast Asians are also very concerned about how Indonesia is handled by the outside world during the East Timorese transition.
"We have to maintain diplomatic communications open," he said. "We have to maintain the political discussion, so that we can avoid any possible area of misunderstanding."

HEADLINE: Welfare Officials To Search Records Of Drug Treatment

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration is planning to search thousands of medical billing records for evidence it can use to place welfare applicants in mandatory drug and alcohol treatment programs as a condition of receiving public assistance, city welfare officials say.
The information will be culled from computerized Medicaid insurance bills submitted in the past on behalf of applicants who have voluntarily sought treatment for drug and alcohol problems. The record search is for the applicants' own good, welfare officials said this week, and will be used to push them to finish treatment and to get jobs faster. 
 Officials say that record checks are needed because the city's current system of drug screening and testing is finding unrealistically low rates of substance abuse among welfare mothers who need help.
But privacy experts and lawyers for the poor say the record search may violate a Federal law protecting the confidentiality of drug and alcohol treatment records. They contend that the city's plan will frighten poor people from seeking treatment or benefits and will send a chilling message to anyone considering help for drug or alcohol problems.
The issue, privacy experts say, is a classic example of the conflict between public concern over the loss of privacy, especially in health care records, and public support for using computer databases to monitor or track suspect groups, like welfare recipients, illegal immigrants and parents who fail to pay child support.
Federal officials said they had no official notification of the plan. "But there are confidentiality provisions in New York's Medicaid plan, and we expect them to be followed," said Christopher H. Peacock, spokesman for the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees Medicaid records.
Jason A. Turner, Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, said no breach of confidentiality would be involved because the billing records to be checked are submitted by drug and alcohol treatment providers to the city's Medicaid office, and both Medicaid and public assistance fall under his agency. "These are our own records," he said. "We are not interfering with the doctor-patient relationship. We're helping poor people here."
But advocates of the poor who support treatment as a condition of aid say the record search crosses the line.
"If people go into treatment thinking their records are confidential and then, lo and behold, the information is illegally disclosed, that will upset just about everybody," said Paul N. Samuels, a lawyer and the director of the Legal Action Center, a nonprofit advocacy organization that specializes in substance abuse issues and has offices in New York and Washington. "Violating confidentiality is an ambush that will drive many people away from treatment."
No date has been set to start searching applicants' records. The plan is one of several new measures introduced by Mr. Turner to meet a deadline set by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who vowed last year that by the year 2000, "New York will be the first city in the nation, on its own, to end welfare."
Mr. Giuliani, whose welfare overhaul is expected to be a centerpiece of his likely campaign for the United States Senate, did not mean an end to public assistance, Mr. Turner said. The Mayor meant that all adult recipients would be moving from welfare to work through a variety of assignments, including treatment for drug and alcohol abuse that is a barrier to employment, Mr. Turner said.
The Mayor has cited one estimate that 20 percent of all people on public aid have such substance abuse problems. Ten percent is the figure more commonly accepted by substance abuse experts. But among mothers, who are the bulk of adult recipients, only 2 percent have been identified as substance abusers through a system of screening and testing put in place two years ago, Mr. Turner said.
In several other jurisdictions around the country, including Florida and Los Angeles County, officials have also identified lower-than-expected rates of welfare mothers as substance abusers, for reasons that remain unclear. But no other state is known to be contemplating a record search like New York's, according to the Washington office of the Legal Action Center, which represents many treatment centers nationwide.
Brian J. Wing, Commissioner of the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, which oversees city and county welfare operations, approved the city's record search plan, said Daniel D. Hogan, his deputy. Mr. Hogan added that some upstate counties have already conducted such searches case by case.
Marc Rotenberg, executive director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center, a civil liberties advocacy group based in Washington, said: "Welfare recipients are among the first to lose their privacy. But the unfortunate consequences of these tracking and matching technologies tend to make their way up the line."
A Federal law passed in the 1970's makes it a crime, with few exceptions, to disclose information about patients in drug and alcohol treatment programs without the patients' narrowly defined written consent. That consent does not allow redisclosure for any other purposes. Experts on privacy law call the measure unique and exemplary, and contrast it to the blanket consent forms allowed in the gathering of other types of health care information.
Corinne Carey, a lawyer who has studied drug testing and welfare reform nationwide, said that instead of searching records, the city should be asking why more mothers on public assistance are not being identified by the city's current screening system for substance abuse.
As tougher rules and a strong economy have combined to shrink New York City's welfare rolls to about 670,000 from 1.1 million in 1994, including children, fewer substance abusers are applying for public assistance because they cannot deal with the hurdles or meet the work requirements, said Ms. Carey, who works for the Urban Justice Center, an advocacy organization opposed to the record search. Others hide their problems from caseworkers because they fear losing their children.
And some advocates suggest drug use may actually be lower than experts thought in the younger generation of poor mothers who saw crack devastate parents or older siblings.
A different kind of explanation was offered by Bill Panepinto, an administrator in the State Office of Alcohol and Substance Abuse Services. The substance abuse screening form used by the city was intended to be the framework for a personal interview by a trained worker, he said, but for the last two years it has instead been handed out to welfare applicants as a nine-question paper test. Those who answer yes to two or more questions are referred to certified alcohol and substance abuse counselors for further assessment, including a drug test.
Seven out of 10 welfare applicants referred to mandatory residential treatment end up cut from all assistance, said Michael Kink, legislative counsel to Housing Works, one of about 30 advocacy, legal services and provider organizations that met yesterday because of concern about the city's plan. "The sanction rate shows that this program is designed more to drive people off the rolls than to get people help," he said.
Mr. Turner vigorously defends the program's intentions. Now, he said, mothers are known to coach each other in the waiting room on how to answer the questionnaire to avoid being assigned to mandatory treatment. But treatment billing records may show they have been in and out of care many times, he said. "If you're sick and your children are at risk because you're a substance abuser," he said, "we believe it's not compassionate to ignore that fact."
Like most states, New York considered but rejected a requirement that all public assistance applicants submit to drug tests. Instead, it asks drug-use questions of all applicants, but uses physical tests only on those whose answers or behavior raise a reasonable suspicion of abuse.
Universal testing is permitted under the Federal welfare overhaul, but only Michigan is planning to use that approach, which has been widely criticized as expensive, ineffective and vulnerable to constitutional challenge.

HEADLINE: Reform Party Unsettled By Quest for a Nominee

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
After struggling to create the most successful third party in 80 years, many longtime members of the Reform Party say they are growing more fearful by the day that they will be left as virtual bystanders if Patrick J. Buchanan or another famous person decides to flood the party with supporters in pursuit of its Presidential nomination.
Others in the party, determined to become more than an asterisk in Presidential politics, say they are willing to overlook their differences with Mr. Buchanan in return for the attention and success that his candidacy could bring. Either way, party leaders agree that their nominee is almost certain to be determined by people who are not current members of the party, portending a frantic and expensive organizing contest. 
 "If Pat Buchanan brings enough people, we become the Pat Buchanan Party and there's nothing we can do about it," said Robert K. Pavlick, 52, of Bridgeport, Conn., a member of the party's national rules committee. "Their votes will far outweigh those of the indigenous Reformers. They can put all our issues on the back burner."
Wendell B. Kinney, 64, the state chairman for Maine, said many founding members feared they would be no match for Mr. Buchanan's forces. "They've been around politics a long time, and we're mostly novices," Mr. Kinney said.
In the most dramatic evidence so far of this concern, the Reform Party of New Hampshire canceled a state convention that had been scheduled for Saturday because officials said they feared a takeover by Buchanan supporters in elections for the state party's six offices.
John R. Talbott, a spokesman for Reform Party in New Hampshire, said officials learned on Wednesday that supporters of Mr. Buchanan planned to pack the convention.
"We're getting our introduction to power politics," Mr. Talbott said. "We were not happy that we had to do this, but we thought it would be best in the long run to preserve an independent and unbiased organization."
The Reform Party has never been about size: just 50,000 people voted in its nominating contest in 1996, and one leader said that Florida, for instance, has 60 active members. But because of the success of Ross Perot in 1992 and 1996, the party has automatic slots on the ballot in 20 states and is eligible to receive $12.6 million in Federal funds.
The chairman-elect, John J. Gargan, 68, of Cedar Key, Fla., said the party was vulnerable to a takeover because of what he called its "blank-check provision," a rule that allowed any registered voter to write in and get a ballot for the Presidential nominating contest, scheduled for next July.
Ballots can be cast by mail, telephone or the Internet. The results will be ratified at the party's national convention, to be in Long Beach, Calif., from Aug. 10 to 13.
Besides the voters who might be recruited by Mr. Buchanan or by old-guard members of the party, others might be recruited by Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, who has said he will work to promote a centrist candidate to counter Mr. Buchanan.
Roger Stone, a political consultant who is advising Donald J. Trump, the developer, on a possible Reform Party bid, has said Mr. Trump might use his database of 6.5 million gamblers, renters and hotel guests to reach out to potential voters.
Mr. Gargan, an ally of Governor Ventura who will take over as national party chairman in January, said that he welcomed all comers for the nomination, but that he had been warning other leaders that the nominating process seemed tailor-made for exploitation by anyone with a big mailing list.
"Our party's membership is very thin and it's spread out," he said. "We have nowhere near the resources we would need to cope with an outpouring of requests for ballots."
Mr. Gargan's concern is that some other group with a lot of supporters -- say, a gun-control group -- will decide that Mr. Buchanan should not be allowed to get the nomination, and would mobilize its own ballot drive.
The party's departing officers, who were deposed at the party's national convention in July after Governor Ventura endorsed Mr. Gargan, defended the rules as the sort of open process that they see as sorely lacking in the two major parties.
"If millions of people get up off their couch and write in for our nomination ballot, that probably means we're going to win the general election," said Michael H. Farris, 30, of Los Angeles, chairman of the Presidential nominations committee.
In Mr. Buchanan's case, a hostile takeover may not be necessary. Already, some Reform Party members are offering reasons they could support Mr. Buchanan, who reflects the party's views on many economic issues. But Mr. Buchanan is a vocal opponent of abortion while the Reform Party platform intentionally ignores social issues.
"We've always said that our members and our candidates can follow their conscience on abortion," said Elizabeth A. Christman, 35, the Maryland state chairman, who favors abortion rights. "He agrees with our economic and government reform issues, and that's what people in this party care about."
Donna Donovan, the party's national press secretary, also favors abortion rights, but was eager to defend Mr. Buchanan, saying, "The media is already starting to Perotize him -- picking on little things and finding quotes they can kind of hang on him and spin in a negative way."
Besides legions of supporters, qualifying for the nomination will require a lot of money and manpower. To be listed on the Reform ballot, a candidate must have made what the party considers significant progress toward qualifying for the general-election ballot in the states where the party does not have a slot. That can be as easy as paying a filing fee, or as complex as gathering 37,380 signatures in Texas.
Party officials said the process would probably require 600,000 signatures and, without volunteers, would cost about $6 million.

HEADLINE: Stolen Uranium Intercepted By Georgia in the Caucasus

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 24

 BODY:
A cache of stolen uranium was intercepted by Georgian officials this week, underscoring the continuing danger of nuclear theft in the former Soviet Union.
Georgian officials said they confiscated a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of uranium-235 on Monday night just miles from the Georgian-Turkish border. 
 Experts said that the nuclear material seemed to be low-enriched uranium and that the smugglers had not acquired nearly enough to help anyone make a bomb.
Low-enriched uranium is far less of a worry than highly enriched uranium, which can be used to make nuclear bombs. But low-enriched uranium can be processed to make a smaller quantity of high-enriched uranium.
The episode indicates that trafficking in nuclear materials remains a major worry. It also suggests that there has been a breakdown in controls at a nuclear power plant or fuel-fabrication factory, probably in Russia or Ukraine. Georgian scientists insist that the nuclear material did not originate in their country and that Georgia was simply being used as a transit point.
"The good news is that the Georgian authorities were paying attention to the problem of nuclear smuggling and did something about it," an American official said. "The bad news is the uranium found its way into the black market. It is important to keep this material locked up."
Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, there has been enormous concern about nuclear theft but relatively few documented cases of diversions of nuclear materials.
One of the most significant incidents occurred in Prague in 1994, when the authorities there confiscated 2.7 kilograms of highly enriched uranium, which is believed to have originated in Russia.
While there have been no major smuggling cases in recent years, Western officials have been concerned that the economic crisis in Russia and neighboring republics would lead to a new series of thefts.
The Georgian authorities said the case began with Valiko Chkmivadze, a 60-year-old Georgian. The authorities said today that they had kept a close watch on Mr. Chkmivadze because he was previously detained by Turkey on suspicion of trading in nuclear material.
The Georgian police followed him and two other Georgians as they drove to Batumi, near the Georgian-Turkish border on Monday. They were arrested with the uranium.
The uranium has been sent to a closed research reactor outside Tbilisi, the Georgian capital, for safekeeping. The Tbilisi reactor has a storage area equipped with a sophisticated alarm system that was installed by the United States several years ago.
Because of the concern about keeping nuclear material in the volatile Caucasus, highly enriched uranium and a cache of spent radioactive fuel was flown by United States Air Force planes to Britain in 1998.
The material confiscated in Batumi this week has not yet been analyzed. But it appears to be low-enriched uranium fuel pellets for a nuclear power plant, according to Georgian and American experts.
Zurab Salaridze, the deputy director of the Institute of Physics in Georgia, said in an interview that the cache consisted of 219 small dark-color tablets. The cylindrical tablets are one centimeter high and seven millimeters in diameter.
"A nuclear weapon cannot be made with low enriched uranium," said Matthew Bunn, a nuclear expert at Harvard University. "But a sufficient quantity of such material could greatly reduce the amount of work required to make weapons-grade uranium."
An American official added, "If Iran somehow managed to obtain 100 or 200 kilograms of lower-enriched uranium we would have something to worry about."
Still, even the confiscation of one kilogram has prompted concerns. One question is whether the Georgians have seized all of the stolen supply or whether other material is available on the black market or had seeped out of the former Soviet Union.
Another concern is the origin of the uranium and whether its appearance on the black market indicated that nuclear controls in the former Soviet Union were fraying.
"I would guess that it came from Ukraine or Russia," said William C. Potter, the director of the Center for Nonproliferation Studies in Monterey, Calif. "Low-enriched uraniuim fuel does not constitute a significant proliferation hazard. The significance of this case is that it indicates there is traffic in radioactive materials."

HEADLINE: Clinton Asked Ex-Aides' Help To Buy House

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
In the tense days and hours before and after they signed an agreement to buy a white house in Chappaqua, N.Y., for $1.7 million, President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton sought financial assistance from former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and two former White House chiefs of staff, according to several people with knowledge of the arrangement.
But Mr. Rubin, as well as the chiefs of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d and Erskine B. Bowles, declined to help the Clintons buy the first home they will own since 1983, several people with knowledge of the requests said today. They said that Mr. Bowles had originally committed to being the guarantor but declined on Sept. 1, just three days after the Clintons signed an agreement to buy the house under the condition their loan would be guaranteed. 
 The couple then quickly put out feelers to Mr. Rubin and Mr. McLarty before finally asking Terry McAuliffe, the prolific Democratic fund-raiser, who agreed to guarantee the Clintons' mortgage by depositing $1.35 million in the bank as collateral.
The McAuliffe guarantee was criticized by Republicans and public watchdog groups because Mr. McAuliffe is also raising millions for the Clintons' legal defense fund, the Clinton Presidential library to be built in Little Rock, Ark., and the First Lady's all-but-certain Senate campaign in New York State. Now, three people knowledgeable about the matter say, the Clintons are considering seeking a mortgage from a different lender who would not require collateral. That would eliminate Mr. McAuliffe's role.
It had not been known publicly that the Clintons, apparently through intermediaries, had sought help from both Mr. Rubin and Mr. McLarty. The Washington Post previously reported that Mr. Bowles had agreed, then refused to assist the Clintons before Mr. McAuliffe stepped in earlier this month to put up his own money to cover the full value of the Clintons' mortgage with Bankers Trust.
None of the three would comment on the matter and it was not clear why they all turned the Clintons down. Mr. McAuliffe also would not comment.
The Clintons, indebted by $5 million in legal bills, have slightly more than $1 million in assets, according to their most recent financial disclosure report, made public in May.
Leaders of several public watchdog groups said that the refusals by Mr. McLarty and Mr. Rubin demonstrate that the favor done by Mr. McAuliffe was even more important to the Clintons than anyone had first realized. "This is a President who has never had any compunction about going around with a tin cup," said Charles Lewis, the founder and executive director of the Center for Public Integrity. "Most people would have a very, very difficult time asking someone to write a check for $1.3 million."
The approaches to Mr. Clinton's friends were deliberately indirect. Mr. Rubin, for example, was never asked outright to help the Clintons finance the house. Instead, according to one person familiar with the delicate dance, he received a quiet inquiry about whether he would be receptive to a direct appeal. But he demurred, and the subject never came up again.
Mr. Rubin declined to discuss the matter, except to say, "I spent six and a half years in the Administration and I never discussed the President's business during that time and I'm going to stick to that policy now."
Mr. Rubin, the chief architect of the Clinton Administration's economic policy, resigned from the Cabinet in July. Before joining the Administration, he was co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking firm, and reported making $26.5 million in 1992. Several years ago, his net worth, mostly in family trusts, was estimated to be $100 million.
Mr. McLarty, a close friend of Mr. Clinton since they attended kindergarten together in Hope, Ark., declined through a spokesman to comment on the matter. Using Mr. McLarty's nickname, his assistant, Carl Lingenfelter, said, "Mack does not want to comment on any of his private conversations with the President or the First Lady." Mr. McLarty's net worth was recently estimated to be $107 million. Last year, he sold a 51 percent interest in his 19 auto dealerships in Arkansas to Asbury Automotive Group of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Bowles did not return several calls this week. A longtime confidant of Mr. Clinton, he is a general partner at the New York buyout firm of Forstmann Little & Company. In his 1997 financial disclosure report, Mr. Bowles estimated his family's net worth at $30 million to $60 million.
Two people close to the Clintons said today that the couple was now considering taking out a mortgage with another bank that will not require collateral. The Clintons intend to put down $350,000 as a deposit, or more than 20 percent of the cost. Jim Kennedy, a spokesman for the White House counsel's office, declined to comment.
The Clintons' unorthodox financing arrangement has drawn harsh criticism from several Republicans, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who, like the First Lady, is considering a bid for United States Senate next year. "A million-three is a lot of money; somebody putting it in the bank for you is quite unusual," Mr. Giuliani said last week on his radio show.
One person close to the First Family said that the Clintons, especially Mrs. Clinton, had been genuinely concerned that they might not qualify for a mortgage. In August, several mortgage lenders contacted by The New York Times said that despite the Clintons' enormous legal bills, the couple would have no problem qualifying for an unsecured mortgage because they would almost certainly earn millions of dollars from book contracts, speaking engagements and service on corporate boards.
The white-shingled, five-bedroom house in Chappaqua that the Clintons are buying had been shown to the public only three days by its owners, Dr. Jeffrey Weisberg and his wife, Cheryl. They then invited closed bids, which were opened at 3 P.M. on Sunday, Aug. 29. Not long afterward, the Clintons, who were at the time on vacation in the Hamptons, were informed that the Weisbergs were prepared to sell the house to them.
But of the eight bids submitted on the house, the Clintons had tied with another bidder for the highest price, $1.7 million, one person with knowledge of the deal said today. It was not until the following Wednesday, Sept. 1, that the Clintons learned that Mr. Bowles had decided not to back the loan. The Clintons then quickly tried to find someone else to back the mortgage. As they put out feelers to Mr. Rubin and Mr. McLarty, the Clintons worried that they might not find a guarantor and could lose the house.
"It weighed very heavily on Hillary," said one person close to the Clintons. "She was very worried that they were going to lose the house. She was distraught."
On Thursday, Sept. 2, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton, who were vacationing just outside Syracuse, asked Mr. McAuliffe personally for his help. Mr. McAuliffe and the President had played golf together that day. Mr. McAuliffe did not hesitate to help, this individual said.
"Terry would do anything for them," this person said. "He clearly knew there were consequences to helping them and that he would put himself in harm's way, but he was ready to take the heat."

HEADLINE: President? Why Not? Says a Man at the Top

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump was sitting in his office on the 26th floor of the Trump Tower the other afternoon, with Central Park stretching out 50 blocks behind him, and a desktop of newspaper clippings spilling out in front of him, all addressing Mr. Trump's latest venture: Presidential politics. And in case anyone finds the notion of President Trump unsettling, the real estate developer and casino owner was prepared with evidence to validate his potential candidacy.
There was, for one, the laudatory column that appeared on the op-ed page of The Washington Post by Richard Cohen. And there was, Mr. Trump related in the next breath, a poll conducted by The National Enquirer of 100 Americans (about one-tenth of the sample size of the standard-issue national poll) that found, as he put it, that the nation appears to be clamoring for this famous New Yorker to get into this race. 
 "Those are the real people," Mr. Trump declared of the Enquirer readers, earnestly laying his hands across his desk. Roger Stone, his paid consultant, who was sitting across the desk, offering Mr. Trump the occasional pointer during the 45-minute interview, added, "That is the Trump constituency."
It had to happen. In an era when, it seems, everyone seems to think that he or she can be President of the United States -- actors and wrestlers, billionaires and governors -- Mr. Trump is trying to determine whether there is a place in American political life for a rogue: a developer, casino operator and proudly public womanizer. Characteristically, Mr. Trump, who at 53 has never run for office before, has decided to begin at the top, contemplating offering himself as the Reform Party's candidate for President.
"I build the best buildings, and I'm the biggest developer in New York by far," Mr. Trump observed, shrugging off a question about his own preparedness for office. "While that's real estate and this is politics, are they really so different?"
In truth, Mr. Trump's new adventure is shaping up as more than another high-profile chapter in the life of a man who was described by Howard Rubenstein, the warhorse New York public relations consultant and former Trump counselor, as "probably the most flamboyant promotion person I have met in my 45 years in the business."
Given his private fortune, personal bravado and name recognition, Mr. Trump might become the presumably witting tool by which a faction of the Reform Party prevents Patrick J. Buchanan, who is a Republican, from running as its Presidential candidate. If he succeeds in blocking Mr. Buchanan, it could be a welcome turn of events for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the leading candidate for the Republican nomination, who could do without the drain of conservative votes that a Buchanan candidacy would bring.
Beyond the convoluted internal politics of the Reform Party, Mr. Trump's emergence suggests the extent to which celebrity and money are transforming politics these days. Mr. Trump has never before displayed much interest in politics, and professional politicians have never expressed much interest in Mr. Trump, his checkbook excepted.
Mr. Trump, who hates the mandatory political practice of shaking hands (he described it as "barbaric" and unsanitary), recoiled at a question of whether he might visit New Hampshire and Iowa to measure whatever popular support he has. "I don't really think it is as necessary as people seem to think," he said.
Mr. Trump says that his ultimate decision -- which he says he will make within three months -- will be guided only by a determination of whether he can win, which in turn would mean a determination that the economy will be bad next year, so voters will be open to a third-party candidacy. And asked to present the basic rationale for a Trump candidacy -- why someone might vote for him -- Mr. Trump offered a response that seems certain to distinguish him from the rest of the field.
"There has been a lack of spirit in the country with respect to what's going on," Mr. Trump said, tapping his fingers on the desk and glancing at a wall lined with pictures of, well, you know. "Obviously. Things are starting to look a little bit queasy. People are worried about the 2000 phenomenon. The Y2K. And I don't know that I am. Because I don't think I am particularly. But you know, they think the computers are going to come out and gobble and destroy the world. I'm not a believer in that.
"I mean, some very bad things and some very good things can happen over the next year," he continued. "I really think whoever is the Reform Party candidate is, I've always felt that the Reform Party itself is a much more potent party in bad times than in good times."
Mr. Trump is a registered Republican, who describes himself, adopting the formula that has become so popular among Northeast Republicans, as moderate on social issues (he's for abortion rights) and conservative on fiscal issues (he supports big tax cuts, especially for the rich). Issues aside -- and this seems likely to be an issues-aside kind of candidacy -- Mr. Trump is presenting himself as a personality unlike what Americans have been accustomed to in the White House.
For example, Mr. Trump disapproves of President Clinton's behavior in the White House over the last four years, though he suggested that he was bothered less by what Mr. Clinton did than by whom he did it with. "It was his choice," Mr. Trump said. "It was Monica! I mean, terrible choice." Mr. Trump, who showed off fashion magazines displaying cover art of the latest in a line of models he has dated, suggested that if Mr. Clinton had confessed an improper relationship (Mr. Trump offered a more earthy phrase to get the idea across) with a supermodel, as opposed to a White House intern, "he would have been everybody's hero."
"I'm not making any justification for cheating on your wife," added Mr. Trump, whose own extracurricular marital activities have been a tabloid staple.
From there, Mr. Trump volunteered a confessional apparently intended to clear up any issues that might arise in a Trump candidacy.
"You know, my social life is a very active one," he said, with uncharacteristic understatement. "So I can truly say I never took a drug in my life. I never had a cup of coffee in my life. I never had a cigarette in my life. And I never had a drink in my life. I never had a glass of alcohol.
"When it comes to women -- I've been out with lots of beautiful women, O.K.?" he continued. "I guess we all have our Achilles' heel. There's nothing like -- I love women."
Whether Mr. Trump is serious about running for President is the matter of some debate. For one thing, he happens to have a book coming out in January, just about the time when he plans to announce his intentions. For another, Mr. Trump is a man who has a better command of self-promotion than, well, most politicians. Mr. Trump is very much enjoying the publicity he has received since associates of Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, who has become Ross Perot's rival in the Reform Party, suggested Mr. Trump as a possible alternative candidate to Mr. Buchanan, after Mr. Trump and Mr. Ventura met at a Wrestlemania event in Atlantic City.
Now, Mr. Trump said, he would move to the next phase of his pre-campaign campaign, which is to determine whether he could really win the Presidency. Mr. Trump said he plans "to sell myself," as he put it, describing what politicians more typically refer to as "campaigning."
"These guys have been politicking for a long time," he said. "Whereas, I've been building for a long time. I think over the next several months I'll make the determination as to whether getting out there and getting on the stump -- as you would say -- could give me enough votes to win."
Mr. Trump, whose net worth has been estimated at $1.5 billion, and who has never shown any hesitancy to spend money to advance his name or career, said he would spend whatever it took to finance his campaign. That said, it appeared that he may not have given much consideration to the nittier and grittier side of getting on the stump: The 16-hour days, the run of $50-a-night hotel rooms, the bad food, the repetitive questions by voters and reporters.
Whatever his final decision, Mr. Trump said he saw nothing wrong with trying to enter the profession at such an elevated level. "Well, I know what working your way up -- I mean, look," Mr. Trump responded, gesturing around at a windowed expanse of an office that, truthfully, makes the Oval Office seem a little ordinary. "I mean, if you look at Ronald Reagan, who I happen to think was a great President, look at where he came from."
Reminded that Mr. Reagan served as Governor of California after finishing his years in Hollywood, Mr. Trump settled back into his chair for a moment. "You know, I feel that I've been in politics all my life," he said. "I'm sure that lots of people will come out, and be very harsh, and unfairly harsh. But I have been very much an open book. I mean, one thing, people know who I am. While I haven't been public, I am public."

HEADLINE: One Last Explosion At Kazakh Test Site To Aid Arms Treaty

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: KURCHATOV, Kazakhstan

 BODY:
Here under the desolate Degelen Mountains in the wind-swept Central Asian steppes, the Soviet Union detonated more than 400 nuclear explosions during the cold war that helped it perfect the world's largest arsenal of nuclear weapons.
If all goes well, at noon on Saturday, Sept. 25, the earth is expected to reverberate once more with the seismic shock waves of an underground blast with the force of 100 tons of TNT. 
 But this time, the explosion in the next-to-last tunnel of an underground maze that once crisscrossed the world's largest nuclear test range will be conventional, not nuclear. And its goal is to insure that this site will be used for war no more. Scientists say the blast will also help them identify and measure secret underground nuclear tests conducted by, say, India, Pakistan and China or by rogue states.
"North Korea is full of tunnels," said a senior Pentagon official.
Since 1994, the United States and Kazakhstan have quietly collaborated on a series of ambitious projects worth more than $170 million, financed by Washington, to help the now independent Government of President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev carry out his pledge to forswear the nuclear, biological and chemical weapons that Kazakhstan inherited from the Soviet Union. But this security relationship, which American officials describe as the closest they have with any former Soviet republic, is now roiled by recent disclosures of the sale of more than 30 MIG-21 fighter jets to North Korea for $8 million.
While Kazakh officials lobby to dissuade Washington from imposing economic sanctions that would cost their country $75 million in annual foreign aid and jeopardize the close security ties, scientists here at the Semipalatinsk test range, roughly the size of Indiana, are struggling to stop impoverished Kazakh scavengers from stealing copper and other precious minerals from the radioactive tunnels. A large amount of irradiated copper was sold to China by a private Kazakh company three years ago, prompting a protest from Beijing, Kazakh officials said.
"We've told people in surrounding villages a hundred times how dangerous it is to touch this metal, but what can we do when people are hungry?" said Murat Akhmetov, director of the Institute of Radiation, Safety and Ecology in Kurchatov, the once secret nuclear city of 30,000 which has shrunk to one third its former size. "Scavenging irradiated copper is as self-defeating as selling MIG's to rogue states."
The extraordinary "calibration" experiment scheduled for Saturday is the second of three tests intended to accompany the closing and sealing of the last of 181 tunnels here at the Degelen Mountains, where the Soviet Union conducted hundreds of underground blasts after atmospheric testing was banned in 1963.
Hundreds of people have been involved in preparing for Omega 2, as the blast is known. In addition to implanting seismic monitors in a tunnel on the eastern side of the mountain range and its drift, Kazakh and American scientists painted rocks and joints inside the tunnels bright red, green, yellow and white.
Vladimir Kovalev, director of the Degelen Mountain complex, said the paint will enable scientists to assess how the blast shatters, moves and distributes the rocks.
"You are standing in one of only 15 'clean' tunnels where nuclear tests were not conducted," said Dr. Kovalev, as he walked carefully through a part of the tunnel that will soon become rubble.
More than five miles of copper-lined cable was laid to provide power to the electronic sensors and monitors buried deep inside the shafts. Sandbags were placed along the tunnel walls to protect the instruments from the blast's full force. Near the end of the tunnel, the scientists scooped out a huge cavity some 20 feet in diameter that now holds the explosives and the detonation charge. The test chamber's floor has been painted blood red.
Walking through these vast underground passageways, whose multi-colored coats of paint are illuminated by slightly iridescent lamps affixed to the rock walls, is like exploring a surreal mine shaft decorated by a mad finger painter. The air is dank and moldy. The railway track that carried equipment and construction materials deep inside the mountain is now covered with gravel and loose rock.
"It was tough for us at first to do this work," said Dr. Kovalev, who came to Kurchatov 30 years ago to build these channels of death. "It's not psychologically easy to destroy what you helped build."
But a week before the blast, Dr. Kovalev supervised the loading of 100 tons of chemical explosives into the test chamber. The instruments placed in 11 bore holes that were dug from or near the chamber into a lower tunnel, the drift, were re-checked. The video cameras situated just inside the tunnel portals were switched on to insure that they, too, functioned properly.
On "D-Day," or Detonation Day, police and army units sent to aid the hundreds of engineers, scientists, technicians and guards who prepared for this test will fan out through the site, insuring that the area immediately around the tunnel is clear of people except the scientists and security guards charged with detonating the explosives and monitoring the test from stationary and mobile control centers at designated control points.
For this test, as for the first one, called Omega 1, at another tunnel in August 1998, scientists from Kazakhstan's National Nuclear Center, their 20 American counterparts -- including participants from the United States nuclear test site at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in Nevada and from the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University -- as well as observers from Russia and France, will be on hand to help monitor or interpret test results.
Given the low labor costs here, American and Kazakh scientists agreed that conducting similar tests at the Nevada site would cost 10 times as much as the $2.3 million that these calibration tests are expected to cost.
Luke Kluchko, a Pentagon program manager for the test, wrote in an in-house Defense Department newsletter that the last Omega test produced high-quality seismic records as far as 3,700 miles away. Yuri Cherepnin, director general of the National Nuclear Center, where some 2,000 former Kazakh nuclear scientists and technicians now work on nonproliferation, said he expected seismic stations in the same range as those in the Omega test to be able to detect the Saturday blast.
The "calibration" experiment is rooted in a series of Kazakh-American agreements signed in 1994 to help Kazakhstan get rid of not only its weapons of mass destruction, but also the infrastructure that supported them. Since then, Kazakh and American officials have quietly removed more than a thousand nuclear weapons, closed the giant missile silos once occupied by SS-18 Mirved Soviet ICBM's, converted key biological weapons production centers, and spirited more than 1,300 pounds of highly enriched, weapons-grade uranium out of the country. Other major projects are under way or being planned.
"Kazakhstan has taken unprecedented steps to advance nonproliferation and become a model of arms control for Central Asia and other regions," said Vladimir S. Shkolnik, the Minister of Science, a Russian physicist and veteran of the old Soviet nuclear program here.
As part of that effort, Washington agreed in October 1995 to spend $20 million blowing up and sealing the 181 horizontal tunnels, each a mile and a half long on average, as well as numerous vertical bore holes, each 1,000 to 1,650 feet deep, that are situated on the Balapan test site, near the granite-filled Degelen Mountains, whose hard rock geology makes them perfect for underground weapons tests. So far, 179 tunnels have been blasted and sealed.
In closing the tunnels in which the Soviets conducted hundreds of tests, Washington sensed opportunity. So did the international agency created to monitor compliance with the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. Washington pledged an extra $1.2 million for the first two calibration experiments in the last remaining tunnels. The independent monitors of the test ban treaty, whose Vienna-based organization is affiliated with the United Nations, provided another $80,000 to see whether an international team of inspectors who are expected to arrive at test site nine days after the blast will be able to identify its precise location.
Don A. Linger, a deputy for technical programs at the Pentagon's Defense Threat Reduction Agency outside Washington, said the measurements from the tests would enable seismic stations throughout the world to "calibrate" their equipment and help scientists distinguish between a natural event, like an earthquake, and a bomb test.
The distinction is not always obvious, he added, noting that seismologists were divided, say, over what kind of nuclear test India conducted last year, as well as its strength.
Dr. Cherepnin said he hoped that the United States and other observers would eventually support research to measure contamination levels at this sprawling test range. Soil samples taken at different areas of the test range, he said, "show the existence of plutonium residues that exceed the acknowledged levels by 100 times." But Kazakhstan, he added, cannot afford to conduct such tests.
While the precise levels of contamination have not been measured, Kazakh scientists are painfully aware of some of the adverse health and environmental effects of some four decades of nuclear tests in the Semipalatinsk region, the first decade of which were conducted above ground.
According to a 1998 United Nations report, much of the test site is contaminated by cesium-137 and strontium-90. Local studies attribute several lethal and debilitating illnesses, including high rates of cancer, to radiation from the tests. Kazakhstan estimates that 1.2 million people in and around the test site received above normal doses of radiation.
But the United Nations team that visited here last year had difficulty distinguishing between adverse health effects produced by the tests, which was limited to underground explosions after 1963, and those stemming from the impoverishment of Kurchatov and other towns and villages in the Semipalatinsk area due to the end of nuclear testing in 1991.
Half the buildings in Kurchatov, named for the father of the Soviet atomic bomb, now stand abandoned or crumbling. The once elegant, tree-lined streets are filled with potholes and buckled pavement. For much of the harsh winter, there is neither reliable heat nor electricity.
Given this region's dependence on foreign assistance and technical cooperation with the West, Kazakh scientists here were particularly furious about recent disclosures that some senior Kazakh officials either approved or failed to stop the sale of 30-year-old Soviet jet fighters to North Korea.
"It is a freaky accident that does not reflect Government policy," said Dr. Shkolnik, the Science Minister, who noted that two senior officials had lost their jobs over the incident. "But it has undoubtedly hurt our country's image. I hope it will not jeopardize tests like these and the close cooperation that benefit both Kazakhstan and America."

HEADLINE: France Calls U.S. Callous For Allowing Iraq to Suffer

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France today accused the United States of insensitivity to the "human disaster" in Iraq caused by economic sanctions.
"The United States is insensitive to the human catastrophe under way in Iraq," Mr. Vedrine told reporters during a breakfast meeting. "Iraq is not just made up of Saddam Hussein himself," he said. "There are men, women, and children, a whole society which is being destroyed." 
 Mr. Vedrine, who is here for the General Assembly's annual debate, said that Iraq poses no threat now, but could again. He said a new monitoring system was needed so that President Hussein does not revive his programs to develop biological, chemical and nuclear weapons.
The United Nations has not had inspectors working in Iraq since last December, when they were pulled out before the United States and Britain launched punitive air strikes.
The Iraqi Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, speaking to the General Assembly today, insisted that Iraq had fulfilled its obligations and complained that a new British-Dutch draft resolution circulating among Security Council members would impose "new obligations" on Baghdad.
Mr. Sahaf did not identify the obligations. But he said that the Security Council, in the course of 40 sessions reviewing Iraq's performance, "failed not only in taking a decision to lift the comprehensive embargo, but to ease it by even 1 percent."
He also accused the United States of "doubling the sufferings of the people of Iraq" by refusing to end the sanctions. He referred to a recent survey by the United Nations Children's Fund that found that mortality rates had more than doubled among Iraqi infants and children under 5 years old since 1989, the year before the Security Council imposed the first sanctions.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said it was not the United Nations sanctions but Saddam Hussein who inflicted deprivation on ordinary Iraqis. "We are quite sensitive to their suffering," Mr. Rubin said. "That is why we instituted the oil-for-food program that has bought billions of dollars of food and medicine.
"But we're also sensitive to the dangers that could come from allowing Saddam Hussein and his mad military machine access to additional funds," Mr. Rubin continued, "and we hope that everyone is as sensitive as they should be to that danger. It is that danger that the U.N. sanctions are designed to contain."
The program allows Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil to pay for food, medicine and other necessities. He said that Iraq has sold about $5 billion worth of oil in the past three years, and charged that the United Nations had taken most of the proceeds to subsidize inspections and to compensate Kuwait.
The Security Council imposed the first sanctions on Iraq after its forces occupied Kuwait in August 1990. Subsequent resolutions made lifting of sanctions conditional upon Baghdad's compliance in destroying its weapons of mass destruction and not making more. President Hussein has refused to open Iraq to unrestricted inspections.
President Hussein has refused to cooperate unless the sanctions are lifted, a position that his Foreign Minister stuck to today. But Prime Minister Tariq Aziz was quoted today in Baghdad as taking a more conciliatory approach. According to Reuters, Mr. Aziz said that Iraq would consider accepting a "serious easing" of sanctions if a total repeal could not be achieved.
The United States insists that Iraq give inspectors unimpeded access before sanctions are suspended. But the draft resolution put forward by Britain and the Netherlands, and backed by the United States, reportedly envisions raising the cap on Iraqi oil exports and suspending sanctions on some imports for periods of a few months, under strict United Nations supervision.
France, Russia and China have generally balked at the resolution as too inflexible. But Mr. Vedrine seemed to be positioning France to bridge the gap between the United States and Britain on one side, and Russia and China on the other.
If the United States and Britain agreed on a joint position with France, Mr. Vedrine said, "the Russians and the Chinese will agree with us." The French Foreign Minister said that the prospect of ending sanctions could give Baghdad an incentive to cooperate with fresh teams of weapons inspectors.
The United States insists that sanctions cannot end until the inspectors certify that Iraq is rid of weapons of mass destruction. The French Foreign Minister said such proof could not be found. "You can check that there aren't any missiles anymore," he said, "but it is impossible to make sure that there isn't one little flask of biological or chemical product left."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about United Nations sanctions against Iraq misattributed the accusation that the United Nations has taken most of the money from Iraqi oil sales in the last three years and used it to subsidize arms inspections and to compensate Kuwait for Iraq's invasion of that country. The charge was made by Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, not by James P. Rubin, the spokesman for the United States State Department.
