HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
How Safe Are Thrill Rides?

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
LAST year, my husband and I took some grandchildren to watch a tiny circus set up on a baseball field in Maine. We particularly hoped to see the elephant put up the tent poles with her trunk. No such luck. A backhoe was used. The elephant's owner shouted to bystanders that the elephant could do the job better, but that animal-rights people usually arrived as she started, and by the time all the documents and veterinary certificates were inspected, the tent-pitching was behind schedule, and it was easier to use a machine.
True or not, the tale indicated that people had their eyes on the elephant in her daily work life giving rides and lumbering along in the parade. 
 That memory returned while I was researching amusement park and carnival safety in the light of the recent cluster of four roller coaster deaths. Whose eyes are on the carnival rides, and what powers do they have to protect the customers, especially young ones?
As it turns out, that one-ring circus, which performed twice and struck its tent, was inspected by the Maine Department of Public Safety when it came into the state, and the rides were checked after they were set up. But that show was also under the eye of the Federal Government because the rides traveled from state to state. Not so the big rides in Ocean City, N.J., Santa Clara, Calif., and Doswell, Va., that brought four deaths last month, or those involved in the two earlier reported deaths this year, in Coney Island, and in Arlington, Tex.
In 1981, Congress shifted jurisdiction over nonportable, or "fixed," rides -- roller coasters, whirling devices, water rides and the like -- to the individual states to inspect and regulate. At this time, legislatures in 42 states have established some oversight of amusement rides, according to the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission, and 8 states have none: Alabama, Kansas, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah and Vermont.
The state laws have some relationship to the importance of amusement parks to a state's economy. Florida, for example, home of Disney World, Universal Studios Escape, Busch Gardens, Sea World and Wet 'n Wild, has a law that exempts from inspection permanent facilities with 1,000 full-time employees that maintain an inspection staff approved by the state.
 
Strength of Laws Varies
Isadore Rommes, head of the Bureau of Fair Rides Inspections in the Florida Department of Agriculture, says his bureau inspects 120 to 125 smaller parks twice a year, as well as mobile rides. "We think we have the most stringent law in the United States," he said. Since 1987, there have been no recorded deaths on fixed rides in Florida but two on mobile rides and two on rides whose status was not known.
California has 72 permanent theme parks and 48 roller coasters, the most of any state. But although it has had 15 ride-related deaths in 25 years, its law has remained as it was in 1968, with mandatory inspections only for mobile rides and aerial tramways.
However, this year the legislature was still in session in August, when the four ride deaths occurred nationally, and on Aug. 25, when the Boomerang ride at Six Flags Marine World in Vallejo stuck, stranding 28 people above the ground in 100-degree heat for four hours.
The legislators had before them since January a bill presented by Tom Torlakson, a Democratic Assemblyman from Antioch, in the East Bay area, to end the exemption for permanent rides. It was Mr. Torlakson's second attempt with such a bill, and there had been three other efforts since 1979, when there was a rash of accidents. In the last week of the legislature, Mr. Torlakson's Assembly Bill 850 was approved. "It was unfortunate that we had such a mysterious rash of accidents," Mr. Torlakson said. "But they raised public awareness, and people began to ask why we were not regulating this area. The bill was poised for passage this time, but events clinched it." The Assembly confirmation vote was 66 to 6.
Gov. Gray Davis said he looked forward to signing a bill to enhance consumer safety. His signature will mean that beginning Jan. 1 all permanent amusement parks will be checked annually. Los Angeles County, which performs its own inspections, is not covered by this law.
The Federal agency's summary also shows that six states with regulations do not have Government employees conduct inspections, but assign this to insurance companies or other private organizations. These are Arizona, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Mexico, Tennessee and Texas.
The amusement park industry often describes its rides as less hazardous than the automobile trip the family may take to get to the park. Noting that there were 900 million rides taken in 1998, John Graff, president of the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions, said that the possibility of being injured seriously enough to be hospitalized was 1 in 25 million and the possibility of being killed was 1 in 450 million. It also compared 43 deaths listed by the Government Consumer Product Safety Commission since 1987 to the 141 people killed by air bags in cars since 1990.
 
43 Deaths Since 1987
Although it does not regulate most of the rides, the safety commission compiles data on ride-related deaths through death certificates, hospital records and news reports. The injury statistics are developed from the National Electronic Injury Surveillance System, which sorts through hospital emergency room data by codes. From Jan. 1, 1987, to June 30, 1999, the agency's list of 43 deaths linked to amusement rides -- deaths of employees are excluded -- included 21 children under 16.
The reports for 1998 and '99, the agency said, are still incomplete, but the agency said the largest group of deaths, 11 in the 1987-99 period, involved roller coasters. Whirling rides like the one at Coney Island were involved in 10 deaths, water rides in 4, trains in 3 and Ferris wheels in 2. The agency noted a trend toward increased injuries from 1994 to 1998, which may be a result only of an increase in the number of rides and riders, or may have additional causes.
In 1998, the agency estimated, there were 9,200 amusement-park injuries treated in emergency rooms: 2,100 involving mobile rides, 4,500 fixed rides and 2,600 where the type of ride was not known. The agency estimated that 0.8 percent of these injuries required a hospital stay, a very low rate since the overall hospitalization rate for all areas was about 4 percent.
 
Customer Behavior an Issue
Although the agency gathers and publishes amusement park injury and death figures, as it does for other sorts of products, it has no power to investigate or link injuries and deaths to four potential causes: consumer behavior, operator behavior, mechanical failure or design limitation. Ann Brown, chairwoman of the product safety commission, describes herself as frustrated. A number of officials in the industry, including a spokesman for the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions and a spokesman for the Six Flags theme park company, say that rider behavior -- "horseplay," one spokesman called it -- is at fault in more than 75 percent of the cases. "We don't really know if there is a pattern," Ms. Brown said. "The industry can say something, and they may be right and they may not be right. We need Federal oversight of amusement park rides. We need to do what we do in other areas. We need on-site surveys, so we can come up with recommendations."
Ms. Brown said her agency considered children a major concern. "When a product is investigated," she said, "we separate out the cases involving children under 5 and work on what needs to be done, and then at the next level and so on." In the cluster of four deaths last month, there were two children, one 8, who died with her mother in the roller coaster in New Jersey, and a disabled 12-year-old, who died on the Drop Zone, a ride at Paramount's Great America in California.
The amusement park trade organization has been fighting on several fronts to avoid injuries and to improve its reputation. Boyd F. Jensen, a lawyer who serves on the safety committee of the amusement park group, said his group was pressing states to adopt "patron safety laws" and that 15 jurisdictions had. "There are three causes of injuries," he said, "customer behavior, operator behavior and mechanical safety. These last two are heavily regulated but there aren't any laws that attempt to regulate the behavior of patrons. We are just trying to even the balance."
Mr. Jensen's model laws provide civil penalties for patrons who interfere with rides or do not comply with posted rules. "People need to know there will be a consequence if they cause accidents," he said.
 
Black Diamonds for Rides?
Joel L. Cliff, a spokesman for the amusement parks group, which has a convention in Atlanta in November, said that guidelines for safety signs were being worked on. One version adopts the three shapes and colors used in skiing because, the literature said, it is logical to have a uniform standard for all forms of recreation. A "mild thrill attraction" would have a round green sign, a blue square would indicate "moderate thrills" and a black diamond, "high thrills."
One version of a black diamond sign had this text: "High speeds with extremely unusual and stressful physical forces. This ride contains startling and unexpected thrills appropriate only for the most healthy and physically able riders."
The Consumer Product Safety Commission's directory of state amusement ride safety officials can be read on the commission's Web site at www.cpsc.gov. Or a copy of the information for a particular state may be obtained by sending a request and a stamped self-addressed envelope to the commission, whose address is simply Washington, D.C. 20207.

CITY: SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA, CA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: In the Region /Long Island;
Luxury Rentals for Those Who Don't Want to Own

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: FARMINGVILLE

 BODY:
TAKING advantage of the strong housing market, Terence and Virginia Ciccone sold their four-bedroom Cape Cod in Lindenhurst last March for $170,000 just a day after listing it for sale.
Now they are spending $1,775 a month on rent, not counting utilities, for a three-bedroom, three-bath apartment in a new project here called Fairfield Hills, happy to leave all the headaches of homeownership to someone else. 
 "We'd been talking about selling the house for years, but we could never really decide where we wanted to go," said Mr. Ciccone, who runs a truck-repair shop. "So we decided to rent to see what it was like. This way, you take a year-to-year lease and if you want to stay a year, you can, and if you want to stay 10 years you can, but you can get up and go any time your lease is up."
Mrs. Ciccone is a graphic artist and the couple have two children, Terence Jr., 21, and Joseph, 18.
Families like the Ciccones are stoking demand for a relatively new type of housing on Long Island -- apartments that command high rents and are attractive enough to compete with new for-sale housing by offering spacious layouts, private garages in some cases, and the pool, clubhouse and other amenities usually found in condominium developments.
The market is attracting a broad spectrum of customers whose preference is renting, but who want a product that offers more than the traditional garden apartments that have been standard in most of Long Island, especially in Suffolk. They include older couples who have sold a house and no longer want to deal with even a leaky faucet as well as professionals who want the flexibility of relocating any time they choose.
"This feels like a house, but gives me flexibility -- and I don't have to mow the grass or clean the pool," said Donald Frost, a 51-year-old self-employed interior designer who, with his wife, Maureen, rented a two-bedroom and den apartment at Fairfield Hills. With a washer and dryer it costs them $1,860 monthly.
Fairfield Hills, one of several such communities under construction in Suffolk, began leasing in March. All but 19 of its 169 apartments have been preleased or rented, said Mark I. Broxmeyer, one of the principals of Fairfield Properties of Commack, which is developing the project on 25 acres near the Bald Hill Cultural Center. Those still not spoken for won't be ready before January, he added.
"We can't build them fast enough," he said.
His three partners are his brother, Gary, his son, Michael A., and David Schachne. "What we have provided here is the comfort of a home without the obligations of homeownership," said Gary Broxmeyer.
Fairfield Hills is a $19-million project. When completed it will have a gatehouse and a 7,000-square-foot clubhouse, with a business center, a fitness center and a library among other features. There will be a pool, a playground and a sports court for tennis, volleyball and basketball.
Renters can choose from nine different layouts, providing variations with eat-in kitchens, loft areas overlooking the living room, fireplaces and private garages. All have central air-conditioning and alarm systems. Vaulted ceilings, ceramic floors in bathrooms and kitchens and tiled baths are also standard.
Ranch-style apartments range in size from a 1,207-square-foot one-bedroom and den with a monthly rent of $1,485 to a three-bedroom, 1,575-square-foot unit with an attached garage, which rents for $1,835 monthly. The apartments, which have either a patio or a deck, are on the lower and upper floors of two-story town houses.
Individual town houses are also available. The smallest, a one-bedroom, den and loft with a private garage and 1,343 square feet of living area, is available for $1,625 monthly and the largest, a 1,434-square-foot two-bedroom and den with no garage is available for $1,565 monthly. Those without private garages have two allocated parking spaces. Detached garages are available for $85 a month extra.
APPLIANCES include stoves, refrigerators, dishwashers and microwave ovens. Hookups are provided for washers and dryers, which can be rented separately for an extra $35 a month.
Each apartment has a private front entrance behind a private landscaped front yard, which is separated from the street by a low brick wall. "That courtyard gives a sense of entranceway to each individual units and provides a sense of elegance," said Thomas J. Pirkl of Bay Shore, the architect for the project.
Exteriors are partly brick, and the design elements include varied roof lines, Palladian windows and nine-foot-wide sliding glass doors that lead to patios and balconies instead of the more standard six-foot doors.
Fairfield Properties has started construction on a similar project in Setauket, where leasing will start in December for its 64 units; Another, with 66 apartments to be built in Port Jefferson Village, will start start leasing in March. The company has also applied for a rezoning on a 31.5-acre parcel adjoining the Farmingville project on which it hopes to build 204 apartments.
The profile of renters is changing, Gary Broxmeyer said. Residents of Fairfield Hills typically have annual family incomes of $90,000 to $100,000, he said.
The relative affluence of a new generation of renters willing to pay for space and better design, along with the fact that many are former homeowners, is leading to a change in attitude. Even in communities where homeownership has always been sacrosanct rentals are now becoming more acceptable because of the kind of rental housing being built, said Gary Broxmyer. This is also the nationwide trend, said Michael D. Giardiano, a partner in the Martin Architectural Group in Philadelphia, which is the architect of another luxury rental, the 165-unit Stonegate apartment complex under construction on 79 acres in Middle Island.
"The whole pace of our society is picking up and people are moving much more fluidly," he said. "People are making a nice living and they are being single until later in life and they want to live in a nice community. And the people who are maturing and want to get out of a big house are used to a feel of luxury and space and don't want to move into cramped quarters."
The Stonegate apartments on average are smaller than those at Fairfield Hills, with one-bedroom units ranging in size from 747 square feet to 830 square feet and two-bedroom apartments 1,035 square feet to 1,118 square feet; three-bedroom units are 1,369 square feet. All have either a deck or a patio. Monthly rents start at $1,075 and go to $1,495, not including heat and utilities.
Other than size of units, Stonegate, which is being developed by Wilder Balter Partners of Elmsford, N.Y., at a cost of $17.5 million, takes the same approach as the Fairfield Hills project by providing features normally found only in condominium projects. Each unit has a private outside entrance and the design incorporates a lot of window glass.
Of the 165 apartments, 45 have attached garages, which can be rented for an extra $90 a month. Amenities include a clubhouse with a business center, a library, an exercise room and a party room. There is a pool along with two tennis courts. All but six of the apartments have been leased since renting began in January.
"A lot of people today no longer take the approach of, 'I have to own a house, I want to go out and mow the lawn,' " said Robert H. Wilder Jr., one of the development partners. "People today often work more than a 40-hour week and value their time more and want to do different things. They are what we call the renter of choice. They can afford to own, but they elect to rent."
The higher rents people are now willing to pay allow projects of this type to make economic sense, said Ross C. Cassata of Babylon, who along with a partner, Glenn D. Feldman of Deer Park, is building a 402-unit rental project costing $30 million on 45 acres in Holtsville. Of the 130 units at Victorian Gardens that are completed, 125 are rented, Mr. Cassata said. Leasing began in March. A second phase of 150 units is under construction.
One-bedroom units at Victorian Gardens are 1,000 square feet in size and rent monthly for $1,250, and the 1,200-square-foot two bedrooms rent for $1,425. Rentals include heat and washers and dryers. The 45-acre complex includes a 5,000-square-foot clubhouse, a pool, two tennis and basketball courts and a three-acre lake.
"Right now, the buzz out there is luxury rental housing with all the amenities," Mr. Cassata said.

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
'Living Large' in the State's New 'Wealth Belt'

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FOR some time, planners and developers have known that, with the southward migration of employment centers and home buyers, much of the state's growth has in recent years settled in its midsection.
Now two Rutgers University professors have collected the statistics to show that the state's growth has shifted to what they call "the emerging wealth belt" at its core, and away from its northern sector. 
 In terms of property values, population jobs and personal income, they say, the wealth belt -- made up of Hunterdon, Morris, Middlesex, Mercer and Somerset Counties -- has supplanted the mature northern counties of Bergen, Essex, Passaic, Hudson and Union Counties as the most prosperous. That assertion is in "The Emerging Wealth Belt: New Jersey's New Millennium Geography," a report by James W. Hughes and Joseph J. Seneca.
Dr. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Policy and Planning at Rutgers, said this shift is different from earlier ones because "the state's transition from a service- to a technology-age economy converged with the maturing of the baby boom generation, causing both an economic and demographic shift farther and farther away from the urban areas."
It also reflects a phenomenon the authors call "living large in New Jersey," which provided the wealth belt with its clearest sign of prosperity -- large and expensive homes for well-off baby boomers who want to live where they now work.
That trend is benefiting the market for high-end homes, said John G. Udell, president of Weichert New Homes and Land, a land broker and marketer in Morris Plains. Most of these homes, he added, are going up in the central part of the state, notably in Somerset and Morris Counties, where land is more available than in the northern counties.
Lynette Hamara, district manager in the new homes division of Coldwell Banker, added that purchasers of the high-end home projects in the district she manages, which includes Somerset, Hunterdon and Warren Counties, are generally trade-up baby boomers who work in the area. "And there are a lot of them out there," she said.
But the emergence of the wealth belt is both good news and bad news, said Dr. Hughes. "It reflects both a vigorous economy and an increase in sprawl and congestion."
The employment gains that resulted from that strong economy, the report said, settled in the six central counties. Those counties experienced explosive office growth, driven by the financial-services industry, in the 1980's, when 80 percent of the state's office inventory of 110 million square feet was built, much of it along highway corridors in the wealth belt, such as Route 1 and Interstates 80 and 287.
IN the 1990's, computer-related, genetic-engineering and new-media companies moved into that ready supply of office space. According to the report, from 1970 to 1997 the number of jobs in the state grew from 3.1 million to 3.8 million. In that time the wealth belt's share of the total number of jobs increased to 35 percent from 25 percent, while the northern counties' share dropped to 40 percent from 53 percent.
At the same time the state's population grew by nearly one million to 8 million, with the wealth belt capturing half of that growth, pushing its share of the state's total population to 31 percent from 27 percent. In comparison, the northern counties' share fell to 38 percent from 48 percent.
Those gains, the report said, spurred the demand for housing from maturing baby boomers, many of whom work for the technology companies. And with most of those buyers at their peak earning and family rearing years, "their ability to buy ever-larger single-family homes is at unprecedented levels," the report said.
In the 1990's, more than 85 percent of the building permits issued in the state have been for single family homes, representing a record share of the market, the report said.
In 1998 the average size of a new home nationally and in New Jersey was nearly 2,300 square feet. In the large-lot subdivisions of the state's central counties the size of a typical home is easily 3,600 square feet, and goes to 5,000 square feet or more.
According to state figures the average price of a new house in New Jersey is about $251,000, up from $227,500 last year. For homes in the luxury category, many of them concentrated in the wealth belt, prices start at $500,000 industry professionals said.
Dr. Hughes pointed out that while large, high-end homes in the wealth belt were proliferating, established towns like Short Hills in Essex County and Alpine in Bergen County, in the northern sector, continue to snag their share. Because land in the latter communities is scarce the trend is to raze small existing homes and replace them with larger more expensive ones.
Dr. Hughes said, and real estate professionals agree, that the demand for new homes has not been dampened. Among the reasons, he said, are that most baby boomers are still raising families and the state is in its 102d month of recovery. One effect of such factors is an increase in the construction of large, high-end homes; over the near term, Dr. Hughes said, "we'll see the same type of housing being built."
In Holmdel in Monmouth County, for example, Pinnacle Communities of Millburn, which builds high-end single-family homes, has started work on a 35-home subdivision called the Gables. The homes, each on a two-acre lot, are spread over 120 wooded acres on Laurel Avenue, within a mile of Route 35 and the Garden State Parkway.
"Holmdel is a major growth community and our audience is people who live and work in town," said Brian Stolar, Pinnacle's president. "We're still selling to baby boomers, as we have for the last five years, only now they want a bigger house that works for their busy lifestyle."
Base prices for the homes, with 4,500 to 7,500 square feet, are $750,000 to $1.2 million and so far contracts have been signed for 10 homes, Mr. Stolar said. He said the more than 500 homes his company has under way or will begin in the next 18 months are evenly distributed between the central part of the state and the northern counties.
Sterling Properties of Livingston, however, has concentrated its focus for high-end housing on Morris and Somerset Counties and looks for locations close to corporate hubs, said Joseph Forgione, a Sterling principal. "Our buyers," he added, "absolutely are baby boomers who live and work in the area and want to trade up."
At Oakview, a 14-home enclave Sterling recently completed in Hanover Township in Morris County, Mr. Forgione said four of the buyers work for Lucent Technologies and AT&T, whose headquarters are nearby. He said the homes, each with 3,500 square feet on average and set on minimum 1.5-acre lots, sold in the $600,000 range.
Mr. Forgione said his company expects a similar response to Chestnut Ridge, a 49-home project in Bernardsville in Somerset County. The 65-acre project, on Pill Hill Road, is about five miles from both Parsippany and Bridgewater, two office hubs. Prices for the homes, with 3,000 to more than 4,000 square feet, start at $500,000.
Wayne Patterson, a senior vice president at Toll Brothers, of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., a national builder of high-end homes active in New Jersey, said that of the 620 houses Toll will build in the state this year, half are in Somerset County. "The availability of land for the homes we build is in the wealth belt," he added.
Its latest project is Montgomery Green in Montgomery Township in Somerset County, with 53 homes, each with 3,000 to 5,300 square feet and set on acre lots. They are spread over an 80-acre tract along Green Avenue, not far from Route 202, which is home to many pharmaceutical firms, Mr. Patterson said. Base prices start at $534,975, he said, adding that "typically our buyers are 41-year-old trade-up buyers."
Dr. Hughes said the growth pressures were likely to continue in the wealth belt, but the sprawl and congestion problems raised the question of whether it was "at the limit of space and population."
John Udell, of Weichert, added that the tear-down, build-up trend is beginning in certain parts of Morris and Somerset Counties.
Other factors affecting the wealth belt, added Dr. Hughes, are state antisprawl initiatives. He was referring to the state's intent to buy 1 million acres of open space, which will make it more difficult to develop in the suburbs, and its Development and Redevelopment Plan, which is aimed at channeling growth back to cities and towns.
But, he said, demographic changes and building for baby boomers as they become empty nesters and make new housing and location choices may well determine the next housing and growth pattern. "That future hasn't been invented yet," he said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property /Stamford, Conn.;
A Pioneer Business Park That Confounded Critics

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
HIGH RIDGE PARK, the iconic 32-year-old office campus in Stamford's leafy northern reaches that was a pioneer in accommodating the 70's flight of corporations to the suburbs, is up for sale. While an aggressive but brief marketing effort has come to a halt, the six-building center is still on the market.
 "It's up in the air," said Robert N. Rich, 71, president of the F. D. Rich Company, developer of the office park and city-designated urban renewal developer of downtown Stamford in the 60's and 70's. "We got some bids, but no offers that prompted a sale. We are not actively pursuing it." 
 Rockwood Realty Associates of Manhattan retains its status as broker.
Hidden from view just off High Ridge Road and Exit 34 of the Merritt Parkway, the six-building complex with a total of 500,000 square feet is valued at $100 million by local brokers and by the partners who have owned it since the first building went up in 1967.
Mr. Rich, his brother, Frank D. Rich Jr., and his son Thomas L. Rich and their families are the managing partners, with 31 percent ownership; the Hoffman Brothers and the Calman Ginsberg families of Stamford and New York, respectively, each own 31 percent and Ruth Miller, widow of Sam Miller, the real estate broker who sold the 40-acre site to the Riches in 1965 for $450,000, has 7 percent.
"We share the same investment goals as the Riches," said Steven Hoffman, a partner and third generation head of his family's real estate firm. "We are rarely sellers. But every piece of property has its price. At a price, we would sell the park, but we operate day to day as if we were going to own it forever."
The office park's futuristic, sculptural white buildings are set amid luxurious landscaping along a winding road. A large circular pond punctuates the center of the property. The late Victor Bisharat, a Jordanian educated at the American University in Lebanon and the University of California at Berkley, was the architect.
From opening day to completion seven years later the buildings, each one markedly different from the others, were, according to Mr. Rich, "loved by the public and universally disapproved of by architectural critics." In newspaper reports the low, round General Time building took the brunt of the quips, which likened it to a hamburger or a space ship.
Nevertheless, leading companies committed to 20-year leases at annual rents of $5.75 a square foot for the first few tenants. The first two were CBS Laboratories and General Time, followed by Continental Oil, Champion International, Texas-Gulf (later Elf-Aquitane), General Signal, Xerox, Citizen's Utilities and the American Thread Company, among others. All set up headquarters in the park. Today, rents range from the $20's to more than $30 a square foot.
Early on, architectural criticism was not the only unkind cut. Jon Smith, Stamford's planning director from 1950 to 1993, recalls the lawsuits. "Site plans went all the way to the State Supreme Court, twice," he said. The neighbors appealed the Planning Board and Zoning Board approvals of the park for permitting it in a residential neighborhood. But the property had been rezoned by a previous owner as a "design commercial" district, allowing for campus development in residential areas, and the court upheld the boards, said Mr. Smith.
High Ridge Park was the Riches' first major project as developers after almost half a century as a construction company founded by F. D. Rich, Sr., a stonemason from Italy. Now, it is their last major holding.
All that remains of an empire of office buildings, hotels, and apartments stretching from Connecticut to the Caribbean is their part-interest in High Ridge Park, the Avon movie theater in Stamford and an office building in Puerto Rico. The rest was lost in the real estate recession of the late 80's and early 90's, except for a half-interest in the Town Center mall, which they sold to Allegis Realty Investors in Hartford last October.
With the sale of the park on hold, Mr. Rich's son, Thomas L., senior vice president of the F. D. Rich Company and president of Thomas L. Rich Enterprises, said that refinancing its mortgage was being considered. "Rates are lower and could generate cash for the partners," he said. "We are in the real estate business to make money."
The location of the business park -- about three-and-a-half miles north of the business center -- was originally expected to make it difficult to attract tenants. But occupancy rates have held steady in good times and bad at over 90 percent and a current spike in vacancies is shrugged off by the owners as temporary.
AT present, the 74,000-square-foot Building No. 1 will be available at the end of the year if Priceline, an Internet hotel, car, mortgage and airline ticket-pricing service, does not renew its lease. A total of 44,000 square feet are available on a sublease from Cadbury Beverages in its 160,000-square-foot headquarters Building No. 6 and 7,000 square feet will be ready for occupancy in Building No. 2, the "hamburger" building, after renovations are completed early next year.
"In general," said Edward Tonnessen, a broker with the Stamford office of Albert B. Ashforth, a real estate brokerage, "the park needs overall updating. There are challenges in dated lobbies, elevators, and mechanical systems. It's still a very sought-after location next to the Merritt, and second only to downtown." Mr. Tonnensen is leasing agent for Cadbury.
Commonplace as office parks are today, in the 60's there was only one in New York City's northern suburbs comparable to High Ridge Park. Built on Route 1 in western Greenwich, outside the business district, the 450,000-square-foot Greenwich Office Park is still going strong.
Constructed between 1969 and 1978 on 23 acres, its nine buildings were the headquarters of Anaconda Wire and Cable, Phelps Dodge, Continental Can, Clarion Marketing and United Parcel Service, among others.
"Greenwich Office Park is more understated -- uniform," said Steven J. Schacter, second generation head of Fawn Associates, Greenwich developers and managers of the park and several other complexes. "The low brick buildings were designed to blend in with the existing landscape of rolling hills, lots of trees, and two natural ponds."
The park was sold in May 1997 to the Oregon Pension Fund after nine months on the market. "The seven partners," said Mr. Schacter, "were all in their 70s, and it was time to disentangle themselves." It was sold fully occupied with 60 diverse tenants. In the 70's nine corporate tenants filled the entire complex.
Sy Schwartz, a retired founder of Fawn Associates, said, "my park was a longshot, but the land was cheap enough and we succeeded by moving very slowly." Independently of each other, he and Robert Rich sensed movement in the office market of the 60's, sought partners and began building on speculation.
Mr. Rich said he was listening when "Pepsico, Olin, American Can and the New York Stock Exchange were talking about leaving the city." By the mid-80's, at the height of the real estate boom, the F. D. Rich Company had built, owned and managed more than 4.4 million square feet, or about one-third of the first class commercial space then in Stamford.
The properties included High Ridge Park, the company's signature Landmark Building, the Stamford Town Center mall, the GTE building, the Marriott Hotel, 4, 6, 8 and 10 Stamford Forum, 300 Atlantic Street and 177 Broad Street.
Several of those buildings were positioned to form a glittering, mile-long wall of glass along the north side of Interstate 95. Again, the Riches were criticized, this time for the fortress architecture that marked almost all of their projects. The public was dismayed by a pedestrian-hostile downtown where buildings could be entered only by car.
"The streets were never meant to be for pedestrians," said Mr. Rich. "GTE came here because they were bombed in New York. Crime was a problem in the city. That's why the buildings were designed to be impenetrable."
Over the years criticism has ebbed, and the Riches are accepted by a new generation of residents and inbound commuters. "Rich was a prime mover and he has been good for Stamford," said Arthur Collins Sr., head of Collins Enterprises in Greenwich, a major developer of high end waterfront projects. "The architecture of High Ridge Park is a bit diverse, but lots of companies want that individuality. The important thing is to rent the space, not satisfy architectural critics."
Charles T. Lee, a Stamford attorney who was chairman of the Urban Redevelopment Commission from 1984 to 1991, wonders whether High Ridge Park would have been built at all were it not for lawsuits against the city and the commission that halted downtown reconstruction for eight years.
While resident groups protested in court against the demolition of nine city blocks, and the displacement of 400 businesses and 110 families, the Riches turned their energies toward developing High Ridge Park.
In recalling reactions of residents to the later total alteration of downtown Stamford by the Riches, Mr. Lee said:
"I would get nightly phone calls from a former letter carrier who couldn't find the streets he used to walk. The people were reeling from future shock. But we now have a superb emerging city. We're not just some office complex out in a cornfield on the interstate."

LENGTH: 1488 words

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER

 BODY:

Best Bet
With three major exhibitions opening, art dominates the cultural scene this week. Today at the Nassau County Museum of Art off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor, "Rodin: Sculpture From the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Collection" begins a stay through Jan. 2, with 70 works ranging in size from 10 inches to 9 feet tall, including "The Age of Bronze," "The Thinker" and "The Kiss." The second-floor gallery is showing "Three Realist Sculptors: George Segal, Duane Hanson and John De Andrea." From Oct. 8 to Nov. 19, the museum will be open until 9 P.M. on Fridays with jazz and swing concerts (484-9337). 
 Also today, the Parrish Art Museum on Job's Lane in Southampton opens "Drawing Is Another Kind of Language: Recent American Drawings From a New York Private Collection." The collector is Werner H. Kramarsky, and his collection, seen in public for the first time, includes works by Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Brice Marden, Agnes Martin and Richard Serra. The show runs through Nov. 14 (283-2118).
On Saturday the Museums at Stony Brook on Route 25A turn the Art Museum over to "William Sidney Mount: Family and Friends," an exhibition that focuses on the human roots of his genre painting and seeks to identify his models. It runs through Jan. 9 (751-0066).
 
Another Roosevelt
In its first major conference of the new academic year, Hofstra University takes a look at "The Vision of Eleanor Roosevelt: World Citizen Ahead of Her Time." The three-day event, Thursday through Saturday, on the Hempstead campus features scholarly papers on her life and times; panel discussions focusing on her relationship with the news media and her contributions to human rights; personal reminiscences of those who knew her, among them her granddaughters Anne Eleanor Roosevelt and Nancy Roosevelt Ireland, and sessions with biographers like Blanche Wiesen Cook.
On Thursday, "Eleanor's Gift," a commissioned by New Heritage Music from the composer Chen Yi, will be performed as the centerpiece of a chamber music concert, and on Saturday the original cast members from the recent production at Ford's Theater in Washington will offer a concert version of "Eleanor: An American Love Story," with music by Thomas Tierney, lyrics by John Forster and book by Jonathan Bolt. Both performances are at 8 P.M. at the John Cranford Hays Theater. An exhibition, "Opportunities for Joyous Living: The Vision of Eleanor Roosevelt," runs through October at the Lowenfeld Exhibition Hall and the Filderman Gallery of the Axinn Library (463-5669).
 
Back Again
Four Island-based musical groups return to the stage today. The Wellwood Ensemble plays classical works and folk tunes at 2 P.M. at the Babylon Library on South Carll Avenue (669-1624); the American Chamber Ensemble, joined by Stanley Drucker, principal clarinetist for the New York Philharmonic, holds its annual "Music Party," featuring classical music and musical comedy, at 3 P.M. at the Axinn Library on Hofstra University's Hempstead campus (223-0454), and Ridotto, "Concerts With a Touch of Theater," offers "The Romantic Piano," with Alexander Peskanov tracing 19th-century piano music from Beethoven to Schumann, at 4 P.M. at Old First Church, Route 25A in Huntington (385-0373). Finally, the Brentano String Quartet plays music by Schubert and Mackey in a benefit concert for the Garden City Chamber Music Society at 3 P.M. at the Unitarian Universal Congregation on Stewart Avenue in Garden City (248-8855). On Saturday, performing "Baroque Jewels," the Long Island Baroque Ensemble has the spotlight all to itself in a concert at 8 P.M. at St. Andrew's Lutheran Church on New Mill Road in Smithtown. It will be repeated at 3 P.M. Sunday at Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay (724-7386).
 
Going It Alone
Solo singers take center stage this week. Megan Henry, a mezzo-
soprano who has appeared with the New York City Opera, performs music of Barber, Bellini, Copland and Purcell in a benefit for the Long Island Singers today at 3 P.M. at the Roesch home on Petite Place in Glen Cove (759-6105). Richard Adler, the composer and lyricist of "Damn Yankees" and "The Pajama Game", appears in a session of talk and songs, backed by a vocal duo and pianist, at 8 P.M. on Friday at the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center on Main Street
(288-1500). Kathleen Battle, one of the reigning divas of the day, gives her only New York-area recital, singing music of Donizetti, Faure, Handel and Mozart, on Saturday at 8 P.M. at Tilles Center on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville (299-3100).
 
Still More Fairs
Four more newcomers are in the offing this week. Today from 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., the Long Island Apple Festival, with games like bobbing for apples and relay races, open-hearth cooking, an apple pie bake-off, storytelling and traditional music, arrives at the Sherwood-Jayne House on Old Post Road in East Setauket, an 18th-century farmhouse with its original apple orchard (751-3730).
The weekend brings three events. Celebrate Huntington takes over Heckscher Park at 6 P.M. Friday and 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday and Sunday with entertainment, international food, a horse show, antique cars and a farmers' market (351-1910). Farther east, Wildwood State Park in Wading River holds its Fall Festival with a pie-eating contest, tractor rides, entertainment, American Indian dancing, a craft fair, a petting zoo and pony rides Saturday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. (669-1000, extension 247). Finally, in Yaphank, the Suffolk County Farm and Education Center holds its Pumpkin Fest '99, with games, rides, a mime circus, a 15-acre corn maze, hayrides and pumpkin picking from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and Sunday (727-7850).
 
Two Tours
Touring, by foot or bike, figure in two offbeat events. Today, via Long Island Traditions, those who prefer to travel by shank's mare may visit the cottages at West Meadow Beach in the Setauket-Stony Brook Harbor. Nancy Solomon, a folklorist, will lead two-hour tours, starting at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M., of these bungalows built in the early 1920's by local residents anxious to escape flu epidemics along the East Coast. Unless they get preservation status in time, they will be razed in 2004 (767-8803).
Next Sunday, a Discover Long Island Bike Tour leaves the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale at 8 A.M., wending its way, traffic-free, down Meadowbrook Parkway to Point Lookout Beach and back again to the Coliseum for a festival, complete with stunt biking, entertainment and food concessions. Participants may ride for 15, 25 or 50 miles. Proceeds will go to local charities, including the Education and Assistance Corporation (735-3100).

HEADLINE: Habitats/Downtown Manhattan;
Moving in With the Boss And Renovating a Co-op

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
FELICITAS OEFELEIN, a 30-year-old immigrant from Germany who works as an interior designer, has moved five times in seven years. Her boss, she says, jokes that when it's time to paint, it's time to move. And clearly, she agrees.
For the last month, she has been renovating a one-bedroom co-op at 3 Hanover Square, a 205-unit building near Wall Street constructed in 1928 as the Cotton Exchange. She paid $135,000 for the 700-square-foot apartment, the same amount she got for her studio in Chelsea, which was half the size. In fact, impressed by her (relative) bargain, three of Ms. Oefelein's friends, including Frank Scala, a decorative painter who is her boyfriend, have decided to buy apartments in the building. 
 When Ms. Oefelein found the building, she wasn't really serious about moving. Just looking. While browsing through real estate listings on the Internet, however, she happened to see that an open house was planned for an apartment at 3 Hanover Square. "I didn't even know where it was," she says. She has always lived in the Village, or Chelsea.
But for fun, she decided to go downtown. And when the broker, Katherine Kane Vaccaro of Douglas Elliman, showed her renderings of a planned restoration of the neighborhood -- including outdoor cafes, cobblestone streets and new lighting -- she was entranced. "It reminded me of Europe," she says. So she asked Ms. Vaccaro to put her Chelsea studio on the market.
Almost immediately, she had a signed contract, and with that in hand was able to get a mortgage on the place at Hanover Square. But there was one problem. She wanted to gut it, and she would have to move out of her old place before the work even started. Fortunately, she and her boss, Laura Bohn, have a history together with renovations.
WHEN Ms. Bohn and her husband were moving a few years ago, they camped out with their dog and cat in Ms. Oefelein's studio for a few weeks, and Ms. Oefelein moved in with a friend. This time, they have more than returned the favor: Ms. Oefelein has been renovating for five weeks and living, the whole time, with the boss.
Every morning, before she goes to work, Ms. Oefelein, who is the general contractor on her renovation, heads down to Hanover Square, a few blocks from the Wall Street stop of the Nos. 2 and 3 trains, and meets with her crew. "It's like the United Nations," she says, with workers from many countries. "Every morning at 8 I'm here, with coffee and muffins, feeding my guys."
Most dramatically, she has transformed the space by tearing out a dropped ceiling, making the ceilings three feet higher. The moment the old ceiling came down was a scary one, she says, because it exposed a giant, no longer functioning, air-conditioning duct.
"The whole ceiling had holes like grenade holes," she says. "It was like something out of a James Bond movie." When the building was converted to apartments in 1984, she says, the developer obviously decided it was cheaper to crop the ceilings than remove all the duct work.
In the kitchen, she has cut a large opening to the living room and installed Ikea cabinets of aluminum and frosted glass, with stainless steel appliances and marble counters. The bathroom, too, is all new, with limestone floors and a subtle mosaic tile pattern around the bathtub. In the bedroom, Mr. Scala will redo the walls in Venetian plaster, which, she says, comes out looking "really smooth, like marble."
In the hallway, all her possessions are in boxes, neatly stacked and labeled: kitchen, dry food; shoes and humidifier; art supplies, handbags. Her furniture is living with another friend, she says, whose dog has made her mattress his own.
Ms. Vaccaro, who says she has sold more than 20 apartments in the building in the last two years, says studios now sell for about $100,000, one-bedrooms about $170,000, and two-bedrooms in the $350,000 range. "I've sold to a lot of traders who fall out of bed and go to work," she says.Apartments were available because rising prices made owners eager to sell, she said.
Not all the apartments need renovating, although many still have the lowered ceilings. For Ms. Oefelein, though, that is clearly part of the fun, although she also likes the economics of buying and building. Two years ago, she says, "I was paying $1,400 to rent a studio."
When she bought her place in Chelsea for $70,000, she spent $20,000 to renovate, getting some help from her father, a brewing engineer in Germany, in laying new floors. After her move, she says, her monthly housing costs were lowered by almost 50 percent.
"I saved it and invested in stocks," she says. In her new place, where the maintenance is $900 a month and renovating will cost about $40,000, her monthly costs will be $1,500, "before taxes," she says.
Ms. Oefelein, who moved to New York seven years ago to attend graduate school in design at Parsons, says she loves it here and plans to stay. Not surprisingly, for a woman who seems to deal deftly with any problems, she won a green card in a lottery, so immigration has posed no hurdles.
"My name is Felicitas," she explains. "That means the lucky one."

LENGTH: 1263 words

HEADLINE: In Fast Times, Who Has Time to Reflect?

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN 

 BODY:
THE brothers at Little Portion Friary in Mount Sinai offer the rare opportunity to be released from the demands of daily life, to relax and contemplate -- the chance, in effect, to lose time. And their guest house is usually full.
"It's my chance to get away, to take care of myself," said Susan Peverley, a librarian in Babylon who spends a few hours at the Friary almost every week. "I just make time," she said. 
 That's a statement, however, that much of the Long Island community of organized religions doesn't hear a lot. Many of the big churches say their membership is static or down, but worse, nobody seems to have time to attend services, or participate in activities, say ministers, priests and rabbis.
"Long Island is the land of the nominally committed," said David Benke, president of the Atlantic district of the Lutheran Church's Missouri Synod. "Everyone is on the roll somewhere, but on Sunday morning, they're doing something else."
It's not a crisis of belief On the larger cosmic issues, there's been little pot-stirring in America for the last three decades. Seven out of 10 Americans say they believe that something awaits when they have shuffled off the mortal coil; 5 out of 8 profess not even a smidgen of doubt about the existence of God. They even tell pollsters they are still showing up in church regularly.
Yet, when churches plan a fundraising event, they say they are hard pressed to find the volunteers to run it.
"If someone wants to have a street fair, they're likely to get more customers than ever," said Tom Goodhue, the executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches. "But it's harder to find someone to staff the booths."
"I don't know what happened to time, but something did," said Rosemary Sepanski, a financial planner and president of the Huntington League of Women Voters, one of the voluntary organizations that has felt the same kind of pinch for time as the churches. "In the mid 80's, we had 250 active members. Now we've got about 70."
What happened, then, to time? The clergy point to the way lives have become busier. So much competes for people's attention these days: longer hours at work, families with two earners, commuting, soccer games on Sunday mornings. That reality has set churches and synagogues on a search for previously unexplored time slots. Some hold communion services at 7 A.M. for commuters. The United Methodist Church of Bay Shore offers a midnight meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous every day of the week.
"What do you do with people that have to work on Sunday morning?" said the Rev. Betty Lines, pastor at the Bay Shore church. "Paul said you have to go where the people are. How can you do that when you're not amenable to people's schedules?"
Some churches and synagogues have sought alternative places, and even alternative media, for the message. Rabbi Jonathan Pearl of Congregation Beth Emeth in Hewlett holds walking services in a park. Redeemer Lutheran Church in Old Westbury features a "contemporary service" with pop music once a month.
Yet, while pastors of all faiths struggle to accommodate their increasingly distracted flocks, there's a nagging question about commitment. "If you want to do a Bible study, which the younger generation really wants, you must say it's a six-week study," said Ms. Lines. "They want to know there will be a new one starting soon, in case they couldn't come all the time in the first six weeks."
In fact, Long Islanders may have just as much time as ever. They just make different choices. "What if someone said I don't have time to go to the hairdresser, I have to be at services?" said Rabbi Pearl. "People would be shocked. It's usually the other way around. Of course we have the time, but we don't make the time to do it."
What has changed about time may be the way people evaluate it, say religious leaders. And what Long Islander isn't acutely aware of the connection between time and money, when so very much of it is needed to buy a house, to light a room, to pay a teacher's salary?
"There's a real tendency to recognize only those aspects of time that have a monetary value," said Msgr. Donald Beckman, pastor of Holy Name of Jesus Parish in Woodbury. "We judge, for example, whether the amount of time commuting is worth the amount of money we're making."
The coin of time has become, well, the coin. In the post-Marxist world of an ever-rising Dow and an ever-falling unemployment rate, everyone appears to be a convert to the civil religion of consumerism capitalism.
"People are going shopping rather than to Sunday school, and, to make ends meet, they take an extra job rather than go to worship services," said Mr. Goodhue of the Council of Churches. "The stock market has even invaded work time. For everyone at work and day trading, I think moments of introspection are pretty unlikely."
The American economy is a marvel, and everyone is a beneficiary. Right?
"People start thinking of their time as worth something, as money, and if you're not making money, you're getting behind," said Ms. Sepanski, the financial planner and League of Women Voters leader. "When I'm doing League work," she said, "I'm thinking I really should be doing my own work. "
Ah, there's the rub. Long Islanders may be so focused on their economic behavior that it has become the only thing they have time to do.
"We go through swings, from one extreme to the other, from liberal to conservative, from totally community oriented to the opposite," said Rabbi Pearl. "I hope we've seen the peak of 'it's-all-about-me.' "
In the hysteria of economic good fortune, Long Island's clergy see the signs of men and women searching to fill a void they still feel, and not necessarily in the traditional ways of churchgoing. The full guest house at the friary may be one such sign, the growth of Alcoholics Anonymous programs another.
"There's so much 12-step help around that if it's 2:14 on an afternoon and you want to go to a meeting, you can probably find one somewhere," said a Long Island member of Alcoholics Anonymous, who, heeding the group's rules, asked not to be identified.
Many big churches say that young parents have begun showing up at their doors in larger numbers, many looking for a welcoming congregation that's not the one in which they grew up. The Atlantic district of the Lutheran Church's Missouri Synod has seen its 30-year membership decline reversed for the last two years, said Mr. Benke.
"A lot of people felt mistreated by the tradition in which they grew up," said Mr. Goodhue, of the Council of Churches, "and they're on a quest, perhaps vague, for something different."
"The larger cultural phenomenon, the triumph of consumerism and materialism, has both captured whole nations and left a kind of emptiness," he said. The vicious cycle of consuming, working harder to make the money to support consumption -- "which leaves you too tired to go to the P.T.A., but not too tired to watch television," which then encourages more consumption -- has left many with an ache they cannot quite name, he added.
"I think people may be groping for that sense of community, of eternal value, of something beyond each of us," Rabbi Pearl said. "One of the things we forget to do is live our time. We're too busy trying to do."
"I find a lot of people have a vague sense that they need to get off the merry-go-round, perhaps even feel their lives would be richer if they could," said Monsignor Beckman. "But they don't know how to do it. They can't make the time to move away from time."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Replacing 2 Tenements on East 23d;
An Art Deco-Style Rental Residence

 BODY:
Two rundown brick tenements on 23d Street between Second and Third Avenues are being bulldozed to make way for a 22-story rental apartment house.
When completed in 14 months the $20-million building, at 215 East 23d Street, will contain 74 one- and two-bedroom units, with 580 to 825 square feet of space. Levine Builders of Douglaston, Queens, is developing the project with R & M Gershon, a Manhattan-based real estate investment group. 
 Last December the partners bought the two four-story buildings as well as the air rights over two adjacent low-rise structures, enabling them to increase the height of the new rental by six stories from the 16 stories, allowed under the zoning. That, in turn, not only gave the project enough units to make it economically feasible, but provided it with light and air to make the apartments more attractive, said Mr. Levine. Summit Bank, in Cranford, N.J., is providing 75 percent of the financing for the project; the rest is coming from the partners' own money.
Mr. Levine said location was also on the side of the project since it is near the established residential neighborhoods of Chelsea to the west, Gramercy Park to the south and Murray Hill to the north. "This is a niche area that is seeing new housing construction," he added. Monthly rents in the building, which is to have 24-hour doormen, are expected to be $40 a square foot, or $1,800 to $2,400.
The project, to be known as Art Deco Tower, is being designed with a tan and beige brick facade that will have such Art Deco-style architectural touches as ornamental metal trim and masonry details. Architects Design Group, of Manhattan is the architect for the building.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Taking 'Angels in America' to Storrs

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
EVEN though "Angels in America," by Tony Kushner, startled the theater world, winning the Pulitzer Prize even before it opened on Broadway in 1993, it was not meant for Broadway.
In truth, the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater was to have the play's New York premiere. But so hysterical was the buzz that preceded it, that producers and investors with deep pockets stepped in and, unlike "A Chorus Line," "Angels" was untimely ripped from its rightful birthplace by the lure of commercial success, which it did not have for all the hoopla. Opening first on Broadwaywas a morally and it turns out, even economically incorrect choice for "Angels." 
 It may be time for Connecticut theatergoers to discover "Angels in America, Part 1: Millennium Approaches," in a less showy way at the Connecticut Repertory Theater in Storrs from Oct. 7 through Oct. 17. It is not that the production staged by Leah C. Gardiner, a director in ascent, is to stint on production values.
It is simply that "Angels" encompasses both the intimate and the epic, and an emphasis on showiness, bravado and bluster -- the Broadway production was so emphasized, not to mention the hype and the street brouhaha -- throws it out of whack. As David Richards said in his review in The New York Times: "If you want the most out of Mr. Kushner's unfettered dramaturgy, it helps to think smaller, not bigger." And a 489-seat theater, the Harriet S. Jorgensen Theater on the University of Connecticut campus in Storrs, helps.
"Angels," which is subtitled "A Gay Fantasia On National Themes," takes place in 1985 as the AIDS plague was beginning to penetrate public consciousness, and it may be too forbidding for what has been called a conservative audience in Storrs.
The production is a test case and may determine whether Part II ("Perestroika") of Mr. Kushner's surreal stage piece mixing real characters (Ethel Rosenberg, Roy Cohn) with the fictitious, including an Orthodox rabbi, a drag queen and two New York couples in crisis (one Mormon and ostensibly heterosexual; the other, gay males: a WASP suffering from AIDS and his Jewish lover who leaves him).
Ms. Gardiner, saying that "Angels" is "a big risk and a smart move" for the theater, is interested in how the audience is going to deal with the play's graphic but not gratuitous scenes. "I opted not to pretend, or to keep secrets," she said in a telephone interview from her home in Middletown after a recent rehearsal. When two men kiss, for example, or there is a nude scene, it is possible for a director to soften the images or darken the stage as an offering of protection, one might say, but Ms. Gardiner said, "I feel it's all part of Tony's storytelling."
"Now that many people have been living with AIDS 10 years or more, it is still important to deal with the play's issues," Ms. Gardiner added. These include dysfunctional existences and relationships as well as denial, she said.
On an even bigger scale, Mr. Kushner is "pushing buttons," as Ms. Gardiner puts it. "Diversity, capitalism, the immigrant experience -- and the mental state of America, of which religion is a part," she added.
And she agreed that Mr. Kushner is taking a quantum leap to assimilation redefined. "Through it all, there is an element of hope," Ms. Gardiner said. Ms. Gardiner, 33, and married to a teacher of American history at Wesleyan University, comes to "Angels" with a preparation that is dazzlingly thorough and varied. In 1995, a year before she graduated from the Yale School of Drama, she was an assistant to George C. Wolfe, the Broadway director of "Angels" and head of the New York Shakespeare Festival.
The first show she worked on was "The Tempest," which moved from the Delacorte Theater in Central Park to Broadway. Then Ms. Gardiner served as associate director of Mr. Kushner's revised adaptation of the Talmudic fable "A Dybbuk," which was first seen at Hartford Stage Company. As an assistant director of the replacement cast of "Wit," Off Broadway, she "kicked in" as its director when Derek Anson Jones fell ill. The smashing reviews Judith Light received as replacement to Kathleen Chalfant (who played three roles in the original "Angels" ensemble), as hard an act to follow as one could imagine, is no small credit to Ms. Gardiner.
"Judith's courage and willingness and unending quest to grasp this thing called theater again, after television fame, to break through playing insularly, out of the close-up shot, and send the action to the back of the house, was amazing," Ms. Gardiner said.
The Connecticut Rep's "Angels" is employing two Equity actors; the rest in the cast of eight, except for one, are mostly graduate students playing multiple roles. "The energy, the essence of the work, the process, are what count here," Ms. Gardiner emphasized. "In New York all those other factors including pressure, money and reputation get in the way and there is less opportunity to have fun, they are so focused on the end product.
"Broadway is about being in the right place at the right time," Ms. Gardiner remarked, indirectly referring to the failure of Mr. Wolfe's production of the musical "On The Town" last season, on which she also worked. But regional theater, she added, is truer to the incomparable live experience.
"There is nothing like having people right there, responsively," she said. "That is so rich, and that is only theater."
But what about "Perestroika?"
"Whenever I'm asked," she said. "I feel incomplete."

HEADLINE: Buyers Showing Interest in Millstone Plants

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
FOR sale: used nuclear plant. Frequently could not be started. Numerous fines for safety violations, but should pass inspection. Serious inquiries only.
For most of the last five years,the three nuclear power plants at Northeast Utilities' Millstone complex in Waterford have been in trouble with Federal regulators and were shut down in 1997 and 1998. They were the reason Northeast went from a financially solid company to posting losses of almost $220 million in the last two years. But when the company announced this month it would sell the plants, instead of buyers steering clear of the troubled units, utility companies began to line up.
"If anybody's interested in selling, we're definitely interested in buying, and Millstone is one of the plants that interests us," said Kelle J. Barfield, a spokeswoman for the Entergy Corporation, a New Orleans-based utility company. 
 "When the auction occurs, we will be there," echoed J. William Jones, a spokesman for the Peco Energy Company, the Philadelphia-based company that has teamed up with British Energy P.L.C. to form the Amergen Energy Company and has already bought four reactors around the Northeast, including one of the Three Mile Island reactors.
Utility analysts said the state's pending deregulation of the electric industry, and a strong market for energy in the Northeast, mean there should be strong interest in the Millstone plants by companies seeking to establish a foothold in the region.
"I'm sure there will be a lot of buyers looking at Millstone, because it is a nice cluster of plants and will allow for some local economies of scale, and one of the plants is large and relatively new, which will make it even more attractive," said Danielle M. Seitz of UBS Securities in New York. "I expect at least three or four serious bidders will show up."
Barry M. Abramson, senior utilities analyst with PaineWebber in New York, said the sale would be good for Connecticut.
""It will likely mean that the plants will continue to operate," he said. That not only means they continue to generate taxes and jobs, but they will continue to be a large local source of electrical power.
"And there will be another benefit as well -- I don't think Northeast has regained the confidence of the public and elected officials," Mr. Abramson said. "Companies with a better operational history are going to be more confident they can transfer that record of success to Millstone, which should get the plants back to business as usual a little more quickly."
Analysts said the more money Northeast can get for the plants, the less that will be passed on to customers. Because the company built the plants as a regulated utility, it is allowed to recoup most of its construction costs from its customers in their electric bills.
Beryl Lyons, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Public Utility Control, said she didnot expect that Northeast Utilities would get as much for its nuclear plants as it did for the conventional power plants that went to auction in July. The gas, oil and hydroelectric plants Northeast operates brought almost six times their book value; by contrast, nuclear plants generally have been bringing only 10 cents on the dollar, and Northeast officials have said they expect the Millstone plants, carried for $1.8 billion on the company's books, will bring no more than $200 million -- leaving customers to pay the rest.
"I don't know that they'll get above book value for the nuclear plants, but we will make sure they get as much as they can," Ms. Lyons said. The department will set a minimum bid for the plants next year.
Guy R. Mazza, the Connecticut Consumer Counsel who represents consumer interests in issues before the D.P.U.C., said customers would have paid those costs no matter who owns them, and if a larger company can come in and run the plants more efficiently, Connecticut consumers will have a reliable source of inexpensive power.
"This will definitely help the development of a competitive electric market in the future," Mr. Mazza said.
Northeast said in its filing with the D.P.U.C. that it would also seek a guarantee that the new owner will not fire or lay off any of Millstone's 2,000 employees for the first year and offer $3,000 in retraining costs and job counseling to anyone let go in the six-month period after that.
Bruce Kenyon, head of Northeast's electrical generation group, said he expected the plants could be sold as early as 2001, almost three years ahead of a legislative deadline for divestiture. As part of the state's plan for deregulation of the electric utility industry, existing utilities must auction off their power plants and split into two companies, one for power generation and the other for distribution. Included in the Northeast sale will be Millstone 1, which the company is now decommissioning. Millstone Three was restarted last year and Millstone Two in May.
"To be a successful nuclear operator in the coming deregulated environment, it would be necessary to buy and run several additional nuclear facilities to take advantage of economies of scale," Mr. Kenyon said. "Divestiture of these plants would best serve our customers, our shareholders and our Millstone employees."
But not everyone is thrilled with the prospects. James P. Riccio, a staff attorney for Critical Mass, an anti-nuclear group that is an arm of Public Citizen, the consumer group founded by Ralph Nader, said it was unfair that ratepayers suffered years of mismanagement of the Millstone plants and now would have to pick up the bills when another company comes buys the plants for a fraction of their book value.
"Who's really getting the benefit of this, then?" Mr. Riccio asked. "It's a sweetheart deal between two nuclear utilities, and the public is getting ripped off. It's a boondoggle on a royal scale."
And while Northeast's announcement means an end to speculation about the future of the plants, local officials were apprehensive, particularly because a fire sale of the nuclear plants means a major portion of the town's tax base could disappear.
"We've known they are going to auction, so we've been preparing for a worst-case scenario," said First Selectman Thomas A. Sheridan of Waterford. "The town is in excellent financial shape. We have a substantial surplus that will carry us forward, and we have no debt as of next year."
And under the deregulation legislation, Waterford will get a state grant equal to 90 percent of the difference between the old and new assessments the first year after divestiture, declining to 80 percent the next year, 70 percent the third, and so on for nine years.
When all three nuclear plants were operating, it was estimated they saved more than 25 million barrels of oil per year. But for much of the last few years all three plants have been out of service as the company addressed safety concerns raised by Federal regulators.
Ms. Seitz of UBS Securities said the scrutiny Millstone had received from Federal regulators over the last several years could increase interest in the plants. Several of the potential bidders, including Peco, have had teams at Millstone for the last couple of years helping them to recover from their safety problems.
"Those plants have better documentation than anyone in the industry, because everyone has gone through them so thoroughly," Ms. Seitz said.
"The companies that are probably going to be interested, they know those plants well, they know the area, and they know the people running them, which is going to make them more willing to make a bid," Ms. Seitz said. "That doesn't mean that they're going to be willing to pay a ton of money, of course, but in general, I think the outlook is generally pretty positive."
