HEADLINE: In the Pulpit, Seeking to Relieve Suffering

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
SOMETIMES the Rev. Dr. W. Franklyn Richardson, the fiery leader of the largest black church in Westchester, really preaches to himself from the podium and just allows his congregation to listen in. Such was the case a week ago, he conceded.
Standing on his toes and reaching toward the heavens on that last Sunday of the summer, Dr. Richardson drew his inspiration from Isaiah. "The morning cometh, and also the night," he called out from the pulpit at Grace Baptist Church here. "There are good days and bad ones, sunshine and rain. The good news is that the morning is coming." 
 While Isaiah's message undoubtedly had relevance for many attending the services, it was particularly meaningful for Dr. Richardson.
In a stinging defeat on Sept. 9, he lost the election for president of the largest black religious organization in the United States, in a vote at the annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A. (The convention's last elected president, the Rev. Henry Lyons, was sentenced in March to five and a half years in prison for stealing money from the organization.) But instead of voting as predicted, delegates at the recent meeting in Tampa elected the Rev. William Shaw of Philadelphia, edging out Dr. Richardson in a 3,694-to-3,451 vote.
Last week, after the two morning services at Grace Baptist with a standing-room-only crowd -- there were about 1,100 worshipers at each service -- the 50-year-old Dr. Richardson, a resident of Scarsdale, retreated to the well-appointed suite of offices he occupies on the second floor of the massive white brick church.
There, away from the public eye, he removed the colorful vestment he wears when he preaches, unbuttoned his shirt collar, ran a comb through hair that is just beginning to turn gray and lowered his burly frame onto a small couch.
"Yes, today's sermon was personal," he said.
On a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being the highest, he rated the defeat as "a 6, and maybe even a 7."
"It was a significant setback," said Dr. Richardson, who was also defeated in a race for president in 1994. "And I don't understand it now, although I will in time." He had hoped to steer the convention away from infighting and power struggles and refocus it on the larger educational, economic, political and spiritual problems facing blacks in America.
In terms of losses he has experienced, he said the defeat in Tampa was second only to the death three and a half years ago of his brother Ron Richardson, who won a Tony Award in 1985 for his performance as Jim in the Broadway musical "Big River: the Adventures of Huckleberry Finn." The actor, who was 43, died of AIDS.
But Dr. Richardson, who has been the pastor of Grace for close to 25 years, explained that because he does not want to emphasize solely the disappointments and losses of life, he reached to Isaiah for the hopeful passage last Sunday. His goal was to remind himself and his congregation that balanced responses must be sought. "One must remember that you can't have a mountain without a valley," he said in his preacher's voice. "They live right next door to each other."
His goal, whether it is through the Baptist Convention or another organization, is to relieve the spiritual suffering of what he refers to as the black community. That often involves entering the fray not just through the church but in the political, economic and educational sectors as well, he said.
In Mount Vernon during the early 1990's, Dr. Richardson founded a political-educational group called the Coalition for the Empowerment of People of African Ancestry to oppose an all-white organization, the Italian Civic Association, which had dominated school board elections for as long as anyone could remember.
"We are trying to overcome an imbalance," Dr. Richardson said then. "We are not on a level playing field."
The son of a laborer in the meat-packing industry and a beautician who operated a beauty parlor out of the family's home in Philadelphia for 30 years, Dr. Richardson observed that the inequities of the past persist. He explained that historically "second-class" blacks have come to church for "first-class" affirmation so they could "deal with broken relationships, shattered marriages, racism, hum-drum existences, disappointments, not enough money, nonacceptance and sometimes jobs so bad that aren't worth having."
He continued: "Blacks are living tremendously below their capacities. They are not lazy or shiftless, but some people like to blame the victim. The truth is that there's a spiritual crisis in our communities."
He spoke of violence and drugs and families in distress, explaining that the church, above all other institutions, has the capacity to lift up people. He viewed the role of the National Baptist Convention, which is based in Nashville, as "putting the nation on notice that its 8.5 million members are a force to be reckoned with."
The convention was organized in 1880, when it broke with the white Baptist church; in 1915, it was incorporated as a separate entity. It now has more than 33,000 member churches and is the third-largest Protestant denomination in the United States. Its officials say it is the largest black organization in the world.
As Dr. Richardson has said, "It's time the largest black organization has a large presence."
Last week, the question most on his mind was whether to wait five years until the next election to enact his agenda of empowering blacks through the church -- specifically the Baptist Convention -- or to find expression elsewhere.
"The issue haunts me," he conceded. "What do I do about it? I didn't run for a title, but I did see an opportunity to do something positive."
Paradoxically, the one to whom others come for answers now finds himself struggling alone when searching for answers. "I am at a strange place in my life," he said.
Dr. Richardson sometimes consults with his wife, Inez, his closest friend for almost 30 years. (They have a son, the Rev. W. Franklyn Richardson 3d, and a daughter, Orchid Richardson-Burnside, who is a commercial real estate agent.)
Occasionally, he turns to a few trusted friends, whom he chose not to identify. But whatever his agenda is to become on a national scale, he said he would not leave his congregation in Mount Vernon where people like Ruth P. Anderson, 92, call Dr. Richardson "my sweetheart," and Nadine Bent, a computer engineer and the mother of 6-year-old Baqiyyal Muhammad, said she feels "at home and nourished in a loving environment."
Dr. Richardson said: "Everyone can come here. We create a warm space where the doctors and the domestics, the Ph.D.'s and those with no education can leave their titles and positions outside the door."
The church, where the collection plates fill to overflowing on Sundays, began in 1888 under the direction of five black women, former slaves, who organized the Grace Baptist Mission.
The initial prayer meeting was held in what was known as Willard Hall, now the site of the Levister Towers public housing development. At the turn of the century, Grace erected a frame church on Eighth Avenue; it burned in 1939. Grace now occupies a former PresbyterianChurch at 52 South Sixth Avenue, which it bought after the 1939 fire and renovated and expanded. The church draws about half its members from outside Mount Vernon. Dr. Richardson said it is outgrowing its quarters.
Today the church has 11 ministers including associate ministers, a music minister and a minister for health and wholeness. Dr. Richardson, who came to the church when he was a student, has since earned a bachelor's degree from Virginia Union University in Richmond, a master's degree from Yale University School of Divinity and a doctorate from United Theological Seminary in Dayton, Ohio.
Under his ministry, he established "The Grace Hour," a radio ministry, which has quadrupled the church's membership and brought in advertising revenue. Also under his leadership, the church completed a $4.2 million restoration and expansion project and built Grace House, an $11 million, 100-unit housing complex for the elderly.
In addition to being a member of the National Baptist Convention, Dr. Richardson is a board member of the Congress of National Black Churches, a trustee of the National Urban League, a former member of the central committee of the World Council of Churches and a former chairman of the National Council of Churches.
Although he says he is at a personal crossroads in his life, he has little patience for self-pity. "Good morning, Grace," Dr. Richardson said buoyantly to the congregation at the start of last Sunday's service. "We do our best and go on. Let's move forward."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 13; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1638 words

HEADLINE: Longer Classroom Periods Test Tradition

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
AFTER 90 uninterrupted minutes of a pre-calculus class, Helaina Winnicki, 17, says her brain "starts turning into mush." And a 90-minute gym class -- with no shower afterward -- is "really disgusting."
But longer classes are not always a bad thing, Helaina said, because 90 minutes of English or economics and government allow students more time for meaty discussions before they pack up for the next class. 
 Helaina, a senior at Lincoln High School in Yonkers, is among the 11,000 students at the district's public middle schools and high schools adjusting to "block scheduling," which began this fall. Traditional 43-minute class periods ended this school year when Dr. Andre Hornsby, Superintendent of the Yonkers School District, replaced them with four 90-minute periods a day.
The block scheduling has been a central issue in negotiations over a new contract for teachers. Steven Frey, president of the teachers' union, said teachers did not know about the planned schedule changes until shortly before school started this month and have not had time to prepare for major changes in their approach to teaching, which is required by the longer classes.
"We are opposed to this on such short notice," Mr. Frey said. "There are a lot of versions of block scheduling, and this is the worst one. It might have some merit if there was sufficient lead time to learn how to deal with this."
Yonkers administrators said that teachers knew at the end of the school year that the change was coming and why. .
"It increases uninterrupted instructional time," said Ray Willis, assistant superintendent for communications. "It's widely heralded and accepted around the country. There are some challenges and kinks, but we feel it is far superior to traditional scheduling."
Block scheduling has become increasingly popular at American schools, with its emphasis on more time spent in fewer classes. Robert Lynn Canady and Michael D. Rettig, former teachers and authors who are proponents of block scheduling, estimate that more than 50 percent of high schools in the United States use some extended class periods.
In their manual, "Teaching in the Block" (Eye on Education), Mr. Canady of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville and Mr. Rettig of James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va.,, who are professors of education, argue that traditional 40-minute periods worsen discipline problems, limit teachers' possibilities and create a "factory-like environment" with assembly-line classes.
State education officials in New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey do not keep figures on the number of schools with block scheduling, but all said the system is becoming increasingly widespread.
"Anecdotally, it seems that a larger and larger number of school districts are using it," said William Hirschen, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Education. The appeal seems to be that it lends itself to more innovation and flexibility in teaching, he said.
Ken Tobin, who is the University of Pennsylvania's director of teacher education and a professor of science education, said, "There are advantages, if the students and teachers know how to take advantage of the time. You have to manage the activities. You have to make sure that the lessons are varied."
When Mr. Tobin and a colleague taught a 75-minute course last year at University City High School in Philadelphia, they found that they needed about five activities in each class to hold the students' attention. Because teachers must plan a more varied classroom experience, Mr. Tobin said it was essential that the school support the plan.
"It's not going to work if it's a top-down kind of thing," he said. "Teachers need to feel that they can make it work and that there's flexibility."
In Westchester, Dr. Jerry Cicchelli, Superintendent of the Greenburgh schools, is a proponent of block scheduling, which is being used for the second year in Greenburgh's middle schools and high schools.
"This schedule can empower teachers to do certain things that you cannot do in 43 minutes," he said. "It empowers teachers to be more innovative and creative."
At Woodlands High School in Hartsdale, part of the Greenburgh district, students have six periods a day and have the same schedule every other day. The day is broken into three 80-minute blocks and three 40-minute blocks. Students can "more deeply and thoroughly get into subject areas," Paul Gross, the school's principal, said.
The district administration and Woodlands began studying block scheduling in the 1993-94 school year. Last year, before the block scheduling started, teachers attended a three-day staff development program to plan the transition from 40-minute to 80-minute classes. Woodlands High has a committee of students, teachers and administrators, which meets once a month to discuss how the process is working.
So far, the passing rate for students has gone up slightly, from 85 percent to 87 percent, Mr. Gross said, and there has been "a dramatic decrease in disciplinary issues" because students spend less time in the halls.
Dr. Christine Casey, who was assistant superintendent in the Greenburgh district for nine years before moving this fall to the Stamford school district, said most districts in Westchester have a form of block scheduling and she thinks it is a positive move: "I think that anything that gives you flexibility and time enhances education."
But Ms. Casey said teacher support was the key, because the longer periods transformed the structure of a class for the teachers.
"In Greenburgh, it was the staff that really wanted it," she said. "It needs to come from the teachers. It really means you have to teach differently."
Kate Sammon, a high school English teacher in the Pennsbury school district in Bucks County, Pa., said the extra time had liberated her to teach literature in a new way.
For example, the day she introduced William Golding's "Lord of the Flies," the novel of schoolchildren fending for themselves on an island, students came into Ms. Sammon's room to find a series of instructions on the board. They were to locate hidden pieces of candy, look up vocabulary words and rearrange the furniture in the classroom. They had 15 minutes to accomplish the tasks as a group. When the time was up, they discussed how the experiment in adult-free interaction had fared: how taller students helped shorter students reach the candy and how leaders soon came forward. They talked about their willingness to trust one another. The issues that emerged in their experiment were the same ones that were pivotal in the novel.
"I can do things that are outside of reading the literature," said Ms. Sammon, who is starting her second year of teaching. "It gives us time to discuss more and allows more creative teaching."
At Pennsbury High School, which has 1,650 11th and 12th graders, block scheduling started four years ago with the day divided into four blocks. Students take eight classes a year, four each semester. Classes run 87 to 92 minutes, said William Katz, the principal, who graduated from the school in 1967.
"We were pretty much doing things the way we'd always done them," Mr. Katz said. Many teachers were comfortable in the 40-minute classes, he said, but the administration felt "we had to evolve." The longer classes allow students in art and environmental studies to go outside, permits students to do research and work in groups during classes and make classes more than just a lecture, he said. "They've got to have research skills and they've got to problem solve. By doing that, they remember much more."
Pennsbury teachers spent a year preparing to go to block scheduling, Mr. Katz said. Some teachers retired rather than make the change, but most were excited about trying new approaches.
"You can prepare on paper and in groups, but when you actually do it, it's different," he said.
Sometimes teacher opposition has been a factor in schools deciding not to try block scheduling.
Cherry Hill East, a southern New Jersey high school of 1,780 students with some of the area's highest Scholastic Achievement Test scores, has stayed with the eight-period day, even though teachers and administrators have looked into the longer block classes.
Teachers did not want to make the change, said Margaret Regan, a psychology teacher who has taught in the high school for 15 years. "You need a faculty who is enthusiastic about it," she said. "I feel that if you could have it one day a week, it would be great."
Attention span of the students is the biggest problem, she said. "With a lot of them, at the end of 42 minutes, you're kind of losing them."
Mary Ellen Winnicki, mother of Helaina and president of the Yonkers Parent-Teacher Association, does not object to the concept of block scheduling for her daughter or the district, but she said it needs time to be studied and phased into the district.
"Block scheduling is useful if it is planned thoroughly and implemented slowly," she said. "But there was no sitting down or shared discussion in this decision. You heard rumors, but you didn't know."
Her daughter received her schedule the first day of school instead of getting it by mail ahead of time, she said. "You had mass scheduling problems in all the high schools," she said. "It was atrocious."
Mr. Willis said the schools are going through an adjustment period that they would have had with any change.
While administrators trying block scheduling are positive about it now, they are still watching it to see if they get the performance improvements in passing rates and test scores that they hope to see. "The true test is over time," Mr. Gross of Woodlands High School said. "This is Year 2 and we're pretty comfortable that we're moving in the right direction."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2625 words

HEADLINE: Shortages Are Slowing Construction Of Homes

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
FROM the pipes in the trenches to the trusses for the roof, from the panels for the walls to the insulation between the beams -- and, just as acutely, in the search for skilled workers to hammer it all together -- home builders in New York City and its suburbs are struggling with shortages of supplies and labor.
In coping with the scarcities, the builders find themselves engaged in frenetic juggling acts that have consequences for their profit margins and for homebuyers' budgets. 
 Squeezed by bottlenecks for one material, then another, developers are realizing just where they rank in their suppliers' pecking orders, their allocation for a particular product dependent on how much they bought last year -- a serious circumstance for the little guy. Stymied by delivery delays, some find themselves staring at foundations without frames, frames without walls. Others turn to alternative materials or methods.
"Absolutely, I've got war stories," said Jeffrey Levine, president of Levine Builders, a Queens-based corporation that has built about 3,000 housing units over the last 20 years.
Shaft walls for three elevators in a 240-unit co-op building going up at 95th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan were supposed to be lined with fire-resistant coreboard, Mr. Levine said, "but due to its lack of availability, time constraints dictated that we make a change."
Masons will now have to build brick firewalls, Mr. Levine said -- at a not inconsiderable extra expense.
"The masonry costs about $2.50 more per square foot than the coreboard," Mr. Levine said. "The elevator is 10 by 10, and it's 10 feet from floor to floor, so that's 400 square feet per floor. At $2.50 extra a foot, that would be $1,000 per floor for each elevator." There are three elevators in the 11-story building, or 33 times $1,000, for a total added cost of $33,000.
In the suburbs, according to one estimate, increases in the cost of lumber can add $4,000 to the price of a typical home and $10,000 to a luxury residence.
Some developers pass along those extra costs to the homebuyers. But, said Mr. Levine, "depending on the circumstances of the contractual agreements, if it's a fixed-price contract I bear the burden."
What the developers cannot avoid passing along are the delays in completion dates -- postponements that have sent buyers packing for motel stays or to the homes of relatives.
Joe Mutinsky is president of the New Jersey division of Centex Homes, a company that last year built 15,000 houses around the country. "When I moved from Florida to New Jersey in 1985," Mr. Mutinsky said, "the home-building market was very active. And, at that time, the same types of delays were occurring" -- including for the home Mr. Mutinsky had ordered.
"I ended up in a hotel with my children and a dog," he said, "and here I am almost 15 years later, causing that same problem to my homeowners. I never wanted to do that."
Mr. Mutinsky estimates that the panoply of delays he faces these days has pushed back completion dates on his projects by at least three months.
At Island Estates at Shoreham in Suffolk County, where 140 houses are pushing toward completion, the builders are also feeling the squeeze.
"We had one supplier say, 'O.K., I'll give you Sheetrock if you buy lumber from me,' " said Lennard Axinn, a partner in Island Estates. "We were desperate. It was a different form of ransom."
"There certainly are houses delayed by the shortages," Mr. Axinn said. "That has an impact when the homeowners are counting on moving in by a certain date, getting the kids into school. Of course, they were screaming at us."
Not that the builders require an excess of sympathy, since their problems are the product of a booming, profitable housing market.
"We're operating at sales levels that are, basically, records," said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. There were 886,000 new homes sold in the country last year, "an all-time high," Mr. Seiders said. The previous record was 819,000 in 1977.
And through July of this year alone, 577,000 new homes were sold, Mr. Seiders said. "Compared to the first seven months of last year, that's an increase of 6 percent," he said. "So it was a record year last year, and the first seven months this year we ran above last year's pace -- that's red hot."
Demand, as usual, is reflected by prices. In New Jersey, for example, said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of that state's Builders' Association, "prices are surging."
"I can tell you that the average price of a new home in New Jersey is about $250,000, up more than 10 percent from a year ago," Mr. O'Keefe said. "It's attributable to the robust demand, and constrained supplies."
The lack of supplies and labor, said Mr. Seiders, "tops the problem list for builders at the moment."
ACCORDING to a survey of 400 members of the association, 72 percent nationally and 77 percent in the Northeast -- the nine states from Pennsylvania through New England -- said they were experiencing shortages of materials. Asked about labor, 75 percent, both nationally and in the Northeast, said they were experiencing shortages.
The builders' concerns about supplies surpassed, even, their reaction to the fact that the Federal Reserve has twice raised interest rates in recent months.
Saying that he did not want to sound like "a cheerleader for a slowdown," Mr. Seiders pointed out that "usually when the Fed is in a tightening mode, that's enough to throw the builders into a state of panic." However, he said, builders are "pretty sanguine about that right now."
"This is supposed to be the most interest-sensitive sector of the economy," he said. "So, obviously, when the Fed has tightened policy a couple of times, they really do want this sector to lose some steam. But the builders are not carrying on about the tightening. It's hard to operate in a market where you have trouble getting decent workers and things like gypsum wallboard. So a rebalancing of supply and demand in this market would not be a bad thing."
Still, for those in the trenches of the building business, keeping their balance can require a juggler's touch.
"Now you've got me going," said Mr. Mutinsky of Centex Homes in New Jersey when asked about the pitfalls of the current construction cycle.
"Right now, in developing the land, we have a problem getting ductile iron water main," Mr. Mutinsky said. "That has added a three-week delay. And once the water main comes in, the subcontractor doesn't have the manpower to make up that three weeks' difference."
"We also have a problem with the availability of PVC pipe," he continued, referring to sanitary sewer pipe made from polyvinylchloride. "We have just been informed that the prices are going up; they won't tell us how much and there may be a shortage. This is what they're telling me."
As for the actual construction of the home, Mr. Mutinsky said: "In the permit process, municipalities in New Jersey have 20 days to review and comment on and/or approve your plans. But they're so swamped with applications and no manpower to handle them that on the 19th day you get an additional list of deficiencies from the municipality. It's either a true deficiency or a delaying tactic to give them more time to review the application." That alone, Mr. Mutinsky said, adds a month's delay.
"Now, framing the house," he said. "I have an additional one-month delay receiving the pre-manufactured panels and trusses -- these are the wooden floor and wall panels and what holds up the roof. Again, because of the demand, we wait an additional month for the delivery of those. And again, the framer does not have the additional crews to make up that lost time."
Another product Mr. Mutinsky said he was having trouble getting is called R-30 Batt -- fiberglass insulation with a paper backing that goes between the studs. "We are experiencing allocations in the Northeast corridor," he said, "and that adds another two weeks."
But, by far, the greatest shortage confounding the industry is of gypsum wallboard -- otherwise known as coreboard, drywall or by its trademarked name, Sheetrock. "We used to be able to get it in two days," Mr. Mutinsky said, "but due to the allocations, it's now up to almost 14 days."
The delays are not sequential, but overlap.
"When we go to contract with a customer," Mr. Mutinsky said, "we used to anticipate a six-month delivery of that home. But because of all of the above, we now state anywhere between eight to 10 months out. That's an average of an additional three and a half months."
It is not for lack of trying that the wallboard industry has not filled all of its orders, said Pam Kassner, spokeswoman for the USG (G for gypsum) Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of wallboard. "The industry and USG, we've been running 24 hours a day since last summer," Ms. Kassner said. "The demand is at record levels." Last year, the industry produced 28 billion square feet, and expects to exceed 30 billion this year, Ms. Kassner said.
"We're shipping, but it's never enough," she said.
Moreover, the price has gone up. The cost to a distributor for 1,000 square feet of wallboard was $149 at the end of July, 17 percent higher than the year before.
"It will get better toward the end of the year," Ms. Kassner said. "We have new plants from us and our competitors coming on line." But demand, she said, will not dip. "We think it's going to be just as strong in 2000 as in '99, and the repair and remodel market is growing gangbusters." Potent, too, is the office market, which also uses wallboard.
The supply-price equation for lumber is also vexing for builders, though more difficult to quantify because lumber is much more of an international commodity, subject to the vagaries of many a national market. In some parts of this country, builders are befuddled by price fluctuations; in others, they are hamstrung by actual shortages.
DESPITE the strong demand for new homes, lumber prices in the United States actually slackened somewhat last year, primarily because profound weaknesses in Asian economies undercut the demand in those nations -- particularly Japan.
"So we were able to consume a huge amount of lumber at pretty attractive prices last year," said Mr. Seiders. "But then prices spiked up from last year's low."
The average price for 1,000 board feet of lumber was $349 in 1998. By mid-July of this year, it had bounded up to $490.
In Connecticut, according to Joanne Carroll, president of JMC Resources, a housing research firm, lumber costs for a typical 2,000-square-foot home have risen by about $4,000 since last year. For a trophy house in a swank Connecticut suburb, the price of lumber spiraled up by about $10,000, she said.
At the lower end, said Norton Wheeler, the lumber buyer for United Builders' Supply in Waterford and Niantic, Conn., "a sharp rise in lumber costs could knock a first-time buyer out of the box."
In the last two months, however, the average national lumber price has slipped back to $390 per 1,000 board feet -- still considerably above last year's mark. "Lumber prices are very volatile," Mr. Seiders said, "a lot of ups and downs, a lot of speculation. Usually when you talk about shortages, the symptom is high prices, but you can still get it."
Not everybody.
"I've got 12 houses out here in East Windsor," Mr. Mutinsky said of one of his projects in New Jersey. "I had to wait 10 weeks for delivery of the wall panels when the normal delivery is five. If I can't put lumber on a foundation, it sits."
At least it has something to sit on.
"The amount of approved, developable land is dwindling rapidly," Mr. O'Keefe of the New Jersey Builders Association said, "and, consequently, we may see a trailing off in production in 2000."
To meet incessant demand, some builders are turning to commercial or industrial sites that can be rezoned for residential use, or to previously ignored parcels passed over because they were too difficult to build on. For example, Brian Stolar, president of Pinnacle Communities of Millburn, said his company was buying a 35-acre site on a hilltop in Wayne, N.J.
Scarce land coupled with high demand can be costly. John Udell, president of Weichert New Homes, a land broker, estimates that land today constitutes 35 to 40 percent of the cost of a new home, compared with 30 percent just a few years ago.
But, even assuming that all the land and all the supplies can be acquired according to a reasonably coordinated schedule, there's no telling whether the developer will be able to hire workers capable of doing the pipe-fitting, the cementing, the wiring, the sawing, the hammering.
"Almost worse than these material problems are the labor problems," said Mr. Axinn of Island Estates in Suffolk County. "It's been sort of a balancing act so we aren't getting creamed."
Normally, 80 percent of Mr. Axinn's workers do the basic building and 20 percent perform what he calls customer service, like touching up paint and fine trim work after the house is up. "We've had to reallocate those resources so that people in customer service can help complete the homes," Mr. Axinn said.
Mr. Mutinsky said that when he first came to the New York area in 1985, hard times had hit the Sunbelt states, "and the skilled labor from down there came north, so that all these Texas license plates showed up on the sites here."
During the recession of the late 80's and early 90's, however, many small- to medium-sized builders went out of business in the New York area. "Thus, the license plates went back to Texas," he said.
Residential developers have also been losing workers to the booming commercial segment of the building industry, said Mr. Seiders of the national home builder's association -- adding, somewhat sheepishly: "Right now, in fact, we're adding four stories and a wing to our headquarters building here in Washington, near the White House, and the contractor is luring workers from the residential area."
In the view of Carl Goldberg, a partner in the Roseland Property Company of Roseland, N.J., which builds about 1,500 homes a year in the region, the industry must do more to expand the labor force.
"Over the last 19 months, the scarcity of qualified workers has become a crisis," Mr. Goldberg said. "It's not only a problem in numbers, but also because people haven't had full training."
CITING the lack of trim contractors -- those carpenters who do the fine finish work -- Mr. Goldberg said, "I often hear people saying these days, 'Gee, they don't do things like that anymore.' "
Fewer and fewer students are choosing to go to vocational school, Mr. Goldberg pointed out, and trade union apprenticeship programs are running at about about 60 percent of capacity. The industry needs to create outreach programs and provide scholarships to entice young people into trade schools, he said.
"We need to communicate that there are opportunities in being a licensed electrician or a licensed plumber, financial opportunities," Mr. Goldberg said. Take, for example, a carpenter, he said: "Four or five years ago, a carpenter would make $16, $17 an hour. Now, most of the time, it's upwards of $25 an hour."
To be sure, residential development is a profitable enterprise these days. Still, all the crunching and juggling has taken its toll on builders.
"You learn how not to lose sleep," Mr. Mutinsky said, "but it does bother you when you come to work in the morning. It's frustrating."
And as Marshall Davis, president of Carlton Construction in New City, N.Y., put it, "Yes, we are pulling our hair out."
"Business is good," Mr. Davis said, "but it's not a fun job anymore."

HEADLINE: Hoping Ball Parks Succeed In Speeding Urban Revival

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

 BODY:
NOT long ago, baseball purists were lamenting the disappearance of minor league baseball. Major league expansion, the explosion of cable television, the rise in popularity of football and the ponderous slowness of the game were all seemingly good reasons why minor league ball should wither away.
But in the 1990's, minor league baseball has become a growth industry in New Jersey, especially in its cities, which -- drawing on the successful examples of Cleveland, Baltimore and other major centers -- have viewed new stadiums and the ball teams inhabiting them as instruments to revive languishing downtowns. 
 Factories, banks, stores and offices may have fled Newark, Trenton, Atlantic City and Camden, leaving them with blighted streets and reputations, but those cities have either built baseball stadiums or have one in the works and, in some cases, indoor arenas as well. And the city fathers view such places as the introduction to exciting new futures for their downtrodden downtowns.
"We've just finished our fifth season and the numbers of people who have come continue to grow," said Mercer County Executive Robert D. Prunetti, referring to the Trenton Thunder. "It is not a novelty whose popularity has declined." This summer the Thunder won 90 games for the second straight season at Waterfront Park, set on the Delaware River south of downtown Trenton. "The numbers are way beyond our expectations, Mr. Prunetti said, "but the most significant thing is that it has changed the perception of what Trenton is."
Most summer nights the Thunder are playing there, nearly all of Waterfront Park's 6,500 seats are filled. Few of the Thunder, a Boston Red Sox farm team, at Class AA two levels below the big club, will ever make the big leagues. But thousands have paid from $4 to $8 a ticket to see them play anyway. Mr. Prunetti said that with tickets, parking, souvenirs and ancillary spending, his office estimates that the team has pumped $12 million to $16 million a year into Trenton's economy, which more than justifies the $17.5 million the county, with some state help, spent on Waterfront Park.
The Sandcastle, where the Atlantic League Atlantic City Surf, an unaffiliated team, play their games, was an even less expensive proposition. The three-year-old stadium next to the old Bader Field Airport in the Chelsea Heights section was built for $14.5 million, much of which came from the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, the state agency charged with funneling casino revenue to worthwhile projects.
"It's brought diverse entertainment for youngsters here and for other people who want an alternative to casinos," said Stuart Wiser, Atlantic City's director of redevelopment. "If nothing else happened there but baseball, we'd be pleased." But Mr. Wiser is looking for more. Bader Field is scheduled to be phased out for use as an airport next year, and Mr. Wiser said an ice-skating complex is in the planning stages for the site. He wants to utilize the stadium for concerts and other athletic events and hopes restaurants and shops will follow the fans out to the neighborhood as well.
Newark and Camden are also dreaming big dreams surrounding stadiums. In Newark, Riverfront Park, familiarly known as the Den, was completed on Bridge Street off Interstate 280 this summer. It is home to the Newark Bears, who play with two other New Jersey teams -- Atlantic City's Surf and the Somerset Patriots of Bridgewater -- in the Atlantic League, which is unaffiliated with the majors; essentially, that means the players have even less of a chance of ever making the big leagues than those from the Trenton Thunder.
Still, fans have flocked to the 6,014-seat Den near the Broad Street train station. More than 1,200 season tickets were sold for its first season at the $22 million park. The team's president is Rick Cerrone, the former Yankee cather, who greets many of the fans, something his old boss, George Steinbrenner, would presumably not ever do on a bet.
Betting in Newark is that there will also be a new arena downtown early in the next decade. Lewis Katz, one of the new owners of the New Jersey Nets procfessional basketball team, favors building an arena there rather than refurbishing the Nets' current home, the Continental Arena in the decidedly non-urban Meadowlands. Mr. Katz has pledged that a portion of his profits will go to inner-city projects, particularly in Newark and Camden, and he has said a downtown Newark arena would go far to helping realize his dream of a revived downtown in Newark.
Camden, too, wants to put a stadium along its Delaware River waterfront as part of its growing entertainment complex there, which already includes the New Jersey State Aquarium and the Blockbuster-Sony Music Entertainment Center. Negotiations started earlier this year with the developers Kravco Company, of King of Prussia, Pa., to build a $100 million sports complex on a 30-acre parcel between the aquarium and the Benjamin Franklin Bridge. Camden's Mayor, Milton Milan, has said the project will include five or six buildings, including the stadium, a skating rink, a sports bar and sporting goods stores.
Mr. Prunetti, the Mercer County Executive, said all this sports development was fine so long it was kept in mind that the ultimate beneficiaries were supposed to be the residents of those cities.
"Without some integration and synergy with the surrounding neighborhoods trying to rebuild, I don't know how beneficial any of this is," said Mr. Prunetti. "Location is very important, but you can't just build a stadium. You have to look at the blocks of old buildings nearby and have a plan to improve that area as well."
Mr. Prunetti said Trenton had set up improvement districts for businesses and programs to invest in improving homes near Waterfront Park. He cited a plan that would supply low-interest loans for residents to buy the homes they rented in or ones nearby.
He said that the same programs would go on near the $60 million, 10,500-seat Sovereign Bank Arena, which will be completed next month in Trenton near the old Roebling industrial complex. The arena will be home to teams in the minor league International Basketball League and East Coast Hockey League. In addition, the Philadelphia Kixx indoor soccer team will play a few games there. It will open Friday with a World Wrestling Federation exhibition.
"Trenton had been a steel and pottery and rubber town, and the factories have long since left Trenton," said Mr. Prunetti. "The city leaders prior to this administration, their strategy was to bring industry back, and that just wasn't going to happen. As we saw it, tourism, sports and entertainment were going to be it. For a while it was just government here. Now there is government in the daytime, sports in the evening and the historical sites on the weekends. And you've got to think other good things will follow."
"Look, when the people who wanted to start a baseball team came to me, they said they wanted to put a stadium in West Windsor, where it was, to them, nice and safe," he said. 'I told them we didn't want it there. They said, 'Why? It will be successful.' I said, 'Yes, I know it will. But it won't energize the economy at all.' What we have now is great. I wish the other New Jersey cities the same fortune."

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Cities: Sad Urban Presence Encircled by Wealth

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
IN the heart of Newark, people are moving into three new housing developments -- subdivisions, really -- that recently sold out. Paterson is the new home of four companies that relocated from New York. In Trenton, construction on a hotel is to start before winter.
Facts like those are barely worth noting in any suburb with a highway cloverleaf. But in the cities known as the Big Six -- Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Elizabeth, Trenton and Camden -- the smallest stirrings of new life draw attention. 
 Seen in one light, urban revival is positively vigorous. Manhattan has exported thousands of jobs to what was a broken-down industrial belt across the Hudson. Four of the Big Six have begun to register population gains, which is more than Boston or Philadelphia have managed. Last year, the state's leaders in construction activity were Jersey City, Elizabeth, Newark and Rahway. Indeed, one site in Jersey City sold for $10 million an acre.
But from another perspective, the Big Six are just bleeding more slowly than they used to. Their combined population was halved from 1930 to 1970, and more economic devastation would follow: since 1975, Camden has lost one in three jobs, Newark one in four. Except for Jersey City, all of the Big Six have lost jobs even since 1995. All are on life support from a reluctant and often exasperated state government.
The question is obvious: Why can't New Jersey support cities?
After all, New Jersey is a wealthy state, second only to Connecticut in income, and the most densely populated in the nation. Yet the cities are small -- Newark, the largest, has 267,823 people, and the smallest of the Big Six, Camden, has only 83,546 -- and their residents' income is about half the state average.
Benjamin Franklin, Philadelphian and cosmopolitan, described New Jersey as a "barrel tapped at both ends," and many urban experts still say New Jersey has two important cities, which happen to be in other states.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said New Jersey's cities had always been stunted by the mere existence of New York and Philadelphia. "Those two cities drew the allegiance of the elite of New Jersey," Mr. Hughes said, and even now those two keep a lock on media and major league sports.
But there is more. It has to do with New Jersey's historical and geographic accidents, its dependence on property taxes and its tradition of fragmented local governments, known as home rule, which makes each city just one among 567. Then, too, there is the nation's relentless exurbanization, fed by yearnings for what Mr. Hughes calls "McMansions" and "suburban assault vehicles" -- and a way of life not offered in Camden or Elizabeth.
The cities' survival "is not just a matter of more state revenue," said Stephen A. Salmore, a political scientist recently retired from Rutgers and the co-author of "Politics and Government in New Jersey: Suburban Politics Comes of Age." "It's a matter of economic development. The state has not been successful in attracting business. The market does that, and at this point the market is not interested in setting up businesses in large cities."
The Whitman administration disagrees. Last week, in announcing a state report on business relocations, the Governor emphasized that more than half of the 116 companies that moved to New Jersey last year chose "metropolitan centers." (Jersey City, with 14 of the 116, and Newark, with 6, were identified as "hot spots." Paterson got 4, and Elizabeth and Trenton each got 2.)
And when Jersey City, Elizabeth and Newark appeared at the top of the rankings on construction activity, the Commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs, Jane M. Kenny, spoke of "a building boom in the cities."
Ms. Kenny -- who was born and grew up in Jersey City -- leads the administration's urban revitalization efforts, a slew of programs providing professional help and seed money in the hope that private enterprise will bloom. "It's a combination of the state having tools that cities need, and I think we have, and a city that knows how to take advantage of the tools," she said.
William Dressel, the executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said, "It's still a struggle" to attract businesses to older downtowns. But Mr. Dressel added: "Every mayor I can think of in the past five years or so has been basically reinventing urban government. I see more doing roll-up-your-sleeves work up and down the state, redoing their wharves, their central downtown areas, Brownfields cleanups, and really doing some very aggressive lobbying and arm-twisting."
ONE is Mayor Douglas H. Palmer of Trenton, who has spent almost a decade wheeling and pleading for one hotel for his city -- while others proliferated along Route 1. The state finally agreed this month to release a $5 million loan for the downtown Marriott that he covets, and the Mayor said the groundbreaking could be expected soon.
Still, as many visitors ask, what kind of capital has no hotel rooms? And what kind of state operates with no healthy cities?
"The state that compares with New Jersey is Connecticut," Mr. Salmore said. "Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven are all in very bad shape. They're poor cities in a wealthy state. It's a very suburban state, with very similar problems and similar political situations. Both are tax-averse and upscale."
But those Connecticut cities do a little better than New Jersey's Big Six, at least in income levels. Hartford has television stations and major league sports franchises. All have hotels.
Newark comes closest to behaving like a big city, especially with the opening of the new Performing Arts Center, the investment in offices and retail development -- more than $100 million last year -- and its university complex. Still, Newark, which once provided one in five jobs in the state, now accounts for fewer than one in 25.
"It's unlikely that cities in New Jersey are ever going to be important," said Barbara Lawrence, the executive director of New Jersey Future, a nonprofit planning organization. Ms. Lawrence, reflecting after a conference on sprawl, added that in view of the centrifugal force sending the population ever outward, any growth was remarkable. Still, she said, a little is not enough.
"Think of it as market share," she said. "If you were a company and increasing revenue but losing market share, you'd say, 'Whoa, we're on the wrong track.' That's where our cities are."
Mr. Hughes at Rutgers says New Jersey's cities have been on the wrong track for decades, since their short-lived reason for being expired.
"We did not build great cities in the European sense," he said. "What happened was manufacturing firms agglomerated into tight complexes in the 19th century, and we woke up and had six overgrown factory towns."
Now, they are factory towns short on factories. The Big Six have managed a 1.1 percent increase in employment in private industry since 1992, roughly the beginning of the economy's expansion, but since 1975 they have lost almost 20 percent of their jobs. And of all the new jobs in the Big Six since 1992, one city, Jersey City, accounts for more than 90 percent.
Jersey City is the celebrated exception. It's a city being physically remade and economically -- if not fiscally -- held together by its new role. Like New York, from which it received thousands of jobs, Jersey City is a center for finance.
On a recent drive around the city, Annemarie C. Uebbing, director of housing, economic development and commerce, spoke with an ease that sounds right in a city that saw $203 million in development last year.
"We've got the waterfront, and we don't have to create the market," Ms. Uebbing said. When developers approach, she said, "we can say, 'We'll get this through for you.' You have to put on this political show. It's almost the field of dreams thing."
To start, she pointed out the office towers newly risen on two one-acre parcels that Hartz Mountain Industries bought for $20 million. To the north, past residential towers, she noted the Doubletree Hotel, a Marriott, is under construction, she said, and Hyatt and Embassy Suites plan to build.
Passing the Newport Centre Mall, where Manhattanites come for the sales tax break, she mentioned that Modell's and Office Max are joining Sears, Stern's and J. C. Penney, the only department stores in the Big Six.
Along the way, on the waterfront and on the inland streets that resemble Detroit or Gary, Ind., Ms. Uebbing indicated vacant swaths where housing is planned.
And she talked about the pedestrian-friendly, neotraditional "new urbanism" of the architect Andres Duany -- something the well-educated urbanites the city draws actually might have given some thought to. Some colonized the brownstones that reminded them of Park Slope, in sometimes uneasy buffers between the gleaming waterfront and the poverty that still makes life in Jersey City difficult.
The other Big Six cities, of course, beg for any measure of gentrification. But few expect that to come about.
Mr. Hughes, for one, sees little to be restored. The housing slapped together for factory workers "doesn't have chestnut moldings and walnut doors," he said. "It's not the housing that today's middle class would ever consider living in."
Mr. Salmore wavered before concluding, "I'm not even cautiously optimistic." "There are pockets," he said. "There are some neighborhoods in Elizabeth. Camden? I don't see anywhere in Camden people want to move back to."
The result, naturally, is that New Jersey's cities, even more so than other American cities, are custodians of the poor. Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City, a Republican who often quarrels with the Republican Governor, says the state fails to account for the exhaustive social needs in the cities.
"You need someplace for the poor to live," Mr. Schundler said in an interview, gesturing and talking urban policy at the rat-a-tat pace for which he is known. "The issue becomes: if you have a lot of people who need services and live in property that doesn't pay much in taxes, you ghettoize your cities."
That was a point that Camden politicians tried to illuminate for their overseers from the state on a bus tour last month, not long after Mayor Milton Milan filed and then withdrew his city's petition for bankruptcy.
The hosts on the bus tour were four City Council members, and the guests were two members of the financial review board that has supervised Camden's budget for a year, plus Commissioner Kenny of the Department of Community Affairs and several other officials from Trenton.
The tour accentuated the negative, although the Council members eagerly showed off restored housing and introduced a few friendly constituents. At the first pause on the tour, in front of Riverfront State Prison, Councilman Angel Fuentes said: "The residents would really like to see a hotel and convention center here, but unfortunately, we got stuck with this prison. At least the landscaping is nice."
In East Camden, the group had alighted for a discussion of infrastructure dollars -- a local housing activist explained that the area was off-limits to new housing because the city could not repair storm sewers -- when some on the tour happened on a house with an open door.
The startled occupant, a man in a wheelchair who spoke only Spanish, was soon being introduced to Stephen R. Sasala 2d, the chairman of the financial review board who has since stepped down. The people in suits looked shyly at the craters in the walls and the bare, dangling light bulb, an artificial leg and a table crowded with prescription vials.
Councilman Francisco Moran finished his segment of the tour a bit sardonically. "I don't know if you've noticed, but I haven't had the pleasure of talking about big companies with lots of jobs," Mr. Moran said. "East Camden doesn't have any. It's not a good thing being an elected official in this city with no alternatives to offer people."
He added, "I hope this has been at least touching for you guys."
Camden also exemplifies the bind that results from one distinctive fact of political life in New Jersey: its reliance on property taxes. Already drained of commercial and industrial taxpayers -- in Camden's case, the Campbell Soup Company, RCA and an entire shipbuilding industry -- the cities have to tap residents in a self-defeating cycle.
When Camden filed for bankruptcy, Governor Whitman received a lecture from the other side of the border as The Philadelphia Inquirer complained in an editorial: "Camden is merely the poster child for broader problems in a wealthy state where poor cities are punished by their forced dependence on a shaky property tax base -- with matters made worse by the Governor's cuts in state income tax."
Camden taxpayers clearly fare worse than those outside the city. Camden's effective property-tax rate -- that is, the tax per $100 of market value -- is $3.88, while Cherry Hill's is $2.68 and in Voorhees it is $2.90. Trenton's burden is even worse. Its effective rate is $3.43, compared with $1.95 in Princeton Township and $2.676 in Ewing Township.
These disparities do not exist in most states. In New York, for example, Buffalo and Rochester have effective tax rates almost identical to those in the suburbs.
Professor Hughes doubts that this makes much difference. If all capital investment by the state is counted, he said, "I bet on a per capita basis New Jersey's expenditures on its cities are probably commensurate with New York's."
But Mayor Schundler, like Mayor Milan in Camden, complains that the state's formulas for direct aid leave the cities forever at Trenton's mercy. "Since aid is a function of distress, they're paying you for distress," Mr. Schundler said. "They're basically saying, it's your fate to be a ghetto. The minute you begin to climb up, we'll cut your aid so you'll have to raise your property tax rates."
IF that is ever going to change, the cities will have to find alliances in Trenton. The Big Six have less than 10 percent of the state's voters and not much of a legislative delegation at all, let alone one that can wield influence like those in New York, Illinois or Pennsylvania.
The Whitman administration has focused not on aid -- in fact, state funds to all municipalities have declined -- but on self-help measures and land-use planning. The State Development and Redevelopment Plan, for example, is meant to direct state infrastructure spending to urban areas, and the Brownfields program offers incentives for redeveloping abandoned urban sites.
Ms. Kenny, the community affairs commissioner, subscribes to what many call "the broken window theory," holding that small gestures can have inordinate effects on how people treat their surroundings.
"Everybody talks about the squeegees in New York City as a tremendous symbol," she said. "People start little by little to feel the neighborhood's improving. We've seen it with home ownership. I'll use Newark as an example. When we go there, you see brand-new houses and homeowners for the first time getting a homeowners association and putting swings in their backyards. You go back the next time, and people on the next block have started fixing up their houses."
Newark is indeed the place to look. While Jersey City houses its newcomers in sleek apartment towers, Newark is trying to recapture its old residential self with single-family houses for the middle class and the near-poor.
The city, which led the state in rehabilitation construction last year, also had 611 new housing units, most of them one- and two-family houses. And many went into the Central Ward, which has so much vacant or abandoned property that big chunks can be claimed for what is, in effect, tract housing.
One new development built last year, Magnolia Court, occupies an entire city block where just one house had been left standing. The builder, RPM Development Group of Montclair, sold the 32 new houses quickly and, left with a waiting list, took a nearby three-block tract for Magnolia Court II.
Now, closings are beginning on those houses. Not far away, buyers are moving into two more developments, Crystal Gardens and Macedonia Heights, sponsored by church-affiliated nonprofits. Most of the buyers are church members, said Paul R. De Bellis Jr., vice president of the builder, American Dream Homes.
These and a half-dozen more new inner-city subdivisions, all built with state mortgage subsidies and construction financing aid, amount to a vast experiment, but for now the market is hotter than anyone had dared to predict. Add them up, and they probably account for Newark's population gain last year of 644 residents, after a loss of more than 7,000 since 1990.
"This is not gentrification," said Ed Martogio, a principal of RPM. "It's bringing middle-income people back to the core."
Not that Mr. Martoglio is opposed to gentrification. "We're looking to have more people come to Newark," he said, including "people with plenty of money."
Then, allowing that he might be getting carried away, he added, "I can't help thinking there's tremendous potential in downtown."

HEADLINE: Study Finds Rise in Working Poor

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
A lagging minimum wage, job growth focused mainly at the low and high extremes of the pay scale and welfare reform have combined to increase the number of working poor families in New Jersey over the past decade, a child advocacy group says.
In a report made public last Tuesday, the Association for Children of New Jersey, based in Newark, found that the number of working poor families rose from an average of 45,300 for the three-year period of 1987-89, to 57,000 for 1995-97. 
 The report defines working poor families as those with total incomes below the Federal poverty level and with at least one adult employed at least part of the year.
The poverty level was $16,530 for a family of four in 1998, and the report said 260,000 children were living under it. The report was based on Federal census information, said Jeannette Johnson, who helped write it.
Ms. Johnson cited the minimum wage as one factor in the growth. The wage "just hasn't kept pace with inflation, and is 30 percent of what it was 30 years ago in real terms," she said. She added that new jobs in the state tended to be low-end service work or high-paying skilled positions.
One of the association's chief concerns is that with welfare reform, it can be even more difficult for parents in low-paying jobs to care for their children than it had been for them be at home, on welfare.
"It's great that people are moving off of welfare," said Ms. Johnson. "But if they're not moving out of poverty, we should be doing something to help them."
The number of families living in poverty overall has also increased during the survey period, from 88,000 to 108,000, Ms. Johnson said. While the percentage of working families who are poor has increased, from 4.9 percent to 5.8 percent, she said, the percentage of poor families who are working is roughly the same.
The report does not assert that the overall plight of children in the state has worsened. And, said Andy Williams, a spokesman for the State Division of Youth and Family Services, "We don't have any indication that it has."
The report recommends raising the state's minimum wage, which is now the same as the Federal minimumof $5.15 an hour. Ms. Johnson said New Jersey was not among the eight states with minimum wages above the Federal level. She said Connecticut's minimum, for example, was $5.65, and was scheduled to increase to $6.15 next year, even though housing costs in Connecticut were lower than in New Jersey.
A second recommendation is for the state to implement an earned income tax credit, similar to one adopted by the Federal Government, as well as by some states, including New York. For example, someone earning $10,573 a year, the pay for a full-time minimum wage job, would have owed New Jersey $92 in state income tax for 1997, whereas in New York, which offers a state earned income tax credit, that same earner would have gotten a rebate check for $487, Ms. Johnson said.
The association supports legislation sponsored by the the state Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, which would gradually raise the minimum taxable income from the current $7,500 to $20,000 in the year 2002. The legislation was approved by the Legislature in June, and is incorporated in Governor Whitman's budget for the 2000 fiscal year.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Strong Economy

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
New York's economy showed consistent strength in August, with employment in the private sector up from the year before, the state's chief economist, Stephen Kagan, said.
"The strength was evident throughout most industries and most regions of the state," Mr. Kagan said. "In particular, construction employment in the state was up 6.6 percent compared with 4 percent in the nation, reflecting robust spending by homeowners and businesses." 
 Westchester fared even better, with jobs in the construction industry up by 7.4 percent in August, compared with a year ago, said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the state's Department of Labor.
Manufacturing jobs were up 2.4 percent, compared with the national figure, which was down by 2 percent.
Mr. Surdey said manufacturing figures were especially significant because they presaged an influx of new dollars from abroad. Growth in the construction industry, he said, is an indicator of new housing, new business activity and "more expansion and jobs down the road."

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
O.K., Class, Open Your Bookbags And Dig In

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
The reading season has just opened, and here's your fall list. Pop quizzes to come.
Andrew Zimbalist, a Smith College economist (yes, even a coach there asked him to be lenient with an athlete), locates the end of intercollegiate sports innocence in 1852 when a railroad offered "lavish prizes" and "unlimited alcohol" to lure Harvard and Yale rowers to a race on a New Hampshire lake. The lures have worked ever since, although most of the prizes seem to be going to coaches and schools. Nothing is as heartbreaking as the $8 million in post-season bowl revenue Notre Dame missed out on when a kicker missed an extra point. 
 In remarkably clear and clear-eyed prose (even his charts are readable), Zimbalist follows the money instead of the ball in the emotion-charged world of college sports. "Unpaid Professionals" (Princeton University Press) uses this basic starting point -- "No other industry in the United States manages not to pay its principal producers a wage or salary" -- to survey the compromised standards of academia and suggest reforms, which include outright professionalization of teams. One provocative innovation would be requiring the National Basketball Association and the National Football League to support their college "minor leagues" financially.
Zimbalist will be joining such reformers as Professor William C. Dowling, architect of the Rutgers 1000 campaign -- which is devoted to de-emphasizing sports at the university -- and Professor Murray Sperber of Indiana at an extraordinary conference at Drake University in Des Moines on Oct. 21 and 22 "for those who are fed up with the corruption, exploitation and hypocrisy in collegiate athletics and are willing to work to end it." Created by Professor Jon Ericson, the gathering is unusual in that it not only starts with the consensus that the system is wrong, but that the ultimate responsibility to fix it is in the shaky hands of a faculty that either ignores sports or is besotted by it.
One wrinkle in the student-athlete system is the role of the traditionally black colleges, before and after integration, in creating leadership. Did anyone think all their coaches and quarterbacks were white? As African-American institutions, those colleges were far more important than the relentlessly sentimentalized Negro baseball leagues. And the colleges still exist and have influence. "Never Before, Never Again," (St. Martin's Press, $24.95) is the autobiography of Coach Eddie Robinson of Grambling, written with Richard Lapchick, the founder of the Center for the Study of Sport in Society. Since both men are determinedly friendly (George Steinbrenner wrote the foreword, Jesse Jackson the afterword), the criticisms are muted, but the sense of place and history, and "the winningest" football coach's own story are happily preserved.
"Inside Sports," edited by Jay Coakley and Peter Donnelly (Routledge), is a basic sociology text heavy on ethnographic methodology. But there is enough truth to the title to make this interesting to the general reader.
Janet Saltzman Chafetz and Joseph A. Kotarba follow Little League mothers "doing gender," working harder at fulfilling their stereotypes than the "son gods" they are servicing. Todd Crosset describes the almost familial relationship between female pro golfers and their fans.
Beckey Beal reports on the subversive dogmas of skateboarders; they believe they are combating mainstream competition with cooperation. Alan M. Klein contributes a timely piece on the North American socialization of Dominican baseball players, and Douglas E. Foley goes to South Texas to study Friday night rites, including the "ritual of reversal" called "powderpuff football" in which the cheerleaders don pads and try to play seriously and the players don drag and mock women. This experience leads Foley to return to Iowa after more than 40 years and interview the Indian "hellraiser" who starred on his own high school team.
A hockey wife, writing under a pseudonym to protect her husband's career, and Bette McKenzie, a hockey daughter and former football wife, write revealingly about the culture of celebrity sports families. Each deserves a book of her own.
The coffee-table gift book on the list is "Glory" (William Morrow, $45), a collection of Richard Corman's startling photographs in which the obvious subjects -- Muhammad Ali, Cal Ripken Jr., Michael Jordan, dancers, Special Olympians -- seem to be moving in previously unseen and revealing ways.
For pure fun and apocalyptic nightmares, there is "Roller Derby to Roller Jam: The Authorized Story of an Unauthorized Sport" by Keith Coppage (Squarebooks, $19.95), as much promo as history of an exhibition that is trying to reinvent itself on the model of pro wrestling, with characters and story lines. I always liked roller derby because the sex and violence was right up front.
There were mom-and-son combos (the "diabetic housewife," Josephine Bogash, and Billy, stars of the 30's and 40's) and matinee idols (Charlie O'Connell and Joan Weston) and an inspired silliness that seemed only a putsch away from the fascist image of Rollerball. Now it's all back, cable ready, and a good, small, accessible, metaphorical subject for some of those apprentice sports sociologists.
