SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 2085 words

HEADLINE: Bringing the Party to Sotheby's

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HAYT 

 BODY:
IT was nearly 11 P.M., and Tiffany Dubin was seated at a vanity table on a hot-pink velvet chair in the dressing room of her Upper East Side apartment, wearing a baby-doll nightgown. Her day had begun with meetings at Sotheby's, where she is the head of the fashion department, continued with an afternoon trip to Chinatown to buy bar stools and after a quick change into a 1960's Norman Norell dress, wound down at a business dinner at Fressen in the meatpacking district.
But even though her makeup had long since worn off and the flip of her brunet bob had gone limp, Ms. Dubin seemed to be getting her second wind. "I'm a workaholic," she said perkily. "I have to hide it from my husband. It's a problem. I'll put him to sleep at 11:30 and then go on the Internet to buy plexiglass display cases for my sale." 
 "My sale" is "Cocktails," the latest in a series of themed auctions of vintage clothing and kitsch accessories that have challenged the stodgy, elitist world of Old Master paintings and rare coins that Sotheby's and Ms. Dubin's own upper-crust background represent.
"I'm not making fun of that whole world -- I'm having fun with it," she said.
"Do you think it's O.K. to say that?" she asked, letting out a nervous, high-pitched laugh.
The sale, to be held on Thursday, includes 1960's Pucci hot pants, Hugh Hefner's silk pajamas and all kinds of lounge accessories -- corkscrews, openers, matchbooks -- more typically found at flea markets.
Ms. Dubin is well aware that her esthetic, as well as her position at Sotheby's, raises eyebrows. Because her stepfather is A. Alfred Taubman, the shopping-mall tycoon who bought Sotheby's in 1982, took it public four years later and reigns as chairman today, her professional qualifications are often questioned.
"Her stepfather must have something to do with Tiffany getting the job," said Keni Valenti, an antique clothing dealer in New York, expressing a view shared by many. "A lot of these kids at Sotheby's are well-to-do children who have been handed something to make something of themselves."
But Ms. Dubin, 33, shrugs off charges of nepotism and the spoiled-rich-girl image. As a teen-ager, she started at the bottom at Sotheby's, filling in for receptionists. In 1984, she entered Georgetown University (where she met her future husband, Louis Dubin, a real estate developer), but she took seven years to complete her bachelor's degree because she took time off for secretarial school and a job as a waitress.
Returning to New York, she worked at Sotheby's as a personal shopper for major clients, handling everything from phone bidding to jewelry repairs. In 1997, after she handled the fashion end of the sale of the estate of Martha Phillips, the owner of Martha, the high-end Park Avenue women's clothing store, she was allowed to create the fashion department.
To mount her first big sale that year -- of vintage haute couture from France -- she relied on family connections. Ms. Dubin's mother, Judy Taubman, is a statuesque blonde and former Miss Israel who resembles Britt Ekland and is well known at the Paris couture houses. Ms. Dubin called on her mother's friends, couture customers like Sao Schlumberger, Catherine Deneuve and Empress Farah of Iran -- to consign their one-of-a-kind dresses.
Despite her high-society breeding, Ms. Dubin distances herself from her mother in terms of taste. "My mother is a safe dresser who wears classics and doesn't experiment," Ms. Dubin said. "She has very definite ideas about what is right and what is wrong in terms of clothes. I'm wrong. She doesn't like trendiness."
Ms. Dubin may have put herself on the map by raiding the closets of her mother's friends, but her promotion of used (even expensive used) clothing was a detour into flea-market chic that her mother's set would never appreciate. Her seven fashion sales to date -- given witty titles like "To Have and to Hold" (for handbags) and "Pulp Fashion" (for paper products) -- have exploited the recent interest in midcentury design, attracting a much hipper crowd than normally found at the auction house at York Avenue and 72d Street. A Dubin sale brings out deejays, East Village clothing vendors in vintage Nikes, downtown designers like Pixie Yates and models like Chandra North who, between sneaking cigarettes outside the building, mingle with suited corporate types from Hermes and the Costume Institute.
"Her sales are fun, inventive and sexier than most anything else you'll see at auction," said Bruce Wolmer, the editor in chief of Art and Auction magazine. "Her sales get a range of people, not just the traditional collectors of vintage couture but a whole crowd of style tribes in New York."
Trendiness is what Ms. Dubin is all about. She recently sold off an apartmentful of antiques, including a 19th-century English commode and her Piranesi prints, to redecorate with 1960's and 70's furniture, much of it bought on Ebay. Posing for the January cover of Town & Country magazine, she wore a $75 vintage dress. Her mother's response, as Ms. Dubin recounted it: "It would be so much better if you wore simple clothes, not those silly trendy things."
Last week Mrs. Taubman was traveling in England and could not be reached for comment, but Ms. Dubin's brother, Christopher Rounick, confirmed that his mother is not the staunchest admirer of his sister's taste. "My view of my mother and sister is that growing up, my mother instilled in my sister her fashion taste, but my sister wanted to try out different things," he said. "My mother's style is impeccable, but modern taste isn't her era, and she's not doing anything to understand it. I don't think my mother is wild about my sister selling vintage clothes. She doesn't really understand the nostalgia. She's from Israel, and 'vintage' is more an American thing."
Ms. Dubin said the other day: "My mother thinks I'm crass. She doesn't like it. I got that from my father. It's amazing how genes split themselves up." Ms. Dubin's parents divorced when she was 12; her father, Herbert Rounick, died in 1991. An owner of several clothing companies, Mr. Rounick was the son of a Lithuanian immigrant who peddled socks on the streets of Philadelphia.
D ESPITE Ms. Dubin's identification with her father, others are not so quick to see the connection. "Tiffany is very refined and elegant," said Mr. Valenti, the antique clothing dealer, who recalled his surprise at learning she was Mr. Rounick's daughter. "I knew her father, and he was a short, husky guy who smoked cigars, a real go-getter. He was in the rag business, but I guess Tiffany is now in the rag business, too." Far richer rags, however.
Ms. Dubin's 10021 ZIP code and her ties to the pashmina pack have certainly helped advance her career. "What Tiffany has done, which is brilliant, is to target her circle of well-heeled Upper East Side girls who have fairly honed fashion sensibilities and are sophisticated shoppers," said Hamish Bowles, Vogue's European editor at large and a vintage clothing collector himself. "She has made vintage clothes acceptable to a certain set of people who have been squeamish about buying old clothes." People like Jennifer Creel, Milly de Cabrol, Nadja Swarovski and Marina Rust.
That set may also have deeper pockets than the ordinary couture collector. "Tiffany Dubin pulls in clients that bring in bigger bucks," noted Mr. Valenti, who sold a Christian Dior suit at Sotheby's for $44,000. "She can sell a Courreges dress for $6,000 to $7,000. Can Doyle do that?" He was referring to William Doyle Galleries, the only other auction house in New York with an independent fashion department. (Christie's includes clothing in its celebrity and entertainment sales.)
Ms. Dubin's auctions are more like publicity events for In Style magazine than highbrow sales with a roomful of silent bidders. In December 1998, for an auction of celebrity-owned designer and vintage handbags, Kevin Krier, a fashion show producer, helped Ms. Dubin recruit Tom Ford of Gucci as a sponsor. The auction room was transformed, with waiters dressed in black Gucci outfits passing trays of fruit-flavored sodas in psychedelic colors.
E! Entertainment Television covered the event.
Those with more conventional expectations of an auction house say Ms. Dubin's sales lack substance. "Sotheby's fashion department is all about publicity, parties, presentation and image," said Linda Donahue, the director of couture and textiles at Doyle, where fashion auctions have been held since 1983. "We're a whole different ball game. We're about buying the clothes."
Another criticism is that Ms. Dubin's sales, despite their high profile, do not generate much income -- grossing less than one-half of 1 percent of Sotheby's $2 billion revenues in 1998. Mr. Wolmer of Art and Auction estimated that individual sales have brought in $300,000 to $400,000. "The events are more spectacular than the price results," he said.
Her last show, "Pulp Fashion," in May, was an out-and-out flop: about 30 percent of the items -- 1960's paper dresses and a duct-tape copy of the Kelly bag -- went unsold.
But Sotheby's defends Ms. Dubin, saying that she has attracted new customers. "So much of what the fashion department does is to bring in new clients and collectors," said David Redden, an executive vice president. "I would guess most of her customers are new to Sotheby's, and they're young, too. We have to keep renewing the collectors." Ms. Dubin says that she has added 6,000 new clients to Sotheby's mailing list and that about 40 percent of them now cross over to other sales categories, like photography and jewelry.
Moreover, Ms. Dubin has gradually built up the prices for vintage fashion. The items in her first show of Paris couture three years ago brought an average of $500 each. For "Cocktails," there are many lots estimated at more than $3,000, and Ms. Dubin expects a profit of at least $100,000. Helene Verin, a housewares and shoe designer, sold a pair of Norma Kamali sneakers for $1,100 at a Dubin sale last year. "Nobody else can get that kind of price except her," said Ms. Verin, who bought the shoes in the 70's for less than $100.
Ms. Dubin's budget is small -- not enough to pay for her splashy color catalogues or the sales themselves, and so she has taken the somewhat controversial step of selling ads in the catalogues and seeking corporate sponsors for the sales. After "Pulp Fashion," she received an angry letter from a client. "She was very disappointed that Sotheby's was demeaning itself by relying on advertising," Ms. Dubin said. "But I said: 'Great! We're another form of retailing, so what's the difference?' "
For "Cocktails," Ms. Dubin again is pushing the boundaries of what customers expect at Sotheby's. With the economy bubbling and the taste for luxury sweeter than ever, the sale is a timely acknowledgment of the role of cocktail culture in New York social life. The sale includes a Playboy Bunny costume (estimated to sell for $8,000 to $10,000), the first ever offered at auction, and the proceeds for this and several other lots will benefit the Community Research Initiative on AIDS.
Last Wednesday, Christie Hefner, the chief executive of Playboy Enterprises, was the host for a dinner to stir interest in the auction, drawing a stylish crowd to Playboy's penthouse on Fifth Avenue. Playmates in Bunny suits greeted guests like the junior jet-setters Sloan Lindemann and Ghislaine Maxwell, the artists Ross Bleckner and Tom Sachs, and Jack Kliger, the president of Hachette Filipacchi Magazines. The entertainment featured a drag queen who belted out a song. The decor, including a Playboy Bunny ice sculpture and fake fur runners on the tables, was pure 60's kitsch.
The tables glowed with lava lamps, which Barbara Cirkva, the fashion director of Chanel in the United States, confessed she had never seen before. But another guest recognized the lamps right away as part and parcel of the recycled esthetic Ms. Dubin champions.
"What she has done is take the buying and selling and collecting of vintage clothing from an obsessive, arcane club into the wider public arena," said one guest, Amy Fine Collins, a fashion writer and special correspondent for Vanity Fair. "She has people buying vintage clothes, boasting about wearing vintage clothes. People used to be ashamed, or at least secretive, about wearing these clothes. Now it's a badge of honor and chic. Tiffany legitimated all that."

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Unions See Fertile Fields At Lower End of High Tech

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
IN a valley that celebrates its bumper crop of winners, you might count people like Julian Cornejo as among the losers. Mr. Cornejo, 55, a technician in computer-aided design, has spent the last 15 years working as a kind of high-tech gypsy for various temporary agencies, a situation that now leaves him nearly broke and on the brink of homelessness.
"Temporary workers have become a hidden subculture here," Mr. Cornejo said. "You don't enjoy the stock options or the holidays. When you're laid off, you just bite the bullet. You don't get much respect." 
 Mr. Cornejo's experience as a temp, which included a financially ruinous dispute with an employment agency over a workers' compensation claim, has led him to support a new effort to organize contingent workers throughout Silicon Valley. And the travails of workers like him offer what union organizers see as a unique opportunity to improve on the negligible headway they have made among technology workers at established companies.
The drive to organize the valley's huge army of temporary workers also reflects growing concern about the widening gaps between differing classes of workers in the high-tech economy of the late 1990's. Research from both ends of the labor-management spectrum shows that while top executives' compensation has been soaring throughout the decade, the real wages of lower-end workers have been stagnant or dropping, even in the pulsing heart of the technology boom.
"There's a myth that everyone is rich and that poverty is just a transitional problem," said Bob Brownstein, policy director for Working Partnerships, a labor-backed group that has studied the valley economy. "That is something that is simply not true."
Mr. Brownstein and several academic experts trace much of widening class chasm to a shift by high-technology companies to hiring temporary workers. Since the mid-1980's, employment in temporary agencies in the valley has risen at twice the overall job growth rate and now accounts for 27 to 40 percent of the total work force, according to Chris Benner, a researcher for Working Partnerships. Wages for part-time workers -- mainly clerks, electronics assembly workers and technicians -- have generally lagged behind those of full-time employees.
Greater reliance on temps is a trend in many sectors of the economy, but according to Mr. Brownstein, it represents an especially stark shift in culture in the technology industry, where the role models used to be giants like Intel and Hewlett-Packard that prided themselves on generous, almost paternalistic employment policies. A new wave of companies, he said, reject such practices and instead use temporary or contract labor to maintain flexibility while restricting their permanent staff to a small number of core employees.
Many of the valley's temps, like Mr. Cornejo, have trade-school-taught computer and technology skills that once might have spared them from the kinds of indignities more usually associated with garment sweatshops or farm fields. No longer, said Erica Rios, a union organizer. Unlike the young programmers and engineers who work crushing hours but can hope to join in windfall profits through stock options and other incentives, "these workers do not feel they are part of the high-tech industry," she observed. "They play an important role but feel totally unappreciated."
Their disaffection is the starting point for organizing efforts like Working Partnership's Temporary Workers Project. The project includes setting up a temporary-workers' association, drafting a new model code of conduct for employers and establishing a new temporary agency called Together@Work. Ms. Rios said the effort sprang from workers' complaints that the workers' compensation and health benefits offered by for-profit temporary agencies are inadequate and that the agencies make it difficult for workers to avail themselves of their benefits.
Mr. Cornejo said he filed a workers' compensation claim in February 1998 after experiencing a shoulder injury on the job at a local semiconductor company, but received nothing until October, because of what he called foot-dragging by the agency that had placed him; the injury left him far behind on his bills. "The agencies don't want to press a claim that may cost a company something," he said. "They don't want to bite the hand that feeds them."
The unions may see an opportunity, but industry officials doubt that labor will have any more luck organizing contingent workers than they have had with full-timers. Carl Guardino, president of the Silicon Valley Manufacturers Association, said unions simply do not fit well into what he sees as the region's highly collaborative culture.
"I think the reason that Silicon Valley has functioned so well for so long -- and so many boats have risen -- is that there is not so much of this 'us versus them' that is associated with many of the unions," Mr. Guardino said. "I can appreciate that they are looking at this sector. But will they be effective in Silicon Valley? I don't think so."
So far, the evidence backs him up. The organizing effort has not succeeded in changing policies at major temporary agencies, and after nine months in existence, Together@Work has placed only 100 people. Yet both Ms. Rios and Christine Macias, who runs the temporary agency, see their efforts as just the beginning of a breakthrough for unions in an industry unfriendly to their efforts.
For one thing, the issue of contract workers and their treatment in the workplace has attracted media attention, including articles in The San Jose Mercury News, and a California State Senate committee plans hearings on the subject. Mr. Brownstein says that the valley's image as the home of a new democratic capitalism is beginning to wear thin, and that both workers and employers are coming around to the idea that new standards for temporary labor are needed.
"There are more and more people, even in industry, who fear that the gap between the rich and poor is becoming the biggest threat to the security of the valley," Mr. Brownstein said. "You don't have to be a Cassandra or a radical to know something needs to change. That's the discussion we're trying to start."

HEADLINE: COPING;
Into Thin Air: Buying Shelter From the Storm

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
IT was gray and rainy the day we signed a contract to buy an apartment in Morningside Heights, but we tried not to take it as a symbol of anything. We signed and we surrendered a down payment check with a lot of digits. Then my husband and I went to a neighborhood diner and slumped in a booth, weary rather than exhilarated by the experience of buying a piece of Manhattan.
It has become a truism that the current real-estate market is a funnyhouse of high prices, neurotic co-op boards and nasty bidding wars. But as with childbirth, everyone's pain is different. 
 In New York, what counts is where you are on the housing continuum: homeless, subletting, rent-controlled, desperately seeking three bedrooms, fleeing the city for the suburbs or fleeing the suburbs for the city.
Buying an apartment threatened, on one level, to reduce me and my husband to pay stubs, net worth statements and income tax returns. On another level, we struggled with the weird vertigo of being middle-class on this island of economic extremes.
Squeezed between the visible effervescence of the rich and the blatant reality of the poor kids around the corner who will be wearing scrawny jackets this winter, I find myself torn between desire and despair. I worry about the people I know who are just getting by, and at the same time I am lured by the trappings of wealth I see displayed on the Upper West Side, the land of Maclarens with an undeserved reputation for diversity and vestigial funk from its bohemian past.
In our neighborhood, the rich and the poor and the black, white, yellow and brown faces generally share public space more than anything else. The raging divide, though, is class. Like so much in New York, even class categories have an other-worldly quality. One can make money on paper, but the economic ante is upped on everything: housing, schools, restaurants.
When we told friends and relatives in other cities that apartments with two bedrooms, a dining room and an additional small room called a maid's room went for upward of $600,000 on the Upper West Side, the response was either silence or sympathetic gasps. In other places, that fetches a mansion.
This surreal situation was driven home to me when a neighbor assured me that families making under $200,000 a year qualified for financial aid at one of those schools at which tuition for 3-year-olds is over $10,000. It was driven home when my husband and I trooped out of curiosity to an open house for a nice -- but not outstanding -- two-bedroom for $765,000, and the line of apartment seekers filled the hallways and dribbled down to the lobby.
Living here is a choice you have to reaffirm at any number of junctures, I reminded my husband and myself. In some ways, those reaffirmations parallel the city's invitation to rearrange or even reinvent yourself in the climb upward.
Strolling West End Avenue with its dowager buildings, I remembered being a young girl in Chicago and seeing my parents sleeping on a sofa bed. We ate dinner in the kitchen rather than a dining room. My sister and I shared a small bedroom and a single closet until I left home.
There was, therefore, something vulgar and disappointing in what should have the upwardly mobile experience of looking for one of those overpriced apartments with a maid's room. The caffeinated brokers told us that we had to compromise, that we did not need to see the sky or have a laundry room or (fill in the blank). True to the war stories we had heard, there was something amiss in most of the places we saw for our family of four. There were weird divisions of space, or no light, or water damage or not enough closets.
Soon we started recognizing the same people sniffing the same turf. There was a sweet concert pianist with a fear of co-op boards who needed space for the piano, and a couple in our building, expecting a child, who finally found a bigger place a few floors down.
One of our favorite fellow travelers was Edward Tarallo. We watched his son Daniel grow from a ball of fists and feet into a handsome infant. Edward and his wife, Eileen, looked at more than 100 places during a nine-month period before they bought.
One summer day we found a place. It had light, views and a fair price. First, the seller wanted the full asking price. We said O.K. Then, he wanted to keep our 10 percent deposit even if the deal didn't close. We said no. Next, he called mournfully and said a couple with three big children and one big dog had agreed to pay even more. We wondered if that family really existed.
We bid even higher and we had a deal. Then, on the day we planned to sign the contract, the seller called our lawyer's office after hours and said he had another buyer. We never found out why. Luckily, a few weeks later we found a cheaper place in the same building.
Our new apartment needs work. The bedrooms have no views and the doorman works part time. But rather than whine (which we do), we try to give ourselves a reality check. We look into the faces of the people scrambling home to the housing projects east of Broadway rather than the ones climbing into the limousines parked outside the Broadway shows.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
An Internet Stable Is Ahead of the Pack

BYLINE: By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
DURING a summer of Internet flame-outs, the stock of Internet Capital Group was noteworthy for streaking higher.
Internet Capital, a holding company in Wayne, Pa., that owns stakes of between 10 and 50 percent in a portfolio of 36 mostly private Internet-related companies, sold an 11 percent stake in itself to the public on Aug. 4, at $12 a share. Despite the ugly recent environment for Internet stocks, the shares finished their first day of trading at $24.4375 and are now at $91.125. That gives the company a stock market capitalization of $11.3 billion, versus $8.08 billion for CMGI, the Internet holding company in Andover, Mass., to which it is often compared. 
 Even with that run-up, the stock has continued to receive some favorable notices. Henry Blodget, an Internet analyst at Merrill Lynch, which was lead manager for Internet Capital's offering, has called it a "must-own" holding for long-term investors. The stock, he said, "allows public-market investors to invest at private-market prices."
Nearly all of Internet Capital's "partner businesses," as it calls its holdings, are engaged in so-called business-to-business commerce on line. And many Internet experts say it has enormous growth prospects.
Forrester Research in Boston expects business-to-business E-commerce to grow from $43 billion in 1998 to $1.3 trillion in 2003 -- far above the $108 billion it expects in E-commerce directed at consumers.
Bob Turner, chief investment officer of Turner Investment Partners, a money manager in Berwyn, Pa., who bought shares at the offering, said the company's "built-in diversification" is key to investing in business-to-business E-commerce, "where winners and losers are especially tough to identify."
The company was founded in 1996 by Walter W. Buckley 3d, now 39, who is chief executive, and Kenneth A. Fox, 29, a director. Both were employed at Safeguard Scientifics, an information technology firm with an impressive record in starting technology companies; Safeguard is Internet Capital's largest shareholder, with a 14.3 percent stake.
Internet Capital's largest holding, Verticalnet, went public in February at $16 a share and is now at $32.4375. It has 47 industry-specific on-line sites for commerce.
A big advantage of business-to-business E-commerce is scale. "It's a higher-margin, higher-impact business," said Charles Finnie, managing director at Volpe Brown Whelan, the San Francisco investment bank that was a manager for the Verticalnet underwriting. A typical transaction, he noted, can be thousands of dollars, compared with, say, $15 for a book.
Internet Capital may have advantages in attracting start-ups. It has devoted 40 percent of its current budget to amassing in-house expertise to help such businesses get off the ground. Because it owns only part of its businesses, their entrepreneurs can keep big positions and share in future growth.
Still, some Web-stock investors have stayed on the sidelines, seeing that Internet Capital trades at more than 11 times analysts' estimates of net asset value. Moreover, management expects to incur operating losses for several years.
Jay Tracey, manager of the Oppenheimer Enterprise fund, does not own Internet Capital shares, saying the company's businesses -- some with little more than a trickle of revenue -- are just too young to evaluate. "I may not be giving them enough credit for the individual properties," he said, "but their companies are very early-stage."
Mr. Blodget, for his part, predicts the shares will reach $125 within two years, on his assumption that Internet Capital, through its stakes in its partner companies, will account for 1 to 3 percent of all business-to-business E-commerce.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Harlem on the Brink

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
THE year was 1919. It was a new beginning. The Great War was over, and 1,300 black soldiers received a heroes' welcome as they marched victoriously up Fifth Avenue and home to Harlem. Life was going to be different for black people in New York and everywhere. It was time for the black intelligentsia to be received in the parlors of New York's power brokers.
A few years later, in 1925, the curtain rose on the Harlem Renaissance. The explosion of cultural life on a small strip of upper Manhattan -- the Langston Hughes readings at the Harlem Y.M.C.A., the burlesque and jazz clubs shooting stars into the night sky, the novels of Countee Cullen and Zora Neale Hurston, the glamorous evening walks along the wide boulevards -- were just around the corner. 
 This renaissance was no accident, says David Levering Lewis, the author of "When Harlem Was in Vogue" (Penguin Books, 1997). It was created by half a dozen intellectuals who called on their peers to join them in Harlem, where a new movement of literature and art would be born.
Now a new cadre of men and women are summoning another generation to Harlem to join what they call the Second Renaissance, an economic one.
The plan has been strongly criticized -- as an outsiders' notion, a danger to Harlem's heritage, a tourist promotion -- but it is nothing if not ambitious.
"The call is out," said Terry C. Lane, an investment banker who recently moved to Harlem and became the president and chief executive of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a development corporation created by the Federal Government in 1994 to promote economic revitalization. "It comes from the booming economy. This community should not be left out of the boom the city, and the country, is experiencing."
The response is in. Central Harlem is being remade, literally and figuratively. On almost every street from 110th to 155th Street, Fifth Avenue to St. Nicholas Avenue, some development is under way. Vacant lots are being filled with new homes. Boarded-up and abandoned brownstones are being restored. Big companies -- the Gap, Disney, Time Warner -- are embracing once-deserted commercial strips. Once-redlined business districts are getting loans from Chase, Citibank and other banks. People who left the city for greener pastures decades ago are rediscovering Harlem's broad avenues, turn-of-the-century row houses, vibrant nocturnal culture and easy access to the rest of Manhattan.
"The scale of development in Harlem is remarkable, both because it has not happened in many years, but also in comparison with other low-income communities," said Mark A. Willis, who runs the community development program at Chase Manhattan Bank, which has invested $150 million in Harlem in the last three years. "I don't think any other city has anything quite on that scale." And the projections for the future sound even better.
In five years, there will be 15,000 more units of housing in Harlem than there were five years ago, said Carol Abrams, spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. Private investment in a score of major projects, more than $700 million in the next five years, is slated to create more than 10,000 jobs by 2005, says the Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency.
But though the plans are ambitious, the problems are huge. Harlem is still the most economically depressed section of Manhattan, by many measures. The citywide unemployment rate was 5.5 percent in 1996, but in central Harlem it was 9.8 percent. Central Harlem's median household income was $20,000, compared with $30,000 citywide. The home ownership rate is 10 percent, half the rate in Manhattan.
If there is to be another new beginning in Harlem, does it hold the promise of improving its prospects? Does it offer residents a shot at economic equality? Will increased lending lead to more local ownership and local leadership? Or, with such powerful corporate interests in their midst, will Harlemites lose control of their neighborhood?
Some wonder whether a new image will be consistent with Harlem's history. Some fear it could become a place its own residents do not recognize.
 
On the Street of Dreams, Dawn Brings Hopes and Fears
Barbara Askins, whose office is on 125th Street just down from the Apollo Theater, steps from behind her large desk and in crisp sentences lists the projects under way on that street. She sits in a chair that practically vibrates, so close is it to the heart of central Harlem. She is the president and chief executive of the 125th Street Business Improvement District, created by the city in 1993 to revive what was long known as "the street of dreams."
All day her phone rings with offers of business deals, inquiries from tour companies, questions about rentals and expressions of concern.
"The fears," she said, sighing. "Fear of big business coming in and taking over small business. The fear that 125th Street will start looking like Times Square. The fear that all the people will not look like the people of Harlem, that the Harlemites will be pushed out."
Asked if the fears are justified, she gazes out the window at a huge construction site across the street, where a 285,000-square-foot $66 million shopping plaza called Harlem U.S.A. is due to emerge by Christmas. It will house a Magic Johnson nine-screen multiplex, a Disney Store, an Old Navy and a branch of the New York Sports Club.
"It can become a reality," Ms. Askins said, answering somewhat indirectly. "But when you're in a growth period, everyone has to pick up the pace and get on the train and start heading to the destination."
The trouble is, no one knows what the destination will be. Despite years of meetings, negotiations and proposals, there is no single plan for Harlem. No central planning group has mapped out the neighborhood's future and discussed it with residents.
Nor, some say, could such an entity exist. Central Harlem is simply too large, with too many competing interests vying for control. Every level of government, Federal, state and city, is committing huge sums to development, as are development corporations, banks, housing organizations, local entrepreneurs and private investors, for a total of $900 million during the next five years.
So, while construction and economic development continues apace, everyone from Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who visited in July to encourage private investment, to the neighborhood shopkeeper eating fried chicken and waffles at Pan Pan's lunch counter at 135th Street and Lenox Avenue, is debating Harlem's fate.
 
From Hub to Emblem of Decay To an 'Urban Planner's Dream'
There may be no other section of New York whose name means so many things to so many people. It is one of the city's most popular tourist destinations, with its multilayered history part of the draw.
In the 18th century, it was a breezy summer getaway for wealthy city residents. In the late 19th century, it was home to Jewish and Irish immigrants escaping the tenements of the Lower East Side. From the 1920's through the Great Depression, it was a glittering magnet for writers, artists and performers, the hub of black America.
But during the next three decades it became an emblem of urban decay. By 1975, so much of the area had been abandoned by tenants and that 65 percent of all property in Harlem had fallen into the city's hands through abandonment and foreclosure.
The flight of middle-class residents, the crack epidemic and a seemingly endless stream of violent crimes made many shun what was left. Private investors and real estate developers could not be persuaded to take a chance on Harlem.
In 1977, Congress passed the Community Reinvestment Act, a law intended to halt redlining by requiring banks to lend in low-income areas.
Then, about 15 years ago, residents began to take stock. As the city prepared to auction off its property holdings in Harlem, Community Board 10, which covers central Harlem, intervened to stop the sale. Residents began to discuss their hopes for the neighborhood.
"We all sat down and we took blocks and lots and sat there and said, on this block we need a major tenant," said Ms. Askins of the 125th Street BID, who served on the community board then. "Because so much of the property here was in the hands of the city, it was like an urban planner's dream. It was wide open."
It wouldn't be wide open for long. Developers were starting to look at Harlem, too. Recognizing that the suburbs where corporations had long concentrated their energies were saturated with stores and services, companies were exploring low-income sections of America's cities.
Drew R. Greenwald, president of Grid Properties, one of the developers of Harlem U.S.A., said his group had begun looking at Harlem real estate in the mid-1980's because so much public and private investment was occurring there.
"The community looked different, people started to return," Mr. Greenwald said. "They tended to be professionals, and the median income doubled between 1980 and 1990. There were also a lot of immigrants in the community who had a higher earning potential."
That was good news for retailers. Before deciding on the Harlem U.S.A. project, Mr. Greenwald's company studied the area's income base and buying patterns. It found that the income density, the amount consumers earn in a certain area, is $868 million per square mile, twice that of most other sections of New York, because so many people live in close quarters. At the same time, the quality of life was improving, so retailers were feeling safer in Harlem, he said. One crucial indicator was crime rates. In the last five years, the homicide rate has dropped faster in Harlem (down 77 percent) than in the city as a whole (down 67 percent), the police say.
The flint intended to spark the fire was the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, which received $250 million in city, state and Federal money in 1994, along with a mandate: lend it all by 2004, to projects that would spur economic development. The organization has already allocated half the money, said the president, Terry C. Lane.
The new era, some say, began with a grocery store, not the most glamorous of projects but critical nonetheless. In April, Pathmark opened a $15 million 50,000-square-foot store at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue, the first major chain supermarket in Harlem in more than three decades.
Next came the groundbreaking for Harlem U.S.A., which has been trumpeted as the economic anchor that will hold the entire business district together. Neighborhood leaders say they expect the development to have a ripple effect.
Other developments are also expected to contribute. Time Warner has taken control of the board of the historic Apollo Theater and promises to revitalize it. The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has invested $271 million in renovating or building new homes and intends to invest $72 million more.
The Abyssinian Development Corporation, an arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and one of many local development groups with their own projects, is rehabilitating 33 brownstones in central Harlem.
Historic sites like the Art Deco Lenox Lounge and the Renaissance Ballroom are being restored or renovated.
Housing developments with ground-floor commercial space are under construction, including Strivers Gardens at 135th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard and the Renaissance Plaza at 116th Street and Lenox Avenue. On easternmost 125th Street, the Washburn Wire Factory will become East River Plaza, a shopping center with Manhattan's first Home Depot and Costco stores. Planning is under way for the Harlem Piers, a long-neglected stretch along the Hudson River.
All these projects are coordinated by partnerships in which the public sector typically subsidizes private development.
 
The Mystique Is There, But Whose Harlem Is It?
The ingredient that will sustain economic renewal in Harlem, Mr. Greenwald said, is the interest in the area. "The mystique was always there with Harlem, even in its decline," he said. "As it comes back, I think people are really going to be rooting for it, like a team that was the underdog for many years and is now winning."
But if the people of Harlem were the underdogs, are they now the winners? Some think not.
"The people who are benefiting now are the people who once abandoned Harlem," said Lloyd A. Williams, president and chief executive of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce and an outspoken critic of current plans. "They are the ones who turned it into slums. Those people are being encouraged now to come back and acquire properties, and they're getting a lot of tax breaks and subsidies to do it.
"The people who are benefiting are the external retailers who are being encouraged by the market, and who will take money out of the community. They are the people in the tourism industry who drive tourists through but they don't get off the bus. They are the elected officials who are standing for photo opportunities and ribbon cuttings. In the final analysis, it's not the average Harlemites who are benefiting."
If the market in Harlem is so promising, he asks, why do large corporations like Pathmark and the Gap need government subsidies? The reason, he suggests, is that the people making decisions -- city agencies, private housing developers, public-private partnerships -- have no permanent stake in Harlem. Whether black or white, whether recent arrivals or outsiders, most are not Harlemites, he said.
But who is a Harlemite? How long must one live in the neighborhood to qualify? Does a Harlemite have to be black? No, Mr. Williams said. But he said many of the people who are making decisions now only know three things about Harlem: 125th Street, Sylvia's Restaurant and the Apollo. "It's ignorance leading ignorance," he said.
Others say the issue is the image Harlem will project. There is much more to the identity of Harlem than those cultural touchstones, said Michael Henry Adams, a Harlem historian and preservationist, a fact that many of those directing the economic renaissance ignore. He is one of many residents unhappy with the new image.
"They're demolishing Harlem and putting up something that looks like a cross between Las Vegas and Paramus, N.J.," he said. "And if people come to Harlem to see Harlem, and it's not Harlem, they'll leave."
That concern is shared by Barbara Ann Teer, who founded the National Black Theater and this year helped organize the Harlem Strategic Cultural Collaborative, which includes the theater; the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Studio Museum. "If they are about conserving the culture, every time they mention Disney they should mention the National Black Theater," Dr. Teer said.
Her 31-year-old company, which owns a building at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue, has debts that could force it to close. Her organization has been promised support from the empowerment zone and elsewhere, but nothing has materialized. She watches unhappily as corporate enterprises arrive to considerable attention and support.
"You can go to Orlando and get Disney, you can go to Paris and get Disney," Dr. Teer said. "Why Harlem? It's a cultural war, and as far as I'm concerned, we don't have the resources to fight back."
Even Councilman Bill Perkins, who represents central Harlem and who has participated in his share of ribbon cuttings, has his doubts. Opening the blinds in his office in the State Office Building on 125th Street, once heralded as the anchor that would revitalize Harlem, he stares down at an empty shop at 125th and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. It used to be Freddy's, where in 1995 residents demonstrated to demand a boycott of stores run by outsiders.
Mr. Perkins says he wants to make sure that the people who stuck it out in Harlem through its long winter will be able to smell the flowers in its spring. It won't be easy.
"Historically, what's been missing in the legacy of Harlem is ownership," he said. "We live here, but we don't own it. There's a feeling that we've been here so long we should have a piece of it.
"Part of what you're seeing out here is very interesting and exciting, because probably now more than ever before, this community can be owned by the people who live here. But you're talking about an opportunity that is quickly disappearing. And money and power are not gifts. So the question is, will it happen?"

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
In Home Ownership Data, A Hidden Generation Gap

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
RISING home ownership is billed as one of the great rewards of America's economic boom. And so it is: The percentage of households that live in their own homes has never been greater. But examine that touted superlative closely, and these gilded years come into more sober focus.
Of the nation's 103 million households, 66.6 percent occupy homes owned by a member of the household. A chief ingredient of the American dream is on track, statistically. The breakthrough came early last year, when persistent home-buying everywhere in the country finally carried the home ownership rate past the old record of 65.8 percent, set in 1980. Households in every age group have gained ground since 1995, when the boom years really got rolling. 
 Go back only that far, and the economy has indeed lifted all boats, to invoke an overworked metaphor. But go back to the early 1980's and a less sanguine story emerges. Households headed by older Americans, it turns out, have carried the ball. Without them, there would be no record. In every age group under 55, home ownership remains below where it was in the early 1980's. Lifting all boats turns out to be the wrong metaphor; bailing them out is more appropriate.
"That is really the story of the 1990's in general," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. Most people "are still getting back to where they once were, and they are not back there yet."
For all who believe they see in the current prosperity a new era of greater well-being, history is a useful antidote -- in this case, the history of home ownership. It became widespread only after World War II, when a booming economy, rising incomes, plentiful jobs and the miracle of low-interest 30-year mortgages set off an explosion of suburban construction and home ownership.
THE people who are over 55 today bought in that era. Their parents had been renters more than owners, so, naturally, as the children have aged and have replaced their parents in the Census Bureau's statistics, the rate of home ownership among older Americans has risen smartly.
"They bought before the affordability crunch, and it is just gravy for them," said William Apgar, Assistant Secretary for housing at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Not so for today's under-55 generation. They got into home ownership in a big way starting in the mid-1970's, just as home prices and mortgage interest rates began to rise. Recession, rising unemployment and stagnant wages threw up more obstacles. By the early 1980's, the percentage of American households living in owner-occupied homes had peaked -- and then declined steadily for more than a decade.
Affordability was not the only issue. The proliferation of single-parent households contributed to the trend. So did the tendency toward later marriage. "The predisposition of nonmarried people is to rent," said Nancy McCardle, a research analyst at Harvard's Joint Center on Housing Studies. But affordability is the big issue. Even among married couples in the under-44 age group -- encompassing the most important home-buying years -- the rate of homeownership is not quite back to its 1982 level of 82 percent.
The trends are similar among minority groups. The home ownership rate among blacks, for example, has risen to 45.8 percent from 42 percent in 1993, a considerable increase. The Clinton Administration calls plenty of attention to this growth, whose time frame coincides with the Clinton Presidency. But black households have recovered only the ground lost since 1983, when the rate was 45.6 percent. Viewed historically, blacks are, like so many others, running in place.
Or behind the curve: Homeowners today are much more highly leveraged than 15 years ago. Then, a down payment equal to 15 percent of a home's price was common; now 5 percent or less is more the norm, even to qualify for Government-backed mortgages. "These are the best of times, but how can you reach out to more people when down-payments are already close to zero and both spouses are working and trying to earn all that they can," said Eric Belsky, executive director of the Harvard Center.
Low mortgage interest rates have contributed mightily to the revival in ownership, keeping homes affordable despite rising prices. Still, owning a home is increasingly a wedge separating low-income Americans from more prosperous households, even those only moderately better off. Among homeowners, the median household income (half earn more, half less) has risen to nearly $46,000, up 16 percent since 1982, after adjusting for inflation. Home ownership has lately become too expensive for those with less than $25,000 in annual income, many experts say. More than 30 percent of all households fall into that category.
Therein lies a problem for democracy. Study after study has shown that homeowners are much more active in their communities than renters. "Owning a home gets you rooted in a place," Mr. Jencks said. "You find yourself caring about the community, the politics, the schools, the appearance of your neighborhood. You go to more meetings and what happens at those meetings matters more. By and large, these are good things. They are the American way."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Robert E. Kern;
Fremont U.S. Micro-Cap Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
ON weekends, Robert E. Kern cultivates lima beans, beets and potatoes in the garden behind his country home in northeastern Pennsylvania. During the week in Manhattan, as portfolio manager of the $237.3 million Fremont U.S. Micro-Cap fund, he tills a different field: some of the smallest publicly traded companies.
While his agricultural endeavors have suffered from the extremes of this year's weather, his stock-picking has yielded a bumper crop. The fund was up 122.1 percent in the 12 months ended Sept. 17 and 56.3 percent in 1999 alone. 
 Longer term, Fremont U.S. Micro-Cap has returned 25.1 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Sept. 17, compared with 11.1 percent for its small-growth peers, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.
Mr. Kern, 63, credits the success of the fund -- advised by Fremont Investment Advisors, an affiliate of the giant Bechtel Corporation of San Francisco -- to a relentless focus on companies with new kinds of products, services or technology.
"Our investment philosophy is growth -- but importantly, within growth, a focus on innovative growth companies," he said from his midtown Manhattan office. "These are concentrated mostly in the economic sectors where the level of innovation is the highest -- in technology, health care, consumer and service companies."
In choosing stocks, he starts with 5,100 companies with market capitalizations of $10 million to $500 million, a traditionally volatile group. He whittles those down to fewer than 1,000 by screening for annual revenue growth of at least 20 percent. "We also like to see increasing profitability," he added.
Special attention is paid to gross profit margins. "High margins tell you if a company is able to price goods and services on a value-added basis, as opposed to commodity pricing," he said, "and how much money is left over for research and development, sales and marketing to enter new markets and expand existing markets."
He also scrutinizes the market prospects of companies' clients and customers. "If you find companies that serve other companies with very large potential markets, that certainly gives them the opportunity to grow at a very rapid rate," he said.
Mr. Kern says he is a firm believer in the old saw that the success of small companies is determined by their executives' mettle. He figures that he and his two senior investment managers (one of whom is his son, David, 35), along with the fund's two analysts, spend a quarter to a third of their time evaluating management.
"Especially in microcaps, which have limited resources, it's important to see how management is focusing on the best opportunities for future growth," he said.
To arrive at the 60 to 75 stocks that the fund usually holds, Mr. Kern distills figures like projected earnings growth and comes up with his most important number for a company -- its enterprise value, or what it would be worth to someone seeking to acquire it whole. He generally likes to buy stocks that are trading at some discount to enterprise value, but he declined to say how much of a discount.
HE likes Netopia, an Alameda, Calif., company that provides fast Internet access to small businesses over digital modems. These are marketed by local exchange carriers, the phone companies created to compete with the Baby Bells. Netopia also creates Web sites that can be customized by business owners. Company management shifted its focus several years ago to these two areas, "both of which we think are excellent," he said.
He bought shares in March at $20 each; Netopia closed on Friday at $33.625, or 67 percent of his estimate of its enterprise value. He expects Netopia's revenue in fiscal 1999 to be $42 million, a figure that he thinks could double in the next 12 to 18 months. Mr. Kern also thinks Netopia will post its first profit in the fourth quarter.
Another favorite is Photon Dynamics, a maker of equipment used to test flat-panel computer and TV screens. Production of flat-panel displays has risen sharply, Mr. Kern said, and Photon's sole competitor is a Japanese company. "I believe Photon will gain market share, especially in the rapidly growing Taiwan market, because of the advanced technology in its testing equipment," he said.
He bought shares of Photon, based in San Jose, Calif., at an average of $7 a share last fall. He projects annualized revenues of $50 million in the September quarter and a three-year annual earnings growth rate of 40 to 50 percent. The stock now trades at $19.875, or 57 percent of his estimate of enterprise value.
Mr. Kern began buying Adept Technology, also based in San Jose, at its 1996 initial public offering, only to sell the stock, at a profit, in the midst of the 1997-98 Asian economic crisis. The company makes robots used for materials handling and other industrial applications.
He bought Adept stock again late last year, at $7 a share. The stock closed on Friday at $7.625, or 38 percent of his estimate of enterprise value.
Adept has entered the business of making robots for the semiconductor equipment industry, doubling its potential market, Mr. Kern said. "We think there's an excellent opportunity for Adept to gain significant business, because of the increased demand for more reliable and higher-quality robots," he added. He figured that revenues could grow more than 20 percent annually over the next three years.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Formula Fight: A Generic Vs. the Giants

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
JENNA PAXTON is an educated consumer. Never, before last year, had she hesitated to toss a store-brand food into her shopping cart to shave her grocery bill. Like many Americans, she buys cheaper generic drugs instead of the brand names, too.
But during a routine trip last year down aisle 16A of an H.E.B. supermarket in Austin, Tex., she hesitated at buying a product she had never thought of before: generic infant formula.
The idea of saving $3 a can piqued her interest. Still, her first child, Aaron, had started out on Similac, the national brand known to generations of parents. And when her second son, Cameron, was born, she stayed loyal. 
 She studied the yellow label on the store-brand formula, Ms. Paxton remembered, and concluded that the ingredients were identical. Still wary, she bought a can and took it to the doctor's office where she is an administrative assistant. The doctor agreed that it appeared to contain the same ingredients as the name-brand formulas.
"I questioned it, most definitely," Ms. Paxton said. "But that was strictly because it was a brand I hadn't heard of before."
Few people have. Across the country, supermarkets and drug stores are just beginning to stock generic baby formulas. But the economics makes them promising. For retailers accustomed to selling brand-name formulas for little or no profit, the generics represent a potential cash cow. For new parents, they represent substantial savings.
Even so, Ms. Paxton is not the only one who is nervous. Pediatricians have fundamental concerns about lower-priced formula -- whether it will cost them industry-backed research funds, for example, or whether it will persuade more mothers to turn away from breast-feeding.
And the makers of brand-name formulas -- Enfamil, from the Mead Johnson Nutritionals unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb, is the market leader, followed by Similac, from the Ross Laboratories unit of Abbott Laboratories -- must worry about this latest threat to their business, which has been tarred by accusations of price-fixing and condemnations of the formula makers' exports to the developing world.
The formula makers have nurtured intense brand loyalty through aggressive giveaways to new parents and pediatricians, along with big rebates to state welfare programs. Their message is simple, if vague, and it can be found in doctors' offices everywhere, on leaflets like one distributed by Ross Laboratories: "All infant formulas are not the same."
In fact, though, the Food and Drug Administration requires that all formulas, including generics, meet the same rigid nutritional requirements and contain virtually identical ingredients. While the manufacturers are constantly tinkering, advances cannot be patented. So this seems like a marketplace ripe for an upstart that is ready to strip away the fancy marketing and sell formula for less.
That, indeed, is how the marketer of the yellow cans on Ms. Paxton's grocery store shelf presents himself. In 18 months, Paul B. Manning, 44, the founder of PBM Products in Gordonsville, Va., has made just a tiny dent in the $1.9 billion American retail market for formula: sales are running at $30 million a year. But Mr. Manning says that is just a start for his product, sold under store brands and under the names Babymil and Babysoy.
"Anything that has large barriers to entry or difficult markets -- if you're willing to put the effort in -- offers up the biggest opportunities," Mr. Manning said.
But the story is more complicated than the David-and-Goliath match of Mr. Manning's generics versus Similac and Enfamil, which still command 86 percent of the American market, according to A. C. Nielsen, a market research firm.
Cans of generic formula do not bear the name PBM Products. Instead, they name the manufacturer, Wyeth Nutritionals, a division of American Home Products, the global medical company that pulled out of the domestic formula business in 1996 but remains the second-ranked seller of formula worldwide.
After Wyeth withdrew from the American market, Mr. Manning offered to buy its factory. His plan was to keep SMA and Nursoy, Wyeth's flagship formulas, on the market as midpriced products and to introduce lower-priced powdered formula in generic packaging as well. Instead, Wyeth agreed to supply Mr. Manning in an arrangement that is for the moment exclusive.
Now, he must persuade pediatricians and family practitioners -- as well as parents -- that his no-name formula is good enough for America's infants. His plan is to take on the name brands directly.
"We're going to bring the message to the mothers," he said. "We really believe that parents will be shocked when they find out how overpriced Similac and Enfamil are."
 
'Scientific Parenting'
Introduced in the United States in 1911, infant formula became wildly popular in the 1930's and 40's as new mothers sought to raise their children by the methods prescribed in so-called scientific parenting manuals. By 1970, fewer than one-fourth of American infants were breast-fed, according to figures collected by Ross Laboratories that also counted as breast-fed any babies who received both formula and breast milk.
As early as 1952, however, the Journal of the American Medical Association published an article describing the health benefits of breast milk. By 1979, when a Carter Administration commission listed the promotion of breast-feeding as a national health goal, the breast-feeding rate had rebounded to 50 percent. It peaked at 62 percent in 1981 before starting another decline; the latest figure is 59.7 percent.
By 1981, the formula market was controlled by a handful of companies, and the economics of the market was distorted by the fact that the Federal Government was by far the biggest customer.
Half of all formula sold in the United States went to parents in the federally financed, state-administered Women, Infants and Children nutrition program, which distributes coupons to buy household basics in grocery stores, and which continued to subsidize formula use despite the Government policy in favor of breast-feeding. Starting in 1980, formula makers raised their prices 18 times in 13 years, for a total of 207 percent, court records later revealed -- almost three times the overall inflation rate.
The industry's troubles with the Government began in August 1986, when the Tennessee W.I.C. program asked the formula makers to cut their prices through rebates and other states followed quickly. Ross Laboratories and Mead Johnson offered rebates of around 20 cents a can. But Wyeth raised eyebrows with offers like one in Florida: a $1.01-a-can rebate on formula for which the state had been paying $1.28.
Such episodes led retailers -- joined in Florida by the state Attorney General -- to accuse the formula makers of antitrust violations in the early 1990's, contending that there was a secret scheme to raise prices in lockstep. Ross, Mead Johnson and Wyeth settled a series of lawsuits in 1992 and 1993, with the companies reportedly paying a total of $230 million but admitting no wrongdoing.
After the smoke of the lawsuits cleared, the General Accounting Office studied whether the companies were using price increases in the retail market to subsidize the W.I.C. rebates. In a 1998 report, the G.A.O. said that to subsidize the losses in W.I.C. sales, retail prices should have climbed four times as much as they did from 1989 to 1996. The fact that they did not persuaded the Government auditors that the formula business was already highly rewarding for the manufacturers.
"The wholesale prices of infant formula appear to be high in relation to the cost of production," the report concluded, "indicating the likelihood of high profit margins and the associated possibility of significant rebates."
Other critics of the industry say bluntly that the mark-up on formula was and is excessive. "Formula prices were ridiculously sky-high," said Kiran Saluja, chairman of a committee of the National Association of W.I.C. Directors, which promotes breast-feeding. "Basically, formula is cow's milk that you monkey around with a little bit."
Formula makers, of course, dispute that view. That "monkeying around" costs a lot of money, they say -- and makes formula much more digestible than cow's milk, or any other alternative to breast milk.
Asked if formula is overpriced, Peter J. Paradossi, a spokesman for Mead Johnson, replied, "We feel it's a bargain."
"It's three bucks a day," he said. "It's less than a Happy Meal. At no time during a baby's life can you feed a child all the nutrition it needs for that little."
 
A Generic Opportunity
Today, half of the infant formula business still consists of W.I.C. contracts, but the math has changed. For the companies, the welfare program has become a money-losing proposition, but one that guarantees shelf space and credibility. Plus, many parents veer in and out of the program; during periods when they pay cash, they often stick with whichever formula has been recommended by state health workers.
Mr. Manning, however, did a little math of his own and concluded that the economics were not as unfavorable as the big companies maintained. In effect, he found that a baby could be fed for less than the price of a small order of french fries, let alone a whole meal at McDonald's.
He knew the economic power of no-name products from 20 years of marketing generic prescription drugs through Able Labs, a South Plainfield, N.J., company that he sold for $20 million in 1992. Once a drug's patent expired, he could sell a generic equivalent for a tiny fraction of the brand-name product's price, and still make a tidy profit.
And the formula business, he quickly learned, was even more attractive, with no patents to worry about, plenty of manufacturing capacity in the form of Wyeth's factories -- and a ready customer base.
"The retailers in the United States had really wanted someone to introduce a formula," Mr. Manning said.
Here is why: The national brands sell for $8.99 to $11.99 for a 16-ounce can, usually just a few pennies above the grocers' wholesale cost, which varies widely. Mr. Manning's generic formula sells at retail for $6.58 to $7.99, with a wholesale price that hovers around $6. When parents buy the generic formula, they save money -- and the stores earn bigger profits.
Why the huge difference in wholesale prices? According to Mr. Manning, it represents selling and administrative expenses -- not, as his larger competitors would have it, research and development costs. "We don't have 500 sales people out selling to pediatricians," he said.
Yet retailers say that, despite the savings, customers have been slow to embrace Mr. Manning's product. "It didn't respond as quickly as we thought it was going to," said Kari Caruso, brand manager for Albertsons, the Boise, Idaho-based grocery chain that began selling PBM's products in 1997. "I think it's a category that's going to take a long process of educating new moms."
In marketers' parlance, "educating" is a form of selling. With generic formula, that means stores using brochures and newspaper advertisements to inform customers that, as far as nutrition is concerned, all infant formulas are the same. (Other major retailers that sell generic formula include A & P, Safeway, Vons, Finast, Tom Thumb, Copps and Wegman's Food Market.)
But the market leaders have spent decades building their ties to pediatricians and new parents -- and building the mystique of their brands. The formula makers rely mainly on "ethical marketing," a concept that includes maintaining Web sites and phone lines to answer parents' questions, sponsoring seminars and conferences for pediatricians and showering doctors and new parents with gifts.
"We do promote our products primarily through the health care professionals," Roland Tuley, a spokesman for Mead Johnson, said. "Sales reps call on pediatricians. They're out there in those offices every day." And it is a two-way street, he said, since physicians' counsel helps in development of improved formulas.
In the last few years, the companies have begun advertising in parenting magazines and on TV following a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit that led to a somewhat paradoxical 1993 agreement. While formula makers -- in this case, Ross, Mead Johnson and Wyeth -- did not admit to having conspired to ban consumer advertising in the past, they pledged that they would not conspire to avoid advertising in the future.
In any event, many families are loyal to Similac or Enfamil for generations. And while the companies are careful to chant the pediatricians' mantra -- that breast milk is best -- they routinely send new mothers home from the hospital with diaper bags filled with cans of formula.
Mr. Manning's enterprise turns on the belief that when those diaper bags are empty and new parents go to the grocery store, the price of his product will catch their eye. So PBM is advertising in parenting magazines, too.
He also expects that nervous parents will, like Ms. Paxton, take the product to their pediatricians. That is why Mr. Manning will be at the American Academy of Pediatricians conference next month in Washington.
"Their stronghold is the pediatric office," Mr. Manning said of his competition. "We're going to hit the pediatricians hard." Not with 500 sales people, but with ads in medical journals and meetings with doctors.
 
For Doctors, Familiar Worries
All of this troubles some doctors, who believe that breast-feeding faces more than enough competition already. Pediatricians want parents to consult with them on infant nutrition, and they fear that developments like the big companies' television ads and formula marketed on the basis of price make parents feel more confident in making those decisions alone.
Doctors also worry that the rise of generic formulas could deplete funds for research. Formula studies are performed by the manufacturers internally and through grants to doctors, hospitals and the American Academy of Pediatricians.
"Marketing of generic formulas will drive the cost of formula down," said Dr. Michael Georgieff, a professor of pediatrics and child development at the University of Minnesota. "There will be no incentive for research and design."
So far, that has not been the case. Last year, Abbott, Mead Johnson and Wyeth all augmented their formulas with nucleotides, the molecules that compose nucleic acids like DNA and that are found in breast milk. Mead Johnson takes credit for that innovation. So does Abbott. On behalf of his supplier, Wyeth, so does Mr. Manning, who adds that worries about generics cutting into research dollars are unfounded.
"That's the same comment the pharmaceutical companies made back in the 80's," he said. "It's a great thing to tell the pediatricians -- 'we won't have money to do research and development.' It's absolutely not true."
Perhaps the most significant worry is that if Mr. Manning's generic formula is a big success, brand-name formula makers will have less revenue to subsidize the development of special products for babies with various disorders that prevent them from digesting standard formulas.
Abbott sells 23 different special formulas -- like Phenex, for babies with phenylketonuria, a metabolic disorder found in one of every 10,000 births that keeps infants from absorbing the amino acid phenylalinine. Mead Johnson markets 25 varieties.
While many doctors agree that there is no difference -- other than price -- among the basic versions of Similac, Enfamil and Babymil for a healthy child like Ms. Paxton's son, the generic formula comes in only two varieties, milk-based and soy-based.
"God forbid should you have a child who can't digest protein," said Bill Wolfson, spokesman for Ross Laboratories. "You can't go to generic companies for help."
Mr. Manning said he was considering sales of generic versions of specialized formulas from Wyeth, which makes five varieties for sale outside the United States. While there is little profit in it, he said, he will provide the specialized products if retailers ask for them.
Mr. Manning's road to riches is bound to be bumpy. Wyeth concluded that it could not compete in the formula business in the United States. Nestle, bigger yet, has been able to win only a tenth of the American retail market for its Carnation-brand formulas after a decade of trying.
But he is prepared to be patient. After all, this is a man who, when he was in the generic drug business, set up a lawn chair in the F.D.A.'s lobby to wait out approval of a medication. Now, Mr. Manning says that for him to score big, his giant competitors just need to keep doing business the way they always have.
"Abbott made the opportunity," he said. "It's truly an unbelievable situation."

HEADLINE: The World;
Getting Tough Gets Tough for Australia

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
FOR more than two decades, Australia has been trying to promote itself as part of Asia. Now, in East Timor, it has found out how unnerving that concept can be when put to the test.
Having led the charge to intervene and having taken command of the international peace keeping force in East Timor, this easy-going, underpopulated, high-living country is having to ponder the cost. Three questions seem to be on everyone's mind: 
 How can Australia intervene in East Timor, even with the reluctant acquiescence of the Indonesian Government, and still maintain friendly relations with Indonesia, its closest Asian neighbor?
How much can Australia still depend on the United States, its big brother ally of the last 50 years, having seen Washington send only a token force to help out in East Timor?
And now that Washington has deputized it to do the neighborhood policing job, does Australia have the political and financial wherewithal to follow through on its own?
For Australia, which has an army of only 24,000 soldiers -- about the same number the Indonesian Army had in East Timor alone -- these are milestone questions.
Sure, Australia sent soldiers to the battlefields of World War II, to Korea and Vietnam and lately to the Persian Gulf war. But those soldiers were dispatched with alacrity, with everyone understanding that the post-1945 commitments were an investment in an alliance that the United States was leading. This time, Australia is carrying the big burden.
Since the early 1970's, when Australia lifted a so-called White Australia policy that had strictly limited Asian immigration, successive Governments have tried to position Australia to be with Asia rather than against it, if always under the umbrella of American security.
In particular, Australia cozied up to Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation and its closest neighbor. In 1975, it ignored the East Timor independence movement and instead endorsed the Indonesian takeover of the territory after the Portuguese colonial government left. That made Australia the only country to formally recognize the invasion, although the United States, which also favored Indonesia's anti-Communist Government, did not object.
Then, with the idea of building its own strategic solidarity with Indonesia, the Australian Government went on to help train the Indonesian Army, including -- to its current embarrassment -- some of its feared security forces. In 1995, Australia thought it was cementing its ties by signing a defense treaty with Jakarta.
BUT there was a problem with the East Timor policy all along, and it became apparent as complaints of Indonesian brutality there persisted. Australians, who tend to sympathize with underdogs anyway, have long had a special sympathy for the East Timorese, who in World War II helped Australian soldiers trapped in Timor's mountains during the fight against the Japanese. Moreover, the East Timorese, most of whom are Roman Catholic, have forged strong bonds with the Catholic Church in Australia.
So after Indonesia's longtime dictator, Suharto, was forced from office by popular upheaval last year, Australia's conservative Prime Minister, John Howard, wrote to the new Indonesian leader, B. J. Habibie, and suggested that Indonesia sponsor a referendum for East Timor's autonomy.
The Howard Government was surprised when Mr. Habibie went a step further and decided to hold a referendum for independence, which many in the West, including the Australian Defense Ministry, believed would lead to bloodshed.
But the Australians and the United States held their breaths and hoped for the best, even when the Indonesians refused to accept a peacekeeping force in East Timor during the preparations for the ballot.
Then, after the referendum produced a landslide for independence, the Australian Government was taken aback by the killings of civilians and the scorched earth tactics of the Indonesian Army and militias.
But when the Australians decided to get tough, they were also taken aback by Washington.
Mr. Howard said Australia could not stand by as East Timor burned, and he said American troops should operate alongside Australians in East Timor. What he heard in response was sobering. "If you thought the Pentagon was not keen to go to Kosovo, you should have seen their reaction to going to East Timor," said one Australian official.
The American national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, went so far as to point out publicly that the United States had fought in Kosovo because it was in Europe "I think we have to recognize that Indonesia is in Asia," he said. So Washington has committed just 200 troops for the operation, most of them for logistics, and only 100 for East Timor itself. It was hardly the commitment Australia had in mind.
An optimist might find a good side to this. Australia won points in Washington because it was setting a precedent that was comfortable for the Americans: It was leading a regional peacekeeping force, sent in harmony with American policy, that did not require the use of American muscle itself. That contrasts with the reluctance of Britain and France to commit troops to Balkan peacekeeping operations unless Americans were alongside on the ground.
"Unlike the Europeans, who were reluctant to go into Kosovo, the Australians showed themselves to be adults and to take part in adult supervision," said Douglas Paal, a member of the Bush Administration's National Security Council who now heads the Asia Pacific Policy Center, a Washington research institute. "The Australians were not waiting for Uncle Sam. That's the kind of alliance partners we want."
FROM the Australian point of view, such praise was small consolation, and the slow and small response of the United States felt more like a coming-of-age lesson. After World War II, Australians turned away from Britain and toward the United States as their new natural ally in the Pacific. Washington put defense and intelligence installations in Australia and the two countries exchanged sensitive information freely. The conventional wisdom here was that similar values of democracy, free enterprise and a sunny optimism bonded the Australians and the Americans.
Actually, they do. But now Australians have been told, in effect, that the bond is not a free one. With defense spending at the equivalent of less than $10 billion -- only 1.8 percent of the gross domestic product -- the commitment to East Timor of 2,000 soldiers -- to rise to 4,500 in coming weeks --- is more than the current military budget can bear, Australia's preeminent defense analyst, Paul Dibbs, said. Last week, Australia started to call up reservists.
But the biggest cost of the East Timor commitment for Australia will likely be its long-fostered relationship with Indonesia. It is now in tatters. During the recent crisis, Mr. Habibie refused to take a telephone call from Mr. Howard and last week the Indonesian Government scrapped the defense treaty. Australian businesses have become targets for vandals in Indonesia.
As for the relationship with Washington, the ties will no doubt endure, but not with the same open-hearted enthusiasm from Down Under. Max Walsh, the editor in chief of The Bulletin, a weekly news magazine in Australia, wrote last week: "Timor has changed our world."
