HEADLINE: The Nation: Diagnosing Al Gore's Problem;
You May or May Not Have Clinton Fatigue

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON made an extraordinary confession at an intimate dinner with a handful of his biggest fund-raisers at the Hay Adams Hotel across from the White House last week: The American people are tired of him and of his Administration.
Sounding more like an outsider seeking the White House than a fixture there for seven years, Mr. Clinton asked rhetorically: "Do we need a change? The answer is, yes we do." 
 Mr. Clinton was making a case for the elevation of his Vice President, Al Gore. But in doing so, he broached a notion articulated mostly by Republicans, but also by Democrats, that a "Clinton fatigue" has infected American politics. And while Mr. Clinton did not use the phrase itself, he might as well have when he explained the "great challenge" for Mr. Gore: "People think at election time they're supposed to vote for change."
Clinton fatigue is essentially a catch-all to describe a general sense that people have had enough of Bill Clinton. It was bound to happen. He has pulled the public through an excruciating journey of scandals. The most distasteful was the Monica Lewinsky matter, of course, but new ones seem to keep cropping up all the time: The fracas over Puerto Rican terrorists one day; the Russian money-laundering imbroglio the next.
With the explosion of 24-hour news on television and the Internet, Mr. Clinton has been more in the face of Americans than any of his predecessors. The Clintons, still craving the spotlight, do not seem to have learned the oldest trick in show business: Always leave them wanting more. Hillary Rodham Clinton's expected run for Senate from New York will keep the Clinton act on stage even longer.
"The history of this century shows this is really a unique phenomenon," said Michael Beschloss, the Presidential historian. "You have both the disquietude of the President in office plus the added element of him having been there all those years." He contended that while people would be uneasy about a third Clinton term, if he were allowed to run again, they would not have had such qualms with other two-term Presidents.
"There was no Eisenhower fatigue in 1960," Mr. Beschloss said. "He would have been elected to a third term by a huge landslide." Ronald Reagan might have been elected to a third term as well; many Republicans said they viewed President George Bush's tenure as the third term of the Reagan Administration.
OTHER modern Presidents were not as popular, perhaps not so much because of general fatigue but because of catastrophic events that undermined their Presidencies. President Lyndon B. Johnson, unable to climb out of the Vietnam War, did not dare seek re-election. President Richard M. Nixon did, but was soon forced from office by Watergate. Jimmy Carter was the beneficiary of Watergate fatigue, but could not survive the malaise of a foul economy and the Iranian hostage crisis when the sunnier Mr. Reagan came along.
Republicans are delighting in their diagnosis of Clinton fatigue. Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas said former Senator Bill Bradley has crept up on Mr. Gore in polls in some states because "he doesn't have the baggage of the Clinton Presidency around his neck."
Yet the ferment about fatigue may be overblown, stirred up by a restless press and pundits longing to begin the millennium with a fresh Presidential story line instead of what has seemed the inevitable faceoff between Mr. Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. In addition, critics of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore may find it easy to lump the Administration's troubles under the "fatigue" umbrella -- and try to drag Mr. Gore down with them.
Not surprisingly, Fred Steeper, the pollster for Governor Bush, the Republican front-runner, said: "Fatigue is too weak a concept to fit the public attitudes about the White House. I call it Clinton disgust."
Not every voter may be so disgusted. Polls show evidence of a Clinton fatigue, but one that is not particularly potent. Mr. Clinton's robust job approval ratings have barely budged.
And it is not entirely clear that Clinton fatigue is ailing Mr. Gore. In a Washington Post/ABC News Poll this month, 53 percent of respondents said they were "plain tired" of Mr. Clinton, but 45 percent disagreed with that statement. Respondents were evenly split over whether Mr. Gore was too close to the President "to provide the fresh start the country needs."
THE truth is, Mr. Gore may not be electrifying Democrats for reasons that have nothing to do with Mr. Clinton. It has always been a struggle for anyone in a President's shadow to develop a distinct persona early in a campaign.
And, as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said in his endorsement of Mr. Bradley last week, "We'd have to go back to Van Buren to find a Vice President who succeeded to the Presidency." He corrected himself after audience members reminded him that George Bush suceeded Ronald Reagan. Still, that is two Vice Presidents elected to succeed a President since 1836.
Asked about Clinton fatigue, Frank Newport, editor-in-chief of the Gallup Organization, said: "I scratch my head. It's an easy phrase to use. But I'm inclined to look more at the candidate, that Gore is doing poorly because of Gore."
Michael D. McCurry, Mr. Clinton's former press secretary, rejects the concept of Clinton fatigue because, he argued, the public is too disengaged to be fatigued.
"I don't understand how, suddenly, people have turned a switch in their head and said, 'I'm tired of Bill Clinton,' " he said. "They've spent seven years with this President. He's not in their face because most people are checked out."
Indeed, the characteristics that people say trouble them about Mr. Clinton -- notably his morals -- do not trouble them about Mr. Gore. Just the same, voters do not give Mr. Gore much credit for what people see as Mr. Clinton's accomplishments, like prosperity.
The fatigue factor is so tough to gauge that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore seem uncertain how to grapple with it. Mr. Gore is constantly recasting his relationship with Mr. Clinton. First he played loyal lieutenant, boasting about Clinton-Gore accomplishments. Then he stopped even mentioning Mr. Clinton by name. Then he bluntly condemned the President for personal transgressions. (Cynics suspects that that was a ploy hatched with a White House wink to allow Mr. Gore to break out on his own.)
Over the course of one day last week, Mr. Gore seemed to shift his pitch several times. At one point, he criticized his Administration's performance, saying, "I'm not satisfied." Later in the evening, at an event with the President, he softened, saying, "We've been doing a lot of things right, but it is time to start a wave of change in this nation."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore should not necessarily take personally the cries of fatigue. "You can only imagine what the Roosevelt fatigue was like!" said James Carville, an architect of Mr. Clinton's campaign in 1992, recalling the 12-year tenure of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
In the case of F.D.R., Mr. Gore can take comfort, for voters, far from fickle, chose continuity over a fresh face: Taking on Mr. Roosevelt in 1944, Thomas E. Dewey assailed the three-term incumbent for surrounding himself with "tired old men in Washington." But a tired old man won re-election.

HEADLINE: The World: Democracy in Turkey;
A Groundswell for More Human Rights

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL

 BODY:
WHEN Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey meets with President Clinton and Congressional leaders in Washington this week, there will be much talk about earthquake relief, geopolitics, and obscure though important matters like trade arbitration and oil pipeline routes. But on Capitol Hill and elsewhere in the United States, those matters pale into insignificance. There the great question is at once simpler and more complex: How democratic is Turkey?
To the extent that Americans think about Turkey, this is the question they most want answered. They want Turkey to stop jailing people for giving speeches or writing articles, and to grant its citizens the level of freedom enjoyed by most Americans and Europeans. Otherwise, no matter how much progress is made on international issues, Americans will continue to group Turkey with Peru, Malaysia, Belarus, Zimbabwe and other quasi-democracies where human rights have been pushed aside in favor of what ruling autocrats consider issues of national security. 
 Turkey has built a vibrant economy, given equality to women and created a remarkably open society. Yet precisely because the nation is so Western-oriented, its people have become impatient for full Western-style democracy.
Turkish military commanders still enjoy the right of veto over important Government decisions. A highly conservative political elite enforces laws that restrict free expression and other civil rights. Nonetheless, Prime Minister Ecevit and his aides come to Washington with a relatively good human rights story to tell. "They clearly have more to show in terms of actions, laws, decrees and actual shifts on the ground than any other recent Government of Turkey,"' said one Clinton Administration official.
GOVERNMENT-SPONSORED assassins who terrorized the mostly Kurdish provinces of southeastern Turkey for years seem to have packed their guns away. Radio stations there are now allowed to play Kurdish music. The Parliament has approved a repentance law for Kurdish rebels, albeit a highly limited one. In Turkish prisons, according to Sir Nigel Rodley, a United Nations investigator, there has been "a reduction in the incidence of the more brutal forms of torture."
That statement reflects Turkey's dilemma. Its human rights record, not just regarding torture but in all important areas, is better than it has been in years. But it still falls short of what the West considers to be minimum standards.
These days, the greatest pressure for improvement in Turkey's human rights climate comes not from Washington or European capitals, but from within Turkey itself. Millions of Turks, many of them outraged by the state's failure to react effectively to last month's earthquake, have begun demanding sweeping reforms and the repeal of laws that restrict democracy. Even some senior politicians have joined the chorus.
"Turkey understands more clearly than ever how urgent it is for us to create a civil society built on democracy and social justice," said Mehmet Ali Irtemcelik, a cabinet minister responsible for human rights and relations with Europe. "We must bring our country to the level of modern civilization."
Although these views are widely shared, many powerful figures still resist them. This week, President Clinton will probably encourage Mr. Ecevit to embrace the reform movement and overrule those, including military commanders and senior members of his own coalition Government, who fear its consequences.
This autumn will be full of challenges for Turkey. In November the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which places human rights at the top of its agenda, will hold a summit in Istanbul. A month later the European Union, which has also looked skeptically at Turkey's human rights record, will decide whether to make the nation an official candidate for membership.
Mr. Ecevit is acutely aware that the world is watching to see how he deals with a handful of high-profile human rights cases. Foreigners, along with millions of Turks, will be thrilled if final decisions are made to punish police officers who tortured teen-age prisoners in Manisa in 1995, others who beat the journalist Metin Goktepe to death in 1996, and prison guards who killed 10 Kurdish prisoners in Diyarbakir following a riot that same year.
This month one of Turkey's best-known prisoners, the pro-Kurdish sociologist Ismail Besikci, was released from prison. He was warned that he would be sent back to prison if he again violates laws against publishing subversive opinions, but his release was nonetheless welcomed by human rights advocates.
Other prisoners whose cases have attracted worldwide attention include Akin Birdal, head of the country's largest human rights group; Leyla Zana, a Kurd who is a former member of Parliament and whose supporters in Europe and the United States have made her probably the most famous Turkish citizen in the world, and the blind lawyer Esber Yagmurdereli, who has been convicted of supporting terrorism on the basis of evidence that human rights groups say was fabricated. Mr. Yagmurdereli has spent 16 of his 54 years in prison.
"I agree that the human rights situation in Turkey is improving," he said in a telephone interview from prison. "It's the result of several factors, including a lull in the Kurdish war, improved relations with the European Union, and the better climate that has followed the earthquake. But in truly democratic countries, people are guaranteed basic freedoms. That still isn't the case here."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
Small Companies, Big Donations

 BODY:
It may take a huge fortune to make a national splash in philanthropy, as Bill Gates has done lately with his $17 billion foundation.
But as the booming economy produces a bumper crop of new millionaires and successful small businesses, a big growth story in American charitable donations is being played out away from the spotlight. 
 Small business is where the growth is in companies' giving, according to "Give and Take: A Candid Account of Corporate Philanthropy," by Reynold Levy (Harvard Business School Press, 1999). And millionaires, not billionaires, are often unrecognized sources of the new contributions, says Mr. Levy, a former president of the AT&T Foundation who is now chief executive of the International Rescue Committee, an organization that assists refugees.
He says much small-business giving is "obligation-based" -- going to community organizations that expect local businesses to donate. But as small companies mature, the personal values of the entrepreneurs who run them increasingly come into play, inspiring support for causes that are close to these owners' hearts.
The more impassioned giving, Mr. Levy said, is springing from "something very much in the American culture -- a very strong impulse to helping others."
The proliferation of millionaires with maturing businesses suggests that charitable organizations would be wise to get to know as many entrepreneurs as they can.

HEADLINE: India's Election Marathon Lumbers Into Final Week

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 25

 BODY:
As India lumbers into the fourth and final week of marathon national elections, elephants bearing ballot boxes tramp into dense forests and ponies carrying election officials clop their way to dizzying heights in the Himalayas, all to make sure that every citizen -- no matter how remote -- gets a chance to vote.
The fourth stage of voting is today. By the time the last vote is cast in the fifth and final round next Sunday and the last indelible ink stain has been swabbed on the last voter's finger, as many as 6 out of every 10 adult Indians who are not crazy or criminal -- more than 350 million people -- will have exercised their franchise, election officials say. 
 If exit polls and political analysts are to be believed, the kaleidoscope of Indian politics will then settle into a pattern that is similar to the last coalition Government, though different in certain crucial respects.
The Hindu nationalist-led alliance will most likely still be in power, but probably backed this time by a more powerful collection of 23 parties and probably commanding a stronger majority than it did in April before it lost the confidence of Parliament by a single vote.
Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, 73, seems certain to head the new Government, as he did the old for the past year and a half, and will hope to have consolidated his position as the undisputed centrist leader of the coalition, the only man who can hold its disparate parts together.
The exit polls differ over the size of the coalition's margin of victory -- a margin crucial to determining how forcefully the alliance can govern. In its last incarnation, the coalition's majority was so thin that even the smallest parties had the power to threaten its demise by withdrawing. Much of Mr. Vajpayee's energy was consumed by the dispiriting job of placating mercurial, petulant allies.
Some analysts and Western diplomats believe that a resounding victory this time would give the Government more room to take politically risky steps. On the domestic front, it could move more aggressively, for example, to shut down money-losing state enterprises and encourage foreign investment. In foreign policy, it would have more leeway to reopen talks with Pakistan, sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and improve relations with the United States on trade and security issues.
But most agree that even gaining a big majority would not free Mr. Vajpayee's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, the largest partner in the coalition, to pursue its religiously divisive agenda, which includes building a Hindu temple on the site of a destroyed mosque and subordinating Muslim personal law to India's civil code.
The party will still be dependent on regional allies -- for example the Telugu Desam Party in southern Andhra Pradesh -- that count on the votes of Muslims, are committed to secularism and would almost certainly quit the coalition if the more vociferous Hindu nationalists were given free rein.
The factors underlying the coalition's apparent electoral gains are various. The soaring price of vegetables that had led to such disastrous results for the Hindu nationalists in state elections last November have come down. In fact, inflation, a potent political issue here, is low.
Industrial growth is on the upswing and this season's normal monsoon will help insure that agricultural production in this predominantly rural nation is strong.
Much attention has been lavished on Mr. Vajpayee's deft diplomatic handling of a small war in Kashmir that ended with India repelling Pakistani-backed forces from its territory, and that victory does seem to have burnished his popularity.
But in travels to villages and cities in southern, western and northern India, voters almost never raised the Kashmir conflict as a decisive issue. Usually, they were motivated by local, bread-and-butter issues or the interests of their own caste or religious group -- and often saying that they would support regional or caste-based political parties.
The days of one-party rule under the Congress Party are long gone. It is the Bharatiya Janata Party that has wholeheartedly embraced the necessity of building a coalition and sharing power with its partners in New Delhi.
"The B.J.P. has tied up with more heavy-weight regional allies in state after state," said E. Sridharan, a political analyst at the University of Pennsylvania Institute for the Advanced Study of India, based here. "That is a huge strategic advantage."
The Congress Party, led by Sonia Gandhi, the widowed, Italian-born heir to the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty, has continued to organize its campaign around the notion that it is the natural party of governance and the only force that can provide political stability, while minimizing the need for allies. But that position is increasingly implausible.
The Congress Party itself has been weakened internally by disputes over the foreign origins of Mrs. Gandhi, 52. Sharad Pawar, the party's chief power broker in the large state of Maharashtra, left the party earlier this year over that issue and set up a new party that has significantly weakened Congress in a state where it would otherwise have made substantial gains.
The regional and caste-based parties that have proliferated in India over the past decade or two -- -- some of whom had joined with leftists to form a third political force are now increasingly allying themselves with either the Bharatiya Janata Party or the Congress Party as the best hope of winning a share of power at the national level.
"The regional parties have realized that they can share in power only through alliance with one of the two major party blocs," said D. L. Sheth, a political sociologist at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies in New Delhi. "This is a multiethnic, diverse society and it expresses itself through coalitions."

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton's Listening Tour Now Evolving Into Senate Campaign

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 25

 BODY:
In a pair of trial runs at a stump speech, Hillary Rodham Clinton sounded out the themes of her expected campaign for the United States Senate today, listing the weak upstate economy, affordable health care, education, the environment, Social Security and gun control as the most important issues facing New York.
So far, Mrs. Clinton has done more listening than talking on her visits to the state, often taking positions only when prodded by reporters. 
 But today she gave a spirited run-through of her agenda to welcoming audiences, first at a fund-raising breakfast for the Schenectady County Democratic Committee and then at a labor union rally in Albany. She also made some of her most overtly partisan remarks of the year, assailing Republicans in Congress for passing a tax cut that she said put social programs at risk, and for blocking an increase in the minimum wage.
While she offered no surprises and few specifics, her remarks showed the continuing evolution over this year from an exploratory effort propelled largely by her name recognition and the sheer oddity of a First Lady running for office, toward a full-fledged campaign next year and the attendant need to build a platform that will appeal to a broad cross-section of voters.
Speaking to about 300 people at the Schenectady Museum, in this faded industrial city, Mrs. Clinton spoke at length of the need to revive the anemic upstate economy and stem the migration of people from the region. "If upstate New York were a separate state, it would rank 49th in job creation and income growth," she said.
Turning to the social policy issues with which she has been most closely identified, she touched on support for education, and pledged, "We will figure out a way to provide quality, affordable health care to every American."
She took a swipe at Congressional Republicans' bid to cut taxes by nearly $800 billion over 10 years, a bill that is supported by her likely Republican opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and that was vetoed by her husband, President Clinton.
"We need to use the budget surplus that has been created by the good policies of this Democratic Administration to make sure that Social Security and Medicare are on stable financial ground into the next century," she said. "Are we going to be responsible or are we going to go for the short-term, quick-fix political gimmick? Well, I was very proud of my husband when he vetoed that short-term, quick-fix political gimmick."
Howard Wolfson, Mrs. Clinton's campaign spokesman, said her remarks were as close as she had come yet to making what will become her standard stump speech. "Those are the themes being road-tested right there," he said.
At a rally attended by a few thousand cheering union members in a park in Albany, Mrs. Clinton focused on issues dear to organized labor, including her support for raising the minimum wage.
"I believe with all my heart that no working American who goes to work 40 hours a week, who is there being a responsible worker and citizen, that no working American should live in poverty," she said.
She noted that the Republican leadership in Congress had recently blocked a vote on a minimum wage increase. And, with an implicit dig at Mr. Giuliani, who has declined to state a position on the issue, she added, "It is wrong, and we should take a stand."
Through several public appearances today, Mrs. Clinton did not take questions from reporters, who were unable to ask her about the two most recent controversies involving Mr. Giuliani: his threat to block funds for the Brooklyn Museum of Art because of its scheduled exhibition of controversial art works, and his administration's plan to cull Medicaid records of welfare applicants to find those who have been treated for substance abuse and insist that they receive continued treatment in return for welfare benefits. She did not raise either subject.
Mr. Giuliani did not make any public appearances today.
But Mrs. Clinton did edge closer than ever to confirming what has, for months, seemed evident: that she will formally become a candidate for the seat being vacated by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat. "I haven't announced anything," she said, "but I'm leaning so far toward running that I'd fall over if I leaned any further."

HEADLINE: Buchanan's Sister Shepherds Insurgent Race

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Bay Buchanan sighed a bit in admitting that her brother Patrick, the quixotic Presidential candidate, was essentially a man without a party.
"We are in no man's land," said Ms. Buchanan, who sounded, however, far from forlorn at the risks and opportunities as her brother considered casting aside a lifetime of Republican labors to switch his Presidential candidacy to the Reform Party. 
 "We are in political limbo," said Ms. Buchanan, a lean and avid political operative clearly relishing the long odds as she plays chief strategist, fiery alter ego and grass-roots shepherd for her brother in his threatened party switch.
"I can't ask people to give him money," she said in an interview at her brother's campaign headquarters this week. "I can't build a staff until we know where he's running. It's a very delicate time."
In this time, with no formal hustings to welcome him, Mr. Buchanan has been publicizing a new book, "A Republic, Not an Empire" (Regnery Publishing), and teasing out the party-switching question in a dozen broadcast interviews a day. He is well into one of his signature "America First" controversies over his views in the book of Hitler and World War II -- just the sort of verbal fisticuffs that assure both Buchanans that the rebel fire is returning to their quest.
But the harder work in the political trenches has fallen to Ms. Buchanan as she telephones Reform Party officials to make the necessary overtures and to master the arcane procedures for getting on dozens of state ballots.
In their parallel efforts, the Buchanans are far from sibling rivals. They are respected even by their critics as a classic inside-outside political team practiced in the art of insurgent mischief. And Ms. Buchanan, while a familiar sight on the cable-television political circuit, has returned to her strong suit behind the scenes as campaign manager.
"I am now feeling knowledgeable about the Reform Party system," she said, hardly discouraging the likelihood of the Buchanans' defection from the Republican Party, about which they have promised a decision by mid-October. "Technically, I will be able to tell Pat that it can be done and I would be able to raise the money."
Battle-hardened from running the fractious Buchanan Presidential campaigns in 1992 and 1996 against the Republican Establishment, Ms. Buchanan sounds almost enchanted that, after months of her brother's barely registering in this year's Republican pre-primary polls, she is scouting a fresh political Rubicon for him to cross.
Ms. Buchanan is the daughter of a successful Washington accountant who offers a backwoods sort-of twang and sharp-edged glance -- much the way her brother, one of the capital's longstanding conservative elite, savors riffs of blue-collar rhetoric. The two seem united by an appetite for contrariness.
"In '92 people would ask, 'You're his daughter, right?' " recalled Ms. Buchanan, a veteran political consultant who is 10 years younger than her 60-year-old brother. "By '96 they were asking, 'Who's older?' "
For all that wear and tear, Ms. Buchanan -- christened Angela Marie and called Bay in a family of nine children steeped in dinner-table conservatism -- seems addicted to cutting fresh swaths in the campaign trail.
It was Ms. Buchanan, a fierce political warrior with a master's degree in mathematics from McGill University, who first explored the Reform gamble for her brother. Buchanan critics suspect that she mainly had her eye on the $12.6 million in Federal matching funds that await whoever may be the Reform Party nominee next year.
William Kristol, the conservative Republican commentator, has sarcastically denounced Mr. Buchanan as "Pat the Bunny," opportunistically "hopping around on the fringes of American politics" and sniffing out "whatever carrots our political system offers up."
In rebuttal, Ms. Buchanan scoffs at "Billy" Kristol for "not understanding the movement Pat represents."
"This is an anguishing decision," she said, speaking as a Republican who, through her brother's patronage, served in the Nixon and Reagan White Houses. "This is not a decision you make for money, for goodness' sakes. It takes enormous courage."
Heeding the different drummer may be more second nature to her than to her brother. Seventeen years ago, Ms. Buchanan stood up to her staunchly Roman Catholic family, including Pat, in converting to Mormonism and marrying in that faith. Now she survives as the divorced working mother of three teen-age sons, heading home to them in the Virginia suburbs after long days in the Buchanan war room.
"She's terrific with the boys," said Pat Choate, a longtime friend and Reform Party leader who was Ross Perot's running mate on the party's ticket in 1996. Mr. Choate is in daily contact with Ms. Buchanan now as the two strategize about how to nail down the Reform nomination.
"Bay goes home, takes care of her sons and turns off the politics," Mr. Choate said. "People don't know she also took care of her mother in her home until she died in '96. Talk about a manager -- Bay's the real thing."
Others describe her as less an ideologue than her brother and more his devoted agent, as scrappy in the back room as he is on television. In a 30-minute interview, she was interrupted four times by cellular phone calls from her brother with urgent importunings.
"He's panicking because of where he is," she calmly explained, referring not to any position her brother has taken but to the logistics of his rushing to the next television interview.
At the campaign headquarters, Ms. Buchanan offered a no-nonsense sketch of the Reform Party terrain she felt she could master. She emphasized that her brother would be pushing for the reforms in the economy, foreign trade and government that the Reform Party is most concerned about, without abandoning his anti-abortion stance.
"I think we have a real good shot for the Reform nomination if Pat chooses to go," she said. "But we'll have to fight for it.
"It will take $6 million in 30 states," she said, summarizing the effort in having the required petition drives under way by the end of this year in the 30 states where they are needed to get him on the ballot. The Reform Party is already established in 20 states. "For the first $4 million," she said, "I can get $2 million in matching funds. But my goal is to raise more than the $4 million."
Ms. Buchanan said she had been in touch with a dozen state Reform organization leaders so far, with another dozen on her list. "Lenora Fulani asked to speak to us," she noted. Ms. Buchanan hardly sounded flustered by the strange-bedfellow aspect of politics in her brother's having to deal with Ms. Fulani, a New York Reform Party figure who was once an ally of Louis Farrakhan, the firebrand leader of the Nation of Islam.
"Intellectually, there's no question Pat's moved very dramatically in the direction of the third party," Ms. Buchanan said, clearly warming to a fresh field of political combat that would begin with the Buchanans' defection from the party that first inspired their fealty and lent them celebrity. "If your heart is in it, if you really feel the decision is made for the right reason, then you can get through the fire."

HEADLINE: So In, So Very Berlin: A Capital Seeks Its Identity

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Imagine finding a vacant lot on the banks of the Seine, opposite the Louvre, and using it periodically as a discotheque. Unthinkable, of course. But not in Berlin, where the Kunst und Technik club opens its doors from time to time and demonstrates that right now, in this city, anything is possible.
On the banks of the Spree, in the early hours, revelers dance, gazing out at the magnificent dome of the Bode museum of antiquities on the island opposite. Several young men urinate into the dark water. The city's choicest real estate has been given over to a makeshift techno club, and nobody can quite believe it. 
 "Heidelberg was so boring," said Mathias Santelmann, a law student who moved recently from the old university town to the new German capital. "This place is going to be to Germany as New York is to the United States." He pointed out to the mesmerizing river and dome, and exclaimed, "Look, we're here at the creation!"
Germany's inhibitions being what they are, the re-creation of Berlin as the home of the Government in recent weeks has been a muted affair: no big rallies, no public festivities, no showy speeches from the Chancellor.
"We're still fearful of the wrong images, so we like to pretend that nothing is happening," said Peter Schneider, a writer.
And yet. As diplomats and civil servants unpack, as embassies hold "Welcome to Berlin" parties, as newspapers offer "Berlin supplements," as completed buildings emerge from a labyrinth of cranes, as an immense show opens on German art in this century, something is in the air. Perhaps it could best be called the spark of the unpredictable.
Berlin, it has long been said, is damned: the city is so busy becoming, it never gets around to being. Cataclysm has intervened too regularly for that. But everyone seems to sense that this fifth attempt in this century at Berlin-as-capital -- after the Kaiser, Weimar, Hitler and the East German Communists -- is the last best chance for the city to overcome its curse.
"This will be a great city of the next century, but it still has to be created," Karl Kaiser, the director of the German Institute for Foreign Affairs, said as he moved into his new Berlin premises this month. "And I think it is the open-endedness that creates this strong sense of intrigue."
Or perhaps the intrigue lies in the almost physical sense today of a German future being dragged from a still-cloying past. After Bonn, an escape from history, Berlin offers a daily confrontation -- with imperial pomposity, with Nazi madness, with East-West division. And in this encounter Germany's hope of an elusive reconciliation may lie.
"For most young Germans now going to Berlin, our history starts in 1945 or with the Holocaust," said Hans Mommsen, a historian. "National pride, in so far as it exists, has nothing to do with the Bismarckian Reich. It has to do with the Constitution and the democracy of the Federal Republic. We have developed a new national consciousness, one forged from the terrible legacy of Auschwitz."
It is this reformed nation that will be tested in Berlin. For the consciousness of old Germans and young Germans, of east Germans and west Germans, is by no means at one, and this city is the symbol of the traumas that have divided them.
From his anonymous Bonn office, Mr. Kaiser has moved into a building that was constructed as the Royal Yugoslav Legation in the 1930's. After the war, the building housed a restitutions court for property stolen by the Nazis.
That is Berlin: history is everywhere, inescapable as the construction sites hoisting the new city into being, visible in buildings or graves still bullet-scarred from Hitler's war, written on the surviving pieces of the wall.
A pervasive history, menacing, grandiose or just plain hideous, as in Honecker's Palace of the Republic -- a building strangely close to the heart of many easterners, or Ossis, even as it is loathed by Wessis who want to rebuild the castle of the old emperors on that very site.
Can any national pride emerge from such a history? "Patriotism is not a word you use easily in Germany," said Michael Naumann, the country's top cultural official. "But, yes, I am a patriot. I take pride in what we have become, in our language, in our legal system. And I think Berlin offers a chance for this new German patriotism."
Germans had a phrase for the situation at the end of World War II: They called it Stunde Null, or Zero Hour. Then, when the Berlin wall came down a decade ago, it was Stunde Null again, a new beginning.
Perhaps, quiet as they are, these balmy fall days amount to a third Zero Hour, a moment when Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has declared unabashedly that his country is a "great power" again, an hour of emancipation, as if this return to Berlin 54 years after Hitler's Reich symbolized the end of an unseen but powerful tutelage.
So it seems, at least. But this city is scarcely "great" or "normal" yet; nor is it the booming place imagined when the decision to bring the capital back here was made in 1991. Then predictions suggested the population would swell to 4.5 million by the year 2000 and to between 5 million and 6 million by 2005.
In fact, the population -- now 3.4 million -- has stagnated, as new arrivals have been offset by Berliners migrating to the lower taxes of the surrounding state of Brandenburg. A predicted business boom has also failed to happen, leaving the center of the city littered with unoccupied office space. More than 250,000 Berliners are unemployed.
"Instead of the imagined meeting place of East and West here in Berlin, the city is merely the largest used-car dealership for East Europe," Thierry Chervel commented recently in the Suddeutsche Zeitung.
He had a point. Berlin was hypnotic in the 1920's, the charged, menacing sensual city of Otto Dix's canvases. During many of the cold war years, West Berlin was hip, an edgy, energetic place of refuge for those fleeing the oppressive conformity of many of the cities of the old West Germany.
Yet, even then, Berlin was far from the metropole so often dreamed-of. Today, the city often looks seedy and cheap. Stroll east down the central Kurfurstenstrasse and the classy prostitutes at one end give way to ragged young women clearly just arrived from countries farther east.
Not yet gentrified like Paris or most of Manhattan, Berlin remains raw and continues to offer cheap enough housing close to the center to retain its proletarian touch. The aristocracy and captains of industry nearly all fled during the many years when Communism was so close. Few have seen fit to return.
"Berlin is definitely the world capital of bad taste," said Michael Mussotter, an architect. "I love the city for that bad taste, for the mix of classes, for the cheap public housing amid the grand new developments."
Those developments -- most visibly the new Potsdamer Platz with its Walt Disney productions, its Tony Roma's, its immense mall -- have been overwhelmingly commercial, a sign that the hour is one of marketing rather than social or political ideals. Whether Berlin can hold on to its intense social mix as the capital takes form is open to question.
Already, the city has changed immensely. Much of west Berlin, once so lively, now seems a dowdy and forgotten place. The Kurfurstendamm, that mecca of shopping conceived to show cold-war escapees from the east what they had been missing, is simply dismal. All the energy is in eastern districts like Mitte or Prenzlauer Berg.
But for now, these shifts have not produced a whole -- what Mark Braun, an architect, called "the urban grain you have in London or in Paris, the grain that was lost in the demolition that Berlin has known."
Of course, that grain is nothing other than civilization, its slow and patient accumulation, in stone after stone.
And when Berliners talk incessantly about their dreams of a Weltstadt, or world city, then the German thirst for a civilized, cosmopolitan norm is palpable.
Such an achievement -- a great city, open to the world, to east and to west, showing its history but unthreatened by it, powerful but unthreatening to others -- would, it seems, represent the ultimate healing of Germany's many wounds.
For now, whatever Mr. Schroder may say, that reconciliation remains some way off. In its place is a jagged energy, an edginess, an openness that leave a piece of formerly eastern riverside property in the hands of an association of artists who, for reasons best known to themselves, open the premises as a club on every date divisible by six.
That place is Kunst und Technik, very in, very Berlin. Julia Tanzer, 23, comes here regularly. "This city is my future," she said simply.
And what of the city's painful past? "You know, we see it for the first time in schools, when we are 9 years old, we see Auschwitz, and what do we feel? Horror, of course. It's terrible, terrible -- but it's not my fault."

HEADLINE: Returning River to Salmon, and Man to the Drawing Board

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: LITTLE GOOSE DAM, Wash.

 BODY:
Of all the ways in which Americans have reshaped the land to suit their priorities, none is more audacious than the vast network of hydroelectric dams that stretches across the Pacific Northwest, taming wild rivers, opening shipping passages and bringing the region the cheapest electricity rates in the nation.
The construction of these huge dams, dating back to the Great Depression, was an epic engineering achievement, amply glorified by Woody Guthrie in the 1940's. "Your power is turning our darkness to dawn," ran his folk song, "so roll on, Columbia, roll on." 
 But whatever their benefits to man, the great dams have proved lethal on a gigantic scale to the region's wild salmon, striving to complete their own remarkable journey from the rivers out to the Pacific Ocean and back again to spawn, right where they were born. And here on the lower Snake River, two Federal agencies are exploring a proposal that is proving to be far more contentious than building the dams was in the first place, and could have just as enormous consequences: taking four dams out of service, including the Little Goose, and restoring a 140-mile portion of the Snake to its wild, free-flowing condition.
As required by the Endangered Species Act, the United States Army Corps of Engineers and the National Marine Fisheries Service are studying the most radical step of all to save the salmon. It is an idea passionately favored by environmental groups, many American Indians and commercial fishermen as far away as Canada and Alaska, who could someday catch a healthy run of Idaho-born fish in their waters, and bitterly opposed by farmers and many others in this region, who now rely on the river for shipping and electricity.
The debate will almost surely wind up in Congress, where most lawmakers from the area are vowing a tooth-and-nail fight against breaching the dams, which would involve removing the earthen portions, and rendering the dams inoperative.
But the once unthinkable idea is clearly on the table because for 25 years, the Army Corps of Engineers, which operates the dams, has been struggling to find ways for the dams and the salmon to coexist on the Snake.
Despite Federal spending of more than $3 billion on programs that include fish ladders, hatcheries and even a truck-and-barging system "custom-made to make the trip as safe and comfortable as possible" for the salmon, according to a Corps brochure, the fish remain in a terrible decline.
The river's coho salmon have already been declared extinct, and every other species of salmon and steelhead in the Snake River is now listed under the Endangered Species Act. Two centuries ago, when the explorer William Clark wrote that the Snake was "crouded with salmon," about 2 million adult salmon a year completed the trip back to their spawning grounds, biologists estimate. Last year's official count, according to the Idaho Department of Fish and Game, was as follows: 8,426 spring and summer chinook, 306 fall chinook and 2 sockeye.
Environmental groups have already scored some major victories in their bid to take down dams in various parts of the country. This summer, for instance, an aging hydroelectric dam on Maine's Kennebec River was demolished, under Federal order, to open the river so that several species of Atlantic fish, including salmon and sturgeon, could regain access to their traditional spawning grounds.
And a Northwest electric utility, Pacificorp, said recently that it would take down the Condit Dam on Washington's White Salmon River by 2006 rather than pay the $30 million Federal regulators would have required to make it less harmful to fish. The dam, which is 125 feet high, is the tallest dam ever slated for demolition in the United States, environmentalists say.
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said the plan was "yet another example that river restoration is on the national agenda."
But the breaching of the Little Goose and three other Snake River dams would dwarf either of those actions, and would signal a remarkable shift in national priorities. Opponents of the breaching plan seem flabbergasted that the idea is even up for discussion. The dams provide about 4 percent of the Northwest's electricity and were also built to turn Lewiston, Idaho, in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains and nearly 500 miles from the Pacific, into the West Coast's most inland seaport. None of the dams is used for flood control.
The opponents trust that even if Federal agencies do recommend the action, it can be blocked in Congress. A draft report by the fisheries service earlier this year called breaching the dams "more likely than any other hydrosystem action to meet survival and recovery criteria for the listed species," bureaucratic language nonetheless greeted as a bombshell around here.
Still, the opponents have staunch defenders, like Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, who says that breaching the dams would be "an unmitigated disaster and an economic nightmare" for the region.
On the other hand, 107 members of Congress, in a letter to President Clinton, called the salmon and steelhead "an economic and environmental asset whose preservation is a national responsibility," and urged the Administration to consider breaching the dams as an option. Most of the letter-signers are Democrats outside the Northwest.
In the end, the question broadly comes down to whether saving the salmon outweighs the dam's economic benefits to eastern Washington and parts of Idaho, a state that has found itself deeply split over the issue because restoring the salmon could be hugely beneficial for the state's recreational industry but would also effectively wipe out Lewiston's position as a seaport.
Looking at the issue in terms only of the salmon, which Cecil D. Andrus, a former Interior Secretary as well as Idaho Governor, once called "the ultimate symbol of the Pacific Northwest," there is something very close to a consensus among biologists that breaching the dams would be the single most effective step toward restoring their wild runs.
"The biological leg of this stool is very clear," said Ed Bowles, Idaho's manager of anadromous fish, those that hatch in freshwater and migrate to the sea. "If you want to have recovery back to fishable levels and to de-list the fish from the Endangered Species Act, if you want to do this with a reasonable or high likelihood of success, you need to restore a natural river in the Snake. Other options do not provide you with even lukewarm security of getting the job done."
But even Mr. Bowles acknowledges that there are other legs to the stool -- the economic and social questions surrounding the decision. Furthermore, there is no guarantee that the breaching would save the salmon, since their downward spiral seems to be linked to other factors as well, including warming waters in the north Pacific Ocean.
"Would the fish be better off without these dams?" said Danny Consenstein, the Columbia Basin coordinator for the fisheries service. "Yes, but that's sort of an incomplete analysis. Will it lead to recovery? That's a much tougher question."
And many opponents of breaching, even as they say they would like to find a way to help both the Snake River dams and the salmon survive, leave no doubt as to which they believe to be the higher priority.
"I don't want to see the salmon disappear," said Roger W. Koller, a wheat farmer in Pomeroy, Wash. "They are a part of Northwest culture and history. But I don't want to see my farm disappear, either."
To get to the sea, and to come back to spawn, the fish must also navigate four dams on the Columbia River, but for a variety of reasons, more fish make it past those dams, which are not being studied for breaching.
And even as many people who live here fondly recall the wild river before the dams were built, in the 1960's and early 1970's, they are skeptical that breaching them would restore a lost world.
"I refer to it as a kind of environmental religion," said Bob Jenson, a Republican state representative in northeastern Oregon. "I think some people look at these dams as concrete obstructions in the environment and they'd like to return to a pristine natural environment, but that seems to me, personally, ridiculous. We live in a different world than Lewis and Clark experienced when they first came down the river. We can't restore that."
But Buzz Ramsey, president of the Northwest Sportsfishing Industry Association, said: "If we don't do something and we don't do it soon, these fish are going go extinct. That's very clear. And what does it say about us as a society if we are willing to simply let these magnificent fish become extinct?"
The whole issue is enormously complex, and it is not even possible to calculate with certainty, from an economic perspective, whether it would cost more to keep the dams or remove them.
Breaching them would cost about $1 billion and unquestionably add, in the short term, costs for farmers and anyone else who ships products out of the area. And by removing some of the region's electric power capacity, it would probably add as much as $4 to the average monthly electrical bill in the areas around the dams and about $1 to the bill of customers as far away as Seattle.
On the other hand, breaching could bring in hundreds of millions of dollars annually from fishermen, rafters and kayakers who would most likely flock to the river if it was restored to a free-flowing condition. And keeping the dams has potentially enormous costs, too. One is that of continued and expanded programs to keep the salmon alive.
"We've spent billions of dollars trying to tweak a system that cannot be tweaked enough to meet the goal," said Rob Masonis, regional director of hydropower programs for American Rivers, an environmental group. "It's failed miserably. And it's crazy to keep throwing in that money when we know we have an option that can work."
Another potential cost of keeping the dams, possibly a colossal one, could come in lawsuits from American Indian groups whose guarantees of perpetual fishing rights in the Snake and other rivers have been rendered all but useless by the dams and other actions that have harmed the fish. Similarly, the United States recently concluded a dispute with Canada over salmon fishing by signing a treaty that commits the Federal Government to steps that could restore healthy salmon runs from American rivers, like the Snake, to Canadian coastal waters.
The issue is already exacerbating tensions between urban areas like Seattle, where there are car bumper stickers proclaiming "I'm pro-salmon, and I vote," and rural areas east of the Cascades, in which "Save the dams" stickers are abundant.
"There's some massive wealth generation going on on the western side of Washington, but there aren't a lot of dot-coms in this region," said John W. Mitchell, an economist with U.S. Bank in Portland, Ore., adding that the farming areas have also been severely hurt by falling wheat prices worldwide. "They're getting hit, and they're going to feel very defensive about the dams."
The timing of a final decision about the dams -- the others are Ice Harbor, Lower Monumental and Lower Granite -- is unclear. Both the Corps of Engineers and the fisheries service are scheduled to release major analyses of the costs and benefits of breaching by the end of the year, although there are already indications that they may put off full recommendations until late next year, not at all coincidentally after the 2000 elections.
In Lewiston, the port manager, David Doeringsfeld, said breaching could be ruinous to the local economy. "It's 3,000, maybe 4,000 jobs in a region of 50,000 people," he said. "It would be like Seattle losing Boeing."
Still, in an editorial in June, even the local newspaper, The Lewiston Morning Tribune, conceded that breaching the dams was probably the "biggest and best means" of saving the fish.
"Now it becomes a political decision as to which uses of the river the people and their political leaders value more -- the fish saved at any cost, or doom the fish and keep the benefits of the dams," said the newspaper. "That, of course, is a rock and a hard place."

HEADLINE: M.T.A. to Propose Spending Billions on Rail Expansion

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In an eagerly awaited financial blueprint, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday will propose spending $17 billion in a five-year capital plan, with provisions for work on a new Second Avenue subway and other expansion projects.
Flush with the tax revenue that pays for most of its operations and encouraged by sharp increases in ridership on its buses and subways, the M.T.A. will propose spending $5 billion more than its current spending plan, which expires Dec. 31. 
 But the proposed plan leaves unanswered how the M.T.A. will pay for all the projects it proposes. The plan, according to several people familiar with it, relies on more than $2 billion that must be raised in "new government assistance or other M.T.A. resources," a provision that transit advocates say could result in a fare increase.
Although details of the five-year plan have not been disclosed, a senior M.T.A. official, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used, said yesterday that the spending plan would allocate $14 billion for maintenance work on buses and subways and the completion of projects that are already under way, including the renovation of several subway stations in all five boroughs.
He said the remaining $3 billion is designated in the plan for "moving the system forward," mainly through the acquisition of new subway cars, commuter rail cars and buses, and several subway construction projects.
The plan would provide $700 million for a Second Avenue subway, a proposed expansion that has the support of many Manhattan residents and elected officials. The M.T.A. official said the proposed amount would cover environmental studies and engineering work, with some money left for initial construction.
Although several versions of the Second Avenue subway have been proposed, with some advocates insisting that it be built from the Bronx to lower Manhattan, the capital plan is more modest, proposing a new subway tunnel from 125th Street to 63d Street. A new underground walkway at 63d Street would connect to the N and R Lines to enable passengers to transfer.
Because of the groundswell of public support for a new Second Avenue line, the version proposed in the five-year plan could be its most politically divisive element. An unusually broad coalition, the Empire State Transportation Alliance, which includes labor unions, environmental groups, the New York City Partnership and others, has been lobbying the M.T.A. to make the Second Avenue project a higher priority.
Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the New York Assembly, who represents the Upper East Side, has said in recent weeks he would block approval of the five-year plan if it does not provide money for a line running the full length of Second Avenue.
If approved by the M.T.A. board, which is expected to vote on Wednesday, the five-year plan would go to to Gov. George E. Pataki, who is expected to endorse it. The State Legislature would then consider it.
The largest project in the plan, budgeted at $1.6 billion, is a new tunnel for the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal, giving commuters direct access to the east side of midtown Manhattan. The M.T.A. official said yesterday the amount provided for that project, which has long been advocated by Mr. Pataki, would be enough to complete it by the end of the five-year spending period.
Other large projects envisioned in the plan, both advocated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, would extend the N line in Queens to La Guardia Airport, and extension of the No. 7 line from Times Square west to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and other developments on the west side of Manhattan.
The M.T.A. official declined to say how much would be allocated for those projects. He said another major expense covered in the plan is a $1 billion allocation for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which would include the $300 million replacement of the deck on the Triborough Bridge.
The plan calls for the M.T.A. to purchase 1,000 new subway cars and 1,050 new buses, of which 300 would be powered by natural gas or other fuels that emit fewer pollutants than diesel, the official said.
Although the plan is being proposed during what is widely regarded as a period of renaissance for New York City public transportation, it seemed certain yesterday to provoke questions over whether the sharp increase in spending can be sustained.
One reason for the uncertainty is that the increased popularity of the M.T.A.'s buses and subways has not resulted in an increase in fare revenues, because the recent introduction of fare discounts and unlimited ride Metrocards has enabled frequent users of the system to ride for less.
In August, anticipating an M.T.A. plan for new subway construction and sharp increases in spending, New York City's Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan research group that advises the City Council, warned that the M.T.A. could face looming budget deficits if the economy sours.
Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders advocacy group, noted that the M.T.A. had not ruled out fare hikes to pay for the increased spending. "They have laid out their choices, and they are not easy ones," he said.
One aspect of the plan that seemed certain to draw opposition from environmental groups was the M.T.A.'s proposal to buy far more diesel-powered buses than those powered with alternative fuels.
"Diesel pollution is the No. 1 environmental issue in New York City," said Richard Kassel, senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "By saying two out of three new buses will be diesel, they are taking two steps in the wrong direction."

HEADLINE: A FISCAL DEADLINE COULD FORCE G.O.P. TO BREAK A PLEDGE

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
As the new fiscal year approaches, a financial and political crisis confronts Republicans in Congress. They may have to break their repeated promises and raid Social Security to run the Government, their own staff and independent analysts say.
For months, the Republican leaders have sworn that they would pass their spending bills on time, hew to self-imposed spending limits and leave Social Security alone. But with only five days left in the fiscal year, those promises appear almost impossible to keep, as most of the spending bills are not finished. 
 The proposals on the table would break the spending caps or use technicalities to obey them, and most budget experts are projecting the diversion of Social Security funds. Meanwhile, Congress has so far failed to pass other major bills, like those on campaign finance, health care and gun control.
All week, nearly every day, they renewed their vows not to spend Social Security surpluses to run the Government in the coming fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1.
"We're not going to take money out of Social Security," Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said on Thursday, as President Clinton vetoed the Republicans' legislative centerpiece of 1999, a $792 billion tax cut. The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said, "We should not spend one nickel of Social Security." And Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, who has been his party's chief spending strategist in the House, said, "The bottom line is this: We're not going to spend a dime of the Social Security trust fund."
But even as they repeat that mantra this week, their own spending strategies are undermining them. The spending bills written by the Republicans will drain billions of dollars from the Social Security surplus, according to the latest figures from the Congressional Budget Office and the calculations of independent experts.
Although the Government's budget is better balanced than it has been for many years, and the amount likely to be siphoned from Social Security is only a tiny fraction of total Federal spending, the partisan fight over the issue may have political repercussions far larger than the amount of money involved.
How the battle is resolved could affect whether the Republicans retain their thin majority in Congress or Democrats manage to recapture at least the House; and both Republican and Democratic candidates for President are almost sure to focus on taxes, spending and Social Security in the 2000 elections.
In past years, when the Government ran deficits, Congress routinely spent extra receipts from Social Security taxes to run Federal programs. But now, with the expected surpluses, Congress cannot agree with the President on whether to cut taxes, expand Government programs, or pay down the Federal debt. How to account for the Social Security funds is at the heart of the dispute.
To their acute discomfort, the Republicans may be forced to play into the White House's hands by spending some of the Social Security surplus they have pledged to protect.
The Congressional Budget Office's latest figures show Congress spending $4 billion to $16 billion out of the supposedly sacrosanct Social Security trust fund. But those figures are two weeks old, and the calculation has changed for the worse in recent days as Republicans and Democrats alike clamor for more money for their favorite programs.
"If one were to take all the demands that have developed here in the last two weeks, we would definitely be dipping into the Social Security surplus," said G. William Hoagland, the Republican staff director of the Senate Budget Committee.
Representative Richard Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House minority leader, said this week, "We're probably going to edge closer to $30 billion of actual Social Security money spent."
That sum may be no more than a rounding error in an $8 trillion economy, but it is still a lot of nickels and dimes -- every one potentially politically damaging to the Republicans.
"It's going to frustrate and infuriate their conservative base," said Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy studies at the libertarian Cato Institute. "It's an indication of a breakdown in discipline in the Republican Party."
With so many spending bills still unapproved, tapping Social Security is not yet inevitable. But it will take extraordinary discipline, Mr. Hoagland said, for the Republicans to restrain their own ranks. Recent history -- notably last October, when faced with a similar situation, the Republicans allowed a $21 billion bonanza of spending -- suggests this will be difficult.
This situation has White House officials in a state of barely restrained glee. They clearly believe that the Republicans will do themselves political damage if they fail again to carry out the only major legislative task required of Congress by the Constitution: passing the spending bills. Some said they see it as a key to winning back control of the House, and perhaps even the Senate, next year -- assuming Americans pay much attention to how Congress spends their money.
The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said the Republicans had created "a magnificent strategy to box themselves in."
The only way out of this trap for the Republican leadership is to hide billions of dollars in spending with budgetary devices. Their spending plans call for draining most of the projected general fund $38 billion surplus for the year after next, fiscal 2001, and spending it in 2000. Even some fellow conservatives are calling these tactics risky at best and ludicrous at worst.
The Republican leaders have also declared that $4.5 billion in funds for the 2000 census, $1.1 billion for a home-heating assistance program, and up to $8 billion in agricultural aid, mostly unconnected to this summer's droughts, are unforeseeable emergencies.
"They're coming up with gimmicks," said the former Republican chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, Bob Livingston, who left Congress last year after 21 years in office. "For crying out loud, the census has been with us since the conception of the Constitution of the United States. This is not an emergency."
Declaring spending an "emergency" means it technically does not count against the spending limits, or caps, imposed by Congress in 1997. But those caps have already been broken, Mr. Lott concedes.
And the emergency money has to come from somewhere -- namely, the $14 billion budget surplus projected for fiscal 2000, which would have been the first in 30 years. Those three emergency items for the census, home heating and agriculture would all but wipe out that surplus.
There were going to be two kinds of surpluses in the fiscal 2000 spending scheme. One was that $14 billion surplus in the operating budget of the Government, the so-called "on-budget" surplus, which is like a checking account.
The Congressional Budget Office says that money is gone, with or without the emergency spending.
That leaves the other projected surplus for fiscal 2000 -- $147 billion in the Social Security trust fund, which is like a retirement account. Though Congress has tapped into that fund for decades, the Republicans vowed repeatedly that this year would be different, and now fear they will pay a political price if they cannot keep that promise.
"I'm afraid that's the one thing that seems to have sunk in with the American people," Mr. Hoagland said. "They don't want us to spend Social Security. That's the one issue that does seem to bear fruit. "
There is only one escape from this conundrum for the Republicans, but it is a tightrope walk.
The new fiscal year begins at 12:01 A.M. on Friday. As Congress left town for the weekend, 9 of the 13 spending bills were not ready to be sent to President Clinton for his signature -- or his veto, if Mr. Clinton keeps his promise to reject seven of the bills for their deep cuts in favorite White House programs.
Clearly, most of the spending bills will not be signed into law by Oct. 1. In the next five days, Congress must pass stopgap measures called continuing resolutions to run Government agencies lacking legal spending measures. In the meantime, the incomplete or unsigned measures will be rolled into one big package, called an omnibus spending bill.
Continuing resolutions lasting two or three weeks are a fragile architecture. They must be shored up with good-faith negotiations between the White House and the Republican Congress on reshaping the spending bills. But the Republican leaders have said many times that Mr. Clinton cannot be trusted, and some in the White House feel the same way about the Republicans.
If that process collapses, a repeat of the 1995 Government shutdown is possible. That would be a political disaster, Republicans fear. They believe the public blamed them for the 1995 shutdown, which closed everything from national parks to passport offices.
The more likely result is a huge omnibus spending bill that adds tens of billions of dollars in new spending -- which is precisely what happened last year, also to the embarrassment of Congress.
There appear to be only two ways to avoid a deep dip into the Social Security funds. One is passage of the tobacco tax proposed by the White House, which is unlikely at best.
The other is for the Republican leaders to order their members to stop demanding more spending, to pass as many bills as possible before Oct. 1 -- and to hope that they can outfox Mr. Clinton at the negotiating table.
"I can see a way out," Mr. Hoagland said. "The key is discipline. The key is leadership."

HEADLINE: Japan Agrees To Rare Moves To Try to Halt Rise of Yen

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Japan today yielded to international pressure and agreed to take some extraordinary steps to reverse the recent and surprising climb of the Japanese yen against the dollar, which has rattled Wall Street in recent days and threatened Japan's recovery.
After an all-day meeting here, the finance ministers of the Group of Seven largest industrial countries issued a joint communique saying the Japanese authorities had, in effect, agreed to even deeper deficit spending and to begin printing yen to prompt inflation. Interest rates in Japan are already virtually zero, so the move represents a last-ditch effort to keep the yen's rise from making the country's exports more expensive around the world. 
 In return the United States and other major nations issued a vague threat that they might jointly intervene in the markets to weaken the yen and strengthen the dollar, a warning sign to currency traders who have been dumping the dollar.
If Japan actually begins trying to spur inflation -- in hopes of weakening the yen and encouraging its own consumers to stop saving and start buying -- it would be an enormous change of strategy. Hyperinflation in the years before World War II still weighs heavily on the country, and since 1945 Japan has been strongly conservative, keeping inflation to an absolute minimum.
The wording of the statement today was deliberately ambiguous, an effort to keep investors guessing and prevent them from betting against the dollar. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers tonight pointed to a paragraph that he said was "very carefully worded," which referred to Japan's agreement to "provide ample liquidity until deflationary concerns are dispelled." But he said he would not "interpret that remark," nor would he say whether the United States would finally join Japan in intervening in the markets.
Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyawaza, was asked tonight if the United States and other countries had agreed to intervene. He declined to offer a specific answer -- finance ministers never do -- but said, "You could feel and see for yourself that full recognition of the situation has been gained."
The meeting of the finance ministers and central bank chiefs did not carry the high drama of their session a year ago, when Russia's currency had collapsed and markets around the world appeared on the precipice of disaster. Asia has since begun a slow recovery, and even Japan has showed signs of pulling out of a recession that began more than seven years ago. In fact, the renewed interest of investors in putting their money into Japan is one reason the yen has risen by more than 15 percent against the dollar since mid-July.
But big currency moves can also cause big problems. It was the steady rise of the dollar from 1995 to 1997 that indirectly helped start the Asian financial crisis.
Until tonight the United States had indicated no willingness to join Japan in meddling with the currency markets by pouring in yen, and trying to reduce the currency's value against the dollar. Instead, the United States has been pushing Japan to lower its interest rates even further -- no easy trick here -- and to force it to keep spending heavily on new roads and other projects to stimulate the economy.
But the newly independent Bank of Japan declined to lower interest rates earlier in the week, outraging Japanese politicians. And Tokyo is now running up such huge deficits that it threatens to get itself into the same kind of fiscal problem the United States fell into in the 1980's.
The standoff on how to respond to the problem has become the first big test for Mr. Summers, a former Harvard economist who became Treasury Secretary in July. "This will be an interesting moment to see how much Larry learned about timing, about how to keep the markets guessing, and about how to keep the Japanese guessing," a senior Administration official said this week.
Planning -- or feigning -- currency interventions is a bit like threatening military strikes. Governments want to keep the markets guessing a bit about the timing and size of the attack, in hopes that just the fear of intervention will be enough to change the market's behavior.
The rise of the yen was not the only problem on the agenda. Russian officials were invited to sit in on the end of the Group of Seven meeting, chiefly to receive a warning that the wealthy nations will not be willing to extend further aid unless Russia agrees to regular, far more intrusive audits into how it uses loans from the International Monetary Fund.
Congressional hearings this week focused attention on the widespread corruption in Russia, though so far there is no evidence that the fund's money was diverted.
Tonight's communique said Russia's central bank must take steps to improve its "internal controls and initiate quarterly audits" before getting any future I.M.F. funds.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
As League Meetings End, Stern Is Still the Chief Cheerleader

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 25

 BODY:
David Stern attended 24 meetings over the past two days and barely slept at night. Like George Lucas annually exhorting his Star Wars corporate empire, the National Basketball Association commissioner came to the league meetings here ready to market his product into the next century with renewed vigor.
In 48 dizzying hours, Stern saw the good, the bad and the unsightly of his league: 
 *He saw the unveiling of a 24-hour television network, NBA.com TV, which will debut Nov. 2 and represents the league's marriage to the Internet.
*He saw a billionaire buy one of the Canadian expansion teams that had helped give credence to Stern's global vision for the game; the new owner was silent about any plans to move the franchise to the United States.
*He saw a heated discussion between coaches, general managers and officials about how to make the game more esthetically pleasing.
Despite the declining scoring and the abysmal ratings for the finals between the Knicks and San Antonio Spurs last June after a lockout that wiped out most of the season, the commissioner bristled at the notion that interest in the N.B.A. was declining.
"I would say we took a huge hit last year with the lockout, struggling to find a formula that worked -- and it did," Stern said. "I would say that our players surprised even the most hardened skeptics as they came out and did what they had to do to interface with the fans. I would, at least, for some modest period ask you to give them the benefit of the doubt."
During a news conference with about 20 journalists from the United States and Canada, Stern spoke about everything from the rules changes for the coming season to possible expansion overseas. As much as fixing the game on the court, his priority seemed to be selling the game.
He also seemed to shoot down the notion that the purchase of the Vancouver Grizzlies by the St. Louis billionaire Bill Laurie on Thursday meant the team was on its way to St. Louis in less than two years.
"Nobody can move if the board of governors doesn't approve it," Stern said. "And I certainly think that the board of governors could and should be influenced by the performance of the team economically, in terms of fan support. I certainly urge the fans of Vancouver to support their team."
A proposed minimum age for players was shelved for at least the next two seasons. The idea was endorsed by Stern, who in June said 20 years old might be a feasible age at which to join the N.B.A. But resistance from the players association and the lack of progress in talks with the National Collegiate Athletic Association put off immediate plans.
Stern also touched on his plans for international expansion. "In the next couple of years, we're going to be getting some interesting proposals and opportunities for the N.B.A. to affiliate in some way with foreign operations and leagues," Stern said, "Those are opportunities we're going to have to evaluate perhaps more seriously than we would have had in the past, because there's so many of them that appear poised to come to us, in Europe and Latin America and in Asia.
"There seems to be increasing sentiment from a variety of our real and potential business partners and broadcast partners that there is a strong contribution to the growth of basketball by being more involved more internationally than we are."
When he arrived here Thursday afternoon, a press conference had already been planned by the host franchise to announce the ownership change to Laurie. Four years after the Grizzlies had given the N.B.A. a presence in a western Canadian province, the team was said to be on its way to Missouri.
More than worrying about the relocation of a franchise for the first time in 15 years, Stern wanted the 1,400 in attendance -- almost every league employee other than the players -- to understand that they could not sit back and rest on their post-lockout laurels just yet.
The league's fan-friendly approach after the lockout was stressed often during the meetings. All 29 teams will make available $10 single-game tickets, and scrimmages will be held for the public.
During the general session, Stern had a former chief marketing officer from the Coca-Cola Company address the gathering. The message was that the N.B.A. would be "backsliding as an operation" if they continued to stay the course. "What we're saying to everybody is, if you're doing everything the same way you've been doing it for the last 10 years, you're probably not doing it right," Stern said.
Russ Granik, the deputy commissioner, added: "We recognize you've got to make changes, and that's why we're looking at our rules, that's why a lot of time was spent the last two days talking with our various groups about how to improve interaction between players and fans and coaches and fans."
