HEADLINE: The U.S. Lost Its Chance in Russia

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert E. Rubin's Sept. 21 Op-Ed article is the establishment approach to the stealing, diversion and double-dealing by Russian officials of both Western aid and Russia's national assets. The platitudes are tiresome: that "the United States has a critical interest in Russia's stability," that there somehow exists a "democratic, market-oriented Russia," and that the United States must do everything in its power "to increase the probability of a constructive result." Yes, this is all well and good. 
 Now ask the hard questions: What percentage of aid sent to Russia should we be prepared to recognize has been and will continue to be stolen or diverted? Don't the Russian people have good reason not to trust their officials?
Are the vast majority of the Russian people better off than they were 10 years ago, and if not, why we pumping money into Russia's economy if the people don't see the benefit?
 
MICHAEL T. CONCANNON
Seattle, Sept. 22, 1999

HEADLINE: The U.S. Lost Its Chance in Russia

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert E. Rubin gives us an interesting phrase, "market democracy," in his Sept. 21 Op-Ed article, "Don't Give Up on Russia." Yet with low voter turnout in the United States and the gap between rich and poor growing steadily wider, the moral claims for our system need fresh proof. 
 Perhaps there is in the Russian mentality an ancient wisdom that suspects a fraudulent propensity in all human promises. Helping them reform their system requires that we are able to be persuasive about our own. This is a question of world historical importance. Can our democratic processes successfully mingle real political participation with the enormous power of market ownership? Are Americans able to modify the power of this ownership when it seeks to buy and sell influence on a scale that either neutralizes citizen action or corrupts it?
 
(Rev.) CHARLES W. RAWLINGS
South Orange, N.J., Sept. 21, 1999

LENGTH: 138 words

HEADLINE: The U.S. Lost Its Chance in Russia

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Those of us who have experienced the mind-boggling scope of corruption and crime in high Government and civic circles in parts of the former Soviet Union find it difficult to make others aware of the problem. Our best efforts are often met with incredulity and the assertion that this state of affairs is "normal" in business. 
 It is therefore distressing to read about the testimony of Thomas A. Renyi of the Bank of New York at hearings in Washington about his bank's dealings in Russia (news article, Sept. 23). That a man of his stature could be as ignorant of his business partners as his testimony indicated makes one wonder if the "normal" argument may be correct.
 
JOHN KARKLINS
Chicago, Sept. 23, 1999
 
The writer was head of construction for the Bank of Latvia in Riga, 1996-97.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 4; Column 1; Television

HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
All the President's Men . . . and Women

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

 BODY:
Four years ago Aaron Sorkin, the author of stage and film versions of "A Few Good Men," was researching and writing the screenplay for "The American President," about a widowed President who is attracted to a lobbyist. "There were all these stories I wanted to tell in 'The American President' about the senior staffers at the White House but didn't because it was about the romance of these two people," said Mr. Sorkin. 
The following year his agent arranged a lunch date for Mr. Sorkin with John Wells, creator of "E.R." and other shows.
"I knew that he was a big deal, and the moment I saw down at lunch with John, I realized he's a busy and important guy, and he was expecting me to pitch something, to have an idea or two," recalled Mr. Sorkin. "So it suddenly occurred to me: what about senior staffers at the White House? I had never really said it out loud. And's that how 'West Wing' happened."
One of the most anticipated and high-profile shows of the new season, "West Wing," which had its premiere on Wednesday on NBC in a coveted time slot (9 to 10 P.M. on Wednesday), is designed as a behind-the-scenes glimpse into the lives of a group of mostly young White House aides. The cast includes Rob Lowe, Moira Kelly, Allison Janney and Martin Sheen, who plays President Josiah Bartlett, a middle-of-the-road New Hampshire Democrat.
As the President Mr. Sheen was initially set to be a peripheral figure, making one episode a month, with all the attention focused on the staffers. But Mr. Sorkin and Mr. Wells, who is one of the executive producers, revised their plans once filming began and enlisted Mr. Sheen as a full-timer. "It was like they had this three-ring circus, but the third ring was empty," said Mr. Sheen, who acknowledged that he has patterned his portrayal after John F. Kennedy, a boyhood hero.
The fictional President may be too good to be true. "He has the intelligence of Clinton, the heart and passion of Jimmy Carter and the energy and foresight of John Kennedy," said Mr. Sheen. "He won the Nobel Prize for economics. He's a Catholic, like me, and has been married 35 years. I've been married 38 years."
Mr. Wells said that what drove him and Mr. Sorkin to create "West Wing" was a yearning to depict a group of mostly smart people in their 20's and 30's who opted to work for the Government at a salary that was relatively low, compared with what they could earn on Wall Street.
Shows involving politics often meet resistance from network executives, and "West Wide" was no different.
"There's a real fear that political shows won't work because they're seen as too dry," said Mr. Wells. "And people tend to think these shows are like eating vegetables: They're good for you."
Beyond this, NBC executives were skittish because the Monica Lewinsky scandal was unfolding and executives felt that viewers were turned off by Washington and politics. So the show was delayed for a year, and Mr. Sorkin turned to creating "Sports Night," the ABC show about an ESPN-style network.
Earlier this year a new regime at NBC, led by Scott Sassa, president of NBC-West Coast, and Garth Ancier, president of NBC Entertainment, promptly gave a green light to the show and put it on the schedule. Mr. Ancier said the nation's cynicism about politics might actually help "West Wing," whose main characters, from the President to his senior staff, are mostly flawed but thoroughly decent.
"One would think, 'Why would I watch a show set in the political arena at a time like the present when there's a great deal of skepticism about public office?' " said Mr. Ancier. "Well, it may well be that the show is a wish fulfillment for the American public. People in the show have honorable goals and are trying to do their best. And that's what we want to believe our representatives are doing."
What distinguishes the show, its creators said, was an effort to replicate the inner workings of the White House as accurately as possible, even though it is being shot on a Warner Brothers sound stage in Burbank, Calif. A $3 million White House set seems almost a mirror image of the West Wing.
Former White House aides like Pat Cadell, a polling expert for Jimmy Carter, and the former Clinton press secretary Dee Dee Myers have been hired as consultants. And virtually everyone connected to the show seems to have watched the documentary "The War Room," about the Clinton Presidential campaign in 1992 and to have read George Stephanopoulos's book about the Clinton White House, "All Too Human."
Ms. Janney, who plays the press secretary, said, "I'm having dinner with Dee Dee tonight, and I want to know everything: What were her aspirations? What what were her issues as a woman? Did she have a personal life? How did she think on her feet? How was she treated?"
Mr. Sorkin, 38, a New York native, said with a laugh that he had gone out of his way to assuage the concerns of NBC that "West Wing" would turn into an issues show in which the conservatives wear black hats and the liberals are oh-so-good. The pilot episode does take a slap at the Religious Right. But in the second show the President is so outraged by an attack on a United States Air Force jet over Syria with his personal doctor aboard that the strong White House response worries even the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Another episode involves hypocritical rich liberals.
"I'm looking forward to being unpredictable on the show," said Mr. Sorkin.
Aside from Mr. Sheen, the best-known actor on the series is the former Brat Pack member Rob Lowe, who plays the White House deputy communications director and speechwriter who unwittingly gets entangled with a prostitute in the first episode. Mr. Lowe, who auditioned for the part, said it was the role of his career.
"With Aaron's dialogue you're walking on the razor's edge of comedy and drama," he said. "When I read the script, it was as good as any movie I've read, and certainly better than any television show I've ever read."
The cast also includes a number of theater-trained actors who say they expect "West Wing" to advance their careers. Ms. Janney, for example, whose film work ("Primary Colors") has started to flourish, said she hoped that "West Wing," if successful, would lead to more prominent roles as opposed to the often small ones she is usually offered.
"If 'West Wing' is a hit, knock on wood, I'll buy a house in L.A.," she said with a laugh. "And if it's really a hit, I'll finally be able to buy an apartment in New York."
